151435081.review:
OK so the game finally works on Steam out of the box without mods!

Not going to recap why folks hate this game, DX1 was possibly the greatest PC game ever made, it's impossible to follow up, and DX2 IW was obviously rushed due to the success of the first one. Now about the gameplay:

1. The sniper rifle with scope/silencer is still OP. Illuminati Commandos go down in one hit. 
2. Armored Templars are still OP. 6-7 shots with the mag rail sucks. Their "weak point" isn't really a weak point and almost impossible to hit.
3. I had to kill Billie Adams twice, so yeah, patch 1.2 didn't fix everything.
4. Allies on Liberty Island are insanely under powered. You can lose key characters very quickly so watch out.
5. The Mako ammo system still sucks. Probably the worst aspect of this game. No...definitely the worst aspect.
6. The storyline is half baked. If you didn't play DX1 you'll have no idea what's going on.

Playing this really reminds me how much we all got cheated by not having a proper follow up to DX1 with JC as the main character again. The game is still worth it for under $1 though.

150745231.review:
[b]Positives:[/b]

[u]Immersive Storyline:[/u] The game’s storyline is complex and engaging, with multiple paths and choices that affect the outcome. The game’s themes of transhumanism, conspiracy, and political intrigue are thought-provoking and well-executed.

[u]Gameplay Variety:[/u] The game offers a variety of gameplay options, including stealth, hacking, and combat. The game’s open-world design allows players to explore at their own pace, and the game’s skill system adds depth to the gameplay.

[u]Atmospheric World-Building:[/u] The game’s cyberpunk world is immersive and detailed, with a rich backstory and memorable characters. The game’s environments are well-designed, with a mix of futuristic and dystopian elements.

[u]Enhanced Graphics:[/u] The game’s graphics have been updated for the Game of the Year Edition, with improved textures and lighting effects. The game’s visuals hold up well even today.

[b]Negatives:[/b]

[u]Outdated Mechanics:[/u] While the game’s mechanics were groundbreaking at the time of release, they can feel clunky and outdated by modern standards. The game’s AI can be inconsistent, and the game’s controls can be difficult to master.

[u]Steep Learning Curve:[/u] The game’s complex skill system and open-world design can be overwhelming for new players, and the game’s difficulty can be challenging for some players.

[u]Limited Replayability:[/u] While the game’s open-world design allows for exploration and discovery, the game’s linear storyline and lack of branching paths limit its replayability.

In summary, [u]Deus Ex: Invisible War[/u] is a classic cyberpunk action role-playing game that still holds up well today. Its strengths lie in its immersive storyline, gameplay variety, atmospheric world-building, and enhanced graphics, but it’s not without minor flaws. If you’re a fan of cyberpunk settings and thought-provoking storytelling, this game is definitely worth checking out!

[i]58/100[/i]

150024328.review:
A Mixed Bag of Cyberpunk Ambitions

Rating: 3.5/5

Deus Ex: Invisible War, the highly anticipated sequel to the groundbreaking Deus Ex, delivers a mixed gaming experience that falls short of the original's brilliance. While it certainly has its moments, the game struggles to live up to the lofty expectations set by its predecessor.

Story Overview (Spoiler-Free):

So as the main plot of the story has you thrown into a dystopian future where power-hungry factions battle for dominance, Deus Ex: Invisible War puts players in the shoes of Alex D, a protagonist caught in the chaos of global conspiracies. The story centers on the aftermath of the catastrophic Collapse, an event that has drastically altered the geopolitical terrain. In this world of corporate intrigue, shadowy organizations, and clashing ideologies, players find themselves at the heart of the action, making crucial decisions that mold the course of the narrative. As Alex navigates through the intricacies of this altered reality, the player is tasked with steering the protagonist through a landscape fraught with choices, each one contributing to the unfolding story. (this sounds quite good wouldn't you say so?)

Pros:

Choice and Consequence: Invisible War maintains the series' trademark feature of allowing players to make choices that impact the narrative. Your decisions affect the world around you, leading to different outcomes and providing a sense of agency.

Cyberpunk Aesthetics: The game captures the essence of a cyberpunk world with its futuristic settings, augmentations, and conspiracy-laden storyline. The visuals, although dated by today's standards, manage to convey a dystopian atmosphere.

Versatile Augmentations: The augmentation system is diverse, allowing players to customize their character with a variety of cybernetic enhancements. This adds an element of strategy to gameplay, enabling different playstyles.

Branching Narratives: The game offers a branching narrative with multiple endings based on the choices players make. This adds replayability and encourages exploration of different story paths.

Intriguing Lore: Invisible War delves into the rich lore of the Deus Ex universe, expanding on the conspiracy-laden world established in the original game. The narrative explores themes of transhumanism, ethics, and the consequences of unchecked technological advancement.

Global Perspectives: The story takes players to various locations around the globe, showcasing the geopolitical consequences of the Collapse. This diversity in settings adds depth to the narrative and keeps the player engaged in the unfolding events.

Cons:

Technical Issues: Invisible War is plagued by technical shortcomings, including awkward animations, texture pop-ins, and occasional frame rate drops. These issues can detract from the immersive experience and make the game feel unpolished.

Simplified Gameplay Mechanics: In an attempt to streamline the gameplay, many mechanics from the original Deus Ex were simplified, leading to a less nuanced experience. The removal of the skill system and the universal ammo system, while intended to make the game more accessible, may disappoint fans of the original's complexity.

Linear Level Design: Unlike the open-ended, sprawling environments of the first game, Invisible War adopts a more linear level design. The lack of expansive environments diminishes the sense of exploration and limits the player's freedom.

Underdeveloped Characters: The characters in Invisible War lack the depth and complexity of those in the original Deus Ex. The narrative fails to build meaningful connections with the cast, resulting in a less engaging story overall.

Lackluster Character Development: While the game introduces a diverse cast of characters, their development is often superficial. The lack of compelling backstories and limited interaction with NPCs can result in a less emotionally resonant experience.

Pacing Issues: The pacing of the story can be uneven, with moments of intense action followed by slower, exposition-heavy segments. This inconsistency may impact the player's immersion in the unfolding plot.

Vague Plot Points: Some plot points and overarching mysteries may feel convoluted or poorly explained, leaving players with unanswered questions. The narrative could benefit from more clarity in certain areas to enhance player understanding and engagement.

In conclusion, Deus Ex: Invisible War offers a dynamic blend of cyberpunk aesthetics, player choice, and a sprawling narrative. However, technical issues, simplified mechanics, and narrative shortcomings prevent it from reaching the heights of its predecessor. While fans of the franchise may find enjoyment in the familiar cyberpunk setting and choice-driven gameplay, those expecting a true successor to Deus Ex may be left wanting more.

149962138.review:
[h1][b] Invisible War's Biggest Hurdle [/b][/h1]

This is something that [b] HAS [/b] to be mentioned before I would go to rest of the review as most of the issues can be traced back to the same point and that is Invisible War was originally made for console namely Xbox. As you can imagine, due to hardware limitations making the same game as original Deus Ex just wasn't possible. (Even after it got ported into PS2, some streamlining had to be made whenever is it to cutting bigger levels into smaller ones or removing certain game mechanics like locational limb damage)

I would like you to keep this is mind during reading this review as I didn't want to brought it up every 2 sentences. I believe you are smart enough to notice when we get there.

[h1][b] Part 1: Gameplay [/b][/h1]

At its core, it plays very similarly to original. You can go lethal or non-lethal depending on your preference, there are usually multiple ways to aproach the problem at hand, you have multiple abilities to choose from etc. The most important thing to note is that [b] ALL [/b] of them got downgraded one way or another.

First of all are the levels. They are much smaller compared to previous game and a lot of them are hub areas that leads to other smaller locations. The problem is there are a lot of loading screens between areas regadless of their size which can make traversal really annoying especially if you end up backtracking a lot. 
The common usage of vents makes the levels feel smaller than already are, although fortunately they aren't completely free as they are spider-bots that can drain some of your resources. (It isn't much but it's something at least compared to implementation of vents in the next instalment) The ways you can enter certain area are the same with the exception of locks getting removed while giving multi-tools same function. 

The combat is possibly one of the biggest victims of the streamlining process. The locational limb damage got replaced with a health bar, headshots still deal increased damage however after the introduction of spongy armored dudes your guns can feel very weak as they can withstand multiple headshots and rockets, fortunately they aren't very common so it's not that bad. 
The inventory management is gone instead you have certain amount of slots to fill, on the flip side you can carry multiple type of the same weapon whenever it's the pistols or rocket launchers as each gun can have up to 2 attachments each, the system wasn't that well implements though as the attachments range from somewhat useful to mostly pointless. 
As a positive however, I can say that some of the non-meele weapons has additional functions for example: pistol has build-in flashlight and rail guns has emp blast as alternative fire etc.
The stealth related weapons and meele got nerfed, the boltcaster which is essentially a crossbow cannot take down with a single shot and due to absence of locational limb damage, the meele weapons end up being very clunky and ineffective compared to the rest. 
Lastly, the ammo is shared between every weapon while it isn't bad by itself, most enemies you will fight are grunts that always drop ammo which makes fight much less punishing than it was in the original Deus Ex.

The last thing is the upgrade system.  Skills and augmentations get merged into singular system as just augmentations. The canisters now can be used to both acquire and upgrade your augmentations. There a is twist however as they are two types of canisters to get: normal and black market which each give you access to different type of skills that can be passive (Like hacking) or active. (Like cloaking) Unlike in original, you can swap between your augmentations on each slot but at the price of wasting the canisters that were already used as you lose the skill regardless of the level of the previous skill. 

[h1][b] Part 2: Story [/b][/h1]

For anyone how played the original you probably asked: "Okay, which ending is canon?" The common answer is all of them at once but that's not exactly true. In short, [spoiler] Helios Ending [/spoiler] is canon but the other two are the side effects of making that decision.

The best way to describe Invisible War's plot is it's like reading a summary of 500 page book, all the important moments are there but with lack of details. Which is a shame because the core of the story is really good but it's dragged down by the rest of the elements being subpar at best.
The protagonist barely has any personality as the game doesn't give him any opportunities to add any depth to the character. That also stretches to important NPC's that aren't returning characters from the previous game.
The factions despite having big role in the plot besides [spoiler] JC Denton's faction [/spoiler], they never get properly fleshed out which is a result of speedrunning all story beats without looking back.

If there something I can give an earnest praise, it's the worldbuilding. The devs did a great job at establishing more sci-fi elements while remaining grounded in reality which makes sense as it's been 20 years since the last game.

[h1][b] The Conclusion[/b][/h1]
Deus Ex: Invisible War is a considerable downgrade from the original while still retaining it's core elements. So why I recommend it despite it's numerous flaws? 
If you are interested how the story continues from the previous game, it does a good enough job at going into new direction and gameplay can bring a joy time to time. I would recommend to not have much expectations and try it out for like an hour and see whenever you enjoy it or not, so that you can refund in case of the latter.

As for the rating I would say it's [spoiler] 5/10 [/spoiler]
I hope this review gave you some idea on whenever the game is for you or not. Either way, have a nice day!

148985749.review:
This game was made for the OG xbox with 64 mb of ram, this causes some problems with the modern systems.It took me 3 years to figure out how to get past the black screen. Thanks to the fanbase every problem has a solution, sometimes you just gotta look harder. Here's how I fixed my black screen:
Assuming you're already installed the Visible Upgrade and still getting the black screen.
-Wait until the game stops responding
-Pull up the task manager, choose the task that stopped responding. You might need to open the dropdown menu
-Choose the unresponsive process and right click, choose "Go to details"
-Right click on the unresponsive process again and choose "Analyze wait chain"
-You'll now see what was causing the black screen. Either disable it from your pc for a while or just kill it from the window you're seeing. In my case it was RadeonSoftware.
-Voila, enjoy the game!

And for the review...
IW is much shorter than DX, around 10 hours on my final save. Longer with all those experiments and reloads tho.
Smaller maps sucks. Every time you switch a map the game shuts down itself and reopens with the new map. However this is not a concern since any decent PC can load a 64mb map in like 5 seconds. You should disable steam stuff so your friends won't get a notification every 15 minutes.
The gameplay is simplified, easier and kinda forces you for combat. Stealth is pretty hard if you don't build for it IMO.
However the new combat is good, much better than DX. Universal ammo is cool, same with the new biomod system. You don't spend time organizing your inventory since they don't use slots.
The hub worlds are pretty cool and realistic.
You can side with factions earlier. There seems to be more choices and results this time.
The story didn't unfolded the way I wanted but it was still pretty good. Not as good as DX but much better than Human Revolution and Mankind Divided.
And for the finale... The NG Resonance music SLAPS! She's modelled after and voiced by the lead of Kidneythieves, an actual industrial rock band. Her music instantly makes every pub area top tier. I think I'll keep listening to them for a while.
[code]Recommended by: [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/38893669/]Experiences Worth Experiencing[/url][/code]

The sequel to the classic, Deus Ex was panned by critics and gamers alike, but it's an enjoyable game albeit very flawed and obviously the graphics are dated by now.

First with the cons, the areas are very small and loading screens are too frequent. The physics are really clunky, the HUD and the inventory system are godawful. It's easiest the play the run and gun type of character over anything else, but the late game enemies are bulletsponges.

Now to the pros, the exploration is sometimes intriguing and the environments can be neat. The sidequests with the two coffee bar chains competing are funny. It has a great atmosphere, however for that aspect Thief 3 is a much better choice. The plot takes into consideration all of the endings of the original game, making them all canon. In DS:IW there are a total of four different endings to choose from and all of them are outlandish. If playing this as a typical shooter game, it starts out really difficult, whereas mid-game you're fucking everyone up and the late game turns tedious. 

Recommended play for the fans of "immersive sims" and FPS games.

148510526.review:
Yes, it's essentially the original Deus Ex simplified in several respects - universal ammo, no levelling up, only a handful of biomod slots, no inventory management, and much smaller loading zones. 

And yet, I still couldn't wait to replay this game after so long, having only previously played it on the Xbox many years ago. It's still a purely enjoyable game if you meet it on its own terms. Sneaking through enemy-infested levels while crouching and using the Cloak power-up was my favourite method of progress. You'll also like the many different paths available to complete each mission, and exploring the streets of Trier was nice.

Negatives? I get the impression that Ion Storm tried to cram too much story in a much smaller and shorter game than the first one, and I found it easy to lose some of the strands relating to all the different clans and their leaders. And there are lots of technical issues with this Steam version. On my previous computer I was unable to run it completely, and on this one it's prone to crashing and failing to load anything apart from a black screen, which required a restart. A hint: don't load the most recent save upon starting the game - use the second from first instead. 

In the first hub area - Seattle - the game throws so many objectives at you that I sunk about 3-4 hours in that city alone, at first giving the impression that Invisible War will be a time sink. Not so - you can finish the game and see all of its endings in around 15-20 hours. But they fly by and the game goes down a treat while it lasts.

I think that this game is very misunderstood, but also a good case study for what happened to the series as a whole. It essentially is a watered down deus ex 1, with many similarities to human revolution's problems. That makes it really hard to play for people who liked either of those games, since it is essentially Human Revolution 0.5. 

However I think that any deus ex enthusiast should take the time to play and learn Invisible War, since the content and story and world can be really intriguing to anyone who was interested with the first game's. But of course it has its flaws in its execution. Spoilers ahead:

Story Spoilers:
In Invisible war, every single ending in deus ex 1 applies.
Yeah its confusing. JC managed to merge with helios, restore the illuminate, and shut down global communications.
From a world standpoint, the world is changed in ways that should have depended on what endings you would have gotten. 
For example, if you got the Helios ending, the world should have been more prosperous and controlled by a singular being. However, since in IW, JC also shut off the aquinas router, he wasn't able to bring peace to the world with helios. You see how they're clashing? It leaves a bad taste in anyone's mouth. 
(I'm getting tired iterating this point so lets move on)

Gameplay Spoilers:
Ammo is universal across all your guns
there are no skills
augs and their progression have been simplified
Thats basically all the huge stuff
You'll also feel that enemies are either really squishy or absolute tanks
There are a few things i did like, such as the emp black market aug, which at its first rank game you more melee damage against robots, but then you could use it to temporarily change the robot's alliance to fight for you. With enhanced melee strength, this was a really good combo. But it was the only real combo available to me.

143728488.review:
Yeah I'm kinda conflicted on this one.
Is it the worst/weakest game in the Deus Ex series? Yes.
Is it by all accounts, a terrible game? Not exactly.

I still enjoy it, I played with the [url=https://www.ttlg.com/forums/showthread.php?t=147423]Visible Upgrade [/url] mod installed, my laptop has zero issues handling it but it occasionally has bugs that are not game-breaking. But you can tell it's a visible downgrade from the first game as soon as you started playing. Unfortunately, consoles suck so the game opens and closes itself for loading screens to prevent memory leaks.

Universal ammo? Permanent HUD? Simplified skill progression? Constant loading? Bad writing? Boring level design with awful backtracking? Flying 5 feet in the air because you're trying to jump into a vent?

There is no character development, so you don't feel convinced by their rhetoric to pick a side. The obsession with coffee shops in this game is weird (I know its foreshadowing but still). Your dialogue choices are binary, how you approach a level does not have any repercussion because DX loves its choose-your-ending-because-your-allegiances-don't-matter story beats. The wonky bouncy physics threw me off because it's almost impossible to mantle or climb in a vent properly.

Shit could've made anyone drop this game but I love immersive sims too much to do that. It's still very much Ion Storm DNA in this game. The transhumanist/cyberpunk/conspiracy themes, the atmosphere, attention to details you love are still there. Some builds are fun and absolutely broken you could breeze through the whole level.

DXIW is mid, it's not garbage, it's an okay sequel that was dumbed down for consoles and sandwiched between acclaimed titles in the series. I'd say it's worth experiencing this game once, just because you want more Deus Ex, or you want to know what happened to the Dentons' story after DX1. But DX1 set the bar really high and you can't help but lament that this game had so much potential.

Obviamente a nivel gráfico ha mejorado aunque por alguna razon el protagonista tiene un peor modelado que el resto de personajes (nuestros ojos no tienen parpados xd). El inventario se ha simplificado y diria que a mejor (una ranura por objeto). La comida AHORA ES UTIL: no solo cura de forma decente sino que encima puedes stackear casi cualquier tipo de comida en 1 slot. Los mods de armas y habilidades tienen su inventario aparte. Si te dan un código, tu pj lo aprende para cuando actives el panel correspondiente (evitando pasar por varios menús y aprender claves y contraseñas en el proceso o ir apuntandolos en papel o en el movil). En general los menús son bastante mejores que en el primer Deus Ex.

Y ahora lo malo:
Al igual que el primero, este tiene un par de problemas que tienes que arreglar con mods de la comunidad (entre esos problemas que no está en español y la resolución). Leí que a algunas personas les crasheaba mucho, aunque a mi no me dio ningun problema nunca. 
Los mapas se han reducido DEMASIADO comparado con Deus Ex 1, hasta el punto de ser pasillos entre pequeñas zonas, lo que causa que cada 2 minutos te tengas que comer una pantalla de carga (no exageraría si digo que 30-60 minutos de mi tiempo jugado son pantallas de carga). Que sean mapas tan pequeños tambien castiga a la hora de tomar tus rutas y las opciones en el juego, por lo que se vuelve extremadamente lineal. Un poco igual que en el anterior, da igual lo que hagas a lo largo del juego, lo unico importante es la decision del final.
Teniendo en cuenta que es un juego de rol, que tu decision del juego anterior sea irrelevante para este tambien me chirría un poco, porque hace que solo haya un final "canónico" en el primer deus ex que es el que enlaza con IW.

Lo de que se hayan quitado las "aptitudes" del primero no se si calificarlo como algo bueno o malo, porque con el primero yo no notaba demasiada diferencia al subir cada arbol quitando la pirateria y abrir cerraduras (que aqui se ha simplificado y todo se abre con la misma herramienta)

Está tirado de precio a dia de hoy y me parece una experiencia mucho mas disfrutable que el primer Deus Ex. Se aleja bastante de ser un Deus Ex como tal, pero es divertido y ha envejecido mejor que el primero.

[h1] That what consoles do with our games. [/h1]
Worst sequel ever and it’s not even a bad game. It just a super downgrade in every single way, cut version of “sequel”, it even feels nothing like Deus Ex sequel, with visual that looks like a sad, poor joke – we never asked for this.
The thing is – it could have been a good game and it even an ok game, it really has quite interesting things and few good pros: it has decent, interesting story; non-linear quests; the most side-quests are interesting and fun; new biomods system is not bad – where you can install augmentations and reinstall them to other, but the good part is that there are “official” biomods and ones from “black market” which is cooler but much harder to find.  
Pros:
+ Cool biomods system
+ Interesting side-quests
+ Cool pilot system. While traveling you need to find a pilot by yourself and the pilot selection will affect where you land on the next mission
Things that are neutral:
* Universal ammo – it’s not a bad idea (it’s 2072) but execution is not fun and entertaining at all
* Story is interesting but can’t held with original
* Variety of approaching, but locations so freaking tiny that in the same f*cking place you have security terminal, vent, main door and the guy who ready to sell you code
Cons:
- Absolutely horrible visual
- Game doesn’t feel like Deus Ex game
- Absolutely horrible inventory (prepare for the worst inventory ever seen in a video game)
- Locations smaller than the ladies restroom in UNATCO headquarter.
- Skills? – Forget about it
- Entering the code or logs? - Forget about it. You even can't manually enter it, so or you have it or use hacking tool
Why I recommend this? It still playable, somehow it still a Deus Ex sequel and a continuation of the story, you will visit few locations from the original. So, if you fan of the original DE and HR give this a try as I did and you’ll see a new, closed before, page of the Deus Ex universe, it worth the try.

143070024.review:
It's hard to recommend the game in its current state. I'm the type of guy that is willing to forgive a game for its technical issues if the mods can treat them. Alas, ridiculous loading screens, crashes, corrupted saves, horrendous UI and cluncky gameplay, the mods can't in this game. Reason: no SDK. On MODDB, there is literally *three* mods to download, 2 texture mods, one community patch (which I highly recommend). 
Besides the glaring technical issues of the game however, the game is pretty good. Has decent story, neat side mission, decent combat and stealth, and is short and sweet you could say. Shame that for me personally, the technical issues really worsen the experience. I would only recommend playing this game if, and only if, you've play the other 3 main installments, as well as their DLCs, and *replayed* them, and playing other immersive sims, before committing to this game.

142932249.review:
Took heavy modding to get it into a state that was comfortable to play on a modern setup, and apparently this modded version is invisible to Steam so my playtime is well underestimated. 
I understand that this  entry is not the most beloved of the Deus Ex titles, but I found it sleek and enjoyable to play, and I liked the option to pick my character's gender at setup  
I found the locations to be rewarding to explore and I just liked the overall set and character design. 

Now to the negatives 

Compared to GOTY or Human Revolution, the gameplay is very simplified. If you LOVE GOTY and have a firm idea of who your version of JC Denton was, you will likely be disappointed by the endgame levels. 

Invisible War tries to sidestep the issue of which ending in Deus Ex was canon by giving equal play to all three options, but in doing so it waters down the meaning and import of the choices made at the end of GOTY, only to give you a very slightly altered take on that same Big Choice at the end of Invisible War. 

That said, I loved the Greys, I loved seeing the characters from GOTY reappear, and I loved uncovering Alex's past

While this game very definitely is flawed, I find that it's imperfections only make it more beautiful to me. This entry into Deus Ex canon holds a dear spot in my heart, and I heartily recommend that it not be skipped in any playthrough of the series

142848703.review:
My playtime isn't represented, as I played through a 3rd  party patch

which is the first thing, if you dislike requiring a 3rd party patch or download to run the game on modern systems (at least at a good resolution, since the game will change your system resolution down to its level)
avoid this game

Otherwise, it's a decent, if brief, sequel to the original Deus Ex. Despite the plot pulling the "all endings are true" trope, and heavily altering the characterization of 2 side characters from the original game.
The political struggle is honestly a hard choice, but moreso because the canon goodies are too coy and vague, and the alternate factions are all unhinged to varying degrees.

I'd give the game a solid C, you can definitely tell their console push honestly tore down their vision, and the last act again feels super rushed (even more than the original, all I did was run through the last level of IW with max cloak and speed and did it in only the time it took for the mandatory radio transmissions and such).

But if you like the first, or the later games, you'll like IW decently enough. Not sure why the hardcore original fans rabidly hate on the game.

142816063.review:
don't treat the game as a deus ex game, instead treat it like one of those "parody" games with greatly oversimplified mechanics (universal ammo?), a story loosely based on the original and any task or story presented to you as an excuse to be a biomod obsessed kleptomaniac that runs around whacking people, robots, laser security systems or anything else that gets in your way with your black market biomod EMP buffed baton while hacking ATMs, vending machines, security systems and lock picking anything else that gets between you and the credits you need for your next biomod canister fix.

to get the true ending you go to unatco, grab the US flag by the old retinal scanner, put it in the toilet in manderly's old office and then flush.

one thing to keep in mind when playing is that the game has been programmed to DELIBERATELY crash itself and then reopen to load the next area and does this every time you see a loading screen, this was so the OG xbox with its 64MB of ram could clear its memory, this seems like a neat trick to get around the hardware limitations at the time (and also explains why each area is tiny, really pushing the hardware) but because steam keeps track of when you have opened and closed a game and notifies the people on your friends list whenever you open a game this means that EVERY TIME you see a loading screen steam will announce that you are now playing invisible war to everyone on your friends list so be prepared for people to ask why you keep opening and closing the game every few minutes.

lastly, NG-Resonance is a real band under a different name so if you like the music that plays in the clubs and bars then the real band name to search for is "kidney thieves".

get it on special and enjoy some mid 2000s hair gel infused jank.

142577945.review:
Without a doubt, the worst sequel in video game history and a monumental disappointment. Deus Ex was, and still is one of the greatest games ever made, yet Invisible War was nothing more than a pathetically simplistic sequel made for console that is inferior in every single respect. 

The game is painfully linear and the majority of areas are seemingly corridors or small interiors that feel really claustrophobic. There is also a staggering amount of long loading screens between these which absolutely kill any semblance of flow and NPC's will also frequently interrupt gameplay. Characters also look quite cartoony and the voice acting is quite frankly horrendous from most key characters. A stark contrast from what the original game offered from varied locations to its vast cast. 

Elements like Augmentations and the inventory system have been dumbed-down spectacularly and are all condensed into this hideous looking HUD made for controllers. Ammo is universal and things like multi-tools and lockpicks are fused into one. Skills have also been removed so what you are left with is a basic character who can activate augs and that's about it. All RPG elements have essentially been removed along with any real gameplay depth. 

Overall, Deus Ex Invisible War is a terrible follow-up to the iconic and timeless original and a shockingly woeful game in its own right. It's a PC game made primarily for the original Xbox console and it shows with huge technical limitations on top of a surprise lack of developer ambitions.

142327656.review:

Choices matter, but less than i hoped.

I encountered a few crashes during my playthrough, sligtly annoying, but not frustrating.

I do recommend playing it, but it's a slight positive for me, and i understand the negative reviews, just don't fully agree with them,

142304692.review:
I was going into this game already knowing about the issues with level design and dumbed-down gameplay from the OG game but what really held me back was a gigantic technical issue.

For those unaware, the game restarts the executable EVERY TIME you load a level. This includes loading saves from within the same level AFAIK.  On top of other issues that may occur this makes the loading screens unbearably long, which for me is about 2~ minutes for every load. Might not sound like much but remember the areas in this game are much smaller than the original due to it being made for the original Xbox console, so you'll be going between levels a loooot more than you would in the OG Deus Ex. And if you're anything like me who likes to quick save and experiment within these ImSim spaces then waiting 2 minutes to quickload a save is absolutely unacceptable. The community patch does nothing to help loading times and there does not seem to be another fix for it.

I'd really like to play it because I've heard that for all it's faults it's a pretty good game in the end, but the loading times are something I just can't deal with.

What a shame.

142038466.review:
A weird artifact from a different era of PC to console transitions. 

The game has hints of original Deus Ex design throughout, but the execution falls extremely short of the og's heights - overall there's just less to do in IW, less characters to interact with, less interesting choices, less room for emergent gameplay.

The maps are a lot smaller than the first game and end up feeling like samey corridors, and the layouts of the "cities" and facilities you roam around are so nonsensical they fail to suspend your disbelief, whereas in Deus Ex the rooftops and streets of New York and Paris actually immersed you into the world despite the simple geometry, in IW it feels like you're walking around a cheap theme park or an old 90's mall.

The entire aesthetic of the game is quite off-putting and even bizarre, it barely feels like you're in the same world/universe as Deus Ex, which pulled off a quite striking cyberpunk aesthetic that shined through even with the simplistic geometry the game had. IW's engine does have some nice lighting that is quite reminiscent of Doom 3's lighting - but the actual art style of the in-game assets and the world overall feels completely out of sync with what the world's plot would imply.

This is further exacerbated by the aforementioned simplified and shrunk down map design, as factions that are mortally at odds with each other will stand around 12 feet apart from each other like they're tending to kiosk booths at a convention (in one of the maps this is literally canonically the case mind you) - this physical proximity between everything and everyone really removes any sense of scale or gravity to what is happening in the plot.   

There's also an abundance of loading screens and map loads everywhere, given the console limitations: this is extremely detrimental to pacing and is related to a lot of crashes and technical issues.

Overall this game is quite a pity, even more so when taking into account that this is the culmination of the Deus Ex storyline and all other games have been prequels. The game contains a lot of excellent ideas hidden within - its title "Invisible War" is in itself an incredibly captivating concept that feels like its wasted on this mediocre game.

141962408.review: No it doesn't live up to Deus Ex, few games can. It's still a decent immersive sim however that retains a lot of interactivity and player choice. Give it a try and you might enjoy it like I did. Make sure you install the patch.

141578882.review:
Preface: I played Invisible War through the Visible War modpack, which has a download guide in the "guides" section of this game's community page. Visible War reads the game's Steamapp files but is a distinct application, so while it looks like I only played for an hour I played for an hour unmodded before hitting an impassible bug then switched to the modded version. This mod is a QOL mod that's mostly there to get the game running properly on modern hardware, and doesn't impact gameplay. I played on the second-highest difficulty and completed the game.

With that out of the way...

"Boring" and "frustrating" are the keywords when talking about Invisible War. The game is boring, because while on the surface it replicates the stealth-immersive sim gameplay of its predecessor, its simplified mechanics and massive amounts of loot it showers you with means that you rarely have to make meaningful decisions or sacrifices. In the original Deus Ex, gameplay frequently involved tradeoffs. You could never max out every skill (without abusing glitches). You couldn't max out every augmentation. You could never open every container (again, without abusing glitches). You couldn't cheese your way through the entire game with only one gun, because there wasn't enough ammo to do that. Invisible War does away with these tradeoffs. These is no skill tree in Invisible War. You can easily max out your biomods around halfway through the game. There are more than enough multitools and passwords to open every locked door and container in the game. The unified ammo system lets you use one gun the entire game, if you want to. Removing the cost behind decisions devalues the significance of making the choice in the first place. Invisible war does give you choices of who to work with, but for 90% of the game these are false choices, because [spoiler]both major factions you're choosing between are just different branches of the illuminati[/spoiler].

The frustrating aspects of the game are largely confined to its story. Deus Ex speculated on the near-future and commented on the contemporary world, and in doing so predicted the global war on terror and its consequences (and I'm not just talking about a NY skybox without the Twin Towers). The developers, making a game after 9/11/2001, had a chance to build on that foundation and create a game with something meaningful to say about that contemporary sociopolitical climate. America and the rest of the world are still dealing with the consequences of the war on terror, so even a commentary on the 2003 political climate could have been relevant today, two decades later. Instead, they made something with negligible sociopolitical value, focusing on transhumanist pipe dreams that ignored the actual issues around real-world transhumanism. For example, while the plot does indirectly deal with the issue of informed consent to modification, the topic is only really brought up on a global level rather than an individual level, and the issue of access to modification is ignored entirely. On top of that, the characters are largely one-dimensional and/or lacking in any ideological consistency. 

The game isn't beyond salvaging. There's some enjoyable sections in the midgame with some interesting combats and branching paths before the plot goes completely off the rails, and the biomods and weapons are at least fun to play around with. Spiderbombs are pretty mediocre, but are the coolest thing in the game, earning a special shoutout. Invisible War also gets some points back from having the funniest solution to making a sequel for a game with multiple endings, which is "all of the endings happened simultaneously." Also, while the ending itself is poorly foreshadowed and framed, having an ending where you [spoiler]destroy every major faction, kill almost every named NPC, and doom most of the world's population to death by climate change just to get a discount on black market weapons and biomods[/spoiler] is also very goofy, and feels cathartic if you got to the last segment and felt like rebelling against the game's story.

Despite possibly qualifying for a refund because I only used the unmodded game for an hour, I'm not going to refund the game. I bought it on sale for a dollar, and I feel like I got my money's worth of entertainment, even if I had to install mods to make it playable at all on my computer. I guess if you really liked Deus Ex, then you might consider waiting for a 90% off sale, but I can't endorse spending any real amount of money on this game.

141298971.review:
What is Deus Ex: Invisible War ?

Years ago I got introduced to Deus Ex through the prequels which I liked, both of them were great games with Human Revolution being my preferred one, I know that there were 2 other Deus Ex games before it but I never had the chance to play them before, tried the first one which is a revered classic and to this day its still a game that appears in lots of discussions as one of the best games of all time, I played it before and initially put it off due to how aged and frustrating it felt to play but after giving it another chance recently and modding it a bit, I instantly fell in love and played it nonstop.

Now moving to Invisible War, I already heard a lot of bad things about this game but putting them aside, just a few days ago I finished the first one which left a mark on me that Im still thinking about and I decided to at least give Invisible War a chance despite the things I've heard about it because it was the only Deus Ex game I didn't play yet excluding the very skippable mobile ones, also considering it was also a sequel that even featured returning characters of the first, I was curious to see how it would continue the story, what destiny those characters would met and how they would continue from the first one's ending so I gave it a chance and one hour of gameplay was enough to instantly put me off.

Yes, one hour was more than enough for me to know it was a game that wasn't worth playing and that I should just drop it off and dont further waste my time, I've finished wayyyy too many games already and if is there one thing I dont want to waste my time with is boring, mediocre games. Many people brushed this game off as a dumbed down consolized sequel and its exactly what it is, the game cut off several interesting mechanics of the first game, especially the skills/rpg part of it, say what you want to say about the prequels but they still have many more rpg elements than this crap. The story and characters especially the way they were talking in the first missions really put me off, after the amazing quality of the dialog in the previous game and its engaging characters, in invisible war the characters talks like some dumb teenager or an emotionless bland character, the initial setup of the game story felt so forced and stupid and the gameplay, the shooting feels really weightless and bland and with universal ammo the whole gunplay aspect of the game feels more like an afterthought, it just doesnt feel good to shoot things with those crappy weapons all using the same ammo, the new augment system is ok, it isnt the worst thing it has going on for it but the removal of several other stuff that made the game more immersive like you know looting stuff and sorting properly your inventory, being able to acess computer interfaces and hack stuff or even type codes on a door, here you just press buttons with zero immersion. There were many ways a sequel could improve the previous one, especially in the gameplay department and this one just blows at it, nothing here feels improved besides graphics, from story to gameplay, everything feels worse, it doesnt even feel like a Deus Ex game, the whole feel of the game and amostphere reminds me of some random generic scifi game that could be released exclusive on consoles of the ps2 era at bargain bin, the soundtrack is good at least but thats the only positive I have to say about this game.

Theres a reason that the franchise disappeared after this one and why its reception is so negative, this game has nothing to do with Deus Ex and it feels offputting how they decided to continue the franchise after the immense success of the first in this way, even if you put the name aside and ignore its a Deus Ex game it doesnt feel its a game worth playing, the previous game is an aged old game that is worth coming back or giving a chance because it offers something unique that no other game has replicated, this one which is also already an old game, has just nothing going on for it, nothing to offer, no qualities, its just a very skippable game that deserves to be forgotten and ignored, it makes me think what kind of shit people from Ion Storm were eating when they decided to design a sequel to one of the best pc games ever made, even the consolization excuse doesn't justify it when they managed to port the original one to ps2, this game just blows, so, don't even think of wasting your time with it.

140069110.review:
The gaming experience is worth it. However, it is important to note that, in terms of gameplay, it is considered one of the weakest in the Deus Ex franchise. The game has significantly simplified the character upgrade system and unified the weapons, making them all share the same type of ammunition. Furthermore, compared to the first game in the series, there is a significantly smaller variety of available weapons.

Regarding the level design, the game has also undergone simplifications in this aspect, featuring smaller scenarios and loading areas between them. These limitations restrict the options for completing objectives, resulting in a nearly linear gameplay experience.

While the dialogues are interesting, they don't reach the same level as the first game in the franchise. In relation to that, there are only a few key moments of choice during the game. Only in the final phase are four ending options presented.

Overall, it is a rather weak continuation, and if it weren't for The Fall, this would be the weakest game in the franchise. As a result, I only completed the game because I enjoy the universe, but I wouldn't play it again for further exploration. In comparison to the first game in the franchise, which took me 90 hours to complete as I wanted to explore every corner, I only explored what was necessary in this game and finished it in less than 10 hours.

139139802.review:
I haven't played Deus Ex 1.
I decided to try this one first out of curiosity since people seem to disapprove of it as an inferior sequel, so easier to get a more isolated impression.

I think, if DXIW were to release today, under a different name, with slightly changed names and plot elements (but maybe leave some as references), and it were released by some unknown indie or AA studio (with none of the technical issues an old game like this might have, with the "Visible Upgrade" unofficial patch in a sense built-in)--
-- I suspect that DXIW would sit at "Very Positive" reviews on steam, lauded as a loveletter to older RPG/imsims with an engaging retro aesthetic similar to Doom 3 & Chronicles of Ridd:ck that clearly loves Deus Ex and does a lot even if it does not supersede it, that people would still find it to have systems you rarely see in games these days and appreciate it bringing something that feels a bit more like DX1 than modern games, where your actions speak louder than words.

I'm sure DX1 is an absolute masterpiece that is massively superior to DXIW, but isn't that the thing? It's considered one of if not the best video game of all time, to many people everything pales in comparison. So, to me, people seem kind of harsh to DXIW, played in isolation with only having absorbed information of DX1 through osmosis and seeing reviews of it and all the other games it's influenced, I found DXIW a wonderful game that has made me more excited to try out DX1 soon. 
I've put off playing DX1 because it seems intimidating, wouldn't be the first time people hype some game up to such degree that it becomes almost off-putting and I become uncertain if I'm in the right mood.

But hey, I loved DXIW, I'd put this up there with my top 100 games of all time (I have a lot of favorites ok? Hard to pick any one game), so if DX1 is actually more of this and somehow better, then I'm all for it, but that doesn't make DXIW imo bad.

I was a massive fan of the aesthetic, as someone who more fondly remembers the graphical leap in the early 2000's with Halo, Doom 3, Half-Life 2, Chronicles of Ridd:ck, Far Cry, Quake 4, Prey, SCCT & FEAR, this one has those cool dynamic stencil shadows & lighting with normal mapping that looks pretty great, a lot of areas in the game still look wonderful with atmospheric lighting & art.
The imsim stuff was still fun, sneaking, having lighting conditions slightly influence your visibility, though nowhere near Thief/Splinter Cell levels, you'll want the Cloak biomod to go completely invisible, & sound playing a role, a lot of dynamic factions & infighting with decent AI, you have a ton of different lethal and nonlethal weapons, gadgets & biomods available.
What was fun was how as a lite RPG with more imsim elements your actions speak louder than words, unlike so many RPGs these days, in DXIW talking is secondary to what you do, roleplaying isn't just picking red or blue or grey conversation options, it's you looking at situations, deciding if you even want to complete a "primary goal" or do you want to snoop around and see what other options might present themselves if you pay attention and investigate actively more the environment, a lot of your "quest givers" only share their side and what they want you to know, you need to go out and find out if they are speaking the truth, or if there's more to the story.
(I'm sure DX1 already did this and better, not disputing that, just saying DXIW is a fun game by itself.)
A lot of characters had depth to them, I can't really say some were purely good or evil, though the game also avoids falling into the usual "everyone is awful and you'll feel bad regardless of what you accomplish" trope some edgy RPGs end up doing to try and appear mature. I had some minor philosophical quibbles here and there but nothing massive, this is overall a relatively mature and insightful game tackling more complex subjects than you usually see (not just a "racism bad" focus like has been in many games trying similar things, it's an aspect in the game, but only one) and I applaud that, a bit clunky here and there but not really in a way where it detracts, it's not like the subject matter is simple and easy to resolve either.
Also a fan of how it didn't feel like the game was punishing me really for any actions (looking at you Dishonored & Metro), you can be a total pacifist and that's great & to some degree encouraged, killing isn't a massive game ender or locking you into only the scolding ending, it seems you actually kind of have to actively work towards an apocalyptic ending, which is kind of cool that it exists.

What was clear though when playing DXIW was that some limitations were still apparent, a LOT of loading screens being the main one. They are luckily on modern hardware relatively short, but a lot of areas have been chopped to smaller chunks to still try and retain in each area you visit as much variety and options as was possible at the time, which did feel like a decent amount. 
The Inventory too felt a bit consoly, it functions, you can still click around with your mouse, it's not like a poor console port where you'd be forced to only scroll through it or something, but man I prefer grid-based inventories instead of just having slots.
And it did have some awkward collision with the physics and geometry, which could make some jumping/platforming clunky on occasion, and you could see AI also at times struggling with some geometry, making it appear dumber than it would otherwise be (compared to the vast majority of games out there).
Animation quality of course is no "last of us" since this is an early 2000's game & don't expect the voice acting to be big budget hollywood either (the same is probably true of DX1 as well) but I felt the game did a good job with its presentation and direction, I was engaged talking and listening to NPCs and following the plot, many characters might come off initially off-putting or awkward, but that seems almost purposeful at times given their character arcs that they go through over the course of the plot.

Anyway, I'll say some stuff about technical aspects.
https://www.pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Deus_Ex:_Invisible_War
https://github.com/AlpyneDreams/d8vk/releases
I played with the Visible Upgrade, simple installation. Applied the 4GB Large Address Aware patch to the executables to improve stability, & I added the newly released Vulkan wrapper for DirectX8, by AplyneDreams on github, called d8vk, I've had success in the past with DXVK to improve stability & compatibility with old games on modern OS's and hardware, and it too seemed to work here, I had 0 crashes or visual bugs or anything, I locked my FPS to 60 & it stayed there.

Too much for many who want a game to work out of the box I'm sure, and to them yes, I wouldn't recommend this? I've been a PC player/modder for 20+ years so for me all of this were just standard vanilla minor stuff I'm used to tweaking to make sure older unsupported games would run smoothly.

DXIW might not live up to DX1 (not here to argue that), but as someone who's only played DX Human Revolution a bit before now trying DXIW as an experiment, it's still on its own a really solid light RPG/imsim which still makes it massively better than 80% of games released to this day, I kind of feel that it's harsh to just completely dismiss this, the devs clearly cared about the project, it's not just a half-baked prototype completely blasted to be a simple linear stealth shooter for the console audience.

Like I said, release this today under different names, remove most loading screens & make it stable on modern machines natively without tinkering, and I think it would be a mad world if still people would somehow all vote this as being "mixed" at best like it's currently on steam. Then I question why Deus Ex Human Revolution and many other games deserve very positive aggregates if this would today be anything less than "Very Positive".

138341648.review:
What a game.. And i have to say, really not as bad as the steam reviews might lead you to believe!
It certainly has its problems, and many annoyances, but without a doubt i enjoyed my time with this game, and i also appreciated the throwback to the original deus ex at some point in the story. Still no Jaime! sadface.

Starting with the good things, the combat is pretty good, and so is the stealth. I pretty much immediately picked up fully upgraded silent foot though so i can't say what it is like without it. Talking about "silent foot" (It's 100% not called that in the game) I am very happy with the variety of mods and customisation. There are 2 different types of mod canisters and one is supposed to be unofficial, and unpredictable! Sadly they did not explore this at all. They are the most powerful but i really was hesitant originally to use unofficial canisters as i was concerned on what it might do negatively to me - it did nothing. Oh well!

This is controversial, but i also fully appreciate the all-in-one ammo. It canonically makes sense and although i was confused to begin with (I thought all the ammo i was picking up was for the pistol) I later realized and honestly i am happy with it, it makes sense to be there. I understand that many dislike it but at the very least it makes sense in the world of Deus Ex.

Another thing they did, which i didn't like as much (Especially as canonically its fluky) but it did make things simpler, is to streamline the lockpick and bypass tools into just a multi-tool. Yes it does make the game simpler, but i don't think that is a problem in this department, though it is somewhat immersion breaking to convince yourself that every single door uses an electronic lock so the digital tool can bypass it, but it is canonically on base.

The story had good pacing and there was plenty of bonus things to do that reward you for doing them. A lot of them don't really have consequences but some do and reward you well, and others just offer immersion, and help you feel like there is a world and not just 1 main objective.

Combined with the mod choice, i also think the enemy variety and weapons are nice. Later in the story there is most definitely a difficulty curve as some enemies are in stronger gear and some weapons you may use (Specifically, i would knock people unconscious in my playthroughs) will be become entirely ineffective, whilst other weapons you have been sitting on would become more viable.

Onto the negatives.. 

I'll disregard any lack of resolution support, and anything else similar as you must consider that this is an early 2000s game. There are community patches which you can download at your discretion, but i personally did not use this. The only modification i made to the game was to download dgVoodoo to make my frame limiter work. (Without a doubt you will need to limit your frames in this game to have any semblance of it running correctly). The maximum resolution that the game can handle was fine on my 1920x1080 monitor.

The first thing that i absolutely hate with a passion in this game is how they implemented zone changing. In most games you'd expect a little sound, fade to black and then a loading screen. Not in this game. In this game, the game application exits, an Ion Launcher application starts, then the Ion Launcher exits and another application launches and then you get a loading screen. It completely sucks, and to make it worse around 2/5's of the time ion launcher will just fail to launch the new application. I once waited like 2 minutes to see if perhaps i just needed to give it time. No, it'll just come up with a popup saying timed out and then close itself. To make this worse, the zones are inconsistent in size so you'll sometimes find yourself going through zones quickly and consecutively, and each time, risking what can only be described as soft crashing.

Another thing that is really weird is the 2 factions in the game. One is supposed to be traditional government, hogging power and trying to control everything, and the other is supposed to be about freedom of self, charity, selflessness and for the people. The government-like faction behaves precisely as you expect, and the other one does until they interact with the player. There approach to everything seems to be "kill this person for me". There is a character who worked on a project that didn't even want to work on the project who was the head of it, and the non-government faction asks you to solve the issue of their creation by killing them. They will just be replaced! Why not destroy the plans, or try a different approach? The entire functioning of that faction is in complete contrast to what they are supposed to represent, so i found myself going with the other faction quite often just on a moral basis. This could have been an intentional choice to deepen the greyness of morality between the factions despite their viewpoints, with their not being a clear light and darkness, but it completely decredits the other faction and just makes them feel fake, and therefore as if not more corrupt than the government-like faction. Thankfully, throughout the entire game you're not really forced to completely devote yourself to one side, it's more like "Hopefully you don't betray us again".
Some nitpicks. Using the stun prod, sometimes the enemies will break out of it and shoot you even as you continue to "stun" them, despite it being implemented in a way that you hold it down to stun for as long as you have the ammo for it.

You also have to be careful in cases where hostiles are near allies. Even if you hit them with a flash (Bare in mind they'll run around when the enemies shoot at you as they hear) They will not attack you, but will see you as hostile, blocking all dialogue options and them repeating that it is not safe.

Another nitpick for sure is F12 being unrebindable without messing with game files outside the game. I wanted to take screenshots as I always like to do but it was literally impossible using steam overlay, both because of the F12 issue and the way levels reloaded and steam overlay not rehooking to the new application.

Overall, despite these issues it wasn’t too difficult to play the game in its entirety, and considering the age of this game, I am very happy about how everything went. I would definitely recommend this game, though it is important you temper some expectations and adapt to the games uniqueness and quirks.

137982531.review:
Regardless of the game itself, there are several technical issues that I don't see discussed nearly enough here. You should expect these if you buy this game:

- Multiple windows - Every time you enter a loading screen, it starts up a new process and leaves the original one hanging. Loading screens are often, so after a few hours of playing you can have 50+ windows open. Mostly just annoying, but interferes with recording/screen sharing software.

- Long load times - Again caused by killing and restarting the process every time.

- Crashes - There's an unofficial patch to fix this but I still had crashes every now and then. In the final two missions I had a crash about every 5-10 minutes.

- Misc Bugs - I had a really entertaining one where, after going through a loading screen in the final map, all of my augmentations were gone, my inventory was empty, and my character's gender was swapped.

137390264.review:
If you wanted a true sequel to Deus Ex, this really aint it. This game certainly takes place after the first game but really lacks a lot of the depth that the first game brought with it. TLDR: get it on sale with all of the other games or get it bc you want to know what Ion Storm was intending to do with the first games plot. Or just buy it for around the 5$ price range. Otherwise you aren't missing much unless you are a super fan.

Without jumping deep into the story ill just be brief and say that it lacks the intrigue and depth that the original brought with it. While it develops on that game's story by making all three endings technically cannon the resulting mess that comes after is just not unraveled in a way that's well paced or well done. However i will admit that I did enjoy the endgame a fair bit when presented with the ultimate "question" of the game and found it to be rather interesting. Beyond that the gameplay is a straight downgrade with a universal ammo system that at the best of times makes the game more convenient and at the worst forces you to value ammo preservation towards the end of the game. Other than that the light RPG mechanics of levels and EXP are gone and as a result specialization is pretty much gone as well. Meaning this game has much less replay value and most of the variety comes from the weapons and biomods. While that would be okay alot of the higher tier weapons and bio canisters are practically thrown at you like candy. by the end of the game i had like 8 normal mods and 3 illegals left over after fully kitting myself out. This encourages you to really do what you want when you want like in a game like skyrim however I think it just dumbs the game down for the lowest common denominator. As for performance you'll need a mod to even run the game on windows 10 and good god are those loading times long even with an SSD. It makes doing the back and forth of turning in quests a total chore as most of the time is spent just loading. The environments and music tracks are all pretty much a flat downgrade IMO. Overall the game isnt bad per say just a bit of a disappointment if you loved the first Deus Ex, it feels like a lot of the complexity is lost in favor of attracting the most amount of people rather than appealing to what made it a great experience in the first place.

137214675.review:
Ok, the game is not bad, but it's definitely worse than the previous one.
Imho, the main issue is there's no experience/skill points system. That mean, when you finish a quest, the only reward you get is some money, and you know what? After approximately half of the game you don't need the money at all. So, there's no motivation to do side quests except for lore reasons, but you don't get enough lore either....
The developers decided to use the augmentation canisters instead of skill, but I don't think that's a good idea. First of all, there are a lot of canisters in this game - you'll get everything you want pretty soon. The second reason why I don't like the current system is the imbalance between augmentations. Some of them are extremely useful (for example, the one for hacking the computers), and the other ones are not that good.
And, of course, the ammo. Of my God. Maybe the creators though that making the ammo suitable for all guns will help players to use their favorite weapons more often, but in the reality it's vice versa. If you depleted all your bullets with one gun, that means you can't use any of your weapons anymore! It becomes really annoying by the end of the game, when you have to fight some really durable enemies.
The endings are pretty lame - the videos are approximately 10 seconds long and after that you'll find yourself looking at the main menu.
But I recommend playing Deus Ex: Invisible War if you want to know how the story of Dentons ended. The game has some redeeming qualities - for example, there are multiple ways of solving quests, and I like it.

This is an endorsement that I give with a few caveats:

1. I needed to download a mod to get this game running properly. 
2. Even running from an SSD, the load times have been pretty excruciating.
3. There are a number of streamlined gameplay changes that the developers made for this game after the original Deus Ex, that are mostly to this game's detriment.

All that being said, I am really enjoying this game. It may not be as good as the original, Human Revolution, or Mankind Divided, but most of what makes up the DNA of a Deus Ex game is still here, and it's still damn good. The "worst" game in a franchise that I would put in the conversation for best game franchise of all time is still pretty darn good, and if you pick this up at a reasonable price, and don't mind jumping through a few hoops to get it running properly, it is still worth a play for fans of the franchise. 136444592.review:
Honestly? This game isn't that bad.
I just finished Invisible War and I was surprised with how much I enjoyed it, since I had heard all about how terrible it was and how it was "one of the worst games ever." But it wasn't the worst game ever, not even close. It's actually a pretty decent game, not good, but decent. 
The biggest problem, by far, is the gameplay. The game feels clunky to play, with crude, underdeveloped mechanics and bad controls that make it not fun to play. Making things worse is the level design which is cramped, uninspired and dull with repetitive areas and, for the most part, forgettable scenery. So I will admit, the moment to moment gameplay is definitely bad but what kept me going all the way through this game was the story. 
While not on the level of Deus Ex 1, Invisible War's story is actually quite compelling and, imo, unique. It has several very interesting ideas with mature, rarely explored themes that are very well handled. Most of the characters are not particularly memorable but some most certainly are, the AI version of NG Resonance is awesome, the pilot Ava Johnson is a fascinating character and the Omar (they're a hive mind sorta thing so I'm counting them as one character) were my favourite part of the game. The game is a very good continuation of Deus Ex 1 and continues the plot of that game in a fun and engaging way, I don't want to say more than that since...you know, spoilers and all.
Finally, while not getting into them to once again avoid spoilers, I adore the endings to the game which are unlike anything you'd find in games today. Each ending is intriguing and morally complex and each of them left me both shocked and very interested. I'll fully admit that I'm still not sure which ending could be considered the "good ending!"
It's not too long, my playthrough took me just over 11 hours, and if you enjoyed Deus Ex 1, you really should play this as it wraps up the ending of that game quite nicely. While the gameplay isn't great, I've played worse and you can definitely push through it.
So yeah, I recommend you play it if you can give it cheap, even if it's only once.

132327453.review:
[b]TLDR: Watered down Deus Ex. Hassle to set up for an ok game, doesn't work properly out of the box.
Fun but could be better. If you want more Deus Ex and have already played everything else, then it's an alright choice to play.[/b]

First things first: To make this game a smooth experience, you need to google how to set up everything properly. Additional Software might be needed (Project Lasso for example), new launcher, deactivation of Steam and Nvidia Overlay etc. You'll find a good guide here on Steam (Read comments below the guides if the setup doesn't work). Otherwise it crashes on loading screens and can't set up the resolution for modern systems. But only if you don't optimize it via guides! After that it's a perfect game experience!

The Story is a Sequel to the Story of Deus Ex 1 (2000). If you haven't played that first, you will be confused about what's really going on, who the characters are etc. Play DE1, it's great.

This game is a heavily watered down Deus Ex. Only one type of Ammo for all weapons, lockpicks and multitools have been fused to one item. Skill System has been removed. Level design is much simpler, less options on how to approach the mission. In the tutorial you can already choose 3 out of 6 Biomods (Upgrades) which will make you unbeatable. Sneaking isn't as sneaky as it used to be. It feels more like an action shooter. Or a "I'm using my stealth Biomods and run past everything" game, which is not real stealth gameplay.

If you like a theme park styled game, where you pass everything with ease (even on hardest difficulty), then you'll quite like it. I prefered the gameplay of Deus Ex 1. But I still had my fair share of fun in this game! The story is interesting, the ragdoll physics are very fun. The characters are cool.

You can skip this game if the setting up is too much hassle for you, but if you want a quick fun game whith some Deus Ex elements, then this game suits that perfectly. It's not a bad game by all means, but it's not really a true Deus Ex either.
