131797164.review:
I have watched/read a lot of negative reviews about this game, but I actually quite enjoyed playing it (after getting past the frustrating experience of getting it working on my setup).

What I liked :

The best part of this game is its quest design.  A lot of times, if a quest giver tells you to do X, you can still poke around and find an alternate solution or find a reason not to do it.  There are a bunch of factions/characters telling you conflicting info, so it is always up to you to decide what you want to do.  This is the sort of thing you'd not experience if you just rush through the game by following objectives.  Your choices matter, and the game reacts to them.  I think the side quests were very well done, even the simpler ones.

While the smaller levels hurt the game somewhat (for stealth players), personally I don't think they are as bad as people say.  Buildings and rooms are in more realistic sizes than in the first game, and I think the environment looks very good with Visible Upgrade installed.  Exploration is rewarding, and crawling inside vents is a lot of fun.  I think the level design is actually very good in this game.  The soundtrack is excellent, and supports the atmosphere very well.  Worldbuilding and locations in this game are great.

What did not work for me :

I tend to play full stealth if a game allows me, but for this game, it didn't work out for me.  Enemy distances are not as much as in the 1st game because of the sizes of levels, and this makes it difficult to sneak.  Whacking enemies with a baton from behind for non-lethal takedown didn't work for me in this game.  I've defaulted to lethal way using a silenced pistol instead.

Biomods are grouped in a very strange way that, you actually have to pick between Cloak and Hacking.  You get quite a few Biomod canisters very early on, so the progression is not really there.

Ammo system is unified and weapons draw different amounts from the same pool.  For the entire time, I couldn't tell how many shots I had left in my equipped firearms.  If your rocket launcher uses up all your ammo pool, your pistol is out, too.

Late game bullet sponge enemies with lots of firepower were not fun to go up against.  When combine that situation with the above 3 points, things can get quite frustrating. 

The inventory slots are so few while there are lots of grenades and mines.  In the first game, the mines worked also as grenades, but here they are separate.  Lockpicks and multitools were combined into just multitools, but a bug causes the multitools to not stack properly and take up more slots than they should.  Medkits don't heal as much as they did in the first game.

The reticle design is ridiculous, lol.  I had to switch to Dot using the Visible Upgrade patch.

I felt that the game was better in the first 70% or so, when truth and real goals weren't revealed yet.  The game felt a bit short.

Technical issues :

This game was built around the memory constraints of Xbox, and whenever it loads new contents, it starts a new process.  If you have another program which interferes with how this is handled, you'll get "stuck in the black screen" situation.  It took me a while to figure out which one was interfering on my particular system.

Also, since each load is a separate process, sometimes the game would not respond until I click once to focus on that process.  This also seems to prevent the Steam Input based controller support from working properly.  I prefer controller because of an issue with my left hand, but I had to play this with KB+M.

Conclusion :

I enjoyed my time playing Invisible War, and I might actually do another playthrough siding with different factions.  I've listed what I thought was the "negatives", but I actually got used to how things worked in IW, and those ended up not being show stoppers for me.

For a long time, I kept wondering if I should play IW, but I am glad I finally gave it a try.

131624767.review:
A game all about moral ambiguity and being open to many possible choices...executed in one of the most flawed ways of its era. Unless you're ready for about eight hours of mediocrity and disappointment, don't play it. But for those willing to take the dip like I did and play it for historical value:

Gameplay: No single apporach feels right. Combat is a joke, stealth is an unfun chore in most circumstances and just kind of exists in a somewhat usable form in others, and other approaches to problems don't often crop up. Hacking is a thing...sorta. Resource scarcity exists, but mostly as a hollow shell of DX1's.

Story: Seems to deliberately not take shape until late in the game and is nearly adequate at that point. But by that point, you might have stopped having expectations that this game has a story at all. The return of various DX1 characters seems both appropriate and well-executed, even if their actual ingame functions as NPCs are minimal. The endings are okay, I guess, but I won't spoil.

Graphics: Not even that amazing for 2003, because Xbox. At least the game has ragdolls?

Audio: It exists. It's...adequate, not grating, not too loud or too quiet. Music wavers between 2/5 and 3/5. Voice acting is completely hit-and-miss.

131606493.review:
An interesting game, even if it's not its "big bro" (suuuuure)!

After a cool introduction, Invisible War begins in a context similar to the original. Still, it manages to generate surprises!
There is a time of adaptation during the beginning, it's very true if you are accustomed to Deus Ex 1.
After a couple chapters, you'll get more into it; this only goes crescendo, until the last parts which were excellent, especially if you love the first opus; trust me!

The mood, ambient in levels plus the soundtrack is good and goes even better in the second half (the last maps are great). At times I had F.E.A.R. vibes during combats… or S.T.A.L.K.E.R. ones while exploring. You'll understand what I mean.

The gameplay is a lot more simple though… too simple. UI is a downgrade… hey, give it a chance.
Different endings depending on your choices, as usual, that's good.

Be sure to install the Visible Upgrade mod too!
It fixes the game for modern systems, there is also an optional HD pack, rather true to the original game in my opinion.

Mod link: https://www.moddb.com/mods/deus-ex-2-visible-upgrade
There is also a Steam guide here with good tips to play the game in the best conditions, I advise you to read it, it's short: https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2482215439

To finish: try it if you're into Deus Ex!

Eheh 😎👍

131603003.review:
Oh man! I finally finished this game in 2023. It's been on my desktop for years! (TLDR version down below)

I started playing this game out gently some years ago, but barely an hour, and to be honest, I really lacked the interest to put it high on my priority list. The game is almost 20 years old, and it's ugly compared to the new games you can find, even from a decade after this was made. 

So, obviously my reason for recommending this game is not because it looks beautiful, but simply because of all the tech stuff you get to try out, and gameplay wise this is working for me. However, this game is probably not far off from a thumbs down from me either, because even though the game has a rich story, different places to go, and alot of voice acting to enhance the story, I frankly think the game could be a bit boring sometimes.

For some reason I realised I was gonna kill as few people as possible, so I just made most people go to sleep. I also wanted the gameplay to go in a way I wanted it, so I saved and loaded a lot. Did I make someone pissed, that I shouldn't make pissed? LOAD! Did I feel my way of doing things was not what I wanted? LOAD! Did I take too much damage in a place where there was little margin for error? LOAD! 

I THREW A BRICK AT AN ANIMAL AND IT DIED!! LOADED!!!

Anyway. I'm just gonna write a [b]TLDR[/b] version right now:
You are Alex D, and much like in the previous Deus Ex, you're able to augment yourself in a way to enhance your abilities. Along with powerful weapons and mods to help both you and your weapons get stronger, you dive into a story about violence, treachery and lies, but also ALOT of politics. The way game works is that you interract with different characters relevant to the story, and they will send you on a mission. You can ofc choose what missions you wanna do or not wanna do, sometimes for the reason that you wanna ally yourself with a faction. Sometimes you can do extra stuff, for extra credits (cash) too. [b]END OF TLDR.[/b]

There is alot of talk, and even though you can just skip everything, you might get a bit tired of it. I didn't skip anything as long as I had not heard it before. Anyway. As said before the game is old af, so I would just say that it's very tiring to play a game like this, with the graphics being not only outdated, but beyond outdated. Along with happends (the talk) and how the gameplay works, I wanted the game to be done, so I could play something else.

I mean me recommending this game, means that I had fun right, but I just wanted the game to end. When it feels like you have to force yourself to play a game, it's different than if you're actually having fun. I played this game from where I last left off, around 1 hour into the game, but this time I played the game from start to end, and if you're really going for this game, do it like that, so you can get over to play some newer games. 

So yes; I'll guess I'll recommend this game, but I won't play it ever again. Some choices makes different endings, but I got to see at least two of them, and will check Youtube for the rest.

131579758.review: Some questionable choices in terms of gameplay, but this is a nice, if short, conclusion to the Deus Ex timeline.

131464053.review:
Maybe it's not as good as every other Deus Ex game (except The Fall, obviously)
but I thoroughly enjoyed it. I would even go as far as saying that Invisible War
improved on certain aspects of the original. I felt there was too much going on
in the original - too many gadgets, too many different ammo types, etc. Just a 
little too complex - not saying that's a bad thing but sometimes I just can't be
bothered. None of that stuff here. It's very simplified or console-fied if you prefer.

The levels are quite small - a bit more linear. But overall, everything was a-ok.
Physics - check! A story - check! A lot of returning characters from the first 
game (most of the notable characters), the Dragon Tooth Sword, multiple references, 
multiple joinable factions, multiple endings, etc. Choices - check! Nice soundtrack
- check! Dialogue changes based on your actions - check! Whatever happened to 
JC Denton? Find out for yourself in Deus Ex: Invisible War. You also get to return to 
places from the original like Liberty Island. 

One bad thing I noticed is that Stealth is scuffed. You can either have the 
Cloak biomod or the one that lets you hack security and I think without 
Cloak it's not possible to stealth. At times I tried to be quiet, stay in the shadows 
but ultimately I failed and just played the game like a FPS. You definitely can't
sneak up on enemies and one shot them with a melee attack like in the
first game - I tried.    

There were some technical issues, like the game minimising to the desktop during 
loading screens and messing up my display settings (namely the resolution - had to 
keep putting it back to 1920x1080 after I'd finished playing for the night) and I did
have to tweak some configuration files to enable playing in my native resolution and 
to make the game look its best. The in-game settings are not very extensive.

Only one crash when I decided to go on a killing spree.

This is one of those games though that was worth any effort involved and despite
some downgrades (for lack of a better word), I would definitely recommend to any
fan of the series. Moreso from a story point of view than a gameplay one. 👍

131186888.review:
I remember back when Invisible War was coming out, thinking about how awesome the first game was and what they could possibly do to add more on to that gem...fuck I was so disappointed when I saw what it was. Invisible War tries to be what its predecessor was, an action fps game with rpg mechanics and decision making that has reaching consequences to your actions. It tries this, while at the same time fiddling with game mechanics in ways no one really asked for, with a story that misses the par set by its previous game. First I want to start with the positives: this game has some interesting augmentations. Personal EMP charge in your melee attacks? Passive augs that cost no energy? A drone aug that can essentially eat organic life and heal me? Yes, please! Some of the side missions and objectives have some interesting twists, or at least some amusing stuff you do like rigging a greasel match or dealing with the augmentation black market. Bodies ragdoll, and can be picked up and thrown to hide them or just mess around with them; sometimes to an absurd degree if you have the strength augmentation. Augmentation cannisters (both black market and regular) are quite generously laid about throughout the game making it quite easy to make your aug loadout compared to the first game.

The downsides of this game? Easily the biggest one is its universal ammo system. Its the future, so apparently every ranged weapon works off the same power source for ammo. Rockets, flamethrower fuel, rifle rounds, pistol bullets, tranquilizer darts, spitballs, foul language, everything is tied to this one energy bar you grab energy magazines to recharge. Enemies drop weapons and energy mags separate, meaning if you pick up their gun you just get a double of their gun and not the remaining ammo they had for you to scavenge, making it a headache sometimes when scouring the aftermath of a fight. Lets not forget too that if you run dry on one weapon...you're basically dry for all your guns as they all draw from the same ammo pool essentially. This is why I just about never used heavy weapons due to how much of a drain they put on all my other guns inadvertently. While we're on the subject of gear, the inventory system is kinda downgraded from the first game. You can only hold a set number of items as opposed to an inventory space which larger items took more room and smaller ones far less. Because of this, weapons and their size don't matter as well as other items you pick up like healing and bio-cells. Aug canisters each take as much space as a rocket launcher or a sword, and vice versa. The augmentation system itself, as much as some of those powers are fun, is kinda over simplified yet broken. In Deus Ex, you had about 9 slots for augs, and for just about all those slots you had multiple choices you could make for what you want installed. Invisible war offers only 5 slots for augs with three choices for each slot (one of those three being a black market aug). Augs are upgraded with just using more aug canisters on the existing aug you have installed. By midgame, I easily had all the augs I wanted fully maxed out and was still finding more canisters. You can change your installation choices too with just an aug canister, making configurations no longer permanent but it all seemed unnecessary. The skill system is gone from the first game, which took away that sense of progression and specialization that the first game had as you got better and better with equipment you preferred to use or improve on. All this is not even getting into the story, which honestly bored me for the most part; the only thing that kept me going was seeing how broken the combo of Strength Enhancement+Electrostatic Discharge was as I cold clocked bosses to sleep and turned enemy bots to my side with just a tap of a baton.

I recommend passing on this game, while not an abysmal failure comparing it to its predecessor is like night and day.

131074249.review: not as good as the first one especially that they over-simplified the character progression and why the firearms  shares the same ammo clip? but if you want more Deus Ex it is still worth it, just ensure to get the visible mod before playing this game.

130967500.review: This game may have a bad reputation, but I believe it's a worthy successor to the original. There are plenty of downgrades, yes--the mechanics are simplified quite a bit compared to the first game, the environments are a lot smaller, and it gets off to a pretty slow start compared to the original. Nevertheless, I found myself just as engrossed with it as I did the original. While the gameplay is simpler, it maintains the core of what made the original fun. You can still approach each situation in a wide variety of ways, you can still specialize your character to fit your own playstyle, and you still make impactful decisions that shape how the story progresses. In fact, this game has a much greater sense of choice than the first game, mainly due to the ability to choose which faction you decide to align with in every level. While Deus Ex 1 forced you to take orders from whoever the story dictated for that mission, Invisible war gives you several different sets of objectives to follow, each given by different factions vying for control of the world, and you have to decide who you want to side with. It's much like the final level of the original, but in every level. The story itself is great too. It does a good job of making you question your decisions; you're not just choosing whether to be good or evil.

Actually, this feels like a step back from the original [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/6910/] Deus Ex[/url], which was perfectly playable with mods and very entertaining at the same time. Deus Ex: Invisible War, however, has some problems. To resolve some of them, definitely use Deus Ex Visible Upgrade.
Once modded, you'll still have loading screens every other minute (I don't think it was that bad in the first game), the weapons wheel will still be a hassle, and for mysterious reasons some items in your inventory may spontaneously decide not to stack. Well, you'll have way nicer visuals, but the mod can't do away with all the faults of the game.
Also, I have the notion that the balancing may be a bit off. The opponents' AI seems to have been dialed down since Deus Ex, and they seem to be way easier to kill (not that I'm complaining too much about this, in particular).
At the end, I'm left with an Alex D biomodified to the teeth, several biomod canisters left in my inventory, and 4000 credits to spare.

129119851.review:
TL;DR: Game is a technical nightmare with poor optimization. Has a bad story and its gameplay is watered down from the first Deus Ex. If you're interested, buy it on sale, I got it for 97 cents.

About 2.5 hours of my playtime was just set up, trying to get the game to run properly before I could actually begin the game. There is virtually no optimization on the game's side, you'll have to do everything yourself, even just to get it running in your monitor's resolution.

Then after like a week (on/off) of trying fixing technical problems and installing performance mods, the game still crashes unexpectedly, causing me to lose progress. 

The game itself has a horrible story. It wants you to choose between a few different factions to work for, but they're all incompetent and immoral in some way so I don't actually want to side with any of them. It doesn't start following up on plot threads from the first game until a few hours in as well, so you get thrown into this world and all I'm thinking is "what happened to UNATCO, FEMA, the NSF, the Illuminati, silhouette?"

All questions the game isn't interested in answering, instead it throws the WTO, The Order, and the Omar at you, all factions that didn't appear at all in the first game. It also made the horrible decision of making every one of the first game's endings canon to the story, which doesn't make sense because they're contradictory outcomes.

(SPOILERS) I don't understand how JC could've simultaneously merged with Helios and destroyed Area 51 and have the Illuminati take over. My suspension of disbelief is already shattered with that even being the premise the rest of the plot is working off of. It also defeats the point of making you choose your ending in the first game to begin with. I also think, that if we're meant to believe that the Tracer Tong ending of DX1 happened, that it would take more than 20 years for the world to be as futuristic as it is in this game. A lot of locations look more Mass Effect than DX1, weirdly.

Plot grievances aside, they neutered the game play of the first game. What they did with the inventory system is a crime. Even the prequel entries brought back the grid inventory. The universal ammo system dumbs down ammo management, and you may as well only use the pistol if you want to conserve on ammo because not only do your guns share the same mags, but the more damage the weapon does, the more that shared mag depletes. I was constantly out of ammo in the early levels because I was relying on the shotgun, not realizing all the guns share the same clip.

Even with universal ammo being a thing, each gun could've had individual clips, that way if you take a shot with your sniper rifle, your pistol isn't out of ammo? I personally cannot stand this ammo system. I could be wrong on this, but melee weapons feel less effective than in the first game. I swear it takes like 8 wacks to take someone out now.

There's less specialization for your character compared to the first game. As far as I'm aware, there's not really a skill point system so you can't invest in like better lockpicking for example. Speaking of which, they combined multi-tools and lockpicks so anything that could be locked takes the same resource. Some people might find this convenient but I think it just removes another layer of complexity from the original's gameplay and gives you less options to handle situations with. At least you can still blow doors off their hinges.

There are moments where the game feels Deus Ex-ish and you start to get into it, but then either a crash, some bad dialogue, or just an unbelievable world building detail will just pull you out of the experience completely. The first game felt like once it got going, it was a cohesive experience. This game felt very start and stop in terms of my enjoyment.

The smaller maps are a double edged sword. On one hand, I enjoy the convenience of getting from point A to point B much faster, especially in the hub areas where you'll have to go around to the same places multiple times. On the other, exploration is completely uninteresting and the feeling the first game had that there was always a missable room or path just around the corner is gone. I honestly find the maps to be the least of this game's problems, though.

Nitpick complaints: Why did they rename Biocells to Energy Cells and Augmentations to Biomods? It's just annoying that they did this. The UI is uglier than the first game's and oddly feels more dated. Music is okay, suitably atmospheric but no real bangers like the DX1 soundtrack. Alex D's voice is very generic and bland compared to JC Denton's iconic voice. The guy from the opening cutscene is clearly the same voice as Walton Simons, I actually got confused and forgot for a moment that you kill him in the first game and was like "wait, Walton Simons, is that you? You're a good guy now?"

I found it very hacky when a character literally said "I'm fighting an invisible war here." Wreaks of "You're alone, huh? Guess that makes you Han...Solo" type writing. I only got the Cairo part of the game, but I'm still not sure why it's even called Invisible War. The war parts are very visible, the game starts with one of the US' major cities being destroyed. What is invisible about that? From the title, I assumed it would be a plot about hackers, espionage, maybe something involving cyberspace? You know, some kind of conflict that's invisible to the public but that doesn't seem to be the case.

128679076.review:
Unlike the other reviews what I'm going to do is show you how terrible this game is even if you purposefully forget it was the sequel to Deus Ex 1.  Nothing in my review will use the words "like in the old game", "like in DX1", etc.

An inventory menu with 10 slots... sounds like enough until you realize that your weapons take up a slot each.  Since you will need at least 4 and preferably 5 for weapons you will need, this is now cut in half.  But wait there's more!  You will most likely want to be always holding medkits and bio-recharge cells, so we're up to 7/10 slots now.  But wait there's more!  You will also have to be juggling story items too.  So within 30 minutes of the start of the game you will be dealing with 9/10 of your inventory slots constantly filled.  Forget about any comparison to DX1 because I've never played -ANY- kind of RPG/FPS-with-inventory-game/whatever in 25 years that is like this.  Oh but good news, you can stack items in inventory you already have.  What this ends up with is you feeling like a three year old going on an easter egg hunt when some character in game mentions in passing there is a copy of an item you already have, just so that you can validate the slot it takes up.  Frag grenades are useless but EMP grenades are extremely useful for getting past otherwise tough battle robots and indestructible cameras connected to gun turrets, and if you choose to keep them after you find them, congratulations that can be the final thing to bring you up to 10 out of 10 inventory slots filled at all times.

The augmentations are all mostly useless.  Resistance to poison?  You mean for the 5 enemies in the game that shoot it?  And for the 3 seconds that the poison is active, barely giving me enough time to remember I have the augmentation and then go activate it?  Thanks for thinking of me.  A strength augmentation so I can pick up uselessly heavy objects, which weren't blocking anything, and have no point to be picked up?  Thanks for thinking of me.

Weapons all share the same ammo and ammo is virtually non existent in the game.  How non existent?  For a long time I thought weapons were one-shot deals.  The game likes to tease you and remind you of this every 5 seconds because each and every enemy you kill will drop a copy of a weapon you have, and an ammo magazine with, I kid you not, 1/100th of its capacity.  Shotgun and rifle shots take up pretty much an entire spare magazine with one shot, so that's 2 hours of conserving bits and pieces of ammo you found everywhere with one click.  Getting good with melee weapons is required in this game, and at least they give you the electric sword almost at the start of the game (which by the way, is an inventory slot).  Ammo magazines are the one thing that are not in your 10 inventory slots and they are stored elsewhere, so at least you have that!

See that?  No mention of DX1.

If you must play this game, there is a community patch so you can modify the FOV and also have big resolutions and also surround/eyefinity support.  Oh, and it fixes the other apparent legion of system crashing bugs as well.  Which again, other games from this time don't have, even without a patch.

One slight redeeming quality is the story is interesting and unique and that part of it at least feels like they answered questions from DX1 or made it feel like a complete story.  The game is trash even if you ignore it was a sequel to DX1 as hard as you can, so just go watch a longplay on youtube.  Do not play this game, if you are a fan of DX1 or not.

Majority of people positively reviewing this game are "i hAd iT wHeN i wAs a kiD" or "iTs sEeN aS bAd oNlY bEcAuSe oF DX1".  Sorry, but no, this game is legitimately terrible, completely on its own.  Quite literally nobody on Earth plays this now unless they played another DX game and wanted to complete the series.  It's not say, big rigs scam tier, but it's not excusable especially since there is literally no other mainline DX game that is this level of "instantly drop due to exceptionally glaring gamplay flaws".

Why do they have Alex in the cover art holding the gun sideways like a gangster?  He doesn't hold it like that in the game.

Imagine playing this on console....

125861863.review:
I think my review is going to be very different from the others, which largely tell you that this game is worse than Deus Ex 1 in every aspect. Having played DX1 and this one back-to-back, I think it's mostly the opposite. This game has better story (although geared even more towards adult audience), more thoughtful choices (there is even less good/bad than in original game, most of the time you are choosing subjectively the least evil), interface is easier to work with, music is way better. Gameplay-wise, the only bad thing about this game is universal ammo (what a dumb idea).

Why negative review then? Well, it has to do with the program itself. First, you need to install some patches to even be able load the game. Now, if you think you are prepared for it - think again. There are some patches that you can find links to in various guides, but none of them are a universal recipe that works for all systems. You have to spend an evening or more trying different things. Even if you succeed, every level of the game basically starts a new process in a new window(!), and there is a big chance that the previous processes won't be closed automatically (same happens if you reload from a save). Needless to say, loading always takes a long time. You might need to disable Steam overlay and uninstall programs like Overwolf and Geforce Experience.

And the most important thing: this game broke my display settings! I don't understand why that happened and I don't know what exactly changed, but after I first switched from the full-screen version of this game to my desktop, my settings got messed up and I can't get my display look the same anymore. 122928693.review:
[h1] [i] Disappointing shell of its fantastic predecessor [/i] [/h1]

To start off, I have to mention that Deus Ex: Invisible War is not a bad game per se and if someone were to tell me they got their fair bit of enjoyment out of it, I could understand them. However, Invisible War simply cannot be analyzed in a vacuum – it was developed in a shadow of the original Deus Ex which, as we now know, was one of the most inflation games ever made so it is safe to say that it had some big shoes to fill. Did it succeed? 

Short answer: No. Slightly longer answer: [i] [b] Absolutely fu*king no. [/b] [/i]

As mentioned above, on its own, IW can be seen as ever-so-slightly above average futuristic RPG that isn’t very memorable, feels bland most of the time but has some interesting ideas and concepts. However, when compared directly to its predecessor, its flaws pop out like sore spot – virtually every aspect of the original has been dumbed down, simplified, and streamlined, and for worse. Reason? [i] [b] Consolification. [/b] [/i]

IW was developed for consoles first and foremost, with the PC as an afterthought, and since consoles possessed only a fraction of PCs’ performance, it could not handle things large open areas and also was not built for larger quantities of text on the screen, deeper, more complicated RPG systems from the first game (Augments, inventory management…) and thus streamlined what it could, ending up with a shallow, washed-out version of the first Deus Ex. Now you are stuck with these [i] [b] "amazing" [/b] [/i] new additions as universal ammo, closed off and claustrophobic level design and inferior plot.

So what’s the verdict? As I mentioned above, if you get Invisible War, you might enjoy yourself for a while, especially if you did not, for some peculiar reason, play the original game until you discover how shallow, uninteresting and forgettable it is. I say skip IW and move onto Human Revolution, you won’t miss much.

[b] [i] Positives [/i] [/b]

+ Voice acting can be decent at times

+ Some weapons feel better than in the original Deus Ex

+ OST

+ Level design, as bare-bones as it is, still retains some non-linear elements like access shafts and multiple routes to the destination, allowing for different way of approaching objectives

+ Interesting story premise connecting IW with the first game

[b] [i] Negatives [/i] [/b]

- Disappointing storyline

- Boring dialogues

- Stripped-down level desing exchanging large, open areas for claustrophobic corridors with only a fraction of the personality of those from Deus Ex

- Obnoxious UI design

- Streamlined to seventh hell as a result of being consolified

- Universal ammo system sucks b*lls

- Less options and variety

- Graphics have gone from "dated but serviceable" to downright ugly

121693752.review:
Because I have no wifi, I have .4 hours logged when in reality I've played this game quite a bit.  Perhaps 30ish hours is more accurate.  Just pointing that out.

Anyway, if we're talking numbers, this is a solid 4.5 out of 10.  It's mid.  Total mid.

Let's start with the good things:

If you think of this as a separate game from Deus Ex, it's actually quite enjoyable from a gameplay perspective.  You can get your biomods all set up before you even leave the first locality, Seattle, and from there you're set.  If you want to get to the nitty gritty of the gameplay, I'd like to say that stealth absolutely blows.  It's better to play this like you're spec ops, because nonlethal stealth is dogwater.  Once you stop caring and do a lethal stealth until you get caught approach, you're pretty much ballin.  I recommend the strength mod and throwing trash cans and crates at random people.  However, the UI is TERRIBLE, so keep that in mind.

The story is engaging enough to pay attention to, but the writing direction it took is dogwater.  Everyone feels stiff in the acting department and the character models have zero expression whatsoever - all they do is flap lips and wave hands.  At least the original Deus Ex had half decent voice acting despite having this same problem with the models.  Felt like the game had no real love it into it story wise and it shows.  No real emotional engagement, just pure "yeah, kill this and do that for this reason" type of stuff.

The .5 points I took off was simply because of technical issues that's more annoying than a turnoff.  This game will change your screen resolution on your computer proper, making you reset it back to your native res every.  Single.  Time.  On top of this, I can't change the hotkeys to activate my biomods, which even Human Revolution and the original allowed you to do.  Lastly, this game is a LOT of loading screens, though they don't take too long to load - the issue is that they're frequent.  The game rarely crashes, but when it does you're screwed out of an auto save, so save often just in case a crash DOES happen.

The jankiness of the game can be fun to play with, but overall it does limit your options.  You'll still have fun with it regardless, though it feels like an indie game more than a sequel to a critically acclaimed title.  Do I recommend the game?  I mean, sure, I had fun with it when I stopped caring about the nonlethal route and just went guns blazing.  I'm sure you will too.  Is it a good Deus Ex game?  Homie, if you're looking for that grit, just go back to the original or human revolution/mankind divided if the latter is good (haven't played MD).  This is a janky experience and it's mid.  Not everyone will like it, and if you don't like jank gameplay don't buy it.  Simple as.

Had to play it to complete the Deus Ex series which I discovered and fell in love with through Human Revolution and Mankind Divided. Invisible war felt like less complex than the first game in both gameplay and narrative, but not to the point of being outright dumbed down(except for the flimsily justified introduction of universal ammo which gave me Dead Space 3 PTSD flashbacks),but well...streamlined. The controls felt smoother than the first game and more importantly there are way less augmentations but I ended up using more of them than in the first game because unlike there here they are not only very effective but also easier to activate which makes them worth using more often.
Unfortunately this game's narrative dimension does not live up to the very high expectations that the first game will generate in you: there aren't as many charismatic characters, funny side plots and especially thought provoking, High IQ dialogues; and since the story and characters-not gameplay or graphics-were what made the first game a unique and excellent experience, you might experience disappointment.
However, the game overall is pleasant to play and I recommend it at least to people who like me had the compulsive need to complete the Deus Ex series. If you are not one one of us you should spend money and time on something else.

119966336.review:
Consistently mediocre and a downgrade from the original game in every way imaginable. It's not that the game is particularly awful in any of its aspects, but it never manages to do anything well and thus fails to compensate for its faults in any way that would make it worth your time to play.

The issues with gameplay are straightforward enough. The whole combat system is way oversimplified from the original. All skills were removed, all weapons use the exact same ammo, stealth has been nerfed to the point of being completely unviable (unless you use the invisibility skills available right from the start of the game, in which case stealth is ludicrously broken), and the level design was simplified to little more than confusing hallways that occasionally had vents connecting them. Honestly, this game doesn't even feel like an immersive sim anymore.

The story was similarly disappointing. None of the factions felt nearly as fleshed out as the original and relied much more on vague platitudes than any real nuance to their positions. I felt somewhat conflicted between the choices available in the first game, but in Invisible War I knew what my choice was going to be hours before I actually made it in-game because all of the alternatives were just blatantly awful. Looking back at it, the original's structure worked pretty well. [spoiler] You have one side that's more unambiguously bad (Bob Page) which you have no choice but to stop, but there are several different arguments for how to do so (Illuminati, Helios, and Tracer Tong). Any of these three have enough pros and cons that I could see why someone would consider them the best option.[/spoiler] For Invisible War, the choice is a lot clearer. [spoiler] Siding with JC is easily the best option here. The Templars are just luddite wackjobs with a penchant for cruelty, the Omar get practically no real development in their broader motivations, and the motives of the Illuminati aren't compelling when its JC they're up against rather than Bob Page. [/spoiler] 

Invisible War isn't egregiously bad in any of its aspects, but its never actually good either. Its just consistently mediocre and I genuinely feel like my time was wasted playing this.

119718785.review:
[h1] Deus Ex: Invisible War isnt a bad game, but it is heavily flawed [/h1]
Deus Ex Invisible war is a very... interesting game. its considered the worst game in the series, yet... i found myself playing it more than mankind divided, which should go against all the claims people make about the game.

[b] First, lets start with the gameplay.[/b]
its a mixed bag overall, especially coming off of Deus Ex 1. the Gunplay in general is solid, with each weapon filling in the typical role you expect. where this falls apart is everything else. the bio-mods system replaces both augmentations AND skills from the previous game. in some ways this is good, less to worry about. but it makes it feel like the character you build isn't as unique as other peoples build (something guaranteed in Deus Ex 1). that said, the overall balance of bio-mods is far better than the first. almost all slots have 2 amazing abilities, and a third more niche ability. this inherently means every slot is, to some extent useful. on top of that, some bio-mods are entirely passive, like Neural Uplink, Strength, and Bot Domination, meaning you don't need to sort through keybindings and menus to activate (However, unlike the first game, you cant rebind Function keys to anything else for some reason), and THEN use an ability. where this system fails, however, is the fact you can replace any bio-mod at any time, so long as you have the canisters for it. on top of that, every third option for bio-mods is tied to harder to get ones like the Black Market Canisters. even further than that, there are way too many canisters around. you get 3 canisters in the first 30 minutes of the game, and by the time your halfway through, you might've maxed out all your bio-mods.
TL;DR, the gameplay is 1 step forward, two steps back in every area. the Gun play is fun, but universal ammo complicates choices and situations in the worst way possible, the bio-mod system is a step up from augmentations, but between the removal of skills, to the overabundance of biomods, it makes the choice of how to build your character less fulfilling overall.

[b] Graphics: the Environments are still amazing looking, the character models are dog shit. [/b]
Something easily gleamed from videos/screenshots is the amazing art direction and lighting. Honestly i think the lighting in invisible war is more appealing to me than most modern games by a landslide. The art direction leans way more into Sci-Fi than the previous game, which is a double edged sword, it makes things look either way cooler, or way dumber, and it varies from person to person. the biggest offender to all of this is how characters look, between Alex Dentons hairline, eyes that look either glued on or on crack, or some characters not getting shades like they deserve, one of the best aspects of the older game, the characters, feel like a step down, which leeds into the next section

[b] The Story: oh dear god i have to talk about this help me [/b]
so... just gonna put this in the spoiler tags.
[spoiler] This is the big thing people criticize the game for, and for mostly good reason. there are plenty of videos that go into all its fault, so i may or may not repeat things others have said. the biggest problem with the story, beyond the pacing in that regard, is its lack of focus on characters and individual philosophies. what made deus ex 1 so good was that towards the end, instead of (like every game) giving you a good, bad or neutral option, it presents 3 different sides, all with unique and specific ideals. this made the choice for which ending to do first harder, because instead of relying on blank moral choices, you have to evaluate your own philosophy on the topic. different reviews of the game reflect this, some saying Morgan Everett's ending is better, others going Helios, and some out there people side with tracer tong. the main problem with invisible war, is the fact it doesn't flesh out any of them. siding with anyone wont give you any reason to go alongside them, not Apostlecorp, not Illuminati, and especially not the Templars. there is a fourth ending, which is kill everyone (the Omar Ending), which a lot of people ended up choosing, because everyone else basically talks down to you, instead of providing convincing arguments. its the same idea the first game had, but with way worse execution. and beyond continuity issues (like how the world recovered from the "Collapse", and why the Collapse happened), this could've been just as good, if not better than the first game. maybe lock some endings behind who you sided with, with both the WTO and Order (which the order shouldn't be a conglomerate of multiple religions, and instead should be baptist, since most religions originate from the bible, and work well the the Templars gimmick), and the illuminati/Templars/Apostlecorp.   [/spoiler]

i Think if i had to summarize Invisible war in two words it would be: Lost Potential. so many of the games faults either lie with misunderstanding what made the original good, and poor execution. many attribute the faults to Making the game for both pc and xbox (the only thing this changes is how big levels are, which are super small), but its more so the developers making mistakes. if you see this on sale, or have 10 dollars to burn, buy it (and install visible tweaker to make it function properly on modern hardware).

117875985.review: Deus Ex: Invisible War is the sequel to the first Deus Ex, an immersive sim set in a dark cyberpunk world. It had a lot riding on its shoulders and eventually crumbled under the pressure of having to follow it up. I initially had a very rough start with the game and disliked it. As I played through it for a few more hours I thought eh, it's ok and thought that I'd drop a positive review when I finished it, but as I pressed forward and finished the second half, the multitude of issues present in the game became too big and turned it into a dislikable experience that left a sour taste in my mouth. The second game in the Deus Ex series is a watered down, simplified game in comparison to the first. I'd even dare to say that it's hardly an immersive sim compared to the first. The first issue that popped up, very minor, was the fact that all spoken dialogue or dialogue said over "info-links" (the radio communication system) was completely muted when wearing headphones, so I had to play the game listening from speakers. Ok, fine, I'm willing to forgive that, I thought early on. The first section is also bugged so that you can't save until you get out of the lab and into upper Seattle, otherwise the game will hard crash. The more I played the more that I noticed that the voice acting was even worse than the first, the weapon selection is much more limited, boring, and uniform, and they even instituted a universal ammo for every weapon as well as decreased ammo capacity. I get that this game was simplified for easy use for consoles, but that means that a lot of great immersive sim elements from the first game had to be ditched. There is no more worrying about how to fit everything into your inventory box, instead you get a pop up HUD of 12 inventory slots each with far less medkit and energy cells capacity. Part of the simplification was making weapon mods only two to a weapon. They also cut down the number of augmentations you have to only six, further streamlining the game into a steaming pile of shit. Another thing they got rid of was the dynamic health system from the first game where each part of your body has a different amount of health and could have an aug assigned to each limb. They also removed the ability to see what had been said in previous conversations, removed notes, and made it so that you didn't have to enter passcodes anymore, the game did it for you. A couple of other complaints that I had were that the stealth was practically removed because enemies can spot you from far away very easily, giving you far less player agency in how you approach situations. The weapons also deal a lot less damage even when fully upgraded; and towards the endgame you end up fighting a ton of bullet sponge enemies that can kill you in two hits but take five to take down. The game is also floatier and feels a lot crappier. The physics are all screwed up, and many of the assets made to have the game look futuristic end up looking silly and out of place. Another victim of the streamlining was the removal of skills and abilities that could be upgraded and the simplification of hacking. Ok, that's all fine and dandy, I can look past that you might be saying, but wait there's more! I already mentioned how there are far fewer ways to approach situations, but there're also fewer situations to approach. The game length is about half as long as the first. There are three main hub cities to explore throughout the game, those being Cairo, Trier Germany, and Seattle with a small variety of things to do, this is where you can find some side quests and a couple of interesting story beats. The one positive thing that I'll give this game is that the three hub cities can be fun to explore and interact with at times. But once again compared to the first game these three hub cities are a lame offering versus New York, Hong Kong, and Paris from the first game, each with several mini story lines, multiple main story lines and areas to explore. There are also not that many other locations in the second game, only having Antarctica and a brief time spent in New York to add to that list whereas in the first game you were visiting large expansive levels such as area 51, an underwater lab, and tons of other missions within the hub cities. The story in this game is also atrocious. The factions are somewhat interesting towards the beginning being a church and a capitalistic bureaucracy, with another religious entity, the Templars coming in later. There's one twist involving the Illuminati, but the final factions that you end up deciding the world's fate with are a renegade, evil anti-tech cult, the Illuminati, and the Protagonist of the first game's global AI merger. None of the characters throughout the game are particularly likable and I was certainly dissapointed to see the way that the characters from the first game were portrayed. Also it really didn't make that much sense that factions throughout the entire game and endgame tried to kill you and then asked you to choose their side for the ending. The final piece that I have to say on this game is that the world building was very weak. The talk bullets viewed on little stations spread around the levels were interesting in keeping you up to date on news, but hacking into computers and reading the extra lore was non existent. The soundtrack was also far less cyberpunk and fitting for the game and was played far less. The only time you could listen to the music was in the bars, and they even removed the combat music. To wrap this review up, I was disappointed by the sequel of Deus Ex to say the least. It lost its charm and was bogged down by watered down game systems, a disappointing story, and a much shorter length due to fewer areas and smaller levels. I wouldn't really recommend this to anyone other than hardcore fans of the series who want to experience all of it.

115228303.review:
If you've played the original and was curious to see where the story would go from there, I still would not recommend this game.

The levels are claustrophobic and confusing. the lighting is practically nonexistent, even the first level is as dark as a moonless night. The interface is clunky and unintuitive (clicking on pistols won't get you ammo, you will have additional pistols in the inventory for no reason). The characters stand wide-eyed and A-posed. The factions are unclear with weak motivations. Your choices are meaningless until you get to the final area. The horrible level design means approaching a problem in different ways is restricted, better save up those multitools! Also the game crashes and your autosave might not help you.

If you've read all that and still insist on buying this inferior sequel, here's a tip. Go into this folder: Steam\steamapps\common\Deus Ex Invisible War\System and open the Default.ini file in Notepad. Search for [Difficulty] and replace the next four paragraphs with the following:

[Difficulty]
; AI Damage multiplier - damage AIs take from player
Difficulty_AI_Damage_Easy__d=6.0
Difficulty_AI_Damage_Normal__d=7.0
Difficulty_AI_Damage_Hard__d=8.0
Difficulty_AI_Damage_Real__d=9.0
;
; Player Damage multiplier - damage player takes from AIs
Difficulty_Player_Damage_Easy__d=0.0
Difficulty_Player_Damage_Normal__d=0.0
Difficulty_Player_Damage_Hard__d=0.0
Difficulty_Player_Damage_Real__d=0.0
;
; 1.0 = base accuracy, 0.0 = wild, 2.0 = as accurate as it gets (not 100% perfect)
Difficulty_Accuracy_Easy__d=2.0
Difficulty_Accuracy_Normal__d=2.0
Difficulty_Accuracy_Hard__d=2.0
Difficulty_Accuracy_Real__d=2.0
;
; Ammo multiplier for difficulty levels
Difficulty_Ammo_Mult_Easy__d=9.0
Difficulty_Ammo_Mult_Normal__d=8.0
Difficulty_Ammo_Mult_Hard__d=7.0
Difficulty_Ammo_Mult_Real__d=6.0

There, now you're an almost-invincible killing machine so you can breeze through this game in under 8 hours. Do you think this is cheating? Well good luck enjoying this game otherwise. No wonder the series got sold to Eidos.

115107125.review:
This review is too long for Steam Reviews, so I'll just quote some thoughts from that review.

My Full-blown Review is over here, in my Steam Group:
https://steamcommunity.com/groups/TGAEC/discussions/0/3266809271728582792/

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

NOTE: NEUTRAL REVIEW.

Since Steam's system only allows for a Thumb Up or a Thumb Down, I cannot give this game a Neutral Review, which could be interpretted as a "Shrug of the Shoulder" or say "One Thumbs Up and One Thumb Down". Basically, this review could go either way, depending on the subjective-ness of certain things.

[snip]

I DIDN'T ASK FOR...THESE PROBLEMS.
The biggest crime Deus Ex: Invisible War had back in its day, when it came out, was that it...ran poorly on most systems. Sure, the streamlining & console-lization (consolization) of the game did not help by any means in most ways, but now things might actually be even worse than back then. Running this on modern systems can be such a problem, it ain't even funny - and keeping it running can also be a major hurdle too.

To get the game running & to keep the game running on my gaming laptop - which is a i7 4720 HQ; 16 GB RAM; 2TB HDD; and 4gb GTX 960m - I had to do all kinds of stuff. I used the Visible Tweaker Mod to actually get this game booted on Windows 10; used Borderless Gaming & programmed it to handle Deus Ex: IW to keep the game from having issues w/ Fullscreen/Windowed modes; installed Process Lasso (Free version) to set up the Affinity Cores so it handled the game properly; used the DGVoodoo wrapper to actually get the game past the main menu, past any sort of loading screen issues & had to set that up properly; had to use Task Manager to stop other programs like NVContainer (NVidia program), Logitech App's, and anything else you can think of that this game might not get along with. 

Even though I normally save-scum in these type of "immersive sim" games a lot anyways, quick-saving & save-scumming a lot did help a lot namely in case the game would crash when loading, conflict with another app running that happened for whatever reason, and/or for whatever reason or for whenever the game would just straight-up crash while playing. Not sure if this was the poor implementation of engine itself & its lack of optimization and/or any DGVoodoo layers here needed just to keep this running could also cause a slow-down or whatever else - but sometimes, I would have stutters here & there while in important moment of combat, especially when special effects were happening on-screen and/or a lot of action happened on-screen (especially by the end of the game). It was easy enough to keep it stable & locked at 30fps or so, but when it took hits and/or stuttered, that did not help keep the combat fluid.

Even w/ this being an older game, this also isn't the most friendly game for multiple screens - as it would work fine on my 1st monitor which was the laptop built-in monitor, but on other 2nd monitors connected via HDMI would run it fine (no syncing on it), while another monitor (G-Sync monitor) would not.

A new patch, a properly done Remaster, moving this to another engine, and/or something could really be a good idea to fix a lot of these problems out-the-box; it would go a long way in fixing this game, if whoever holding the IP (that would now be Embracer, probably not Square-Enix anymore) would make this happen - especially in an age when Remasters and/or re-releasing an old game is all the rage these days.

[snip]

PLOT & STORY.
The story & plot is really good & really interesting; certainly one of the highlights of this game. Taking place after the first game, all of the endings from the original game actually happened; not just the one you earned in your 1st Playthrough. In IW, you play as Alex D. here, in which you can decide to make this Alex D. either male or female; up to you. You are at a Training Academy Facility to be an Agent, as your Academy gets attacked & the city gets bombed. Of course, you get out of there & you're to figure out why certain groups are after you and/or might be helping you ... and/or even trying to use you. Terrorism and factions at war are the main theme here, though this isn't the tip of the iceberg - as there are other factors, factions, groups & conspiracies at play. Since you're at the center of this, you're to figure out who's attacking cities & places; and what factions are playing what roles in these wars & matters.

I DID ASK FOR THIS...STUFF.
Though, despite tons of complaints & issues - well, everything else about this game though is really good. Despite some of the levels feeling small & load-times are everywhere (so they can try & have their cake and eat it too), the actual level design & their areas are excellent. The hubs of a futuristic & cyberpunk-y Seattle & Cairo, for starters (as there are more cool areas) are really good & cool. All levels are designed in interesting and really good ways, even despite their small size and/or it's broken-up in pieces & sections, when compared to Deus Ex 1: GOTY. 

A lot of the missions are really good & interesting, often having decisions and/or feel unique. If IW gets anything right here, despite being much shorter than Deus Ex 1: GOTY - it's that this game in its content & questing is mostly all killer & little-to-no filler here. This game took me around 19 1/2 hours or so to finish, though Steam won't recognize that b/c it was done mostly offline & with mods - though, it probably could be finished in much less than that if you just followed the main story and didn't tackle a lot of side quests. And to be honest, a lot of the side-quests are really good & often offer-up good rewards (more canisters, BioMods, clips, weapons, etc) - so it is worth taking these on, as this could help make the final few areas much easier to tackle. 

In typical Deus Ex faction, a lot of the missions can be finished in numerous ways - whether you're going all stealthy & silent; going run-and-gun & all loud; using tools to hack open items; using lethal weapons to kill enemies; using non-lethal weapons to knock enemies out; carrying, moving, and dropping bodies; entering or exiting areas via vents; entering through a front or back door; and/or whatever - there's often numerous ways to get the job done.

[snip]

OUTRO:
When it's all said & done, Deus Ex: IW just doesn't live up to the greatness of the original Deus Ex 1: GOTY, in terms of actually streamlining the game, baffling design decisions, and/or other things that make the game nowhere as great as the original.

While I could still recommend the game for numerous other reasons - namely regarding the cool characters, story, plot, choice, music, voice-acting, great quests that are mostly "all killer and no filler", and all of that stuff - it's still the tons of technical issues & modding to get the game running and/or even stable...and that stable-ness still might not always be the case either, which could make this game in many ways a gamble and/or crapshoot. You're likely going to need mod this a lot and try all kinds of stuff, to get it going & also keep it going. Save-scumming is going to necessary, just to make sure when it crashes that you can get right back to where you were.

If any modder could make an all-in-one solution here to fix this game all in one clip; a company fixed all of the technical issues; and/or a Remake/Remaster/Port over to a newer engine could be done here - any of those things happening could make this still an easy recommendation, even despite its other design & streamlining issues.

ON SALE NOTES:
When bought on sale, though - since this game often goes for 97 cents to $2 USD or so - it's certainly a worthwhile & cheap gamble, if you've ever wanted to see what happens after the legendary Deus Ex 1: GOTY Edition...provided you actually can get the game stable and/or running...

113430775.review:
This game still is Deus Ex, despite the "mixed" reviews.

How to tell if you're playing a Deus Ex game (in this case Invisible War).

-Crawling in vents.
-Crawling in vents.
-Crawling in vents.
-Choosing who you want to kill, or when.
-Decent variety of guns, mods for those guns also.
-Constant reloading after using multi-tools to see what's through the doors or in the container/safe.
-Constant reloading because the game is janky.
-Gripping story-line.

I played this game hot-off-the-heels of Deus Ex one. Now I could understand how cheesed off you would be three-four years later waiting for Invisible War, when Deus Ex one was an absolute masterpiece. However this game has its charms, it definitely is a sequel, unfortunately it places itself in a strange position. The game almost solely relies on the success and story of number one. This move possibly could contribute some strange reception met by fans.

So I ended up playing Deus Ex when I was a young human, unfortunately I could not possibly grasp what the game was, after completing Half-Life, I thought *Gasps*, man this game looks good!! However I would have no clue just how good it was. So returning to the original Deus Ex in 2022 was a strange reality.. and I have written a review of that, if you are interested. I completed Human Revolution first as I was interested in how the series rebooted itself into the mainstream gaming world. I really enjoyed it, and I thought I just had to come back and finish the whole series. I was not disappointed with Invisible War other than the aforementioned "piggy-backing story-line." The game had it's own merits and felt like it was worth the title "Deus Ex", the game was around about the length of How Long To Beat had posted, 13.8 hours.

The above 'time-played' is a very long time compared to how long you could actually complete this game, I believe a 8-9 hour play through with minimal path deviation (or possibly even shorter). Playing this game in 2022 and downloading DX2 Visual Upgrade was definitely worth playing at 4k, 144hz (or whatever you have available).

All-in-all, worth buying and worth playing. It was a complete score during the sales, I believe around $1.50-2.

113321309.review:
An average sequel to a masterpiece.
 
[h1]Pros[/h1] 
+ Story
+ Dialogs
+ Gameplay
+ Multiple endings
 
[h1]Cons[/h1] 
- Crashes
- Loading screens
- Sneaking
- Universal ammo
- Action consequences
- Exploding cameras
 
[h1]Summary[/h1]
Okay-ish story, with plot twists on every corner.
Some of the dialogues are still pretty funny.
The gameplay is very similar to the first Deus ex, most of the weapons did not change.
There isn't a “good” ending only bad and worse unless you count the bonus ending.
 
Most of the bad reviews seem to be from the game not launching or freezing, I did fix that by simply [b]turning off the Nvidia overlay[/b].
 
I did still experience a few crashes (5-10) but it was playable.
Every time I launched the game it would change my monitor resolution to 720p and 60Hz so I had to make sure I change it back each time…
For whatever reason, every loading screen relaunched the game, so I had to play in invisible/offline mode.
 
Sneaking is impossible without biomods and way too easy with them.
Only one universal ammo type for all weapons is such a bad and lazy idea.
 
There are almost no consequences to any of your “smaller” actions, genuinely no one cares if you go around and kill everyone as long as you progress to the main objective.
Also, no one seems to notice the difference between you killing someone or just doing a non-lethal takedown.
 
One playthrough is more than enough IMO.
Not great, not terrible.
 
[b]Playtime:[/b] 10-15 hours
 
[b]Overall:[/b] 6.5/10

113028225.review:
I remember playing this on XBOX way back in the day and having a lot of fun with it. It was just as fun this time. It's a Deus Ex light. Do whatever you want in this sandbox. Kill, steal from, betray, or double-play any person or group and watch the outcome. Experimentation is rewarded and you'll never be short on supplies if you know well enough to look through every nook and cranny. Don't fret about getting enough Augmentation canisters to invest and reinvest in case you change your mind, they're fairly common so much so that you'll at least have enough to reinvest several skills to level 3. Most doors, locks and computers can be opened in a number of ways, be it with multitools or your grenades. As long as people have their back turned against yours, you can also do some hacking and dismantling of bots in crowded spaces too.

The port is pretty much identical to my XBOX experience, down to the crashes at Blackgate and Liberty Island, so anyone new to the game would do well to remember to save often. Don't forget that autosaves you get from entering an area does not stick around upon rebooting the game.

While I completely understand the criticism of the universal ammunition, small areas, frequent loading screens, simplified augmentations etc, it still holds up as an enjoyable game for me and the graphics haven't aged thaaaat poorly compared to some titles from the early 2000s. Good nostalgia fun.

111638001.review:
5/10

Deus Ex: Invisible War has always been disparaged because it wasn't a great followup to the original Deus Ex, and that's fair. - IW was not a good sequel to one of the best computer games ever.  That doesn't mean that IW isn't worthwhile though.  I/W is a perfectly fine and adequate FPS-RPG, which isn't meeting the standard established by the franchise (both before and after), but it's not a bad game in and of itself.  If you have no connection to the Deus Ex franchise as a whole, there are plenty of better games out there that you could play in the same genre.  However, if you do have a love for the Deus Ex franchise and have enjoyed the story and the game world presented within, Invisible War isn't a bad game to check out.  It's not nearly as long or involved as the other games in the series, but you could certainly plow through it in a solid 10-15 hours, and have some fun exploring and learning a bit more about the Deus Ex universe while you're there.  If you enjoy the DX universe, its worth spending a couple bucks and knocking this out because there is some value here, especially being a relatively short game. If you're not a fan of the DX universe, then I'm really not sure why you're even looking at this game when there's better stuff out there.

109752783.review:
In general, it is one of those games that leaves you in between. This was the last in the Deus Ex series I had an opportunity to play, and I must say I could not get particularly engaged to the story, as the writing does nothing to make me attached to the characters, the protagonist included. The game is also quite short and small in scope, and simplified in many aspects, while the futuristic setting makes it less relatable than the original and the remainder of the series.

Still, it has some redeeming qualities. The soundtrack by Alexander Brandon departs from the not-to-well-aging direction of the original and sets the foundation for the DX:HR and DX:MD soundtracks. The graphics is easily overhauled with an excellent mod Visible Upgrade (it has a separate launcher, hence only 0.2 hours on Steam against 11.5 actually played). Level design is compact, but quite clever.

109677943.review: I found it to be one of the best story-based FPS/Rpg games ever, particularly because the game had the possibility of three different outcomes. And you could play your way to those three outcomes in numerous ways. If you took one path for example instead of how you played it the last time, those play options disappeared, reported to use as actual newscasts, as in, yes you could have saved those poor kids like you did last time, but NEWSFLASH, you didn't and they're all dead. Fascinating and highly underrated game.

108996030.review:
As much as I think this game isn't irredeemable, it isn't good.  It suffers massively from being made for the Xbox first, and PC second.  Miniscule map sizes to the point where you can have 30 seconds between map transitions, a massively simplified inventory system to the point where it makes no sense, a very crap UI, universal ammo so once you run out of rocket launcher rockets you're also out of bullets, etc.

Its story is also just nowhere near as engaging as other Deus Ex games, lacking a lot of the drive.  Sure, it checks the boxes of some big conspiracy stuff, but it's so shallow that it feels almost tacked on.

The graphics are significantly less immersive than the original game.  They may be technically superior, but the style falls very flat.  The original game straddled the line between sci-fi and realism just well enough to use the realism to immerse you into the sci-fi.  Invisible War goes all-in on the sci-fi to the point where I struggle to get immersed with all the holographic store signs of struggling businesses between the frequent loading screens.

It does have some good/unique (for the time) features, though, like some weapon mods, the main one coming to mind being the one that makes any glass hit break silently.  Mixed with the suppressor, it has the ability to turn a fair few weapons into perfectly silent infiltration devices.  Sadly, what the game does right just doesn't overcome all it does wrong.

108598955.review:
Definitely not as good as the first game but still a great time overall. 

Pros:
- Biomods are very balanced and fun to use. I made an absurdly strong melee build with my only options for 
ranged combat being objects I found around the map to throw at people. Most fun I've had in a video game 
in a long time.
- Literally nobody has plot armor. I've tested it out and you can literally kill every single NPC you meet in 
person and it never breaks the continuity of the game which is a pretty amazing feat.
- Lockpicks and Multitools are combined together into a singular item which is convenient I guess.
- The game gives some pretty difficult decisions towards the end of the game and all of the endings are 
pretty debatable on which is the best.

Cons:
- Removes a lot of the RPG elements from the first game which takes away a lot of the replay value.
- Every gun runs off of the same ammunition for some reason. 
- It was also really hard to find a widescreen fix for this game but it does exist so playing it nowadays isn't too bad.
- The inventory system absolutely sucks in comparison to the first game.
- The main characters personality is as dry as a plank of wood. Absolutely no memorable lines. The supporting characters aren't much better either.
- Guns are pretty terrible. Deus Ex was never really known for its ranged combat but the gunplay is just really bad in this game. 
- The environments aren't very unique and all look very similar. Definitely not as diverse as the first game. Sometimes I just had no clue where I was because everything just looks the same. The only real memorable areas were the base in Antarctica and the Liberty Island towards the end of the game.
- The soundtrack was really lame compared to the first game.
- The game crashed a couple times but it was nothing too bad.

Regardless of these issues the game was still very fun to play and it was nice to see some familiar characters from the first game. It was also cool as they somehow made it as if every ending from the first game could have been possible.

106853369.review:
Before you buy: This game is super old and needs a little work to get running, including downloading a fan mod and turning off overlays for that game from Steam and Nvidia. If you're aware of and okay with this, this game is worth checking out. Back in the day I played this on console and loved it. 

DE2 is basically where the series starts to fall apart,and it devolves into a generic sci fi adventure-shooter with very little actual character building. You're Alex D, a trainee of the Tarsus program recently moved to Seattle after a terrorist plot destroys all of Chicago. During a second attack, you are free to learn the answers of the new world and determine who you can really trust. This mostly involves exploring extremely small maps completing objectives in your own style. There is a gun that does Non-lethal poison damage but it's not really tracked or important. 

Story-wise it's textbook cyberpunk social commentary about how corporations create multiple faces in order to fool consumers/voters into sheepish compliance.  Literally every organization in this game is some kind of front for another one; to the point where it's a little too real. Much like in real life, the factions are built up for one purpose: Consolidation of power/control. The cyborg future is also super progressive, even in the American zones there's a pretty satisfying mixture of races/creeds portrayed in the game. 

Now let's talk about why the series objectively gets worse after the first DE. There is no individual weapon ammo, everything's fired with the same little energy clipazine. What this ends up meaning is that you will go through large sections of the game using little to no ammunition and then at the very end of the game you are BLEEDING for ammo because you have to kill about 20 dudes in heavy power armor. Money is also completely without purpose because there isin't really an economy! There are black market guys you can throw money at and what they have is not worth grabbing in most cases.

The second reason is the lack of hybrid FPS RPG mechanics that the first game had. DE 1 had XP you bought skill ranks in but that's all gone, the inventory is just a flat 20 slots now, and compared to 1 the maps are TINY due to it being a 2003 console game. Once you get your hands on a silenced/glassbreaking handgun you can basically ride with it until the game ends. 

This is a game I played through 3-4 times to get all the endings when I was younger and it's about 8-10 hours long. It's a nice political adventure shooter with plenty of action and choice. It's worth checking out for sci fi shooter fans

105784815.review:
I have played very few games that give me such a negative first impression I instantly know I should stop playing, uninstall, and wash my hands. The too long didn't read, it's not only a lesser game, but it's not even decent enough on it's own to play in my opinion. 
Honestly, I cannot recommend this game at all. Maybe you can try it if you're morbidly curious, but a combination of horribly simplified and dumbed down gameplay and a lack of story hooks make this such a difficult game to justify playing it for your actual enjoyment, even considering how weak it is compared to the rest of the series.
As years go by, I have heard two descriptions to this game, “It’s a game where stuff supposedly happens” and “If you wanna know why consoles were a mistake look no further”, and that’s not far off the mark.

Anyway here's a disjointed rant with no effort, much like this title's game design.

So after the first cut scene that reeks more of Final Fantasy, you get a character avatar with pick of male or female, skin color and hud alpha. I instantly notice there’s no skills to choose (lock-picking, medicine, specialization for guns, demolitions, nothing). You start, get tons of tutorials shoved in your face to do ANYTHING, and are let in the first real gameplay proper, escaping a small building facility.
The inventory as a whole is horrible. Can stack food regardless of size, can only drop with a button on the corner, reorganizing for mousescroll is cumbersome, also I really hope you dont find it’s placement as a circle bad because in widescreen it’s horrible. If you play this game, play it at 4:3 or it will get in the way.
Weapons have no reloading. There is also universal ammo which is so stupid I don’t know where to start. Universal Ammo has two working uses- Coop/multiplayer games where players have different weapons and has to account for it (see Left 4 Dead) or different weapons who’s ammo use is different with benefits and negative drawbacks (classic example, a shotgun vs a double barrel). This removed so many layers of planning, management, overall engagement, I dislike it so much.
It’s also impressive how lacking the story is. Fair, I played like four hours only but I have no idea what to make of it. Why is every faction a “grey area”? 
Speaking off, I cant be sure but they seem to pull a “ALL ENDINGS CANON” which is lame in my opinion. It would be much more interesting to see the consequences of one if the most “rational” endings, like say  JC just blows internet the fuck out and embraces this Dark Age Tong wants. Humanity inevitably builds back. What happens? How would people think of it? What consequences occur? It could atleast be INTERESTING. Every document , news article, conversation, all fail to intrigue me. The writing is noticeably more shallow and barren. Alex’s voice also doesn’t help, JC and Adam were both very “unemotional” but they still display personality and character, the voice makes it so any interpretation of their characters fit. Alex speaks and comes across like a plank of wood figured out how to communicate.
And levels. Small to the point Joe Pesci likes his new Barbie mansion, filled with loading screens (which somehow close and reopen the game between stages every time , never seen anything like it) and with almost nothing to do or see in them.

tldr just play the original again or the two prequels, they are way better. Only a contrarian or someone who can really put up with a lot of concessions will find anything worth playing here. Or maybe do play it and you'll feel a bit warmer towards Adam's games.
