Quite possibly the worst sequel ever made.
1st of all, how tf does this game even relate to the events of the OG DX? Apparently every single ending from the first game is canon, and society collapsed, and society somehow became a super advanced Star Trek-like utopia? None of the grittiness and realism from the original game are present, people behave more like androids than they do people, there's nothing human about them, contrast this with the OG Deus Ex, where every NPC has distinct dialogue, accents and moods that made them feel more human, meanwhile this game has a psychopath coffee shop owner who asks you to burn down a coffee shop because "lol why not", a bunch of secular religious nuts who hate augmentations just cuz, JC Denton from the original game, who is terribly out of place in this game, being that he's the only character who resembles a human in his behavior, in contrast to everyone else.
But even if  we ignored the hilariously bad story, the gameplay isn't much to write home about, like everything else, it's a major downgrade from its predecessor, for some reason the geniuses at Ion Storm thought that their sequel, to one of the most popular PC games; often considered the best, of all time, had to be Xbox exclusive, thanks Microsoft! In consequence the gameplay is dull, unengaging, tedious and unfun.
You'd think the graphics would be the one good thing about this game, but they ain't, every character model looks stiff and lifeless, they have weird bug eyes that make them look like psychopaths, add to this the eye-hurting teal color filter and it's the perfect mix for disaster.
I could say a million more bad things about this game, like how it fucks with the lore, ruins certain characters, has a story that makes no sense, is a complete downgrade in every single sense of the word, etc. But this review is long enough as it is, so to TL;DR: Don't buy this game, specially not if you liked the first game, play GMDX instead, it's free and it's not an utter embarassment.
1/10.

103011277.review:
Its not a great game (especially for a Deus Ex title) but I still find it quite enjoyable. The game got a lot of flack because it has some meh features like universal ammo and lots of loading screens, but it also has some strong points like wide array of gadgets / grenades, decent weapon upgrade system and some cool augmentations to control robots and hurl stuff at enemies. Dialogue, quest- and map design (apart from loading screens) is also decent but nothing mind blowing. Graphics are not too bad except for some over-lightning and weird npc eyes (some of those are actually worse than Deus Ex 1 npc models). Sometimes there is a physics bug (once I fell through the floor) and several times my character kangaroo jumped which hurts. Its also quite funny how far you can throw bodies (I think its related to the muscle augmentation).

Other info: I could not move the ingame mouse pointer till I set Windows 10 scaling to 100%. Tablet mode also needs to be turned off. After that it ran good on my surface go.

101185005.review:
[h1] Deus Boring: Boring War. Or a story about Technical Problems[/h1]

  Right....so the main reason why I personally dislike this game - is because running this game smoothly on modern system is....practically impossible.
  Check this out - if you have Win10 - prepare for unforseen consequences. If you patch the game with Upgrade from ModDB - it will do nothing. Literally. Loading screens are simply dont work - you need to bring up TASK MANAGER to SHUT DOWN some programms that for whatever reasons CONFLICT with the 2004 YEAR GAME, LIKE WHAT THE FECC.
  If you somehow manage to run this game and fix all the problems, withstand constant crashes, freezes, laugh out all of the goofy bugs like not working scripts, broken physics, dumb AI - get ready to be SEVERELY DISSAPOINTED STILL.

[h1]DA "Gameplay"[/h1]
  If you started this game right after Deus Ex 1 - you've made a BIG mistake, friend. All of the gameplay in this game - is a complete ultimate DOWNGRADE from previous installment.
  Narrow corridors, small locations, loadings everywhere (that barely works, mind you), Experience points are no more, augmentations are limited, ammo is now only one type and works for every gun - which is REALLY weird. Stealth approach is not rewardable at all and the quests...lets say they are weird too. The game is not that hard, no. Its easy to learn but sometimes the game will punish you for not caring at all - so...just be careful at what you do.

[h1]Ugly looks[/h1]
  Its hard to believe...but Deus Ex 1 looks better
While some textures looks okay, shadows and lights are kinda cool - they are completely lost it at the models department. Faces are awful, creatures and animals are hideous, and weapons/tools are...well, they are exist. 

[h1]Plot?...what plot?...[/h1]
  The story in this game "Can be" divided in several parts
1)RUSHED BEGINNING - so ye, you're a survivor from burned down Chicago, you're a student AND THERE ARE TERRORISTS WHO KILL EVERYONE
2)Some liberty - tons of various factions storm you, nameless random, to do stuff for them for no reason at all - you dont like anyone of them but...nobody gives a shi~~ and get ready to stumble in small rooms and corridors
3)THE ILLUMINATI - SPOILER WARNING
4)HE'S back - that certain part when you start caring because its Antarctica
5)Grand Finale - shoot everything that moves and decide which bad ending you dislike the least.

[H1] Characters and personality [/h1]
The MC is ... he/she dont give a single shi~ about whats happening around him/her
The NPCs are either stupid/dont care about anything/EXTREMELY AGGRESSIVE/wants you do something for them because YOU WILL
Finally - the voice acting...they managed to fecc up even the nostalgia actors...

[h1]Music and sound[/h1]
The beatiful music of Unreal Engine 1...is not here
The only good song you'll ever hear - is in the main menu. Other than that - maybe in Church..but the rest of it - is meh
As for the sound...well, its there at least.

And finally, because the locations are so small - it made the most of the game really boring and you simply cannot put yourself in such conditions. All you can do - is facepalm.

[H1]TL;DR:[/h1]
  1)HUGE Dissapointment 
  2)Barely functional
  3)Boring as hell
  4)Silly plot
  5)Utter Depression at the end
  
J.C. - we need another Collapse.
Helios has spoken.

It's true that DX:IW—with its different protagonist, cast of characters, engine, mechanics, departure from the '90s-era video game look, exciting but unchallenging combat and Brandon's BGM sounding unenthusiastic—feels like a fan fiction compared to its predecessor. 

[url=https://knowyourmeme.com/memes/to-be-fair-you-have-to-have-a-very-high-iq-to-understand-rick-and-morty]Nevertheless, continuity and consistency are ever present; from the overarching socio-political themes interwoven into the metatextual narrative to the carefully crafted dialogue that reflects a postsecularist age in which contrasting yet homogeneous factions led by Machiavellian demagogues, with growing influence on the global stage, are locked in an eschatological conflict; their respective [i]efforts[/i] (i.e., philosophical proselytism) embodied in the propagandistic dissemination—by speech and by deed—of neo-Hegelian universalism on a far-reaching scale, which is explicitly expressed via populist rhetoric, not to mention the constant evocation of [i]anticipatory democracy[/i] as a model of good government ("pre-Collapse" zeitgeist).[/url]  

Putting aside the prequel–sequel differences, most of the criticisms stem from Invisible War's incompatibility with modern PCs, effectively making it a crash simulator in and of itself. [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=625479384]It's fixable[/url]. The are alternative solution(s), but they involve downloading and/or installing third-party tools.

Imagine ordering an orange soda from a vending machine only to end up getting lemon-lime. That's how Invisible War feels. The game is not bad, it just doesn't live up to the Deus Ex name.

Pros:
[list]
    [*]The story is actually well-thought and interesting with plenty of plot twists and unexpected turns
    [*]Newcomer NPC "NG Resonance" is one of the best characters in the series
    [*]Children can still be harmed
    [*]The multiple endings are actually quite fulfilling and they bring closure to the series
[/list]

Cons:
[list]
    [*]No boss fights
    [*]Loading screen simulator
    [*]Lack of an XP system -- Completing side missions is worthless and a total waste of time
    [*]"Streamlined" interface, augs, combat, stealth and hacking that feel dumbed down
    [*]Maps are way too small and cramped favoring combat rather than stealth
[/list]

Other notes worth mentioning:
[list]
    [*]The game has a nasty game-breaking bug in the very first level where if you save/quicksave before taking the elevator down and out of Tarsus Academy, it crashes the game and causes all other save attempts to cause a CTD. Do NOT save your game until after you are out of the Academy (you can speedrun it in 5-10 minutes). Once out of the Academy you can continue save-scumming to your heart's content.
    [*]Fem Alex has better voice acting than the male counterpart
[/list]

98934857.review:
I don't know what this is, but it certainly isn't [i]Deus Ex[/i].

The best way I can describe [i]Invisible War[/i] is "the [i]Baldur's Gate: Dark Alliance[/i] of immersive sims". It's a title that stripped away everything that made the original so compelling, crippled the experience to fit on the XBox's RAM infrastructure, took out most of the interesting character motivations and murky morality that defined the previous game, and wrapped it up in a package that comes across as some sort of simplistic epilogue DLC.

Every time I see someone say this is "a terrible [i]Deus Ex[/i] game, but not a bad RPG" (console players?), I burst out laughing. This is a title that took every interesting game mechanic from the original (risk vs. reward systems, tough moral choices, skill trees and character customization) and boiled it down to its barest elements, then tried to awkwardly shoehorn a bunch of major developments into the last fourth of the plot to cover how narratively void the rest of the game is.

At the time of this writing, I'm halfway through the game (in Cairo). The game throws out bizarrely-inconsistent character motivations, caused by a "join any faction" system that allows you to work against other groups with no penalty. The Order, a faction who's been courting you through the game, complains about you working against their interest, sends out a hit squad to kill you, then your handler calls you back to say, "Let this be a lesson to you... by the way, we're going to give you more missions." [i]What?[/i]

Most side missions boil down to "destroy x object" or "kill x npc", characters act like you're their best friend when you've barely had more than one conversation with them, the plot expects you to side with a faction that destroyed your hometown (killing your parents -- an act lead character Alex Denton isn't even all that surprised by) and attacked the academy safehouse you're in, and the extent of the exploration boils down to taking a left instead of a right in a tunnel or hopping over a few beams to get a [i]slightly[/i] hidden unique weapon, which are among the top of their class and makes it pointless holding on to the normal versions.

It's a game that "wants to have its cake and eat it too." All of the endings from the original game occurred at once... which is something that only gets revealed two-thirds of the way through the game by former lead character JC Denton, who now has some bizarre Cthulhu-like alternate form living in Antarctica (uh?). Voice actors from the original game come back, some reprising their roles (Nicolette Duclare) and others voicing different characters, which adds to the confusion (Tom Hall, the voice of Walton Simons, as a random scientist in a weapon facility?). Combat boils down to "aim, point and go boom-boom," lacking all of the tactical action from the original (to say nothing of the broken Biomods that trivialize combat). You can hire one of two different pilots, one of whom is completely superfluous and makes you pay for transit so that you can skip more of the level(?). There's plenty of outright confusing moments that take the player out of the experience.

Nothing in this game is a challenge -- you can max out most of your biomods before the midgame if you bother to explore at all, there are no cleverly-hidden conversations or choices (in fact, you can kill one of the endgame bosses in the very first level, and the game kind-of acknowledges this, but still has her appear on communications several times, not to mention bugging out missions to get both rewards from mutually-exclusive questgivers), the combat feels simplistic and floaty, and major moral dilemmas (like interlinking all of society in the final mission) are covered with all the gravitas of a wet fart.

If you're a completionist and just need to see everything this franchise has to offer, you might as well try this to see where it all went wrong (and where [i]Human Revolution[/i] and [i]Mankind Divided[/i] worked the formula much better). Everyone else should avoid this like the plague.

97506224.review:
[b]Deus Ex: Invisible War[/b] is a mix between RPG, FPS and stealth. The story takes places 20 years after the events of original game. However it builds upon the themes presented in the first game, so knowing it's story is required. The game starts with a cool cutscene in which the whole city of Chicago gets destroyed in an explosion, but some of the people escape and one of them is you, Alex D, a special agent in the making. After a series of unfortunate events you find yourself on the streets of Seattle with a lot of voice messages from two warring factions asking you to do stuff. Just like in the previous game there're a lot of twists and turns on the way to the ending. You can influence the story by helping one faction or the other. There are also a couple of side-stories mostly unrelated to the main plot, which you can complete to earn money or other useful supplies. 

Just like in the previous game, your character has access to different augmentations. You can pick one three for each of the body slots you have and upgrade them using the canisters found on levels. Unlike the first game, you get a lot of those canisters right from the beginning, while it does make the game more fun, it takes away that gratifying feeling when you finally get the upgrade you want. As to the weaponry, once again there's a choice between lethal and not-so-lethal, which is represented by stun baton and crossbow. However, the game doesn't comment on your choice in anyway, so there's no reason to use non-lethal weapons other than as challenge for yourself. The gunplay feels a bit better due to the ragdoll physics, but the AI is still very bad. So both silent and loud approaches aren't working as well as they should. Due to some technical limitations locations got smaller than in the original. They are now divided by loading screens. It would have been ok, if the locations were at least a little bit bigger, but seeing 3 loading screens in the span of 5 minutes is enough to throw immersion out of the window. The level design tries to stay true to the original. There are still multiple paths to take, but due to the small environments, they usually look like a choice between a door and the ventilator shaft next to it. 

The sequel does improve on the original in some ways. First of all the graphics, that still hold up to modern standards. The interface looks modern and more intuitive. You don't have to input keycodes manually anymore, yet the characters sometimes say them out loud for some reason. The number of augmentations is lower, so you don't have to move your hand all the way to F12 to turn on the flashlight, which also got a great improvement, it doesn't drain your energy anymore. Moreover the ammo is universal now, hence you can stick with your weapon of choice not being scared that you'll run out of bullets. The story doesn't repeat itself instead it tries to tackle new issues and expand on some of the themes set up in the first game. Coupled with a new visual design that makes Deus Ex's world look more like the distant future it is supposed to be. It turns out to be not a bad game after all. 

[b]Pros:[/b]
+ Interesting story with a lot of twists
+ Good graphics that still look ok
+ Multiple paths to take and choices to make
+ Attention to detail in environments

[b]Cons:[/b]
- Levels feel cramped and there are a lot of loading screens
- Technical issues, getting the game to run correctly is a pain
- Lack of secret paths and locations
- Bad AI

Even though I had some issues with it, I've enjoyed the game. It's not a masterpiece like the original Deus Ex, but it's still a good game. It's worth picking it up, if you're a fan of the series, but you probably know that already. Be prepared though that it takes sometime to get it running on a modern system.

96522582.review:
Definitely better than the first series.

Why? At least the light augmentation does not consume energy, which means I can use it as long as I like! Not to mention, this game does not have a horribly dark surroundings for most areas compared to Deus EX GOTY.

I did not have the recurring crash issues on certain stages encountered on Deus EX which forced me to activate cheats to forcibly remove the NPC causing the crash issues. 

Pros of this game is that you actually can afford to carry any type of your favourite weapons without worrying about how much inventory space they take since ALL weapon types will only take 1 slot each of your inventory slot.(which means you can use as many heavy weapons as you like) Same goes to non-alcoholic foods as they are now grouped to only 1 type of consumables. While the ammo consumption varies for different weapons, it still gives the player much more flexibility on what type of weapons they want to use throughout the game.
Downside is that I wished I could have more than 1 biomods installed on each part. Towards the end I actually have un-used biomods and black market ones as I didn't really change my biomods out much. Controls are kinda clunky at times, but it's still an improvement from Deus EX GOTY. 

I definitely LOVE using the dead/unconscious bodies of those templar knights to heal my hp. Those Templar Knights can SMD for giving me so much trouble at the beginning part of the game when I only have the bare minimum to defend myself.

Overall, a decent immersive sim classic. Worth trying out. Might/might not appeal to different people as the downsides can be a turnoff for some people.

I still don't feel completely comfortable with the choice I made and that's good! Choices should be hard and complicated, especially when it comes to choices that result in how the world will be governed. It does have some continuity errors and the first game is still superior in pretty much all ways, but that's ok, this is something very different from the first game and it's great in its own ways

94928574.review:
WARNING: Invisible War does not run properly on modern systems, leading to countless crashes and bugs for most players. If you're planning on buying IW I would recommend turning off all overlays and downloading the visible upgrade patch off of MODDB to resolve or reduce the amount of crashes you'll experience.

Summary: Invisible War fails to live up to its predecessor in nearly every capacity: from a gameplay, level design, story and even a performance perspective it utterly falls flat in comparison to its masterful older brother, yet I find myself enjoying it anyhow. Maybe it's the calming soundtrack, diverse NPC interactions and missions, the interesting worldbuilding, or maybe it's just fueled by my love and nostalgia for the first game, Whatever it is I find this game to be a enjoyable failure, a guilty pleasure of sorts, so for any fans of DX1 I would recommend picking up IW on sale to catch up on the post-collapse cyberpunk world of Deus Ex. Make sure to heed my warning above if you're going to make a purchase.

ABOUT THE PERFORMANCE:

I highly recommend you look up and install these fixes in the following order:

- Deus Ex 2 High Res Fonts by djdarko
- Large Address Aware (lets the game use more than 2GB of RAM)

Overall there are some improvements but it feels like the devs cut corners and didn't give the game the time and attention to improve.

93016581.review:
[h1]Summary[/h1]
Invisible War was an OK game…for 2003. As the sequel to a true masterpiece, OK is pretty disappointing. In an effort to make it more “accessible,” they stripped out the soul of the original game. Invisible War just doesn’t hold up the same way Deus Ex holds up. Give this one a pass, unless you are a series fan and really need to see the whole plot/story. In that case, set your sights on disappointment and Godspeed.
[hr][/hr]
I really do not think Invisible War was a terrible game. It’s unfair to ask any game to play sequel to a classic that a whole lot of people, myself included, think is one of the best ever made. But nearly every fault I had with Invisible War can be summed up with one quote, “The aim was to [i]create a more [b]accessible[/b] version[/i] of the original game's systems while preserving its essentials.”

Translation: Let’s dumb [b]everything[/b] down to reach a bigger audience.

Translation of the Translation: Let’s sell out…just a little bit.

Now, Deus Ex was such a great game that even after the simplifications, what we are left with isn’t bad. Especially considering the quality of games in 2003…I played MUCH worse games in 2003. But this stripped something essential out of the soul of Deus Ex: the idea that [i]every[/i] choice you make has an impact. How do you spend your limited skill points? Which biomods do you want? Do you spend your last 2 sniper bullets on those goons?

It felt like they wanted to make sure you could do anything you wanted in the game regardless of your choices. Like making sure there is a ladder on the building for a rooftop entry…well, now you don’t really need the jumping biomod, do you. They also wanted to make sure you never feel like you missed out…so computers are easy to hack, you’ll max your biomods about a third of the way into the game, the tasty looking lockboxes can be opened (assuming you don’t try to open every one), and maps are easier to navigate with fewer secret tunnels/entrances.

Here are some highlights of the “simplifications.” Ammo is universal, but different guns use ammo at different rates…and running out of ammo really isn’t a thing. Your tool box is reduced down to a single “multitool” for all purposes. Biomods still do cool things, but the game and maps were simplified enough that they no longer really feel useful (except hacking). Gear/stuff is much more plentiful, so by mid game you never have to make a hard choice about using/saving anything…plus most of the stuff in those locked boxes is useless since you already have full stacks of gear. Oh, and skills…they’re just gone.

Let’s not kid ourselves either, accessible is a code word for easier. I played on Realistic difficulty, and Invisible War is much easier in nearly every way. Yea you can still get one-shot on Realistic, but you never really have to worry about how many snipers are hiding out there in a gigantic ef-ing map with tons of clear sight lines. Turrets and robots are much easier to disable…there are fewer of them, it’s easier to get to them, and you have more tools to disable them.  I could go on….

I liked the direction the plot was trying to take, but unfortunately this also suffers from being over-streamlined. Rather than tell a complex, evolving story with multiple plot elements and good hooks, the story feels shallow and rushed. Story elements are just thrown at you so that you “get it” more easily. Your character’s involvement feels very superficial at times. Tropes stand out and feel cliché. Overall, a shame really.

So, the developers succeeded. They created a more accessible Deus Ex, which received some deserved acclaim upon its release. Unfortunately, to do that they had to strip out the parts that made the original Deus Ex an enduring classic. So, unless you’re stretching all the way back to 2003 to look for mid-tier games to play, you can probably find something better in your backlog.

92596938.review:
Pros
- Solid story. While characters have a lot less in terms of raw speeches in IW compared to the first game, seeing the story and its world along with the impact of JC Denton's actions from the first game, which [spoiler]caused a major apocalypse that made life worse than things were under Majestic 12's conspiracy for many[/spoiler], is still interesting and the game has some unique twists along the way, such as [spoiler]Chad Dumier, the idealistic French revolutionary you met in the first game becoming a cynic and actually joining the Illuminati elite after realising the damage his efforts to bring down the world order resulted in[/spoiler]. While I preferred the realism of DX1, especially the sophisticated political and societal perspectives that this game lacks, IW's far future continuation of the world 2 decades on is still fun to learn about and explore. The competing movements and their ideologies offer some decent food for thought as you watch them jockey for influence, drag you into their battles and almost tear the world to shreds in the process.
- Lots of choices. Wouldn't be a Deus Ex game without them, there's several wildly different endings you can end up with based on your relations with the story's main factions, each with really different outcomes for the world. Throughout the game these rival factions will offer you different objectives to carry out in your missions to help you define your alignments, unlike the first game where you were more or less just working with everyone [spoiler](the Anti-Establishment Primitivist Tracer Tong, the all knowing benevolent Helios AI, the Capitalist establishment of the Illuminati, etc etc)[/spoiler] against the common enemy of [spoiler]Majestic 12 and Bob Page[/spoiler] until the finale offered up the ending choices. The factions in Invisible War have a lot more competition between each other this time around. so you've got more of an incentive to weigh up their pros and cons and question their methods and ambitions, the OG Deus Ex gave you a set list of objectives but great variety on how to accomplish them, Invisible War gives you variety on the objectives you take on as well.

Cons
- Reduced scale. This game was designed for consoles first and PCs second and unfortunately that caused a lot of shortcomings in the end product. Ion Storm didn't do a good job adjusting the Deus Ex formula for the shift in platform priority to the Xbox, that means that it lost out on a lot of content in comparison to the first game. There's a lot less dialogue, the maps are way smaller (shattering immersion as the game tries to pass off single streets and tiny alleys separated by long loading screens as entire megacities) and the gameplay is much more simplified, the game's attempt to pass itself off as a globetrotting adventure doesn't really pan out when each stop in this wondrous globe is a dingy back corner with a ton of fog dumped in to mask how underdeveloped it all is. This is the game's biggest down side for sure, Deus Ex 1 is a game worth hundreds of hours that you can keep coming back to for years and still uncover new things from, with Invisible War you can get about 10 or 20 hours of gameplay max and you'll likely only get through it to completion once or twice.
- No skills system. One of the key RPG elements of Deus Ex, the skills system where you could specialise in some abilities in exchange for lacking in others, doesn't exist in Invisible War, your abilities at things like shooting and lockpicking will always be the same and can't be upgraded or downgraded in exchange for other abiltiies, the only changes to your character that can be made are selecting IW's version of Augmentations called Biomods, this leads to a lot less variety in player skillsets (and by extension, playstyles) between playthroughs.
- Compatibility problems. Getting this thing to run on a modern system can be a pain and you might need to do some extra work by installing fan made patches or fixes to get it to start, can be a tedious process.
- Disappointing soundtrack, the first Deus Ex set a high bar musically, it had an iconic OST with lots of memorable songs, Invisible War doesn't even come close to equalling that accomplishment, most of what it has to offer is just a series of generic electronic melodies for ambience.
- Universal Ammo. One of the most confusing gameplay decisions the devs came up with for Invisible War is the introduction of Universal Ammo, in Deus Ex 1 all the guns had their own ammo types and even came with alternate ammo types that changed up their functions, not so in Invisible War where every single weapon uses the exact same ammo pool and there's no reloading, you keep firing until you run out and then you have to go and look for more clips, a Rocket Launcher will use the same pool of rounds as a Pistol, an SMG or a Shotgun. Not only is this really stupid and nonsensical even as a kind of far future sci fi concept, it's also frustrating in gameplay terms as well, as having no ammo for one weapon means having no ammo for all weapons, this can push you away from using some of the more powerful weapons as they're a much bigger drain on your ammo supply than small arms.

Ultimately DX Invisible War is a decent game that shows its age and suffered from the limitations of being a console focused game at a time when working on consoles was still vastly inferior to PC, if it didn't have the Deus Ex name attached to it I imagine it would be looked at more forgivingly but being a sequel to a cult classic it's inevitable that players will draw comparisons between the first game and IW, those comparisons will almost always be negative since Deus Ex 1 undeniably has a metric ton more depth mechanically and thematically than Invisible War.

However, this is still a solid product and a valid piece of the Deus Ex franchise, it was made by the same team as the original, they just made the mistake of learning the wrong lessons and listening to the wrong people. At the least fans of the first game should give Invisible War a chance and form their own opinions on it as a game, while I'm not a big fan of it I can appreciate its successes and acknowledge where its shortcomings came from, maybe if it was made a decade or half decade later it could've been something iconic, instead it's just okay at best and poor quality at worst, I'd say its a passable game but a truly terrible sequel, and that's where the harshness towards it comes from, deserved or not.

Overall, it's not a bad game but it has its flaws: 

Compared to the previous game, the levels are ridiculously small. There is no command console. If you want/need to cheat, you have to enable a debug menu by editing some files. 

Steam overlay and playtime counter do not work because the game has two executables. One for the game's main menu (launched by steam), the other for the actual game (launched by the main menu). The gameplay seems to be more simple than the first game. The plot is good, but not as memorable as the original one.

Now you may say 'oh well I played postal 2 so the map switching won't bother me' nope, it literally takes like a minute to load everytime, even on a modern SSD - and the loading screens are there practically EVERY step. The map is tiny which makes for good balanced progression but terrible gameplay quality. Go to a nightclub, you get a quest to go to a hotel nearby - literally maybe 20 feet away from each other - that's two loading screens. Come back to turn in and get quest reward, third loading screen.  But ok, you might say, not a big deal right? I'm a patient person.  Well... sometimes, when the game feels like it, it will just crash on loading screen. There's no proper fixes, unofficial patch, disabling steam overlay, they help but the issue isn't mitigated at all, it will still happen at times. My advice is: spare yourself the trouble, just watch a longplay on youtube instead, play DX 1 and if it feels too antiquated to you then play Human Revolution, cause it still has more to do with original DX1 than IW does.

89826273.review:
Sequel that went wrong. Amalgamation of some good and interesting ideas, covered in some really bad design, rushed development, platform power limitation and general casualization.

Game by itself wouldn't be that bad if it had not been for the fact that it's a sequel to DX1.
All of the main gameplay elements were dumbed down and whole game takes place in claustrophobic levels, that often make no logical sense.
Basic elements of an immersive sim are here, multiple choices and ways to approach each problem.
The only issue is that very often all of those ways lead to the same outcome.
There are many interesting improvements over the DX1, like flashlight not using energy anymore and melee build having some extra implants that help with fighting against the machines and bots.
Balance is another problem, near the mid to the end game player is often semi-forced to use heavy weaponry no matter what.

Overall it's a enjoyable experience, nothing special but its still a Deus Ex game in its roots. Just kinda handicapped and malformed.

89718453.review:
I used to play this game on the OG xbox, having spent a decent amount of my formative years playing the first game. 

I am not going to say the game is awful and irredeemable, but...

Having just completed another play through of the first game, thinking 'yeah I wanna play the games based on release date,' I may have been a little overzealous about that concept. The fact of the matter is that IW just isn't a good followup, not when it came out, and not now about 17 years later. 

The acting somehow feels MORE stilted, even compared to JC Denton's stiff-as-a-board delivery (Which, don't get me wrong, I think JC's amazingly entertainingly acted), the sound quality is worse, and while there wasn't a ton of emoting during conversation in the original game, the lack of it is far more noticeably awkward in this release due to the increased overall fidelity.

There IS a large amount of lee-way for completing objectives how you want. But there's also a good amount of handholding, a lot of the characters (your early-game counterpart Billie, for example) can come across as naggy/preaching, and at least as far as my recent run goes (More time than on record, I'm using the visual upgrade and it doesn't like working with steam) the game's world has a lot less nuance. 

It feels watered down, is the best way to put it. The first game let you get steeped into the world a bit, letting you act as a UNATCO agent and carrying out counterterrorism missions. A good quarter to a third of the game (if I'm being generous) is spent working under the impression you're the good guys, only for you to realize 'no, i am the badmens' and do the flip flop. 
This game immediately goes 'LOOK THEY'RE SPYING ON YOU ISN'T THAT SHIFTY GO INVADE PEOPLE'S HOMES AND FIGHT THE CONSPIIIIRAACYYYY' and has like, a grey's corpse in the basement of a nightclub.
Also the game moved to a more fantastical science fiction angle than the original, which loses a lot of the grounding that made the first game feel so plausible. 

Yeah, you should probably play it sometime if you're really interested in the game's place in history. But play it knowing that the game itself isn't really that great. The people who do like it a lot are overlooking a lot of flaws and weird design decisions, and I can't fault them for doing so. 
There IS stuff here to like, but there's too much weird shit like universal ammo, black market biomods having no ramifications to their use, enemies sometimes being aggressive to you for no explicable reason based on things they have no possible way of knowing (hive-mind, I guess). 
10/10 for the main menu music though, fucking sick rendition of the theme.

If you like Deus Ex, you will like this game because:
*Good, engaging story where choices matter
*Good level design, different solutions to the quests.
*Hard combat (you will die a lot so be prepared to load a lot)
*Interesting characters, old and new
*Good locations
*Levelling through biomods, each has 3 levels both normal and black market branches

87537962.review:
Invisible War has a terrible reputation, but I would argue it is unjustified to this degree. Yes, it is a worse game than Deus Ex 1. There is too much backtracking if you want to do all side missions. Plus, it has technical issues due to being a poor console port. For example, every time you load a new area or load a save, the launcher restarts the game to clear memory. Also, the mission maps are smaller, there is only universal ammo now and you could probably find some other issues I forgot to mention here.

However, there are also many pros. There is more Deus Ex content and it gives you a lot of references to the first game. During most missions, you will get contacted by various competing factions wanting you to achieve different mission objectives. This is a fun concept and increases the replay value plenty. There are  enough interesting characters and a few memorable moments. Recommended to players who are ready to put up with the cons to see more Deus Ex content.

[b]Bugs[/b]
I didn't have to install any mods or fixes, but Invisible War doesn't like overlays. Don't forget to disable the NVIDIA shadowplay overlay for this game. Otherwise you might meet a black screen and you might be unable to play the game.

85485414.review:
Install the visible upgrade patch, and you're good to go.
I'll defend this black sheep to my grave. I replay this game every year or two, just like the original. 

Compared to the original, here is what you typically hear...
Simplified inventory? Inventory management is not fun. No issue here.
Universal ammo? An interesting mechanic where different weapons consume different amounts of ammo. No issue here.
AI too dumb? They were just as dumb in the original. No issue here.

Here's what you get that's better than the original...
More side quest. That's right. Everyone loves Hong Kong in the original, but it's pretty much just the main quest there. Here, you get two hub worlds packed with things to do.
Better factions. In the original, you moved from faction to faction linear style. Here, you can play the game favoring one faction over another, and it changes progression.

Where it falters...
Small hub worlds, almost like dioramas. The illusion worked well enough back in the day. And it might even fool you now on a first play-though. But especially the first hub world, it's almost comical to think of it as a city.
Easy combat. Combat was easy in the original too, but here, even on the hardest difficulty, it's still too easy. Maybe it's just because I've played it so much. Even on realistic, 2-3 upper body shots with a simple pistol kills 90 percent of enemies. With a damage upgrade on a pistol, it's 1-2. The super soldiers later on require a lot more, but you're also OP by that point.

Where it ties the original, and the most important part... story. The story is great. In small and big ways. Two school friends interact with you throughout the game, one even offering a different ending if you keep him around. Two competing coffee shop companies enlist your help throughout the game, providing foreshadowing to the main plot. The Omar are cool. You discover plot points with your character, being just as ignorant as you. 

If you optimize how you do side quest, the game is short. Very short. But that's a curse of playing the game as much as I have. It's bitter sweet.

84384621.review:
A bad, bad Deus Ex game, they say. Let's pretend it never happened, they say. Dumbed down, downgraded (insert_an_insult), they say.

Wait a minute... 

Am I, actually... HAVING FUN with this game? Instead of cursing and moaning in frustration as I did with the first DE? Are all those things that annoyed the hell out of me in the first DE just... gone?

Did I say 'wow' while watching the opening cinematic..? Is the story, actually... INTRIGUING, with more things happening in the first 30 minutes of play than it was in the first 5 hours of DE1?

Did I instantly connect to the main character, Alex, as we were trying to figure out wtf was going on around (because neither of us had a clue)? 

Am I having a hard time trying to sleep because of the big decision coming in the game..?

...I mean... Wow...

Different approaches to the same task? Let's see...  It's there all right.

Invisible War definitely surprised me. Why or how the hell it is 'a bad game', or 'a bad Deus Ex game', I have no idea.

The only thing I can agree on with those who scold IW is optimization. From this point of view, the game is a little... messy. There ARE a lot of loading screens, which is not such a big problem if you are patient (I am). The problem in my case was that the only way to make it work at all was running it in windowed mode with the Visible Upgrade mod installed. Otherwise, all I got was a black screen right after choosing a character portrait. Then, I had to close manually a bulk of 'not responding' instances because the game opens a new window whenever you load a save or enter a new area. Even if you don't have problems launching it, I strongly recommend installing the Visible Upgrade mod - it allows you to play with modern screen resolutions. Besides, the game looks really good with hi-res textures the mod offers. As a bonus, you can tweak the looks of Alex and main NPCs (I loved those glowing eyes:) )

83171696.review:
This is a mostly enjoyable and fun game to play, under the condition that you ignore its title, specifically the first two words. 

As a standalone game, it is a fun stealth fps with minute rpg elements. The story is alright, there is some lore to read and hear and there are some interesting characters. What is somewhat annoying is that the game keeps crashing. It is interesting to note that these crashes are not bugs, but, and I’m not kidding, an intended feature. Whenever loading a new area, the game will close itself and reopen. This was the only way they could think for the game to work properly. I admit it is as much ingenious as it is a red flag. But positive feelings! It’s an average standalone after all.

So, inside these arbitrary metrics, it’s an okay generic game.

However, this isn’t a standalone game, is it?

Now, to the crux of the matter. As a sequel to Deus Ex, with the exception of the better graphics, better voice acting (the male protagonist, for instance, is voiced by Vegeta) and some sparse good tweaks; It falls short. Unbelievably short.
Invisible War is inferior in almost every conceivable way. Plot, music, game design, level design, characters, lore, dialogue, among others. You can pick, there is a plethora of detractions from the first game.
It is far more streamlined, less immersive and massively less cerebral. You can have more meaningful conversations with bartenders on the original than with faction leaders on the sequel. The only two moments I felt this was actually a Deus Ex was during [spoiler] the Coffee Wars mission in Trier (which could have been done better and serves as a hint to a plot point which is already obvious to the average Deus Ex player at this point) and the first encounter and subsequent conversation with JC Denton. [/spoiler]

As a sequel to Deus Ex, this is a monumental step back. I honestly feel bad for the developers that had to bend to the corporate desires and mangle this. It’s ironic. What went down behind the scenes between the devs and executives is, most likely, far more Deus Ex than this game itself even attempted to be. (It was originally developed for the Xbox, because money.)
This is, most likely, the worst of the main Deus Ex games. I say most likely because, as of the time of this review, I have only played the original and Invisible War. The only things I know of Human Revolution and Mankind Divided are opinions and reviews of friends, so I have a gist of the overall quality, but am biased due to not actually knowing.

So, I give this game a positive review. Under certain boundaries, I enjoyed this game. And you will, or could, enjoy it also, if:
-You never played any Deus Ex. If this relates to you, you will have a good time, it is a fun game. But it would be best if you played the original first. For any reason whatsoever.

-You only played the prequels/newer ones. If this relates to you, you might find this fun. It is still far less cerebral and nuanced, but there are some traits that you could find familiar. But then again, if you are stepping your toes onto the waters of the old ones, play the original, for the love of g..

-You played the original, but you came expecting nothing of it and try to see the game as something else, disconnected, from the original. If you manage to do this, you will have fun with a good game that, to its unfortunate predicament, sits at the shadow of one of the greatest games of all time.

In summation, Invisible War is a good game, but an awful Deus Ex.

As a wise man once said, 

“I am completely biased, and I don’t care.”  - SsethTzeentach

Once more, I recommend anyone to see Ross’s essay on the game. It is far more detailed, well conveyed and entertaining than this review. Like the difference between the OG and Invisible War! 
“Ross’s Game Dungeon: Deus Ex - Invisible War” on Youtube.

82502605.review:
Even with the unofficial patch ("Visible Upgrade" mod), this game was still a bit too crash-prone for my liking. The game crashed at least three times during my playthrough, and there were also a few times during in-game 'infolink' call conversations with other characters where the call would just get stuck (Resulting in me having to force-crash the game and restart a few times).

Biggest complaint aside from the crashing is probably the absurd amount of load screens (Seems to be an issue with many games of this era built on the Unreal 2 engine - maybe less a design flaw and moreso the developer trying to accommodate for the limited amount of system RAM most people had back in 2003/2004?).

Arguably the original Deus Ex is better than this in almost every way. Invisible War does look better though (e.g. dynamic shadows etc), and the physics engine (especially the ragdoll physics) in this game makes some aspects of the gameplay much more satisfying compared to the original.

If you can overlook the flaws, it's actually not a bad game, just unstable/crash-prone and disappointingly less RPG orientated than its predecessor.
If you do get this, make sure to install the Visible Upgrade unofficial patch, it fixes lots of issues and also applies higher resolution textures to the game characters.

Honestly, this game plays more like a PS2 version of  Bioshock than it does OG Deus. 79557086.review:
Good game, though nowhere near as good as the original.

Pros:
-Greatly improved graphics and physics compared to DX1 and on the highest settings it doesn't look too bad for a now classic title, IMO.
-A decent story continuation of the Deus Ex story with a lot of references and direct linkages to the original.
-Ability to choose to play as 1 of 2 different characters, male or female. Was cool to play as female Alex Denton.
-Black Market Augmentations are pretty fun and unique.

Cons:
-Much more of a shooter-type RPG, arguably. Non-lethal/stealth play feels less rewarding and challenging than in the first game.
-The combat and stealth feel less rewarding and fun in general. I would argue this game feels much easier and more linear than the first.
-Limited levels and environments so there is a feeling of the design including some lazy recycling, but I suppose for a 2003 title it isn't so big a sin.
-In many ways a less immersive, dark, and "sexy" game than the first. Despite the escalation of the story it all kinda feels bland at the end. DX2 might be worth replaying for the sake of trying a different play-style, but it does not come close to DX1 at all.

78798475.review:
Even if this game weren't a huge let down after the first Deus Ex I wouldn't recommend it. It reeks of cash in for consoles sequel. Virtually every system of the game was reduced, dumbed down or simplified from the previous game. I played through using the visible upgrade mod, which makes the game look better and ironed out some bugs. I will also note that I had crashes on loading screens until I disabled the steam overlay, after which the game ran fine.

The game takes place 20 years after the first. Society had collapsed but rebuilt and is now more technologically advanced than before. The rich smart people live in closed societies and everyone else is a hobo. You are a fresh nanoaugmented recruit of the Tarsus Academy when shit starts to tilt. I liked that there were multiple factions with conflicting mission goals on missions. A lot of the choices would greatly effect the later game and change what side you were on which was cool. That being said even when you continually fucked a faction over they would still ask you to do their bidding on later missions, letting you flip flop which detracts from the gravity of your choices. 

The story is far less intriguing than the original Deus Ex. There were some minor twists but nothing that will stick with you. You would think the big reveal of who you really are would be a big DUN DUN DUNNNNNN moment but it was so flat and unceremonious that it was laughable. All of the factions you can choose between are kind of meh, which I guess ends up being a pretty good moral dilemma but it also made me not give a shit about any of them. Even involving characters from the first game didn't spark any interest. There were several subplots that develop through side quests that carry through the levels, but most of them felt like filler fetch quests that I didn't bother pursuing them to the end. Coffee shops? Pop stars? Who cares? I thought the Omar were cool but they played virtually no part in the game, just a flavor side faction. 

So much of the cool stuff from Deus Ex was chopped down or removed. The skill system is entirely gone. Character progression is linked solely to augmentations, which can be renegged on and changed at a whim. After looking at the options I knew pretty much what I wanted to use and had a half dozen canisters left over by the end of the game (the skill canisters and the upgrades were combined into one). Seemingly half of the augmentations are all passive, which while a QOL improvement makes energy a meme and easy to keep topped up. Multitools and lockpicks were combined into one item. The inventory system is gone and is just slots. Weapons all use the same ammo. LAM's are gone but they split grenades and mines into two different items? Bizarre. Hacking may as well not be in the game at all; it is available solely as an augmentation and is used so seldomly that they may not have even added it. 

The actual gameplay and combat was as unmemorable as the story. Fighting felt as limp and disjointed as TES4: Oblivion. Stealth is viable, but if you don't one shot a guy it seems it instantly alerts everyone around. Melee besides the sword all seemed crappy and I can't imagine trying to play non lethal. The level design is samey corridors. They did have some decent multiple paths in places but overall it was very cramped and limiting. The vaulting feature was a nice QOL improvement but it took forever to do and climbing ladders was even more annoying than the first game. 

In summary, if you liked the first Deus Ex I would say to definitely NOT play this one. It's not worth it, pretend it never happened. Not even for continuing the story. Leave it at JC's decision at the end of the first game, where you change the world and the possibilities for the future are endless, because this future sucks.

78055497.review:
Having played this and the original Deus Ex back when I was wee lad, I've come back to play the series since I've yet to beat Mankind Divided. Moving directly from Deus Ex GOTY to Invisible War is a bit jarring, but the overall experience is rewarding. Yes, the mechanics are a bit different and watered down, but looking beyond that - it's an engaging game with rewarding gameplay.

Movement is a bit more of what you'd expect from the first Halo (I'd considered adjusting gravity in the .ini file), but I've honestly enjoyed it considering how stiff the original feels sometimes. Invisible War reminds me of all the games I used to play when I first bought an Xbox and that bit of nostalgia absolutely carries through.

It is a bit weird getting used to all weapons sharing the same ammo supply, but ammo is also plentiful to where I've literally never worried about ammo in my 15+ hours of gameplay so far. The game feels as though it's tailored for a more casual gamer and that could be why it appeals to me now at 34. I typically don't have a ton of time to play outside of work, but Invisible War has made it in there in the last 2-3 hours before heading to bed. It's worth noting that it's in no way as challenging as the first Deus Ex, but it does have its moments, and thankfully the game still preserves its options. 

My only suggestion would be to track down the Deus Ex widescreen utility and getting it running at your native resolution. Other than that, the story is worth checking out and the game is dirt cheap anyway.

76793986.review:
Though a compelling sequel, Invisible War plays it safe and doesn’t really improve gameplay from its predecessor. Endlessly replayable and with a plot just as good as Deus Ex’s--and much better than Human Revolution's--it’s worth the money, especially for cyberpunk or FPS/adventure fans. Compared to shallow modern stealth games with infantile mechanics and terrible framing devices (looking at you Assassin's Creed) Invisible War looks like freaking Shakespeare.

While it offers a lot of freedom to experiment, my lone complaint is that the pacifist approach is often too agonizing to be practical. I’m not even sure it was made with non-violence in mind despite inviting you to act conscientiously. Non-lethal options are underwhelming and, without upgrades, frustratingly unreliable. It doesn’t matter anyway as you can’t avoid killing people (intentionally or otherwise) in the later levels, as enemies spawn out of nowhere and rocket-firing AI blast obliviously in cramped hallways and have no sense of safety for themselves or allies.

76394307.review:
The direct sequel to the Deus Ex already has some negative aura around it, but after having played the first Deus Ex and Deus Ex: Human Revolution, I had to try this one out anyway.

My experience can be summarized in the following topics:

- The first thing I felt was that the game definitely doesn't look very polished, even for its time. We're speaking of the year that brought outstandingly looking games such as Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time and Tony . This one, on the other hand, does not look that pretty, facial animations look a bit overdone, and although I'm not entirely sure whether it's only the fault of my laptop's 120 Hz screen or excessively powerful graphics card (when compared to the graphics cards of old), I could never get a smooth 60 FPS experience.
- The story continues with the typical clash of organizations and cults, each begging you to abide to their conflating wishes, all the way through the game. It becomes a cliché, seriously. And ultimately, this affects how much they trust you, but the ending only changes depending on what you choose to do in the last level.
- Stealth is more feasible than in the former game, but the experience is not as exciting as in the latest generation of Deus Ex games. At some point, I was just smashing everyone that stood in my way with a baton until they dropped unconscious. It worked quite well after investing on strength biomods, but it still felt cheap. Alas, this strategy becomes utterly difficult at the last few levels, so I gave up there and fragged my way through.
- The decision to merge lock-picking into the multi-tool was a refreshing decision, as not having enough tools to unlock doors and alarms was a minor frustration in the previous game. There are plenty of multi-tools to find, although due a bug, not all of them can stack in the same inventory slot.
- And speaking of inventory, this one was different as well. While stacking food items together in the same space is OK to have, the very small number of slots available (expandable via biomods) was a bit disappointing, requiring me to leave many items behind regardless of how much they weighed.

But overall, It's a Deus Ex game all right. It feels and breathes like one, albeit with its rough edges.

76015423.review:
This is the most hated game in he Deus Ex series (I don't think DX: The Fall counts) but it's not completely bad. It's just kinda boring and disappointing. 

But if you can ignore the feeling of being robbed of a proper sequel, this can be a good chill out game. 
The art direction, the ambient music and the "relaxed" gameplay adds to that, I felt like I should be receiving a massage and burning some incense while playing this. Everything is so pleasant, even the dirty alleys full of rats have a nice soothing feel to them. 

The best part of this game is the graphics, they are quite impressive for 2003. Using the VisibleUpgrade mod (I never use the texture pack, they change the look of the game too much) to run smoothly in 1080p, this looks a generation ahead of its time. Too bad the maps are more claustrophobic and with more loading points than in DX1 (thanks Xbox!).  And being basically a ported XB game, you can easily configure antimicrox (or joytokey) to play it with a 360 controller, it works very well. If you prefer mouse and keyboard, I would advise you to play on hard or realistic, otherwise the game is WAY too easy. Especially for veteran DX players.

And I'm not kidding about being easy, some games don't reward exploration but DX2 rewards it [b]excessively[/b] . You'll quickly end up with way more medkits, biocells, biomods and gun mods than you can ever use. Beside that, medbots and repairbots  don't have a cooldown as in DX1 and you can also save multitools by using the widely available explosive craters to open doors and lockers. 

As for the weapons, because of the silly unified ammo system they are mostly redundant (except the rocket launcher) unless you are performing a pacifist run. You can literally one-shot all the human enemies (except the armoured soldiers) in the game with the silenced sniper. And for any robot or turret in the game you can just max out the EMP melee biomod and easily destroy them (even the beefier ED-209 look-alike) with a few hits, they all turn too slowly to catch you. This all amounts to a not very exciting gameplay.  

The whole game is janky as hell, it quits and reloads the executable every time you load an area to free the memory and you can multiply items you receive from NPCs if you have a full inventory. The physics are fun but very wonky too, like how you can climb anywhere parkour-style without the jump biomod by just holding the space bar. It's just like DOOM 2016, but unintentional.    

As the story goes, it's not as good as the first game but is still far better than the tone-deaf "augmented civil rights" plots of DX:HR and DX:MD.

VERDICT: I don't even know why I'm recommending this game, but it's so pretty and relaxing I can't hate it.  So if you want a game to play with a controller sitting on the couch while chilling out (and maybe stoned), it kinda works even if the game itself is not very engaging. And if you are a fan of the series, this can scratch your Deus Ex itchy when you have already played all the other games to death. So I can probably recommend this as a methadone fix for your Deus Ex addiction.

The often disregarded sequel to the phenomenal Deus-Ex, Invisible War does some changes to the franchise that are both welcomed and hated by some. The game is more stream-lined with less branching paths and less stealth focused making the gameplay very simple, the shooting mechanics have been simplified and now it's made the fastest way to tackle any obstacle. There are also exploration in the game like the first one but its mostly for gathering extra items and weapons and your abilities aren't has useful in this game and used in very specific areas, most of them optional.
I can't really recommend if you're expecting a Deus Ex experience, this game was made with consoles in mind so it is easier to pick up and play but its nowhere near the level of polish of the first game.

74907061.review:
Note: The reason why my playtime says 0.3 hours is because I was playing using the Visible Upgrade mod. Steam does not register play-time while using this mod. However, I have beaten the game twice; both in the normal and realistic mode. 

TLDR: Deus Ex Invisible War is the Mortal Kombat Annihilation of the Deus ex series. It's the Star Wars Episode 1, The Devil May Cry 2, Hell even the Zelda 2 of the Deus Ex series. Okay, I think you get my point. It's a tragedy that should have never happened.

With that said...

Let's get the first major issue out the way. The story. They ruined it. If you played the first Deus Ex and wanted to know how the writers decided to wrap things up, then you will be gravely disappointed (at least I was).

The plot in the original was so grandeur and well thought out compared to this. It feels like their only goal was to stitch together some flimsy plot to tie in all the factions and characters from the first game. It lacks a sense of identity like the first game had, and as a matter of fact, it LOST almost all the identity that the original game established.

They butchered certain parts of the lore, removed important characters that SHOULD have made an appearance over certain others, the characters are robotic and lack the sense of charm and intrigue that the original game had, decisions don't matter till the end of the game and overall, they just did not do proper justice to the events that happened before this story took place. As a result, the plot simply drags and never recovers. Ever.

Believe it or not, as bad as the story is, it's not the worst offender here.

The gameplay. Wow. What did you do? First of all, If you insist on purchasing this game, make sure you play it on realistic difficulty unless you like the idea of shooting someone in the head and them not dying because you didn't do enough damage to them beforehand.

The combat in the original was never that great, but they took steps backward in this sequel. No limb damage, aiming is awful (and this an FPS game by the way), limited and overpowered weapons and on that note...

So in the opening of the original, you are offered an option of a few weapons: Crossbow, Sniper Rifle, GEP Gun. You chose wisely depending on your playstyle. While this may seem overpowered at first, it balances off due to the implementation of the skill point system and the rate in which these points were awarded to the player (also having options always rocks). 

You can open with a sniper rifle if you want, but if you didn't allocate your skill points properly your aim would be wobbling like crazy, rendering the weapon almost ineffective.

In Deus Ex Invisible War, there are no such limitations. Your character is awesome from the start. This is fine, but the problem is now when you find that Sniper Rifle (which you find VERY early) all you have to do is put a certain damage mod on it, slap on a suppressor and voila, no need to own any other gun in the game (yes, and I do mean to include the unique weapons).

To make matters worse, ammo is universal across all weapons. Yes, there's a lore reason explained for this, but it doesn't make for great gameplay because you NEVER run out of ammo! There's plenty to find in crates, on the corpses of enemies and with you delivering head shots to every opponent in your way-- how the hell do you plan on running out of ammo?

Gone are the sprawling and complex level design of the first game. Each location feels small and lazily mapped out. Deus Ex boasted amazing multitudes of path you could traverse to get the mission done in different ways. This right here? The bare minimum. The design felt like they did it just it to make the locations feel authentic and less of a labyrinth. Once again another design decision that translated into boring gameplay.

The music was completely forgettable. No need to even spend time on it. The voice acting? Wow. If you were a fan of the original just wait till you hear what the did to some of your favorite and ICONIC voices (what the hell did you do to [spoiler]Tracer Tong's[/spoiler] voice). Straight up hack job is what this is.

Okay, I'm tearing into this game way too much so let me tell you what I liked about it. The graphics. Okay I know I know. It looks like trash in this day and age, but if you are using the Visible Upgrade mod (which I highly recommend) then the game looks stunning. The world is cyberpunk heaven to behold. The locations are also very unique and interesting, if not limited in scope. Just ignore how robotic the character models move. It was 2003, man. Chill.

I do not recommend this game at all, even if you're a Deus Ex fan and even if you need that closure. I recommend that you pretend this game never happened and pray that Eidos Montreal remakes the original and scrubs this from the canon.

74063498.review: Not a worthy successor to Deus Ex at all. A lot of the streamlining was nice, such as not having to manually punch in a keycode every time, but I can't help but feel as though the immersion of figuring out the world around you is somewhat hindered by this. It's not as if there weren't effective solutions to this as well-- sticking with keypads, Human Revolution finds a perfect solution by displaying the code next to the keypad if you've already found it (admittedly this disincentivizes actually reading for the code, but it's a worthwhile compromise). It doesn't help that the game was rushed and dumbed down for a primarily console release, and nowhere is this clearer than in the gunplay. In Deus Ex, killing was a means to an end, but in IW, it feels like the entire point of the game. It's certainly not a bad game by any metric, but it's the worst in the Deus Ex franchise and a sheer drop-off from the incredible quality of the first game.

73764721.review:
No es un mal juego, la historia la encontré decente y conecta muy bien con el universo de Deus Ex. Lástima que algunas mecánicas del original ya no existen en esta secuela (Especialmente en la sección de items y inventario) Me dio cierta nostalgia el hecho de poder recoger armas y descargarlas para guardar su munición, cosa que en este juego no existe debido al sistema universal de munición. 

Todas las armas comparten el mismo tipo de munición (Incluso los lanza-cohetes y las armas que claramente utilizan plasma) otro punto negativo es claramente el limitado inventario que se basa en casillas dejando de lado el inventarío del DX original. Ni que hablar de las biomodificiaciones que han sido balanceadas en este juego y se nota bastante. Volviendo a las armas, estas solo pueden tener 2 tipos de modificaciones. Algunas son obligatorias para mantener un ritmo constante en el juego, como también tener 2 armas iguales pero con distintas modificaciones. 

En el original podríamos ser invencibles sí teníamos solo la nano-aug de la regeneración en su máximo nivel, en este juego ciertamente respeta un poco lo que es la dificultad balanceado este factor. Las biomods se pueden cambiar en cualquier momento y eso es debido a que los "cannisters" son fáciles de conseguir a lo largo de todo el juego (Casi siempre se pueden conseguir siguiendo las misiones secundarías) a diferencia del original que en algunas localizaciones era posible encontrar entre 3 o 4 (VersaLife Labs por ejemplo) por ende es posible cambiar las biomods según las necesidades o adversidades que se presenten.

El sistema de skills no existe y para hackear computadores es necesario una biomod del mercado negro. Lo cual es un gran contra punto para cualquiera que busque la esencia del juego original en la secuela. Lo mismo para las ganzúas y las multitools. Al final solo es necesario una o múltiples multitool para abrir cerraduras u ó desactivar sistemas de seguridad
Los computadores existen pero han sido remplazados por los libros, solo he visto algunos y son completamente opcionales. No afectan mucho en la historia.

Sí quieres seguir la historia del Deus Ex original, es una excelente compra y más si está en una oferta. Sí buscas una experiencia igual o similar al Deus Ex 1. Temó decirte que este no es el juego indicado, tal vez los diálogos e interacciones con los personajes tienen cierto aroma al original pero el sistema de biomods, las armas, inventarío y hasta algunas cosas que hacían el original un juego tan inversivo no existen. Es un juego que continúa con la historia de Deus Ex pero que no es un Deus Ex como tal, sí no más bien un shooter del principio del 2000 con una temática Sci-Fi.

El juego dura un aproximado de 11 ó 15 horas si lo juegas solo con sacar un final en mente (Son 4 ó 5 creó)  

Yo le doy un 6/10 Es un juego entretenido, me mantuvo por 2 días aferrado al tecleado pero aún así, no es un digno sucesor al DX original.
