73632345.review:
Invisible War is not a bad game, but it certainly pales in comparison to the rest of the main entries in the series. In comparison to its predecessor, IW is dumbed down mechanically, and there are plenty of questionable design choices (especially throughout the latter third of the game). You can't go wrong with this game for a dollar, but you really shouldn't expect it to live up to the quality of the rest of the series.

Core mechanics have been severely changed since the original game, and only a few of these changes are favorable. I didn't like the awkward "agent aim" mechanic in DX1, which they decided to remove in this game. Augmentations are generally better balanced, and some of them are passive. You can change augmentations if you want (I don't see why not, especially because it's very costly). A lot of weapons have been given quirky alt-fires, such as the rocket launcher's guided missiles or the shotgun's smokebomb. There's a ton of grenade types, and I actually found myself using them far more frequently than in the original game.

Unfortunately, a lot more of these changes lean towards the bad side. Level design has been severely dumbed down in nearly every way (more in the next paragraph). Skills have been completely removed from the game, removing one of the player's primary forms of progression. Augmentation canisters are sometimes handed out like they're candy despite the fact that you only have 5 augmentation slots. By the end of the game, I had over 10 augmentation canisters that I didn't know what to do with. The unique inventory-tetris system from the original game has been replaced with static item slots. Weapons use universal ammo (something I've personally hated since Dead Space 3), and alternate ammo types have been completely removed.

Level design is a particularly significant problem that I have with this game. Most of the level design is mediocre at best, and it's by far the worst in the main series. It generally feels far too streamlined and condensed. You'll often see segments where a door is the "combat route" and the ventilation shaft several feet away is the "stealth route". Sometimes, you're outright funneled right into combat. The hardest encounter in the game, by far, is when the game effectively forces you to take on 7 rocket-launcher wielding goons at once. The hubs are especially awfully designed, because they're so small and almost everything needs you to look at a load screen. The Trier hub is literally just a small circle with four doors to other areas in it, with each door being around ~15 seconds away from each other. Loading screens are incredibly frequent because of how small most maps are (and this applies to all levels - not just the hubs!).

Carrying on from level design, some cracks start to appear in the armor later on into the game. It seems like the developers forgot to escalate the difficulty properly, so they decided to abruptly start hucking the hardest enemies in the game at you in swarms. This isn't too awful, as the player is far stronger in this game than any other entry in the series. I spent the bulk of the first two thirds of the game wiping out most encounters with my baton, so I did welcome the escalation in difficulty. Still, it seems jarring and lazy to me. It's one of the biggest, most spontaneous difficulty spikes I've ever seen in a game.

This game requires a patch in order to work on modern operating systems. Getting this patch to work is incredibly easy (I used Invisible Upgrade), so at least that isn't a major problem. Though I experienced no actual crashes, there's a bizarre quirk with load screens in this game where the game literally crashes to desktop before just restarting in the next area. I've never heard of a game doing anything like this before, but I guess it works? In addition, the physics in this game are buggy in a good way. They're amusingly jank, and I always laughed whenever I saw a Templar get stretched like he's made of taffy.

Do I recommend this game? I think it's worth your time, especially because it's less than $1 on sale. Despite the fact that I have been rather negative, it's completely playable and it delivers an enjoyable, slightly watered-down immersive sim experience. You still have a ton of tools at your disposal, and the gameplay encourages you to mix things up and adapt your character to your preferred playstyle. As a sequel to the original Deus Ex, it's rather disappointing, but if it were a standalone title, it's a pretty solid game.

73609939.review:
[h1]Got fired. Time to Start drinking Again![/h1]
The original Deus Ex is considered one of the greatest PC games ever made, this title pretty much nearly killed the franchise. I finally played and finished 16 years after release. Also, the developer behind Deus Ex games was shut down soon after this mess. Invisible War has to be one of the most disappointing sequels of all time. Much of this is, again, the result of having been designed and tailored for the original Xbox hardware in mind (which were insanely limited by PC standards of the day especially for a game like this).
Ion Storm managed to take all good things that made original so special and decided to cash into sci-fi genre. There is almost no cause and effect like in the original title, no weight in your choices. Much of the cyberpunk feeling is pretty much gone! The art direction felt very cartoonish and colorful. Everything in this game feels rushed, from the dialogue, the story, the graphics, the controls, even the voice acting, HUD and item screens.

[h1]Cons[/h1]
-Horrible level design, pretty much all levels feel and look the same. The levels Similarly, the outdoor environments are claustrophobic, and there's never many characters onscreen at any one time.
-Invisible War gives you a miserly five bio-mod slots to fill.
-The developers decided to remove the hacking skill, and along with it the fantastic ability to read private emails from all the computers you can find. It was one of the best ways the original fleshed out its fantastic story. Now it’s replaced with automatic hacking. 
-Enemy AI is dumb regardless of difficulty setting. Gameplay balance between Alex and enemies is strangely weird and messy. Initially the game is extremely easy but enemies become op very fast during the final act of the story. It’s like every bad guy drank Red Bull at the end. Also, you get very less ammo for the last mission. 
-No-kill run or 100% stealth playthrough is probably impossible in this game imo because of the advanced level enemy types encountered in the game with tough body armor. There is also no bio-mod that lets you sneak past human enemies (there is one but only for bots). A bit disappointing because playing Human Revolution this way was hella fun!! 
-Your actions result in no consequences for committing undesirable actions against factions other than ending. 
-Excessive loading screens despite lacking large open world environments that were present in the first game. 
-Requires fan made patches and mods to make the game work just right on modern PCs.
-Screen resolution won’t go higher than 1280x1024 for me.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
- The devs have acknowledged the original Deus Ex ending(s). Some of the coolest as well as minor characters from the original also make an appearance! 
-There are many references to the first game including some locations and landmarks. 
-Serviceable story and voice acting. There are also plenty of side quests. 
-There are some cool factions here (incl. Knights Templars and Order of the Church xD) 
-Universal ammo, yes it means no more messing around rearranging ammo in your inventory, plus you could choose to use the same gun throughout the whole game should you prefer to do that. 
-There is a surprising amount of voice acting in this game incl. fully voiced protagonists (male/female) as in Fallout 4/Mass Effect/Saints Row/ games. 
-Combat is something that I feel was an improvement.
-Graphics are decent for a 17-year-old game.
-Should appeal to old school gamers that like futuristic, sci-fi games.
-Soundtrack was fine.
-Multiple endings. Most of them were satisfying (I checked out alternate endings on YouTube).
-Cinematics are well done (cutscenes were very important back then; both for presentation and marketing). 

[h1]Final Thoughts[/h1]
The original Deus Ex from 2000 is one of the greatest PC games of all time and addressing why it’s so special would take hours of explaining. It’s not that Invisible War is a bad game by any means (it’s really a decent game but as a huge fan of Deus Ex series this is far below my expectations. If this is your first Deus Ex game then you might even love this game!! It’s a good sci-fi shooter. It’s nothing to be ashamed of.

It’s just that this game was a huge letdown after the excellent original. It was really hard not to look back and keep comparing these two games as a fan. There was so much potential, they had the budget, they had the technology! Half Life 2, Halo 2, Doom 3, Far Cry, SW:KOR, Thief 3 were proof of concepts that making games with high production values wasn’t impossible in 2004. 

Since IW is canon to Deus Ex official timeline it becomes a little hard to not recommend this game but if you’re a fan of the original you owe it to yourself to try it once.
 
[h1]My Rating: 5/10[/h1]

73607754.review:
All the problems that Invisible War faces can be attributed to one of two things, consolitus and it was a sequel to Deus Ex. For example, the small maps can be attributed to the fact the game was made primarily for consoles at the time and the gameplay in and of itself is not "Bad" but it is so simplified and basic in comparison to the complexity of Deus Ex that it feels shallow empty, about the only complexity is in your selection of augments (biomods) which allows for more variety in gameplay approach, but again in comparison to the Original game, is shallow and empty, we have less augments, we have less equipment, we have zero skills to upgrade, about the only positive in comparison that could be considered is that the augments can be hotswitched, whether you consider them being in a separate inventory system is debatable, because thanks to hotswitching, you have alot of flexibility and there's a reason to go seeking them all out. On the other hand however, if we had access to the same number of augments as in the first game (though some were wisely consolidated, arm strength giving more melee damage as well as the ability to move heavier objects and more inventory space is a nice example) then hotswitching your augments may not have been a needed feature. 

So in summary: As a standalone game, it is good. the characters are engaging, the story is interesting and the ragdoll physics for bodies are a joy. As a sequel, the game is very much a disappointment, it deserved better than to be limited to console hardware and it shows.

73490820.review:
Deus Ex: Invisible War is not a patch on the original game, but that is because this game should not be put into the same class/catergory as the original. Sure, this game is a continuation of the original's story. However, the original Deus Ex was based in reality with sci-fi elements added on. This game is rather more the other way around.

Think of it as a true Deus Ex game and you are likely to be disappointed. Think of it as, say, a Star Wars game with some Deus Ex elements, and this game starts to make much more sense. There are even characters in this game (particularly the Omar, and bots that speak sentences beyond just 'target acquired') that are very Star Wars-esque indeed! Once I started to view Invisible War from this angle, I was able to put some of the annoying elements in the game to one side and actually began to enjoy it. I've even got used to the loading screens which occur very frequently.

Based on the reviews I had read, I was going to give this game a miss. I started it, and found the reviews true enough regarding the game design choices that the developers made, which have been described by a great number of other Steam reviewers and elsewhere. These choices have created a completely different game to the original and it is thus unfair to compare them (although, if I had to choose, I would of course choose the original - it is a far better game for so many reasons!) However, I persevered and I am glad that I did. 

This game is not for everybody but, in the right mind set, and with a little determination, I believe you will be rewarded.

72851440.review:
I generally lean towards the positive when reviewing games, even if a game is flawed I try to point out the reasons why it might not be for everyone within the context of a recommendation. However, I break from that tradition with [i]Invisible War[/i] for two reasons.

First, I couldn't get it to work with a base install. Fixing this didn't take long, there are mods to make the game work, but I feel like the very minimum a game should do is be playable. In fact even after this fix I was still getting crashes in the Trier Templar base. So that was strike one.

Secondly, the game is just kind of lame. Not abysmal, not anger-inducing, but an undeniable letdown after [i]Deus Ex[/i]'s brilliance. It's a hard act to follow for sure, but I feel the quality of everything compared to the first game just goes off a cliff. There's no upgradeable skills, and the biomod system has been scaled down so that you'll have everything installed within the first few areas of the game. This takes away customisation as well as the incentive to explore for canisters and skill points. The wide open spaces and complex maps of [i]Deus Ex[/i] have been replaced with much smaller areas to fit on consoles, and the game is much shorter too. I couldn't quite believe it when I was at the final level, we just didn't seem to have [i]done[/i] much.

Now there are some good things about the game. Though the story has been dumbed down a lot, there are still glimpses of interesting concepts and writing. I liked the feud between the two rival coffee shops, both of the names of which are references to Starbucks. It all seems very early 21st century somehow, along with setting the early game in Seattle of all places (pity we couldn't get NPC expys of Frasier and Niles Crane.) The concept of the virtual celebrity AI "NG Resonance" was intriguing, and some of the NPC conversations were well-written and voiced. One conversation between a businesswoman and an aspiring novelist in the Cairo Arcology actually got me thinking I was in the game for real for a second, it sounded so natural, like something you'd overhear in an airport lounge. However, for the most part the game's locations don't really draw you in because everything feels sort of unfinished and limited, like they were in a hurry and couldn't do all the things they wanted with the game.

To summarise, I think this is for [i]Deus Ex[/i] die-hards only, and even then only for completion's sake. There are multiple endings to the game but I honestly didn't feel like going for them...the different factions seemed far less nuanced than in the first game, so I wasn't inspired to join any of them (though the Omar body-mod freaks were entertaining I guess.) There aren't any achievements either. At least it's cheap!

72797792.review:
Invisible War is a sequel to critially acclaimed immersive sim "Deus Ex" and a complete disaster.

Let's start with the fact that from a technical standpoint is a complete nightmare. Not only it is severely outdated and does not support any of the modern features, including aspect ratios above 4:3. Some people also reported that the game doesn't even start, so you have to go out of your way to fix this. Fortunately, I quickly found the solution in Visible Upgrade mod, that fixes most of the issues and adds some helpful features (you can download it by clicking [url=https://www.moddb.com/mods/deus-ex-2-visible-upgrade/downloads/visible-upgrade-full-edition]this link[/url], if you want to play this thing anyway). But even after that you have to deal with a lot of issues, like small bugs with the invertory items, or random crashes that can ruin you save file (always have back-up save). I also have to mentions the world of the game is broken i a lot of tiny locations, that are separated by loading screens, which result in the fact that you will see a lot of loading screens. Hope you have a good HDD or an SSD, because otherwise this is going to get very annoying. I honestly have no idea what was going on during the developmant of this game, but i'm sure it was pretty bad. This is the most busted game I've played since Vampire The Masquerade: Bloodlines, but that game is actually good.

So even if you going to look past all of this nonsense you get a mediocre FPS with RPG elements, that can't stand even close to the legacy of Deus Ex. 
The story of the game follows Alex D. The student of Tarsus Academy and living experiment in advanced biological modifications. After destruction of his hometown Alex finds himself in the middle of global conspiracy between variety of factions that are over global control over the world and will ultimately lead to the future of humankind. 
Unlike the first game, that had a slow build-up to the initial reveal of the conspiracy behind UNATCO, IW wastes no time and makes you choose between different factions to push further someones interest depending on your role-play. This is probably the best thing that IW has going for it, each faction represents a specific ideology and there is no good or bad choices in deciding who to side with (except Templar). You can be a loyal follower of a specific faction, or be a renegade that will that double and triple cross anyone for his own benefit. Most of the time, even if you betray a specific faction you will have the chance to side with them again, giving you plenty of room to experiment. 
I would say the plot of the game is pretty game is pretty good, but the main problem with it comes from characters, almost all of which are annoying and insufferable. Your fellow trainees of Tarsus are the set of stupid cliches, leaders of factions are self-centered assholes. There is just no one to relate or even care about. Only thing that was stopping me from killing those characters outright was plot convinience, else I would erase those idiots the moment i got a chance. And don't even get me started on what they did to characters from the first game, they were butchered beyond any recognition.

And then there is the gameplay. My god, this is terrible. First off, the game was completely dumbed down from the previous installment. Skills were cut from the game, so the only progression comes from biomods, but you can equip only one biomod from 6 different slots. There are 3 possible biomods that you can equip in each slot, bringing total number of mods to 18. Each mod can be upgraded 3 times and if you try to change any mods, it will completely replace your previous mod in that slot, reducing your options drastically compared to previous game. 

UI of the game is embodiment of "style over substance', it is very unintuitive and covers 50% of the screen all the time. Inventory is so small you can carry just handful of items and everything takes one spot in it, from small multiotools to giant rocket launchers. I get that not everyone enjoys inventory tetris of Deus Ex, but system at least made sense and allowed for enough room in creativity in picking what you want to carry. At least we could have slots to work with maybe? And for some reason we can carry only 10 small items in one slot, anything more will take other slot. The biomod ant info menues are also unintuitive, instead of simple diagram or list of things, every little element of the interface tkaes up entire screen and you have to scroll throgu a lot of things to find what you actually need. Want to find a map of your location? Then you have to scroll through every image saved in your database before you can look at map. 

Then there is combat, which is terrible. Weapons lack any feedback, have hit-detection issues, have completely incosisted damage and also for some reason have universal ammunition, which means that pistol and SMG use ammo from the same pool as flamethrower and rocket launcher. This leads to complete imbalance of weapons. Melee is most of the time suicide, since you can't upgrade your health to tank enough damage to use it, and misses half the time even if you try to hit enemy point-blank. Grenades can fall trough the floor and take too much time to explode anyway, so enemies can just walk away from them. Most of the game i relied on pistol, because it does not consume too much ammo and can kill most of human enemies in a couple of headshots. Unfortunately, that led to the problem in late game where you fight heavily augmented and/or armored enemies, since they required much more firepower to kill, so you have to use something like rocket launcher. This is completely different from DX1 where you could beat the whole game with just starting pistol, provided you invest some skill-points in it and had enough ammo, because you could kill even toughest of enemies with well placed shot. 

Another pillar of DX game design is stealth which is also completely busted. Enemy AI is very basic and reacts  to everything in nery predictable manner. Enemies react to sound and can't see you in the dark. Cameras have extremely obvious outline and always have convenient security terminal next to them which can be hacked with right mod and allows to bypass any security. There is only two states that enemy can be in, patrolling and alerted, there is no inbetween, which is stupid since Deus Ex has figured it out 3 years before the release of this game. We also had MGS and Splinter Cell and Hitman before IW, but stealth in IW is handled in such stupid way there is no reason for it, once you've been seen, enemies just gather to your location and start blasting in your direction. Also for some reason silencers just do not work, people hear shots with it anyway. 

The only reason I would recommend this to anyone is only you're very curious about history of Deus Ex games or the genre of Immersive Sim games. 71726101.review:
So I was 13 when I bought and played Human Revolution for the first time. Loved it. Played on the 360, got all the achievements and played it like four times... Fantastic game. Played the original Deus Ex after that on my laptop. Was blown away by it. Played Mankind Divided too, excellent game with a lot of untapped potential in terms of it's butchered story. Still loved it though. Could've been the best Deus Ex in my opinion if they hadn't chopped it in half. Got all the important cheevos for that too. Recently I replayed the original Deus Ex (still a banging game) and decided to try Invisible War. It'd always alluded me since I could never get it to work on my laptop as a kid. I'd always heard stuff like "Oh, it's underrated." "It's better than Human Revolution." "So overlooked." Hearing stuff like this down the years got me excited, as you'd expect from someone who really loves Deus Ex and grew up with it. So I installed the Visible Upgrade and got to playing it.

Well. This game is fucking trash.

It's fucking doodoo. I don't know what Harvey Smith and Warren Spector were smoking, but I wanna try it! First of all it has to be the most claustrophobic video game I've EVER played. And I've played Deus Ex's PS2 port! I understand the original Xbox's RAM size was the limiting factor for this but oh my god. Am I supposed to believe Seattle, despite the absolutely bleak cyberpunk setting is a hive of tiny favelas? The RPG systems are so dumb compared to the original Deus Ex as well, to the point I felt almost insulted with the lack of choice coming straight off the original game. FIVE biomod slots? Seriously? The dialogue is also weird as fuck, with long pauses between each line. I picked the white guy, as I am also a white guy so that is very relatable. So looking at this Jersey Shore-looking motherfucker with his jaw agape about some nonsense for a second didn't exactly enhance my enjoyment of the game

It also feels like the game has a super form of mouse acceleration? The first few minutes in playing a Deus Ex game, you shouldn't think 'I should play this with my Xbox controller.'  I will give it that the gunplay is better than the original (that's not particularly hard.) and I do like that you have the choice of faction. One thing I did wish for in the original is the choice to stay with UNATCO, but they did improve on that by letting you choose what you want here, instead of pressing a button for a different ending. So bonus points for improving how the world reacts to your choices. 

But no, otherwise, this is garbage. Maybe there is a good game in here and I'll put my big boy pants on to finish it, but I'll pretend I'm not playing a Deus Ex game. I'm pretty sure now anyone who says this game is underrated and better than Human Revolution is sniffing ketamine off a toilet seat. I would've been so upset if I was a Deus Ex fan and this is what I got in 2004.

70732575.review:
Deus Ex: Invisible War is the cyberpunk FPS/RPG hybrid sequel to Deus Ex, set place in the near future after the events of the first game.   A terror attack using advanced nanotechnology has taken place and the protagonist, a young recruit, must uncover the conspiracies being wielded by shadowy Illuminati organisations.

This was hotly anticipated after the unheralded success of the original Deus Ex.  So what went wrong?  Consoles, that's what.  The game was engineered for console first, PC second, and as such the delivery on PC was a wreck.  The developers also dumbed down the rich gameplay from the original Deus Ex, presumably because console gamers wouldn't understand different kinds of ammunition.   Console gamers still didn't get it, because it wasn't Super Mario Brothers and didn't have enough bright cheerful colours, so it didn't do well there and it didn't do well on PC either.  While it has been fixed up a little, the game still runs poorly on PC. 

Consoles make gaming worse.  It's with great sorrow, this gets a thumbs down.  If it wasn't made for Xbox instead of PC, it wouldn't have these problems and it would be a bargain at $10.   Only recommended for people who want to play the whole set of Deus Ex games, but even then, it wouldn't be so bad to give this one a miss.

70418522.review:
[h1]Well that is one way to almost kill a beloved franchise[/h1]
This review is more about why I hate this game so much, so I'm just going to list the bad about it and why it is one of the worst videogames that I've ever played. This game is such a letdown and a downgrade from the original Deus Ex game, which was released 3 years prior to this game:

- [b]The story is more simplified[/b]: This is such a letdown considering that the first game had more depth when it came to story, now it is just basic, all character feel generic and uninteresting, and some of the story elements don't make sense and are not even close to realistic. 

- [b]The protagonist is dull[/b]: their writing and dialogue options are awful and just looking at them makes me want to vomit.

- [b]Awful writing[/b]: the writing is so simplified and the dialogue choices are downright terrible.

- [b]Terrible HUD[/b]: The HUD is a downgrade from its predecessor. I hate the circular HUD; it's distracting and doesn't look good at all ingame.

- [b]Bad tutorials[/b]: The game bombards you with tutorials in the first few levels, and some of which are ridiculous and just unnecessary. 

- [b]Universal ammo[/b]: all weapons use the same ammo, ALL OF THEM. I mean why? why would they do that?

- [b]Health system downgraded[/b] now it's just one health bar instead of one for each body region (head, right leg, left leg, etc.), which defeats the purpose of being a cyborg.

- [b]Skills completely removed[/b]: no specializations, which makes our character even more bland and generic.

- [b]Atrocious level design[/b]: remember how big Liberty City and Area 51 were in the first Deus Ex? since this is a console game they made the maps smaller and claustrophobic. They focused more on their new lighting system and added minor upgrades in textures instead of map size.

- [b]Doesn't work on modern PCs[/b]: why is it that I can play the first Deus Ex fine with no issues and not this game? Apparently playing it on GOG fixes most of the game's problems.

[h1]Final Thoughts[/h1]
I don't have anything else to say; I won't even praise some of its new features as it doesn't deserve it. F*ck this game.

[h1]Final Rating: 1/10[/h1]

69712573.review:
The release of two new Deus Ex games from Square Enix led many critics and fans to re-evaluate the harsh criticisms they gave to the second instalment in the franchise, Deus Ex: Invisible War (IW). Removed from the hype of IW's release and by judging the game on its own merits as opposed to how it stacked up to the previous instalment, one of PC gaming's greatest RPGs, IW's retrospective reviews have been a lot kinder to the stealth/shooter (not RPG) sequel.

Graphically the game holds up with nice lighting and textures. Ironically it was these great looks that were one of the reasons that fans were divided in 2003, as only the top gaming rigs of the time could power IW; while those on Xbox had no trouble. Unfortunately the environments outshine the character models who look, sound, and stand about like shop floor mannequins. The HUD is also big and ugly and obscures a lot. The worlds themselves are a big step down from the original. They don't feel alive and inhabited like New York and Hong Kong did in the first Deus Ex. They're a lot smaller too, with the final battle against Bob Page in the first game taking up more room than Seattle and Cairo do in this one. The 'open worlds' are one of the ways IW really shows off its Xboxness. Every 50 meters you'll be met with a loading screen taking you to another small, explorable area, a far cry from the mostly seem-less worlds of Deus Ex.

Gameplay wise IW keeps the lackluster stealth system of the original, where enemies run around screaming with three tranq darts sticking out of their heads, but this time also fails to make a compelling FPS. I can understand a silenced pistol not downing an enemy in one quick headshot, but when it takes three point blank headshots from a high-powered shotgun before an enemy turns into an admittedly fun rag doll, I start to wonder what the correct play style is. And its not like your character is going to get any better at handling high-powered shotguns at pointblank ranges either, in the first game a gun's kickback made you feel like a little girl but by the end a careful distribution of experience points meant you could run through Area 51 while little girly MJ12 super soldiers were blasted apart by your GEP gun. But IW has no skill tree or character progression, hence my earlier refusal to call it an RPG.

Following the pattern of not living up to the original, IW's story falls well short of the Alex Jones inspiring conspiracy of Deus Ex. I mean all the sames pieces are there: globetrotting, shadow governments, post-human bio modifications, foreign and domestic terror cells, post-9/11 defence and privacy Acts made to curb foreign and domestic terror cells, plagues, aliens, alien plagues, the Illuminati, but this time the conspiracy fails to inspire. The story this time is simpler and easier to follow, but that's far from an improvement. And it's a lot easier to engross oneself in a fictional conspiracy when you can look up the Trilateral Commission and see that it's a real thing with real political influence. The only Omar I know is my Pakistani school friend. And I highly doubt the major religions of the world are going to start co-existing in a one-world global faith any time soon.

Whether on its own or as a sequel, Deus Ex: Invisible War fails to excite. The game can't save the story and the story can't save the game; and if you really want to know what happens to humanity after the defeat of Bob Page, the ambiguity and moral greyness of Deus Ex's endings are much more thought-provoking than anything offered here.

69285824.review:
This one's an "in the middle" thumb. I like this game, but I don't recommend it, and to be honest I don't really like it that much either... I just don't see the point of shitting on a 20 year old game. Besides, the reason why this game is so bad is widely published and it's sad. The developers were fucked over by their shitty game engine contractor, who left them with a half baked product, and their shitty publishers who forced them to make one single game for both PC and consoles. The resulting product is "mixed" reviews. It sold poorly and the studio never recovered. Even worse, it pushed off the creation of new games in this vein--the soi-disant cyberpunk themed, open-ended simulator with deep meaningful gameplay--for another decade. 

It's hard to understate how hotly I anticipated this game, and it's equally hard to understate just how disappointing it was upon release, but that seems a lifetime ago at this point. I like to play it for nostalgia; it has its moments. You might find it fascinating if you've never played the original, but you're much better off picking up one of the more recent titles in the series. The new games are prequels, so if you've played the original and you're dying to know how the story continues and you somehow managed to avoid playing this game for two decades, then perhaps you should check it out--just remember that once you play it, you can't unplay it.

68879741.review:
(EN: This review is in Esperanto, which does not yet have language filter support.)

Ĉu oni devus ludi Deus Ex: Invisible War? Jes kaj ne.

Mi sugestas tiun ĉi ludon por du ludistaroj:
- Tiuj sindediĉas al la serio Deus Ex kaj ĝia historio
- Tiuj eblas alttaksi filozofiajn valorojn spite mezklavita prezento

DE:IW elvenas eraon (en la fruaj 00-aj jaroj) kiam ludaj kompanioj altvaloris inter-konsolan subtenadon. Bedaŭrinde, tiu valoro iĝis la ĉefan koncernon de Ion Storm dum la ellaborado de Invisible War. Evidentas ke la simpligitaj kontroloj, la alta ofteco da ŝarĝado-ekranoj, kaj la regilo-centra uzanta interfaco designis por la Xbox. 

Nek la prima Deus Ex nek ĉi-ludo gardis ĝiajn bonegajn aspektojn post kiam tiom da jaroj. Same, la duo enhavas multajn gravegajn politikajn kaj sociajn temojn kiuj restas aplikeblaj hodiaŭ. Tamen, pro la limigoj derivis de ĝia forta ligo al la arkitekturo de la Xbox, oni ricevis malpli. Ni vidas malpli tekstojn, malpli dialogojn, kaj malpli mediojn (ne la nombro de lokoj, sed la grandeco de ili).

Ekzistas vere la pensigaj temoj de la unua ludo! Estas referencoj al Alexis de Toqueville, Bertrand Russell, kaj pli... Sed oni devas kribri la miopajn designajn decidojn al trovi la malmultan saĝecon kiu restas ene la skribado de la historio. Kvankam tiu ĉi ludo ne ŝanĝis mian vivon kiel Deus Ex, mi trovis iom da la originala esenco en ĝi. Mi esperas ke vi trovos la saman se vi decidus ludi ĝin. Sed se la kribro ne ŝajnus esti valora al vi, evitu ĉi-relikvon.

This game is about illustrating class division, the role of government, organizational corruption, environmental protection, bioethics, black markets, and the never ending struggle to find truth while facing the obstacle of danger and violence at every turn.
Real-world references throughout the video game. Reading about these before hand will help you understand the story as it unfolds.
Learned about 'Vasana', a term used in Advaita Vedanta, a school of Hindu philosophy.
Learned about 'Samadhi', a term used in Hinduism.

68015402.review:
Deus Ex: Invisible War is a textbook example of primitive technology squandering the potential of a work of art, but it's still the best Deus Ex sequel and the 2nd best game in the series. Want to find your objective, no matter what part of the game you're in or what your objective is? It's just down the hall. That's because DX:IW was designed to run on a console with less than 100 megabytes of DDR1 RAM, which will go down in history as one of the worst development blunders of its time. It takes place exclusively in sparsely populated hallways, which is exactly as jarring and unrealistic as it seems on paper, and results in a game that's far too short and too easy. It's also stuffed to the gills with the awful voice acting of its era.

With that said, it's still my favorite Deus Ex game. What's to like? The controls, to start with, are much better than DX1's - there's no more looking for the semicolon key in the middle of a gunfight. Several returning biomods (Light, Combat Strength, Microfibral Muscle, Run Silent) no longer drain energy, and manual biomod activation is only required when it makes sense (e.g. Light is manually activated, Run Silent is passive). The soundtrack is also the best in the series; it perfectly matches the tone and atmosphere of the game.

What makes IW one of my all-time favorites is the nearly unrivaled variety of ways to approach every part of it. By that I don't simply mean "every mission objective has multiple branches", but "every last item container, door, and NPC can be dealt with in at least 4 distinct ways". It makes a game that's already too easy even easier, but it's worth it. It's the type of game where "I'm going to set that guy on fire" is usually a valid plan, yet you're never required to set anyone or anything on fire, even during the quest that's explicitly about setting coffee beans on fire. It's one of the few games that doesn't invoke the feeling of an invisible, clueless middleman "correcting" your decisions in realtime by artificially limiting the solutions to problems.

tl;dr Deus Ex: Invisible War was an innovative, but severely flawed game. 7.5/10

67758967.review:
Continuing my review streak of my beloved Deus Ex series, this time I tackle the black sheep of the franchise. Deus Ex: Invisible War is perhaps the most controversial title in the community. Some think it's a giant disrespect to its predecessor, some consider it simply being misunderstood and overly ambitous. In this review, I will try to describe the good, the bad and straight up ugly of the sequel to one of the most treasured titles in gaming history.

[b]FOLLOWING REVIEW IS SPOILER FREE[/b]

DE:IW picks up several years after the ending of the original Deus Ex. Or, I should rather say, endings. Deus Ex (2000) had three possible endings. Developers at Ion Storm, in an effort to appease every player, instead of choosing one canonical ending, combined all three endings of the original into one. This left hardcore fans confused as they questioned why JC (protagonist of Deus Ex) would ever make such conflicting decisions. However, this is the story we got.

In DE:IW we follow Alex D (some writer really must have thought it sounds cool and edgy). Alex can be either male or female and can choose a color of their skin, a feature returning from Deus Ex (2000). One of the criticisms of its predecessor was the fact that players were unable to side with a faction until the last mission. Invisible War offers you quests from four vastly different political and ideological groups:
- Order Church (spiritual, envitoment-friendly, religious movement)
- Knights Templar (purists fighting for augmentation-free future)
- World Trade Organization (international organization looking to control the world through trade)
- Omar (society of heavily augmented cyborgs)

Their quests are often contradicting, so you will have to keep making decisions. After everything is said and done, it doesn't really matter who you side with. That is because the only "true" choice which has any impact on the story, comes at the very end. You approach a security console and pick your ending. The only original ending is for the Omar who ask you to [spoiler]kill all faction leaders thus plunging the world into apocalypse[/spoiler].

The biggest change came in terms of gameplay. While Deus Ex (2000) had several big open sandbox missions (e.g. Liberty Island) with multiple styles of approach, Invisible War had to make cuts wherever possible. The game was primarily developed for consoles which resulted in small areas obstructed with loading zones. Steam says I beat DE:IW in 12 hours (also completing every side quest and achieving every ending). Out of those 12 hours, around 2 are spent just waching loading bars. The game also likes to crash and doesn't like any OS other than Windows XP. Good luck getting this to work on Windows 7 and higher.

IW also cut corners in the augmentation system. In Deus Ex (2000) player had the option to augment various parts of their body (cranial, eyes, torso, arms, legs and subdermal). Some parts (e.g. torso) were able to hold up to 3 augments and each augment could be upgraded to level 4. Deus Ex (2000) on top of it featured upgradable skills like picklocking, hacking, swimming, melee damage etc. This allowed each player to create their own playstyle and build a character focused on stealth, a skilled hacker or a walking tank. IW simplifies the entire augmentation system. The skill tree is gone completely and Alex can now only hold 6 augments, each upgradable up to level 3, severely limiting freedom of player’s choice.

NPC AI isn‘t something to write home about. Enemies are sometimes able to spot you in pitch darkness and can hear your footsteps even while crouching and installing the „dampen your footsteps“ augment. This puts stealth players at disadvantage. Frankly, the only viable way to play is to rush enemies. Your character is 10x more powerful than any NPC anyway and bots can be shut down with a couple of EMP grenades. In Deus Ex (2000) JC was powerful too but only at later stages of the story and with proper augments. One shot from a sniper rifle could kill you instantly. In IW, you are showered with augmenation canisters during the tutorial mission.

The only redeeming factors of IW are the story and graphics. The story is very much in style with Deus Ex universe, intended for mature audiences. The globetrotting element is still present, you will visit cities like Seattle, Cairo and even Antarctica at one point. Smaller areas allowed developers to put greater detail in environment with dynamic lighting and shadows and realistic physics.

[b]PROS:[/b]
+ story
+ graphics

[b]CONS:[/b]
- gameplay limitations
- broken stealth system
- doesn’t run well on newer OS

[b]SUMMARY:[/b]
DE:IW is not a great starting point to the franchise. For that, I would suggest Human Revolution. If you are a fan and thirsty for a Deus Ex experience, give IW a go. However, you will have to jump a lot of obstacles.

67707495.review:
Invisible War is a HIGHLY controversial game. Made with love, yet with such significant flaws. At the first hours I wanted to drop it, but with patience I beat it and even tried 3 endings. The closer to the end, the more interesting it becomes.

Cons:
- I love Deus Ex for its cyberpunk, IW looks... much less like cyberpunk, more like usual sci-fi
- game is doing a bad job encouraging to play stealth, much easier just to shoot everybody
- badly made interface, bad interactivity
- awful graphics even for 2004; back then we've already had HL2 and Doom 3, there is no reason IW couldn't be on their level
- quite bad physics, many objects have no weight
- level design is very poor in many places, but not everywhere
- IMHO, boring side-quests with discouraging bounty; I sticked to the main story
- no consequences of your playstyle
- bad balance of power between AI and player: initially all AIs are dumb, running into the walls, bumping into each other,  shooting grenade launchers in the wall right in front of them; if you stand close to them they can miss with the flamethrower; but closer to the end there are armies of OP mobs just thrown at you and you lack of resourses to kill them (it's great for survivals but not here)

Pros: 
- good story, continuing one of the endings of the first part, but interest appears closer to the end
- locations from and references to the first part
- 4 endings
- AWESOME music in bars/night clubs
- somehow there can be some variety of gameplay, but the gameplay itself is sort of bad for the reasons above
- factions are present, sometimes (couple of times, actually) they're even fight between each other; you choose sides in some missions

IW could be one of the best games of 2004, but it isn't. It goes nowhere near Deus Ex 1, but I'm gonna leave my review as recommending just as a counterweight to mixed reviews and to encourage people to be patient with this game.

As the continuity of Deus Ex: 3/10
As the standalone game: 5.5/10

65423790.review:
I cannot recommend this game, even (and probably especially) for an original Deus Ex fan. 

The first problems stem from the severe technical issues that the game has. The game crashed on my computer (which is well above the baseline requirements), and when it did run it ran at a very low framerate. It also has no controller support, but granted the original Deus Ex didn't either (but you'd think it would have controller support since it was made for the Xbox). It's terribly optimized because, as aforementioned, it was made for the original Xbox with it's hardware limitations and controller scheme in mind. Design wise, the HUD is terrible and disorienting. It's super claustrophobic, and it reduces the field of view a ton. You're basically controlling Alex Denton through one of those small portholes that are in cheap cruise rooms.

If you're really into the story, just read up on it. You can obviously see that I haven't beat the whole game, but I've read up on it because I was a fan of the first Deus Ex and basically it's not nearly as good. The only really likable characters are Paul Denton and JC Denton, who miraculously is still a well written and intriguing character. If you really care about the story just go read it.

Everything feels very dumbed down. The roleplaying mechanics are simplified and streamlined (think from Elder Scrolls IV to V) in favor of making it more appealing to an FPS audience. Speaking of which, the shooting mechanics are also terrible. When you pull a gun out, it will flail around on your screen as you move (the guns are also surprisingly small). And shooting enemies is not fun at all; from the get go the firefights were very lame and involved standing almost still because I could barely maneuver with the bad field of view and HUD screaming at me to "Press F for flashlight" or "Press left mouse to shoot" every time I pulled my pistol out.

There's so many better games you can play.

TL/DR: It's original Deus Ex as a mediocre action movie. This game is for no one (FPS, RPG, original Deus Ex fans, newcomers, etc.)

65207837.review:
A prominent theme among the reviews I glanced through is that this game is a letdown/disappointment/disgrace compared to the original Deus Ex.  Many of the criticisms along that line are sensible; Invisible War does remove/change much of what made Deus Ex a great game (the realism, the RPG system, etc.).  However, the amount of angst this game attracts is unreasonable.

This is still a good, solid, playable game.  You have an RPG system in which you choose dialogue responses and can opt to side with several different factions (though I find it funny that you can side with any one of them right up to the very end of the game and that each one wants you to do so; you'd think one or two of these groups would have written you off as a possibility after you killed squad after squad of their troops).  I enjoyed the RPG elements, though I missed the skill system from the first game.  Combat was never a strength of the original; more so even than other Unreal Engine games, moving and shooting in Deus Ex was incredibly awkward; Invisible War is definitely more fluid; also, you start the game out being able to aim accurately, whereas in Deus Ex your crosshair wanders back and forth until you level up your aiming skills (y'know, because advanced cyborg agents who, by Walton Simons's account, cost 50 billion dollars would totally be sent out into the field without having been trained/upgraded to be deadly marksmen; granted, inflation by 2052 would make 50 billion worth 10-20 billion in today's dollars, but that's still pretty expensive).  The music for both games was composed by Alexander Brandon; interestingly, he took different approaches; the first game has very defined themes; the second has much more ambient, moody music.  I know some people dislike it, but I found it to be fine; it created a bit of a sense of wonder, thinking about what had become humanity in 2072 and how I could affect it.  

Just as in Deus Ex (and the BioShock series), the right combination of biomods will be OP as all hell.  Come at me world; I'm Alex Goddamn D.  

Probably the biggest criticism against Invisible War is the restrictive level design coupled with long loading times (loading times initiated by the game crashing itself and reopening in order to load the next zone).  I imagine those times must have been awful on machines at the time of release; nowadays they're pretty quick.  Still, perhaps the biggest strength of Deus Ex was how BIG and intricate it was, both in terms of story and level design.  Here, it's small and intricate.  This one has standing with fans because this change is a result of developing the game for the Xbox, a machine with RAM about equal to my TI-83 graphing calculator from high school; with the console plebs to blame for the downfall of their favorite game, the PC master race has stoned Invisible War with gusto ever since.  

Invisible War is different compared to Deus Ex; in some ways it is inferior, in some it is better.  I think it's a worthwhile game to play.  Also, this game has aged rather gracefully in terms of looks (besides the NPCs with their Marty Feldman eyes; they look a bit demented; that made me chuckle quite a bit while playing).  For a 2003 game, it holds up visually quite well.  Sure, it's not Half-Life 2 or PainKiller in terms of aging like Jennifer Connelly, but I find it a good-looking game today.

60908717.review:
***for the love of god install the Visible Upgrade: Unofficial Patch***
As a huge fan of the original I've tried to beat this game since it came out and proud to say 15 years later I finally did it. It took me a few hours to get over the chunky dead-eyed graphics and painful console interface but after I did I was surprised how similar it felt to the original. Sure the skill tree is completely gone and the biomods have been way stripped back (I ended up with a huge surplus by the end of the game) but it still feels very Deus Ex. Plenty of vents to crawl through and side missions to keep you occupied.

The universal ammo system was a controversial decision at the time but it does mean you can just use your favorite gun the entire game without worrying about having to switch to something else due to lack of ammo. Inventory space also feels very limited, especially considering there about 10 different types of grenades/mines available. Also the grenade throwing is horrible in this game, you throw everything about 100m and they bounce around like crazy, making it a total crap-shoot.

Faction-based quest system is pretty much what you'd expect except there is zero loyalty recorded throughout the game so can you consequence-free pick-up/drop faction quests whenever you like, right up until the final stage. The AI is also dumb as bricks. Shoot a guard with a silenced sniper rifle, anyone nearby will run to inspect the body. Repeat until you have a pile of corpses consisting of every guard in the area.

Also no-kill runs are basically impossible in this game due to these armored types that show up later in the game (there is no biomod to sneak past humans in this game, only bots), though from what I could tell it doesn't actually make any difference to the story or NPC interactions whether you kill or knockout people. 

In conclusion, if you are a fan of the original you owe it to yourself to suck up the first few hours and get to the good stuff, there's a kernel of a good game here. For those who have only played Human Revolution/Mankind Divided.. probably best to give it a miss.

55442309.review:
For many years, I wondered if the derision for this game was purely based on it being a follow up to one of the greatest PC games ever made or whether it was a decent game just not on par with the original. Well, after playing this game for myself several years ago and finishing it (somehow), I can say with confidence that 90% of the derision is justified.

This is not a good game, not by a long shot. It's no secret that all aspects of the gameplay have been simplified to the point that it feels like a budget FPS title. Levels are stupidly small and are literally a series of corridors and small rooms off them. The city hubs don't feel expansive enough at all. Highlight in terms of levels is Antarctica but even that place is dull in Deus Ex 2. 

The story was really uninteresting, until you meet JC Denton, suspended in ice and there he gives you an ultimatum for the story that really makes sense, at least for a well-thought out sci-fi world like Deus Ex. Suddenly, you are motivated to finish the game so his goal is realised. I guess the game is worth suffering through for that, but only if you really care about Deus Ex's story to begin with and not every did (the original's themes are another matter).

This game is, for the most part, painfully generic in terms of gameplay, boring in terms of world design and streamlined to the point of insanity. It is only worth playing if you cared about the main plot of the original and want to see closure to the Deus Ex story... assuming you side with JC at the end which you absolutely should because all the other factions in this game have misguided intentions in comparison. 

3/10, for the Deus Ex story fans only.

55238553.review:
A lot of people say this game is actually alright, but just disappointing after its monumental predecessor. It had too much to live up to. This is all wrong. The game's just shite. Even if it wasn't coming directly after Deus Ex, it would still be shite.

This game was released in a time after plenty of great immersive sims. It tries to be an immersive sim itself, but it shits on so many of the core concepts of the genre. Between being a technical mess and a creative mess, there's really not much to like.

A couple of huge bugs ruined the game for me. It took me a solid hour to just get the game running at 1920 x 1080, with a respectable field of view, good controls and the ability to play for more than a few minutes without crashes. Even after fixing this mess, I ended up causing another issue. Now the game wouldn't even boot from Steam. I had to launch it from its folder every time. Then, it started crashing badly enough to prevent any other programs from appearing over it. I had to keep a command prompt open with a 'taskkill' command in history just to shut the game down sometimes. At random times, the game might also just decide that a certain save you made is a bad save, and then crash the game every time you load it.

But sure, there's still a game underneath. What's it like? Kinda terrible. 

Augmentations (biomods) are limited severely. There are only five biomod slots, and the kind of abilities you could buy using skill points are locked to these biomods now. With only five slots, you're forced to choose between some basic abilities. If you want to be able to hack computers, you've gotta give up your cloaking ability. If you want to use spy drones, you have to give up the ability to regenerate. This wouldn't be so bad if certain biomods weren't absolutely essential to playing the game.

Cloaking and thermal masking are practically mandatory to even maintain a semblance of stealth. Even with those augs, stealth was usually impossible. Footsteps are far too loud. People will hear you crouch walking from about five meters away. There's a biomod to quiet your footsteps, but if you take that, you'll never be able to use any other biomods in that slot. Choose at the beginning of the game whether you want to be able to sneak or jump high. There's no middleground.

Without a proper skill point system, you basically decide on your character's "build" right at the beginning of the game. You're just as powerful at the beginning as you are at the end, except for a couple of upgrades to your augs. There's no character progression as you'd expect in an immersive sim. You're not building up to that point where you're unstoppable.

Ammo is also pretty weird. Every weapon in the game draws from a central pool of this abstract thing called "ammo". A top-secret, highly-experimental railgun uses the same ammo that your pistol does. A flamethrower uses the same ammo your pistol does. You might not be getting this concept, because it's really fucking strange. Imagine that your magazines are somehow telekinetically-linked across each weapon. If you fire one shot of your pistol then it'll also drain one shot from the magazines of all your other guns. Even flamethrowers. Fucking strange. And also there's no reload button...

Yeah, weird for that to be missing, right? I looked it up, too. There's just no way to reload. Since your magazines are shared across every weapon, you could fire three shots from your shotgun, then swap to your hitherto fully-loaded SMG to find that there's only one bullet left in its mag. Stupid system. Takes all the complexity away from managing ammo like in System Shock or the original Deus Ex. A designer actually looked at this and thought "yeah, that's good enough".

The story is interesting. Not good, not bad. It feels almost pointless, and alien to the world that the first game started to build. In true Deus Ex fashion though, it puts you in the middle of a couple of powerful people and asks you to consider which person is right.

No music, for some reason. You can make out faint whispers of an actual soundtrack in some places, but most of the game is just dead quiet. Coming from the original's monumental fucking two hour long soundtrack, this game's half hour soundtrack is just disappointing.

I guess there's some traces of Deus Ex in here, but ultimately it's just a frustrating mess that left me wanting to play the original again. There are a couple of other minor issues like not being able to enter keycodes or logins manually and the physics engine treating every object like it's made of feathers. You can't really stack objects and stand on them anymore.

It's really just an immersive sim and RPG with the trademark mechanics of those genres dumbed down or stripped out entirely.

54599791.review:
[h1]It’s Not That Invisible[/h1]

[b] Deus Ex Invisible War[/b] , for PC

Rating: [b] 8.7/10;[/b]  Great

Played: Feb 2019

Highly recommended for anyone who has played DX 1 or a later series entry.  DX 1 should be played before this game.


Deus Ex 2 takes place years after the events of the first game and is the same type of game; that being a story focused first person shooter with stealth and RPG elements.  Compared to the first game some elements have been simplified, particularly in the RPG department.

The largest and first noticed change is the complete removal of skills, and by extension XP.  You will no longer gain XP rewards for completing objectives and exploring.  Instead, all rewards are either: augments, money or items.  This gives less incentive to explore for those alternate paths (there are almost always multiple ways to get through an area and complete objectives).  The lack of skills also means that there is less variation in which alternate paths are suited for your build.  All weapons are used at the equivalent of master skill level and lockpicks and multitools have been merged into a single item, with each lock taking a fixed amount of tools to open.  Hacking has been changed into an augment.

The augment system is less complicated than the first game.  Whether or not it is better and more balanced is debatable, though I believe it to be an overall improvement.  Rather than having augment items fixed to specific slots, you are free to install them however you want.  Each slot has 3 options to choose from; one of which is always a black market option which requires a special black market canister that is entirely separate from the regular canister items.  The same items are also used to upgrade augments, so you can fully customize the order in which you obtain and level up your augments.  An interesting feature is that you can replace augments with others by using the canisters; a kind of respec.  

The inventory has been changed to a simple system where every item takes up a single slot; a rocket launcher and grenade take up the same amount of “space”.  This means you can carry more weapons but limits the amount of small consumable items that you would be able to carry in lieu of a variety of weapons.  There are 2 features that stand out: one is that food stacks in a single slot to a high number, such that a full stack of food might offer more healing than a full stack of med kits (I did not test this).  Like in Dx 1, you can simply pause the game to eat as much as you want to restore health, even in the middle of battle.  The other is that multi tools seem to come in 2 varieties that will not stack.  I suspect this is a coding holdover from the lockpicks and multitools from the first game; it is annoying and should not have made it past testing.

Most of the weapons from the original return and all guns have a Perfect Dark style alternate fire mode bound to right click, which are useful and fun to use.  The sniper rifle is the only weapon with any kind of aim down sight/scope, though there is nothing wrong with the gunplay.  All guns use the same ammo in varying amounts.  This feels like an actual futuristic innovation because universal ammo is tactically and logistically superior; kind of reminds me of the ammo blocks from Mass Effect.  Upgrades are stronger, often come with unique effects and multiple copies of the same cannot be installed.  Grenades and mines have alternate fire modes but otherwise lack the universal nature of ammo; each type of grenade and mine takes up an inventory slot making it difficult to carry a variety.

Stealth is a major focus of the game and has been improved from the first game.  Firstly, stealth is more difficult because your own footsteps can alert enemies, even while crouched.  This is more pronounced on hard surfaces (which are the most prevalent surface) and makes the move silently augment more valuable than it was in the first game.  Enemies will become suspicious and make comments on some unusual things, such as disabled cameras and turrets.  There was one time where I took out a guard and hid the body.  When another guard walked by he became suspicious, possibly because he could see the other guard’s dropped weapon and ammo.  This only happened a single time so I am not sure of how deep the stealth system actually goes.  I can say that the enemy AI is reasonably good.

Hacking is simplified from the previous game.  Computer passwords are treated more like physical keys in that you are not able to use a computer without first finding the password.  No guessing or looking up passwords outside the game.  I like this system better precisely because you can’t cheat by looking up the passwords!  The main structure of the levels and how the game plays is largely the same as the first game; there are plenty of optional things to do, multiple ways to complete objectives, actions that have repercussions later on and different factions to side with.  

Invisible War both simplifies and innovates upon Deus Ex while giving an overall similar gameplay experience.  Though there are a few bugs and steps backward, the only really lacklustre aspect of the game is its length, which is significantly shorter than both 1 and 3.


Pro
[list]
 [*]Great user customization for augment progression
 [*]Can climb up onto things like crates, and into vents that are not at floor level
 [*]All weapons use the same ammo pool, which gives a strong sense of future tech
 [*]Good story, setting, characters and voice acting
 [*]Alternate modes for each weapon/explosive
 [*]Levels and objectives with multiple routes
 [*]Good immersive enemy AI
 [*]Can mostly freely backtrack through current level and you choose when to progress to the next level
[/list]

Con
[list]
 [*]Fewer inventory spots for small items
 [*]Less keybinding options.  Unable to rebind some keys
 [*]Consumable items stack to small sizes (except food)
 [*]Some problems with items not combining into a single stack (multitools)
 [*]Ammo is displayed as a visual representation which is a little confusing
 [*]Bug where Omar trader npc mysteriously dies every time I enter the nightclub
 [*]Aiming down sniper rifle scope with vision augment on has much higher sensitivity
 [*]Augments do not display the effects of all upgrade levels (only the next upgrade level, which hurts planning ahead)
 [*]Every time you get an augment canister, an icon shows on the screen which will not go away until you go to the augment screen (even if you are entirely maxed out)
 [*]Seems to be some collision problems related to moving near robot corpses (feels like lag rubber banding)
 [*]Can go into inventory and freely use healing items
[/list]

54596605.review:
This is the type of game which is both kind of worth playing and is deserving most of the hate it gets from players.

Being a sequel to one of the best games ever made, this is significantly weaker in most aspects, but on its own it is pretty solid. What this mainly lacks in comparison to original is that it has a worse upgrade system, tinier areas and in general this game features constant loading screens. But worst of all is how glitchy this game is, starting from basic technical aspects like aspect ratio, okay, I can play in the square, but after each loading screen it kills my recording software from recording as well as force my PC's default screen resolution as game's... It's somewhat annoying that everytime i quit the game I have to go to settings and change screen resolution back to normal. Also, game sometimes crashes, luckily in my case only about 5 times in my whole playthrough, so it's acceptable.

Then there are in-game glitches, there are dozens of them. Starting from minor ones like side NPCs dialogue skips, dialogues with no sound, different dialogue being said than what's in subtitles, dialogue sound shifting between louder and more silent.
And then there are major ones... Climbing ladders and stairs is broken, you sometimes can get stuck on them or get insane slow-downs in your speed, sometimes you can climb stairs and get stuck a bit under floor and in such occasion the only fix is to get back to the stairs or you'll walk 5x slower. Same with ladder, you climb and suddenly get 5x slower you get back to normal when you finish climbing, but you can't even jump off, you have to climb up the whole way. Another annoying glitches include physics that fire the me off if i climb on them. But worst of all is that inventory is broken, sometimes it lets me pick items when the inventory is full and the item is then forever gone to the unknown. Also, a few times the game made all of my food supply just disappear after getting to a new area, it only happens with food though (and that is very lucky, because it would be even more awful if I lost my guns or something more important), but it happened 3 or 4 times... I lost about 70-90 food items in total...

Besides everything, in later game the enemy health becomes ridiculously huge, I know I'm supposed to be stealthy, but you can't even do stealthy takedows since their health is too big to take them down unnoticed.

But even though the game is quite broken from start to finish it is still worth playing because gameplay is quite fun, stealth and exploration are pretty great, but what really shines is the story and missions. How many of the side and main missions are connected and tangled with each other is truly great writing. You can make plenty of different choices throughout the game and there are some consequences for them.
Overall it's a mixbag of a game, but for me the positives outweighs the negative.


7/10

54467759.review:
Invisible War is a direct sequel to Deus Ex 1, a highly praised installment of the series. Unfortunately, it's steeped in many infamous flaws which seek to downright ruin the game for Deus Ex fans, and people who stumble upon it in particular alike.

It took me two years after my Deus Ex 1 playthrough to finally get around to playing it's heavily divided, and controversial sequel. After finishing the game, I can definitely see why people don't mind this game, and also why people hate this game with all of their heart.

Invisible War strips away so many mechanics, depth, and other things people loved about the first game. It is horrendously butchered in many areas, and over-simplified. As far as I know, the game was developed as an [b]original Xbox release[/b], with it's PC version feeling like a port of their game developed specifically for a console. Deus Ex as a series has been on consoles before the prequels. Deus Ex 1 found it's way on the PS2 as "Deus Ex: The Conspiracy", a few years before this game's release. However, although the PS2 port was minorly dumbed down to put on a console, It wasn't built for a console from the ground up. Invisible War unfortunately, carries that stench that's immediately obvious as soon as you see the game's UI for the first time. Console limitations are very much abundant. 

The gameplay is still in it's own way, Deus Ex. Just unfortunately, it all comes together to feel watered down to myself, and probably most people considering this game's negative reputation. Invisible War still has augmentations, weapon upgrades, and different approaches to problems. Areas are also much smaller than you'd expect (most likely because of the weird limitations stuff). It's definitely enjoyable and playable, if you set your mind to it.

The story is alright, although littered with info dumps that feel lazy & rushed. I preferred the lategame story rather than the early to midgame story. It ramps up really well, and the different endings are still great like you'd expect in a Deus Ex game.

This specific steam release is hot garbage. I started up the game and was greeted with a beautiful cursed resolution of 10x10 (not literally 10x10 but it was one of the lowest ive ever seen my desktop go to). What you need to do to fix that, is download the "Deus Ex 2 Visible Upgrade" mod. It implements many QoLs to make the game run on modern systems, while also containing a texture update pack that was lost to time. Here's a link to said mod. [b]https://www.ttlg.com/forums/showthread.php?t=147423[/b]

All in all, it's enjoyable if you go in without high expectations, and if you wait a while like I did after a Deus Ex 1 playthrough.

I haven't played the mobile port "The Fall", so I can't tell you if I enjoy this over that. But I can tell you that this is the weakest link in comparison to Deus Ex 1, Human Revolution, and Mankind Divided. Love it or hate it, it's at the ass-end of the timeline, and worth a playthrough if you've played every other good Deus Ex game.

* Mapas laberínticos, al principio te dará un derrame encontrar los objetivos de las misiones (en especial porque no hay mini mapa que te diga donde está el objetivo), pero luego de un rato y prestar mucha atención en las indicaciones le agarrás la mano.
* Sistema de munición universal bastante cutre, las armas no tienen recargas, los códigos de puertas están al pedo porque no hace falta introducir ningún número para acceder, solo click derecho.
* Para poner una resolución alta hay que modificar el archivo "user.ini" ubicado en donde se guardan las partidas.
* Aparecen personajes de la entrega anterior con las mismas voces.
* Al principio la historia empieza aburrida, luego se pone interesante y finaliza aburrida.
* Los enemigos desde el principio hasta los escenarios finales son fáciles, luego de un mapa al otro aparecen de la nada nuevos que son muy duros de matar y te sacarán canas, en especial en la última misión.
* La carga de los mapas es muy chota, para ir de un lugar a otro el juego se minimiza, carga la nueva zona y vuelve al juego.
* Sistema de apuntado muy nefasto.
* El juego me duró 7hs 45min haciendo todas las misiones (secundarias y primarias) y desbloqueando todos los finales, debido a la implementación del parche para traducirlo al español, el juego no me contó las demás horas.
* El título viene en inglés, para traducirlo hay que descargar el siguiente parche [url=parche]http://deusex-es.blogspot.com/2013/01/parche-para-traducir-deus-ex-invisible.html[/url]
* Menos aumentos y solo te sirven 2-3, los demás están de relleno.
* A diferencia de la entrega anterior, no existen puntos de aptitud para mejorar apartados como curación, armas pesadas, pirateo y demás, esto además de hacer al juego incompleto, no te insentiva a explorar.
* Para piratear ordenadores hay que instalarse un aumento especial, de lo contrario tenés que conseguir el código de acceso.
* Las físicas son bastantes dudosas, a veces si saltas en determinados objetos pegas un salto que llegas a la luna.
* Gráficos horribles en comparación a la entrega anterior, lo cual es bastante deprimente. 
* Podés conseguir una gran cantidad de aumentos durante la campaña, no solo para ponerte al máximo todos sino también para que te queden sobrando.

53318958.review:
Great immersive sim. The original is one of my favorite games of all time but I'd actually say this is the 2nd best in the franchise (haven't played MD). This game is a great fit for the right audience.

Cons:
- Everything feels kind of soft. Graphics have a soft feel, level designs and objects are beveled or rounded, the tactile "feel" of combat is soft. (Although combat is still satisfying in its way.)
- Areas are made of many small zones. Game was also released for Xbox so they had to build for that.
- Somewhat short. But for $7 I'd definitely say its worth it.

Pros:
- Writing. Writing. Writing. Especially if you're looking for subtle, realistic, intelligent writing. It's practically as good as the original. (DE:IW had the same lead writer.) Almost every NPC has a subtle and complete personality; they're not going to tell you their life story because people don't actually do that with strangers. But you can feel it. You're meant to read between the lines. And what they say - and how they say it - isn't designed to spoon-feed the player with simple lessons, easy morals, or simple caricatures. Nor does it make a point of showing "How People Can Be Complex". They're not complex and subtle to make a point, they're complex and subtle because real people are. And the intelligent characters actually speak and act as intelligent characters. The characters who are supposed to be skilled deceivers are likely to deceive you (compare Human Revolution where Taggart sounds obviously superficial). Nor does the game pick one theme that dominates almost every quest and conversation (compare Human Revolution where people hardly talk about anything besides augmentation). This kind of subtlety and realism isn't what everyone wants in a game; that's totally fine. But if it's what you're looking for then this game (and the original) are top-of-class. Said another way: the lead writer got a degree in math from MIT and English from Harvard, simultaneously. IF you want to interact with characters written by someone like that, when the writer is not holding back, then check this game out.
- Plot/Story, separate from characters. The plot holds up quiet well. The plot makes sense with the world they've set up. Things are thought through. Almost every fiction (book/film/game etc) has plot holes but some fictions, like this one, have few. There are some story elements or character actions that didn't make sense to me but years later I understood them. The drama isn't tacked-on or manufactured by emotional NPCs telling you that something matters; if you're paying attention you will learn on your own how important the events of the game world are to the people in it. The world is consistent and the consequences are logical.
- Acting is pretty good, honestly. It's frequently subtle and restrained, however. This is by design but it's not to everyone's taste. (Personally I like it.)

In summary, really great immersive sim. Has a somewhat strange, soft feel to it; in a retrospective interview the developers said they made the mistake of listening to the people who disliked the original. So where the original is extremely sharp and open, this game is soft and closed-in. But the core essence of the original Deus Ex is very much alive in the sequel.
