51487122.review:
So, I eventually came across Invisible War after gaining every ending in the original Deus Ex. The Mixed Reviews status this game has threw me off for a moment, but I wanted to figure out why it was in this state.

and god frickin darn it i should have stayed away from this game

First, the story felt pale in comparison to Deus Ex, or otherwise known as the GOTY Edition on Steam.
Game was built to fit both the PC and Xbox (big mistake) so that may or may not have led into issues within the PC version of the game... notably, the size of the locations throughout the game. I felt so crunched in with every world, it actually made me feel claustrophobic.
Crash issues out the ass. At first, I thought it was due to the weapons, specifically the SMG, firing on my screen all at once. Then, I began running into crashes in the lower Antarctica, even in the Arcology in Cairo which I had no idea why. I can't tell what it's all about.
Soundtrack was really, really, REALLY boring to me. Not a single track (besides the licensed ones from Kidneythieves) appealed to me at all.
Weapon mods were nerfed.
Storage space nerfed, too.
Biomods, though a neat change with upgrading, kinda felt lackluster.
Besides Tong, Chad and Nicolette, we don't even know what happened to the remaining cast of Deus Ex. No Jacobson, no Reyes, no Jock.
Oh, and I pretty much let everyone Alex knew from the Academy die. Klara, Leo, and Billie, all on my first playthrough. To be fair, they dawned onto me as pretty bland characters. Besides Leo, he's kinda alright.

Oh, and I also fell off the map and to my death in that Germany map because I collided with a fucking box.

That's pretty much all I can say about this game, really. I was expecting a bit more from this sequel, but all I got in return was disappointment. Not the worst game, though - I've seen worse. Just wait for Invisible War to go on discount, like it is right now when I write this on the Steam Summer Sale of '19. Unless you took note from the other reviews on this page, avoid this at all costs.

51424104.review:
Horrible game, nothing like the first one.

* Story: Too complicated, Cringy and very barebones.The first game did a good job explaining the story and it was actually interesting. In Invisible war, you just don't care about anyone, kill them all and stuff them in dumpsters.

* Music: The music is almost non exsistant, in some parts it remixes the music from the first game, or adds generic ambient sound, nothing memorable.

* Gameplay: Extremly dumbed down, 12 slots to store items, by the end of the game you have thousands of credits that you have no use for since you reach max upgrades too fast. Lockpicking and Electronics bypassing is now a single tool. Bio mods are few and uninteresting. Ammo is a single universal meter, completely removing everything that made the first game interesting, stripping all the details of the world. 

Overall its an extremly dumbed down game, you walk trough boring corridors troughout the whole game with a ton of loading screens, talk to boring characters. Only good thing is the ragdoll physics, to throw corpses around in creative ways.

51416420.review:
Video game consoles. Those cute little beasts that are responsible for the death of the [b]AAA[/b] PC gaming as we used to know it. When you hear “bad port” nowadays, it usually means things like low [b]FPS[/b] and other technical stuff. While the game itself stays pretty much the same on all platforms. But it wasn't always like that. Back in the days, when they wanted the game to be represented on both PCs and consoles, very often they've made two drastically different versions. Up until some smartass appeared and said: “Hey! Let's just make one version for all systems! It'll save us a lot of money!”. And that was when s***t hit the fan. The thing is – even though both consoles and computers are totally cool in their own way, they are completely different by their nature. Just look at [b]DCS World[/b] and [b]Ace Combat[/b]. Both are a lot of fun, but... it's a different kind of fun. For different people / different needs. Computers allow more complicated gameplay, while consoles are famous for more basic, but addictive fun. Unfortunately, when the “big change” began, a lot of the complicated PC titles were downgraded to consoles' level and became pretty dumb. And [b]Deus Ex[/b] was one of those.

The original [b]Deus Ex[/b] was ported to [b]PS 2[/b], but it took a lot of effort to achieve that. And when it was time to make sequel, [b]ION STORM[/b] was no longer able to afford such things. Suffering the consequences of [b]Anachronox[/b]' poor sales, both [b]John Romero[/b] and [b]Tom Hall[/b] (founders of the company) have left, closing their main office in [b]Dallas[/b]. [b]Warren Spector[/b] and his [b]Austin[/b] team stayed, but... even though the new game got much bigger budget for things like fully voiced dialogues, they were unable to focus on the PC version of the game with the console port coming “sometime later” (the original [b]Deus Ex[/b] appeared on PS2 only two years after the initial release). They needed [b]Deus Ex 2[/b] on both PCs and consoles. At the same time. And the result... well... you can easily imagine what happened here. Almost exactly the same thing that happened with [b]The Elder Scrolls[/b] series after [b]Morrowind[/b].

First of all, the game has [i]a lot[/i] of loading screens now. And as the result, feels way, [i]way[/i] worse than the original. In the original game we had big maps and we were able to fully explore them without all those nasty loadings. Here? It's like a loading screen after the every few minutes. Doesn't feel as bad nowadays, since hardware became more powerful, but back in the days? It was a disaster. And here's a question for you – why should people, who invested in their gaming PCs suffer just because some other people only paid for consoles? The answer is, of course, money. But OK. Maybe we can at least plug in the gamepad and enjoy the game in the consoles way? Sure, it's a different thing now, but maybe it'll be fun with the gamepad? Unfortunately, like many other multiplatform games from that period, [b]Deus Ex 2[/b] have a lot of problems with gamepads. I've tried [b]Logitech Rumblepad 2[/b] ([b]Direct Input[/b]), I've tried [b]Logitec F510[/b] (both [b]Direct Input[/b] and [b]XInput[/b]), I've tried wired [b]Xbox 360[/b] controller and I've tried the [b]Xbox One[/b] controller. Neither of them worked properly. Even though there's a juicy rumble feature in options. So, yeah, good luck getting a full experience here. Did I mention that the PC version also crashes quite a lot? Well, it does. Enjoy the inferior experience for far higher price, PC users.

But enough about technical stuff. What's about the game itself? Well, obviously, we're stuck with the gamepad-oriented interface that doesn't feel good with keyboard / mouse combo. But unfortunately, it isn't the worst thing about this game. Every single aspect of the original [b]Deus Ex[/b] became worse. The locations became smaller and feel much more dull and straightforward. Even the famous lock system was dumbed down. Some doors just can't be hacked now and require the right combination. And you can't just input the combination anymore. You'll need to find it. Sure, the original [b]Deus Ex[/b] allowed players to “cheat” by using the guide to get all those juicy codes, but [i]it was freakin' fun to be able to do that![/i] It was [i]fun[/i] to say “Nah, I'm not looking for your codes, I'm a bad, bad hacker and I'll hack the heck of your big and important door!” Sorry, won't happen with some doors now. Because linear crap. The entire skill system also disappeared and not only the game won't reward you for the exploration (there's hardly something to explore anyway, just some basic choices between the doors and the ventilation shafts), most of the side-quests feel like a waste of time and resources. Stealth doesn't worth it either, since the game feels more like an advanced [b]FPS[/b] now.

Maybe it's good as an [b]FPS[/b], though? Nope. Sorry, guys. [b]Deus Ex 2[/b] introduces two things that pretty much ruin it as an [b]FPS[/b]. First – there's one ammo to rule 'em all. All weapons use the same exact ammo. Just the different amount of it. No matter what you'll use – a poison dart, or the rocket launcher. It'll be the same exact ammo. Which is stupid. To say the least. But maybe, just maybe, it is fun? [i]NOPE[/i]. Because there's a second thing – it's freakin' hard to get the ammo in this game! And even enemies will not always drop it! The right combination of the biomods (yes, they're calling 'em like that now, because it's shorter) would help, but there's no way to guess what you'll need without reading the guise and with no respec option, it's totally possible to end up at the end of the game with just a sword against squads of the guys with rocket launchers. So much for the balance...

The story is not the worst thing here, though. It's a direct sequel to the original [b]Deus Ex[/b], it takes place 20 years later and it follows the merging with [b]Helios[/b] ending. The game even introduces a pretty neat “everything is a lie” idea that will later be used in [b]Arkane Studios[/b]' [b]PREY[/b]. Unfortunately, there's still a lot of things that went wrong. First, instead of using the dark and realistic design of the original [b]Deus Ex[/b], the [b]Invisible War[/b] decided to be... like [b]Ghost in the Shell[/b]. Even by looking at cover, you can't help but ask yourself: “What the heck is this anime-like crap?”

The good thing, though, is that you'll be able to make a lot of choices. Pretty much every map have some. The bad thing, though... nothing in this game matters. Except of what will happen on the final map. Before that point – you're free to do whatever you want. And it doesn't feel as good as you may think. Quite the opposite. It feels [i]awful[/i]. Just because without the consequences, it feels like nothing you do matters. [i]That's[/i] the sequel to the game, in which even visiting the wrong restroom used to have consequences? I don't think so. Add pretty stupid writing, full of cheesy lines, ridiculously bad journal, which fails to explain the goals very often and the fact that the game can't even get its own crap together (sometimes it'll claim you've made choices that you didn't make) and you'll get the idea that it's really hard to enjoy the story here. Even though the initial idea and the endings (at least we still have multiple endings here) are not that bad.

So, yeah... [b]Deus Ex: Invisible War[/b] was one of those titles that came out between two eras and suffered just because of that. Not only it sucked as both [b]Deus Ex[/b] sequel and a good PC title, it also sucked as a console game. Sure, it's this game we should thank for the fact that [b]Thief: Deadly Shadows[/b] turned out to be OK. [b]Deus Ex: Invisible War[/b] was like the first try. But still, it's really, [i]really[/i] hard to like it. Because, as you can see, there are way too many things that speak against it.

51096975.review:
Deus Ex: Invisible War is story-wise, the final part of the Deus Ex series. Despite the hate, I still find this game quite okay and enjoyable to play. Non-lethal knockouts are easier than the first game, and they added some super wonky ragdolls. You can also customize Alex's sex and skin color, and you can choose one of the opposing factions near the end of the game. Though I dislike the fact that they really limit our augmentations, while making the upgrade canisters easier to find. DX:IW feels like a dumbed-down sequel to the original. The maps are very small and claustrophobic, unlike the big open areas of the first game. The story is also considerably shorter, though to be honest it's not that bad. There's no code-entering function like the first game, instead you have to find the code somewhere or use a multitool.

The biggest problem of this game, though, is not the game itself, but rather the optimization. DX:IW has a very small screen resolution, and if you try to enlarge it by modifying user.ini, the screen gets cropped. One way to fix is by downloading this mod: https://www.moddb.com/mods/deus-ex-2-visible-upgrade. The game also closes and reopens automatically if you load another map/older save, which is kinda annoying if you're using a guide, since it closes the Steam Overlay.

I went in with super low expectations and was very pleasantly surprised.  The fun "immersive sim" gameplay is still here, climbing through vents, hacking things, finding multiple ways to deal with situations, talking to people - Some of it has been simplified for the console controls but there was still plenty of variety and things to discover and explore.  The story was interesting with twists and multiple endings, the voice acting was solid with some memorable characters and although the areas were narrow initially they opened up later on in the game.  

I would definitely give it a go if you liked other entries in the series despite all the negativity around it, just don't expect it to be exactly the same as the first game, or the prequels.

On a side note, definitely get the "Deus Ex 2 Visible Upgrade" patch though (there is one with and one without enhanced textures) as it adds widescreen support and fixes some bugs!

49801317.review:
*some spoilers of the original Deus Ex ahead*

I am giving a thumbs up mainly to counter all of the criticism that this game receives. It doesn't stand up to the original Deus Ex. That is for sure but it isn't THAT bad. 

Full disclosure: this was the first Deus Ex game that I finished (I played the original but didn't finish even the first mission and ended up kicking myself later for not finishing quite possibly one of the greatest games of all time). I had good memories of Invisible War because I wasn't comparing it to the original Deus Ex.

I still maintain that the storyline is pretty good. IMO, that is the single most important aspect to any type of RPG and I think they at least got that right. Most of the characters were pretty good. They got me to care about them so that is good. Meeting NG Resonance gave me a chuckle. I liked Klara and Leo but I wish there were more interactions with them. Their characters could have been expanded a bit.

As much as I liked Human Revolution and even Mankind Divided, I really prefer the concept of biomodification to that of mechanical augmentations. Maybe it's just nostalgia from the older games but I just think it is a cooler concept. I didn't like the concept of not being able to use multiple biomod categories but that didn't really bother me all that much.

Hands down, my biggest criticism is the universal ammo system. WTF is that? I want to know who suggested that this would be a good idea. Being designed for consoles was a big downfall to this game. As others have said, the maps were small and simplistic. This is subjective, but another criticism for me is having the canon ending from Deus Ex as the Helios ending. That ending was by far my least favorite. I preferred Tracer Tong's ending. The Helios ending didn't really fit with JC's libertarian proclivities. Should have been Tong's ending or even the Illuminati ending. Speaking of endings, I didn't really care for Invisible War's endings. I felt like a jerk for killing a certain character but I don't like their ending so I do it every time.

Summary: I suggest buying this game with an understanding of a few things:

-Invisible War is good but not great

-The game has a great story and cool characters if you don't compare it to the original

-The game mechanics and level design suck. Accept it. Just try to enjoy other aspects of the game.

-The graphics have not aged well but the same can be said of the original Deus Ex and you can't call yourself a Deus Ex fan until you have played the original

There really needs to be a sequel to this game. Having the series end on a game that was rather average seems like a slap in the face to the franchise.

49735162.review:
Estamos ante un buen juego. No llega al nivel del 1 ni por asomo, pero tampoco es una absoluto desastre como dice la masa de fans fervientes del primer Deus Ex. La historia parte de una conjunción de los tres finales de Deus Ex 1 y a partir de ahí manejamos a Alex, que tendrá que ir resolviendo una trama política y de conspiración entre varias facciones para acabar decidiendo el destino de la humanidad.

Puntos buenos y malos de este juego.

Positivos:
-Historia y ambientación, aunque no tan buena como en el primer juego, menos sorprendente y con personajes más encasilllados.

Neutrales:
-La jugabilidad tiende más a la acción que en Deus Ex1, pero el juego te permite seguir siendo muy sigiloso si es lo que quieres
-Gráficos: con el mod Visual Upgrade, a dia de hoy se puede jugar sin que te de un ictus una vez te acostumbras. La iluminación no esta mal para la época, pero los modelados y caras de personajes creo que dejan bastante que desear.

Negativos:
-Mecánicas simplificadas: misma munición para todas las armas y recarga automática, simplificación del apartado rolero quitando los puntos de habilidad y dejando solo las biomodificaciones, menos caminos para cumplir los objetivos.
-Escenarios muy reducidos: Deus Ex 1 se caracterizaba por tener unos escenarios gigantes sin apenas tiempos de carga, un hito para la época. En esta secuela nos encontramos con escenarios mucho más reducidos y con demasiadas molestas pantallas de carga. Al parecer es por una limitación tecnológica del motor gráfico utilizado. Esto provoca también que tengamos menos caminos para llegar al mismo objetivo.

En definitiva, es un buen juego (sin alardes) eclipsado totalmente por su predecesor. Como cuesta dos duros en rebajas pruébalo si te gusto Deus EX y si no te convence lo mandas a paseo.

48719834.review:
It ain't that bad. But it ain't that good. 

So, DX:IW was made with consoles in mind. As a result, we've had a lot of weird design decisions and compromises: universal ammo (your pistol and your shotgun now share the same ammo!), the world's worst inventory system where your medkits are now as big as your laser sword, the game now doesn't punish you for choosing weird augments too. There's no skill points -- just augmentation levels.

The maps are chopped up into tiny little pieces instead of being huge, intricately designed mazes that reward you for exploration. 

The aesthetic of the game is some early 2000s ugliness, but what do you expect when baggy jeans and frosted tips were the in thing? Alex Denton either looks like a stretched 100x100 image of an anime girl or a lumpy clay gorilla with spiky hair. The guns in the game are no longer as grounded as they once are. The scenario of the game is still undoubtly cyber punk, but the aesthetic feels like schlocky sci-fi. Floating robots? Come on dawg. The OG DX didn't even play with any of that. 

It does some things kind of okay. Like the being able to switch augment paths mid-playthough (seriously, you get augmentation canisters like fucking candy in this game), it's a really short game so you can easily do multiple playthroughs if you want (if you're on crack). 

You don't have to wait 10 seconds to steady your pistols despite you being a genetic super agent! But that's like the only thing I really kind of appreciate. Combat still feels wonky as hell and it doesn't have that visceral feeling of doinking somebody with a 10mm pistol that the original DX had.

I've played way worse games.

Oh yeah, and there's literally no reloading. God, it took me like an hour to realize this. I was just looking at the keybind screen and I was just so confused.

48388410.review:
It's easy to call this the red-headed stepchild Deus Ex of the franchise. I would implore that it be thought of as a spinoff rather than "Deus Ex 2" but it [i]does[/i] follow up on the events of the first Deus Ex - which harms its expectations by making it a deliberate successor. I'd only recommend playing it if you want to see a more conclusive culmination of what effects the ending of the first Deus Ex had on the world, of which it provides in gratuitous amounts. It took me a leisurely 25 hours to finish (and would be much shorter for "normal" people) so it's not a game that overstays its welcome.

A solid spinoff, but a bad sequel.

Here's some bullet points of my most obvious observations of the game. This is written for people looking to compare Deus Ex 1 against Invisible War, in order to temper their expectations.

[h1]Pro's[/h1]
• Play fully voice-acted male or female protagonist.
• A few more interesting weapon mods. EMP ammo, explosive rounds, and glass despirsal rounds that can break glass without triggering alarms.
• Human NPCs in combat do more than just stand around waiting for you to shoot them; they can effectively use flashbangs and will side-roll.
• Grenades have an alternate "on contact" detonation, rather than just timed.


[h1]Subjective[/h1][i]if you're a diehard DX1 fan, most (or all) of these will be Cons.[/i]
• Inventory is slot-based rather than grid-based. Food items stack regardless of what they are.
• Ammunition is universal across all weapons, though some use it more efficiently than others.
• No lockpicks. Multitools have adopted their utility. You'll automatically equip a multitool when interacting with a secured object.
• Augmentations are obtained and upgraded with one canister resource, the exception only being "black market" biomods.
• Some augmentations are passive and don't drain energy, like Move Silent (Silent Run from DX1). Eye lights won't drain energy either.
• No skills or skill points. I have mixed feelings for this, which is why it isn't a Con. On one hand, it removes traditional RPG elements and delegates the remaining scraps to augmentations, and also removes the "reward" system of getting skill points from exploring. On the other hand, DX1's RPG system was frankly just a series of flawed artificial road bumps/shortcuts, rather than a true RPG system. It either needed to be revamped from the ground up or just cut out, and Invisible War chose the latter.


[h1]Cons[/h1][i]parts I thought were outright worse in comparison to DX1.[/i]
• A main menu built to be used by controllers. ie, select options on one side of a reticle, and options appear on the other side of the reticle.
• No corner leaning, probably a limitation of the Xbox controller which this game was made for.
• No walk toggle, only hold Shift to walk.
• No locational hp, just a singular health bar.
• Can't add notes to your datavault images or create new note entries.
• Objective tracking menu is atrocious; you can only view one at a time.
• You can't input keycodes manually; you need to obtain the code. I liked it in DX1 for the "immersive" factor, and I imagine speedrunners prefer it too.

47672176.review:
You play as "Alex D", a male or female character of your choice and you start off in the game as a expert trainee for a program called "Tarsus". The first room is your apartment and straight away there’s a terrorist attack, flinging you straight into the storyline. The player travels to a number of different locations throughout the game, such as Cairo, Antarctica and Seattle, noticeably showing the impressive level design.
At times there are literally half a dozen ways to complete even a simple objective, and the only limits seem to be your imagination and the equipment you happen to be carrying- excellent. Some very fundamental changes are evident in the skills and augmentation systems too - biomod canisters can be installed in one of 5 slots, each of which corresponds to an area of the body, and can hold either an official or black market biomod. The abilities they give tend to influence your style of play far more than in Deus Ex, and this is a good thing in my opinion.
The plot is a little loose at the beginning, but progresses smoothly, and with superb realism. There is a great sense of freedom in your actions, and no matter what you do, the game has been designed to react accurately, and characters will often refer back to decisions you made several levels ago - this is impressive and creates a real sense of cause and effect. There are dozens of missions which are not crucial to the story, but carry rewards of equipment, money or information, and these seem a natural part of the game, rather than a tacked on extra.

47598958.review: I really like it. I played Deus Ex 1 many times and this is not the same ofc, but still a very nice game and I enjoyed the story and playing it.

47556772.review:
A walking disaster of a game. And not just in comparison to somewhat overrated original.

An engine that barely supports itself, the physics going woopity-woop-woop easily and game crashing sometimes. Game employed high-end lighting while also being designed for XBox which resulted in tiny levels. Tiny to the point where epic locations are just few small rooms. Stealth being wonky because devs implemented "you make more noises on certain surfaces" like in Thief but failed to give the proper sound feedback for you to judge this. More gamey interaction than original's sim like. Boring sci-fi world where nano is like magic. Fails to provide a good illusion of consequences of your actions. You get all the stuff by the middle of a game while having lotsa money. Side quests mostly make you a bad person and have a gamey feel to them, people just giving you them just because. Enemies felt more bullet-spongy, which is due to bad combat feedback and just not exciting combat mechanic. Stealth is just Gordon Freeman Air Duct Crawling simulator mostly. And oh god, universal ammo, which I found to be so much more horrible than any kind of regenerative health or other things. Who needs multiple backup weapons. You run out of ammo, you are left with no ranged backup weapon. It sure makes the game so much less strategic on FPS side.

Not to say that it doesn't have good spots. I liked that your character can finally shoot straight from a start. I also liked how they simplified augmentations and skills into one small fancy system which still allows you to specialize and make fun combos. I also liked few parts of setting such as AI of a celebrity acting like a surveliance bot.
Not to mention that you can set penguins on fire.

Also, if you ARE going to the game, install a fan-patch "visible update". Also, don't make saves until you leave the academy, it crashed for me otherwise when I tried to exit that location.

None the less, all the combination of flaws make it extremely unappealing game to go through. I wish it was invisible.

45591024.review:
[h1] Here's my review for Invisible War, finally. [/h1]

Kind of sad that this is the last game (Excluding Project: Snowblind) in the series that actually feels like Deus Ex.
I'm an outlier in this community, I love Invisible War, but not as much as DX1. It has a mysterious story, standard gameplay, augs, character customization, and more. 

[h1] So, Why is this game hated so much? [/h1]

It's hated so much because it's what people wanted; hear me out.
People back in 2000 thought the ammo system was too confusing, so they dumbed it down in the sequel.
People thought the text was too complex; dumbed down.
People thought the story was hard to follow; dumbed down
See where I'm going here? It's the fans fault we got the problems in this game.
But the loading screens, the devs fault, since they wanted to put this game on the Xbox before PC.
Also, I don't know why the music isn't as good as DX1, but the main theme is still awesome.

[h1] This game won't run on my pc!! [/h1]
Download the visible upgrade patch and play in windowed mode. You know that it works if it opens up a new window after a loading screen.

In conclusion, 3rd best Deus Ex game (imo).

45322311.review:
After about six hours of playing - which got me through to Cairo - I just couldn't go on. This game feels SO bargain basement when compared to the fantastic original. Actually, compared to most games. If there was ever a textbook example of "dumb down for consoles" this would be it. Everything that gave the original DX its character has been stripped out in the name of "streamlining." It's amazing that the same people worked on DX2 as the original as it really feels like they palmed it off onto the work experience kids.

Combat is dull, the voice acting sounds like everyone is bored, the missions range from so-so to mundane (a coffee shop war? Seriously?) and absolutely none of the characters are likeable. Even the graphics are ugly, with the three-years-older original looking much better than this trash. Seriously, if this is the future just let it burn!

I really hope we get at least ONE good game set AFTER the events of DX1 is, preferably even eradicating Invisible War from canon. I consider the original Deus Ex to be my favourite game of all time, one I have completed many, many times over. As such I really want to see proper service given to JC and the events of DX1, but IW makes him out to be as bad those he was fighting.

A true definition of disappointing sequel, if you really want to know what happens in this game you'd be far better hitting up the wiki and reading about it rather that putting yourself through this crap.

44696987.review:
Well it's painful to revisit nostalgia sometimes, and this is one such example.

The game was not the best game even at the time it came out. However it introduced some good philosophical musings typical for the Deus Ex series (particularly NG resonance who has the best dialogue). There are unfortunately some bizarre plot points and some very wooden characters. It's still a Deus Ex game though, but it just can't reach it's predecessor's lofty standards.

The plot gets more awkward and weird the more you go through with it, and the clunky and dreadful game engine was pretuned for consoles of the day. The physics in the game engine becomes hilariously rubber-bandlike as objects get stuck in walls and there are plenty of fourth-wall-breaking moments of pure comedy where it just doesn't belong because of this. The horrible presentation means that your belief is suspended for so long it may as well be Wile E Coyote hanging over a cliff waiting for gravity to kick in. 

I remember the game being a lot better than this - even though it was not great at the time - but time has not been kind to it at all. We're used to so much more from our games these days. Your state-of-the-art graphics card will laugh at you for playing this and it will probably run it too fast anyway.

There's still a fun game in here if you don't expect too much from it - like enjoying a badly directed film as a perverse pleasure - or finding fun ways to exploit game engines. Given it's cheap price - and when all is said and done - it will run perfectly fine on your old potato computer. Plus you get to find out how the world of the Deus Ex story ends up, as this is chronologically the last game in the series. One thing you can say about one of the endings though is that it predicted Facebook.

This is an enjoyable game. It's not a great Deus Ex game, no, but if you treat it like an expansion to Deus Ex, it's good. Pick it up if it's cheap and you can get it to run on your system.

On Win7/64 with Visible Upgrade patch it runs perfectly stable at a 2560x1440 or whatever. I think it crashed once. Apparently a lot of people are having trouble.

The Good: 
- Combat 100% better than original Deus Ex (a lot more like an FPS)
- Deusexy storyline: cyberpunk, illuminati, conspiracies etc
- Deusexy gameplay: sneaking, shooting, walking around alleyways trying to find which way to go
- A lot of involvement with different factions with no clear choices (who are the good guys?)

The Not So Good:
- Short. Very Short. Mine was like 15 ish hours and I take my time
- Locations are small compared to DE. Only one big hub location (Egypt)
- Which factions you help doesn't really matter until the final level, and the endings seem very rushed and abrupt
- Simplified compared to DE. No skill point system.
- Very limited inventory space. 12 items. WTF. Fully upgrading strength mod increases it to... 14. Wow.

44115836.review:
I actually liked this game a lot. In many ways this review feels pointless. If you're not buying for nostalgia, why would you not buy the original Deus Ex for the history and concepts and design or Human Revolution for the gameplay and graphics? If you are buying for nostalgia you know this game and don't need a review.... I digress...

No it doesn't add up to its prequel, which was one of the best games of all times, but it does retain much of what made the original great. It even improves on a few concepts.

It improves:

- Graphics

- Super strength mod is ten times more fun. Kill enemies with crates or throw their bodies over the city.

- While it loses much in its complete simplication of gameplay, it does eliminate a lot of annoyances. No more creeping around without legs anticlimatically after a prolonged gunfight, or constantly running out of bioenergy. No more having to spend ten minutes during the game trying to fit the sniper rifle around your throwing knifes and rocket launcher. Either you can take it or you can't.

It retains:

- The complete freedom of choice in much of the gameplay, with 4 massively different endings. Moral choice after moral choice abounds in this game. You can make it through the game without killing anyone, or you can be a complete sociopath.

- Diverse mod choices that affect your style of play

- Abundant philosphical commentary, found in books conversations and the story itself. 

- Great gameplay (imo)

- The laughable nightclubs with like 2 people going nuts on the huge floor.

- The awful enemy AI

It loses:

- Character interest. There is your own character who is no longer the bad ass (if slightly ridiculous) Denton but who is now a robotic mouthpiece. As for the secondary characters, I never felt attached at any point to any of them. They were ALL annoying or completely reprehensible, if not both. Where was the Paul Denton I would gladly fight off an army for?

- The complexity of character skills. Back to the dumbing down. You can mod your weapons still and upgrade mods, but you can no longer improve your different skills. Which was a loss in my opinion.

- The length and depth of the story wasn't quite as good.

- The soundtrack didn't measure up at all. They hired a band and they really tried, but the band was the most cliched, awful thing you ever heard.

But, all said and done, it's an enjoyable enough experience and if you value choice as much as I do in your games, you'll enjoy this game a lot. Buy the other 2 first, but this is worth the cup of coffee or two you're trading for.

[h1]The worst DX game[/h1]

Why do I still recommend this? Story. The story is nice and buried under a gazillion awful design flaws there are some nice concepts in this game. Your affiliation with the different factions changes the game overall to some extend and you may get different goals linked to it.

However, the entire gameplay has been awfully dumbed down to fit evrything onto a console controller interface. In theory you can still take different approaches like in the first game but stealth does not feel rewarding at all, it just feels pointless. It's way easier to just run in guns blazing because you will never even come close to ammo shortage on any weapons because of the shared ammo system. There's also not a lot of exploration or different ways into a room.

Just as atrocious are the really small and claustrophobic levels and sheer number of loading screens you will witness. Each of them, even on an SSD, will take a couple of seconds, because for some reason the exe closes and reboots for every level. On top of that, this game is known for having problems on newer systems. I got my save files corrupted twice because of game crashes. You also can't use a proper high resolution unless you install the Visual Upgrade mod (so get it).

Despite all the errors, the story is pretty nice. It's not as great as DX1 but it's enjoyable. Get the game in a sale and you'll get your not even 2€ worth out of it. Don't buy it full price because this is a very broken mess.

44010755.review:
Invisible War gets a lot of stick because it's considered correct' to dislike this game. I understand that it must have been frustrating to suffer short levels with load waits and to see the decisions of the skill tree obliterated and simplified after the first Deus Ex. Indeed these things must make one lament the influence of the console on games of this period in general. However, these things do not detract from this actually being a rather good game. 

They make up for the introduction of universal ammo by creating a dynamic that different weapons will use up different amounts of ammo, forcing a choice of weapons for suitability to task in order to conserve ammo. This adequately makes up for the loss of decision making with gun specific ammo. The load times between levels really aren't that bad. 

The game does a good job of presenting you with genuine choices to make about what you want to do, but it is here that 'Invisible War' probably has its biggest failing. You can side with whomever you like all the way up to the final showdown; this makes all choices beforehand actually redundant.


So yes, there are things that make this a lesser game than Deus Ex, however there are still multiple ways and orders to approach and complete tasks. This is satisfying and allows you to choose a play style. Biomods will allow you to maximise this style and there are enough of them throughout the game to alter the way you play later on and that's probably needed. Graphics are good and movement is secure and fluid, except occasionally on ladders. In this sense the game is good. As I say, choices are interesting, although most of them (not all) prove pointless in the end. The cut scenes explain the game well as does repeated interaction with NPCs in the spirit of the first Deus Ex. However the music is sparse and poor; rarely is your experience heightened by the soundtrack. 


Overall though, it's fun and wandering round the ruined UNATCO base at the end brings back a lot of memories of how it used to look. For the price it's available for its worth playing. I mean you can often buy this bay for a dollar or less; at that price, money really doesn't come into the issue. 


So is it worth your time? Yes, if you can accept the simplification of it, then there is still a good game to enjoy here. For the record, I played on a Laptop with Windows 10 and had not one single problem. No need for patches, no issue with set-up or play.

First things first: in its current state the game DOESN'T work and yet Steam keeps selling it. It's unacceptable but that's the way it is. To play this game you'll need to google your way out. It's possible, but convoluted and annoying.

Once you've finally gotten your game to work don't expect to be done that easily. It will crash, at random times, and in my case the voices never worked.

And then when you're finally playing the game, was it worth all that blood and sweat? It pains me to say that but it probably isn't.

Deus Ex 1 was an amazing and groundbreaking game with strong replay value. It combined pertinent philosophical and political commentary in an unique - for its time - way and almost all your actions had an impact in the game. Most NPCs were memorable.

That's the problem with Deus Ex 2. Nothing in this game is memorable. The main character is bland and borderline unpleasant. Nothing really stands out. The music isn't as memorable either and yet it's from the same composer that made the Unatco and Hong Kong themes in Deus Ex 1. The level design is boring. The universal ammo system is annoying. The constant backtracking is tedious.

Deus Ex 1 was teeming with little details and little hidden things but there's nothing in this one. Deus Ex 2 is basically Deus Ex  1 without its inspiration and passion. It's very bland and boring on top of crashing and not working on modern machines. A real disappointment. Play Deus Ex 1 and Human Revolution but skip this one.

Choices matter, dialog options account for deviant player behavior and you can see the consequences of your actions. The UI is probably the most dated element, and I admit it's ugly, but you can at least replace the crosshair by using the Visible mod. If it wasn't for the game crashing nearly 10x during my playthrough (Win10 x64) I would recommend this wholeheartedly. As it is, I think it's a good place (alongside Human Revolution) to begin the franchise before moving on to the less welcoming original.

And as much as people complain about this game's theming being inferior to the original game... well now that Mankind Divided is out with its major theme being a terrible racism allegory, those complaints don't really hold water in my opinion. 4 disparate endings, enjoyable gameplay, and great dialog make for an engaging experience, bolstered by the incredibly low price this game regularly sinks to during steam sales. 43305478.review:
Note: Played with Visible Upgrade installed.

---

A terrorist attack has destroyed Chicago and fractured the world into a series of tiny hallways interlinked by loading screens. You play as survivor Alex D in a quest to understand the forces that manipulate you. Throughout the game factions will vie for your loyalty, asking you to complete often conflicting objectives. You will influence the fate of shadowy worldwide organizations and coffee shops alike until... the game crashes.

Even with the VU installed, this game's engine is a mess. Not only will the game crash to desktop without warning, you will also likely experience frequent frame drops. Without the VU, the game will temporarily exit to desktop during every loading sequence, only to start itself back up again. I've never seen that happen elsewhere. It's as if the game is self-aware, too embarrassed of itself to let you play.

But the problems don't stop there. The aforementioned tiny levels seriously degrade what otherwise good atmosphere this game has to offer. It takes me longer to walk to my mailbox than to cross one of these levels. Somehow the cities manage to feel barren despite their compact size, and you can usually clear the combat zones in less than a minute. You will come across nearly all of the weaponry and abilities within the first hour, killing much of a sense of player progression. Also: universal ammo.

I can only recommend this game to anyone looking for disappointment. There's a good game in here somewhere, but the flaws are too overwhelming. Stick to the rest of the Deus Ex series, and keep this one invisible.

I [i] really [/i] tried to like this game. The original Deus Ex is one of my favorite games of all time, and I've heard many people say this is some kind of underrated gem, but it just isn't. 

Everything feels dumbed down, from the levels to the story, which features one of the most wooden main characters I've ever witnessed in a game. The most common complaint you'll see are the small/cramped levels, which is true across every area in the game, which combined with the floaty controls and gunplay make playing the game a chore.

Don't play this game, if you absolutely need to know what happens after the original game, just look up a plot summary online, it'll be more entertaining than playing this piece of wasted potential.

41956480.review:
It's okay. It's hard not to compare it to the original, considering the only reason you'd play it is if you've played the first. I'm hesitant to recommend it, but the game frequently goes on sale for about dollar, so it's not like you're losing a lot if you don't like it.

First off, the levels are small: typically about the size of UNATCO's interior from the first game. There are some slightly larger levels, but they're usually open areas without much detail. For each section of the game, there are usually 3 or 4 of these levels joined by loading zones. Second, later parts of the game discourage non-lethal gameplay by having heavily armored enemies that immune to knockout darts and explode when they die. They also explode if you manage to knock them unconscious with melee. A similar enemy that starts to appear at about the same time disintegrates into a radiation cloud on death or falling unconscious.

As for the story, the game takes place after the events of the first one (with a mix of all the endings). You play as Alex D, a student at an academy where he has gained cutting edge biomods. You meet 3 other students and the academy is attacked. These students are recurring characters that you meet throughout the game, with each one aligned with one of the game's factions. None of them are as interesting or memorable as Gunther or Anna were in DX1. I suppose the intent was to make them relatable by putting you in the same situation as them at the start, but you have 1 conversation with each of them before they split off. As a plus, you aren't forced into a faction like in DX1. On the other hand, it's weird that at the end of the game, you can just join the faction that you've been fighting for most of the game.

The inventory system is simplified into 1 item = 1 slot, and you don't have many slots. Not that you'll need a lot, since ammo doesn't take up inventory space. Speaking of ammo, all weapons use the same ammo now. This makes it unclear exactly how much ammo that you have since there's just an ammo "bar" rather than an ammo counter. Multitools now open any type of locked thing (doors, keypads, chests, etc), taking between 1-3 multitools. One annoying thing is that there's a bug in the game where there are 2 types of multitools that don't stack with each other. These 2 types look and act the same, but for whatever reason, the game considers them to be different items. This means that you'll probably end up devoting 2 inventory slots to multitools until you have enough of one type.

Augmentations are simplified to 4 slots (+1 more for the flashlight) with 3 choices each. Two out of three of these choices are standard biomods. The third choice for each is a black market biomod. You can only have 1 active biomod per slot and each biomod can be upgraded twice (up to level 3, with the exception of the flashlight, which can't be upgraded). Biomod canisters are used to acquire and upgrade biomods, and there are 2 types matching the 2 types of biomods: standard and black market. Black market canisters are rarer than standard canisters.

If you end up buying this game you should be aware of the loading issues on modern systems. The game uses a second executable to switch levels. This second exe closes the first exe (old level) and opens a new instance of it (new level). Many programs can stop the first exe from closing, which causes the game to crash. I played this game on Win10-64bit, and to get the game to run, I did the following things:
• Installed the Visible Upgrade (this unofficial patch allows the game to run at modern resolutions, among other things). This also has the side-effect of not notifying Steam that you're playing, hence my seemingly low playtime.
• Disabled any overlay programs (Steam overlay, Discord overlay, Nvidia overlay, etc).
• Set dx2.exe, DX2Main.exe, and Ion_Launcher.exe to run in compatibility mode for Windows XP (Service Pack 2). This may not be necessary, but it didn't cause it to crash for me.

If it still crashes during load screens you can keep the task manager open (preferably on a second monitor) and close the game exe during a loading sequence (leaving the newly-opened exe running). This isn't ideal, but it works.

Some other things to mention:
• The cheesy voice-overs make a return.
• The music isn't as memorable as DX1. Don't expect anything on the level of the Hong Kong or UNATCO themes.
• AI seems about the same as DX1. Maybe a little dumber to account for the smaller levels.

41813084.review:
It’s a huge letdown after the excellent original: everything has been simplified and condensed, the level designs are smaller and the writing less interesting. It comes with major performance problems on some machines. 

But there was one particular, totally random moment, where my disappointment turned into warped joy, and the whole thing felt worthwhile. 

An important NPC was lecturing me on politics, conspiracy, power, and his vision for the future. As he did so, however, he got too close to a flaming barrel and was set alight. For some way into his speech he didn’t notice, and kept talking while burning. It was a moment of accidental satire that fit perfectly with the game’s themes. 

I’d been hoping to resolve things peacefully, but the choice was taken out of my hands when he eventually realised he was on fire and became hostile. I was laughing almost too hard to fight back. 

Such accidental emergent gameplay moments became my favourite thing. While attempting a stealthy infiltration across rival gang territory, something set them off and the two factions destroyed each other, leaving me alone in an alley of bodies. I was thanking my luck when the sight of all the bodies triggered a neutral guard patrol to turn all the guards in the level hostile to me. I faced a bigger firefight than if I had just taken on the gangs. “Officers, I didn’t do anything…!”

Invisible War is more about wreaking chaos than saving the world. I think that’s one minor reason it’s inferior to the more idealistic original. Your quests are usually grubbier, rather than noble, and everyone, including your character, has to make so many compromises between lesser evils it’s hard to know or care about what you’re fighting for. It rewards a different playstyle, because there’s less incentive to be pacifistic, and even if you try, emergent gameplay moments like I described might derail your plan. 

Invisible War’s take on the politics and ending of the original is far more cynical and disillusioned, but its best moments, including references to the original, work with this. It’s a pessimistic, critical reinterpretation of the story, with enough ideas and wry humour to make it worth following. When you resign to its smaller world it can be a lot of fun wreaking havoc with the new augs, interacting with the characters, and exploring the future you arguably created after the ending of the original.

41614315.review:
Duration: 13 hours

I went into this one with a number of warnings on my expectations.  Only one ended up being justified in my eyes, the "small" levels.  This is not a big issue in itself, but what it did create is some very claustrophobic environments.  This is no where more apparent than when you first arrive in Seattle and the "outdoors" felt like a bunch of connected small rooms.  I don't opine that this "issue" was solved until Antarctica where it finally felt like there was some "space" around you to maneuver and take some long shots.  

The actual story was interesting and riddled with choices that had ripple effects throughout the game.  Eventually I sided with the family and chose that ending.  

The major "complaint" I had with the original was the combat felt very week in the beginning.  This was definitely solved as a single headshot could be fatal and Alex didn't feel like a boy scout with a pellet gun.  So, the combat enhancements are definitely a big step up.  

I didn't mind the other changes (radial menu, universal ammo etc) as the biomods were very fun (Robot Domination!) and I always relied on my quick keys F1-F6 and 1-6 to select.  This felt a lot more user friendly than the original as well.  

Overall a great game that was time well spent.   

8/10

41601526.review:

Better visuals, new and returning characters, the same engrossing story made by the undeniably talented developers. It feels like a good, solid epilogue in a form of a full-length game. 
And yes, the choices are still matter.

I'll make a brief review about this one. First game was simply amazing. The gameplay compared to this game is godlike. In this one... wtf happened ? I feel like they changed dev and publishers but they didn't. Same guys made this game but it doesn't feel like it.

Simply put, this is a game made for casuals. I don't mean this in a insulting way but this is a washed down version of the first game. Less items, less weapons, no skills, less hours to finish the game and so on. I do recommend this game but wait till theres at least a 50% rebate on it. Don't pay full price.

GRAPHICS
On the graphics side, its good. Better than the first one of course but the color palette is bright and colorful compared to the first.

SOUND
For the sound, its wierd. I didn't get into it since in some places the music was stuck in loop; that can be frustrating and annoying. I noticed that some grenades didn't sound or looked spectacular on the sound side. When they exploded, you didn't hear the sound... that was disappointing.

STORY
Story was just a wierd experience. Throughout the ENTIRE game, I didn't know what side to choose as I didn't get enough information from them so at the end I finally made my decision. This shouldn't be the case. Around the developement stage of the story I should be able to change my mind unless new information springs in my face. In here it wasn't the case unfortunately. So the entire story was just lacking in my opinion.
They want you to choose but don't give you enough reasons to tip on a side.

TECHNICAL
Thank god I learned to save often. Please save often and use the quicksave a lot, you'll need it. Why ? Cause the game can crash. I don't even know why as well.

41045044.review:
As a Deus Ex fan, I can’t really recommend this game. This game is about you working for the Illuminati and other related factions. You will have the option throughout all the levels to aid certain fractions in their goals. However, the structure of the game is very loose. I had no idea what helping a fraction would bring me or if it even matters in the story. 

The bad thing about the game is that the game is buggy. Loading takes long, even on my very high end PC with 2 SSD’s. The upgrades via Biomods is different than in other Deus Ex games. You can only choose to level up 1 of the 3 categories. If you level up a 2nd category, the biocanisters used to upgrade the previous mod is gone. The combat AI is weak and sometimes hilariously easy to beat. With a sword you can easily kill NPC’s with guns. The NPC’s search is also bad.

This, together with the weak story, doesn’t make this game worth your while. The multiple endings are easy to achieve if you just keep all fractions as a friend.

40836975.review:
An extremely underrated game, it has the same design philosophy as the original and many objective improvements that actually make it even better to play.
It's still an FPS/Stealth/RPG hybrid with multiple solutions to every problem and possible to complete without killing anyone.

Most of the streamlining really just removes things that were not fun or unecessarily complex from the original, like having to remember/recheck logins and passwords or how inept you were at certain things like jumping and aiming unless you spent skillpoints/augmentations on them.
Many of these things, and more, were implemented in Human Revolution but everyone loves that game, meanwhile Invisible War receives Negative Reviews literally because "universal ammo"...

The sound effects and graphics are great this time, with amazing lighting and an atmospheric art direction accompanied by a soundtrack that tries to immerse you in the world, rather than just be memorable. Once again, like in Human Revolution.
(For some reason the Steam screenshots don't represent what the game looks like, even the interface looks different, like they're from a Beta version. The actual game looks a lot better.)

The story is an unecessary extension of the original but it works extremely well by making all the factions contact you constantly throughout the game (like in the end of the original) giving you different and/or oposing objectives. There are many moments in the game where you're working with friendly NPCs of one faction while knowing that you're about to betray them.
There are 4 endings, and the decision seems harder this time since the factions have more cons to their pros and one constantly critizises the other. It really makes you think.


Use the mod "Visible Upgrade" update the game, it contains various bugfixes and game improvements such as widescreen support, and provides a few tweaks ("Update" version).
It optionally bundles the Unified Texture Pack ("Full" version): http://www.ttlg.com/forums/showthread.php?t=147423

40510648.review:
This game's review section really covered all the pros and cons well, so here's an attempt at a summary with some additions and opinions(this review compares to the first game):

Pros:
+More dialogue branches
+Endings more fleshed out(slightly)
+Improved voice acting
+Non-linear levels remain(though the previous game had more variety)
+HUD now includes a compass, makes navigating easier 
+Improved combat, feels more solid
+Biomods(augmentations) more balanced + swappable

Subjective:
+/-Universal ammo system
+/-100% ambient soundtrack other than NG Resonance songs(no more upbeat techno tracks here)
+/-Ragdoll physics(it's "so bad, it's good")
+/-Realistic turned Futuristic-fantasy aesthetics, looks somewhat cartoonish
+/-Story easier to follow with philosophic and gray morality elements still remaining however execution may feel somewhat lacking/different
+/-Simplified mechanics:
[list]
[*]automatic hacking(no more input username and pw)
[*]skill system removed 
[*]multitool and lockpick combined into one
[*]less biomods(augmentations) slots
(but that also means more biomod(canister) upgrades to assign e.g. swap out regeneration for spy drone to highest level immediately)
[/list]

+/-Ability to switch between factions until the very end
+/-No consequences for committing undesirable actions against factions other than ending(and yelling)
+/-Protagonist is a blank slate(first one had more personality)
+/-Game playtime seems to be only about 1/3 of Deus Ex 1's playtime

Cons:
-NPCs and dialogue lost their relatability/realism
-Stealth seems to require biomods to stealth properly
-AI is still on the dumb side
-Excessive loading screens(although load time is quick enough)  
-Crashes constantly in fullscreen even with Visible Upgrade mod(less in windowed)
-Simplified UI:
[list]
[*]custom note taking removed 
[*]conversation history removed 
[*]thumbnail in saves removed 
[*]game log removed 
[*]less inventory slots than the first
[/list]
-Semi-open areas still exist, but areas are more cramped overall

Some opinions:
If you're wondering if you should get the game, perhaps the question is not "Do you like the first game?" because there is a significant presentation change, but rather "Do you really want to see the aftermath of Deus Ex 1 endings?" because that's what the game expanded on.

If you found the first game endings perfect in and of itself and really liked the atmosphere and presentation of the first game, you may not like this game.

If you're wondering if you should play this game first before Deus Ex 1 expect spoilers, though you might not get the spoilers until you play the first game.

Story picks up after the 3rd level - Cairo so some patience may be warranted

If you do decide to get the game, get the Visible upgrade mod. It has some patches for the game and makes it more stable. Save often though, because game still crashes alot.

40494659.review:
The most controversial recommendation I may ever give, but I give it sincerely.

The Bad: Most of the bad reviews I've seen are from lovers of the very first Deus Ex, which is fine, but cutting a long story short (for people who need it), Deus Ex was pretty advanced for the time and built, initially, for PC (although later gained a streamlined port to PS2). Invisible War was an attempt to catch the console bandwagon and so suffers the sort of limitations you would expect and it does play like a console game.

The Indeterminate: I've seen people post about technical issues with the PC port. I've not encountered any of these on Windows 7 x64 - be sure to check out if others with your specifications report problems!

The Good: I enjoyed my time in Invisible War, and every few years or so, I boot it back up and enjoy it again. There are a limited number of augment modules, so it pays to specialise in certain methods of play. The part I most enjoyed was the story - conspiracy theories, a world on the brink of chaos, and I think a fair take on the whole human-consciousness / A.I. issue. Who you decide to help out will change aspects of certain missions, and the final mission feels pretty rewarding when you work with your team to achieve your objective. The narrative and player input is what keeps me coming back.

Overall: I don't think the hate is justified. I've enjoyed the game from all angles, many times. If you're still unsure, pick it up in a sale for pocket change.

40431628.review:
Invisible War is a misunderstood sequel. It did a lot of things right in terms of building on the original Deus Ex, but it was compromised on release by a really technically janky engine that impacts everything from the size of the game levels (which are pretty small) to the wonkiness of the controls and action. If you can get past those elements, and play with a mod or two, though, this is still an enjoyable game that gets better the deeper in you get and the more you get used to its quirks.

There's no getting around that it's the worst of all the games in its series, and it hasn't aged particularly well - but I still have some fond memories of some of its locations and characters even after all the years since its release, so that has to count for something.

40424808.review:
This is tough to rate. It's another one of those games for which I wish there were neutral ratings. It's a decent game, but it's a bad Deus Ex game. The original did set the bar pretty high, though. I think the biggest damage they did to this game was releasing it as part of the Deus Ex franchise. I understand why people give it bad reviews, but at the same time I don't think it deserves reviews [b]that[/b] bad.

In comparison to the first Deus Ex, it's honestly very dumbed down. Much shorter, smaller levels, more loading screens (my biggest annoyance), smaller inventory, minimal inventory management, fewer weapons, fewer augmentations, fewer items, no skills, annoying HUD, dry dialogue and okay story. With all that said, I'll be honest and admit that I still had fun.

I'll give it thumbs up, but buyers should know what they're getting into and adjust their expectations accordingly. You should probably wait for a sale, I got it for under €1.

(And seriously, loading times are really bad even with SSD.)

40387788.review: If you like MGS2 and Star Trek, you prolly like this one.

40378995.review:
So, the black sheep of the Deus Ex family. Just like Alex. 
This isn't a bad game. Far from it. Its endings are a lot better compared to DX1, factions really do mean something and biomods offer a unique twist on an FPS game. This isn't a typical RPG with skills. Biomods allow you to switch up your gameplay midway if you so want to, whether you want more stealth focus biomods instead of combat ones and vice versa for example. The freedom presented here in the world despite how small each environment is incredible, and the levels themselves have a distinct artstyle that holds well for its age compared to its predecesor.
But, compared to Deus Ex, it's clearly an inferior game. Its philosophical content is somewhat dumbed down compared to its predecessor, and the game never really lives up to its theme. "The Future War On Terror" is a great tagline, hinting at discussion of a post 9/11 world, but it never does this on a relatable scale. Compare terrorists blowing up a few important buildings to losing ALL INFRASTRUCTURE. The latter is much more impactful on the world, and resulted in poverty going through the roof and general corruption throughout the world (like there wasn't any before though). However, this is never portrayed well in the game, just simple rich and poor districts. It's only really prevalent in the Cairo levels where you interact with citizens of both Old and New Cairo in small but meaningful ways.
Yet, despite me playing this game for it's commentary, I was sucked in by its gameplay of all things. It's a slow shooter, and that appeals to me somewhat when I want some casual play that challenges me a few times. The gunplay is solid enough to keep me entertained, rewarding you for being a few steps ahead of the enemy, although universal ammo can be quite annoying at times.
I recommend this game, but before you even start a new game, go download the Visual Upgrade. Everyone says that this game is hard to get running on Windows 10. It isn't. The Visual Upgrade is literally just an .exe file that gives you a Visual Tweaker to mess around with the settings, and the interface is very manageable. On top of that, most of the compatibility issues are resolved and you can now play at higher resolutions with the mod. Here's the link http://www.moddb.com/mods/deus-ex-2-visible-upgrade/downloads/visible-upgrade-full-edition You're welcome. Get it when it's on sale for like a dollar though. Even for the original Deus Ex, I am not paying $7 dollars for it. I may just be that way, but when you catch all of the Deus Ex games on sale, they are a steal.
Don't just buy this game. Buy DX1 as well. It will be well worth it.

40318016.review:
I'm not really a fan of Steam's binary review system because it boils a review down to a simple recommended or not recommended without any nuance, which isn't really helpful for games that might be flawed in certain areas or have more niche appeal, so for this I'll say mostly recommended but with some misgivings.

First I need to address the technical side of things. This game is very poorly optimized for modern systems and an unofficial patch (found at http://www.ttlg.com/forums/showthread.php?t=147423) is the only way to get it to run reasonably. I couldn't get the game to run at my monitor's resolution and it ran like total garbage without, and even with the patch I still had several ctds. I was able to finish the game though and it did only cost a dollar when I bought it, but it is still something to be aware of.

Now on to the game itself. This game is mostly remembered for being "consolified (it was designed for the original Xbox), and for not being as good as the original. Both of these statements are true, but I would argue that it is still a good game regardless. The simplification required to work on the Xbox does lead to some downgrades, such as game areas not being as big as they were before or datapads having to be shorter, but some things actually feel more streamlined. The inventory system has some improvements (though the circle UI realyl kind of sucks), food is now all kept in one slot (huzzah) and they merged lockpicks and multitools into one item. Universal ammo has its ups and downs, it can be convenient, but it's so dumb that the stun prod uses the same ammo as a rocket launcher. Like what?

I must say that it feels like there's less of an emphasis on stealth here, even on realistic difficulty. Guns pack more punch than the original and are much easier to use and the only enemies that I had trouble with towards the end were the Templar and WTO commandos. Again its' a bit of a trade off. The option is still there though and in some areas is more viable. The augmentations, here called biomods, are what really make the gameplay for me. They're absolutely ridiculous and I love it. There's a speed aug that, once maxed out, basically makes you Sanic. I was actually able to skip a lot of enemy encounters because of how good it was, even though sometimes my character went so fast she became hard to control. The Omar biomods are really fun though, obviously, I had to get the one that lets you hack into security terminals and turn enemy turrets against them, but there's also one that lets you take over mechs. I'd speed over to a massive enemy mech, start the hack, run back to my hiding place, then use the mech to mow down the enemy guards, it's very satisfying.

The story is actually solid too, not as good as the original of course, but still having most other games beat. It takes the series much more in the Sci-Fi direction than the grounded original. I expected it to be dumbed down but it actually does manage to explore some interesting themes throughout, largely through the various factions and their interactions, or often surprising similarities, whether it be the WTO and Order, Templar and Omar, Denton and Illuminati, or even two rival coffee shops. Meanwhile, the merits of bioengineering and collective consciousness are discussed as Alexis de Tocqueville is quoted, and I'm not going to spoil it but the Denton ending feels like something Arthur C. Clarke might have written. It can be kind of scattershot in it's presentation, but it is still nice to see a game explore these kinds of sci-fi themes.

Overall, Invisible War isn't the greatness that the original was, but it is a good and interesting game in its own way.

38278925.review: When the game originally came out I was 16 years old, and I quite liked it.  The original Deus Ex was (and probably still is) my favourite game, period, so I was really pumped to revist the world.  I remember being really impressed by the visuals, as the real-time lighting system was very impressive for the time, and the ragdoll physics were also lots of fun to play with.  The shooting also felt like an improvement over the original.  However even in my overhyped state of optimism, it was clear to me that some major concessions had been made on the level design.  The levels were far smaller than anything from the original Deus Ex, and felt claustrophobic in comparison.  The storyline also had no sense of pace, jumping straight into the twists far too soon, and the tone just seemed off in the dialogue.  I revisted the game recently when doing a playthrough of all the Deus Ex games, and now that the graphics are no longer impressive and the physics seem positively ropey, the problems with the levels stood out much more.  I would actually say this game has aged a lot worse than the original.  Invisible War still has some interesting hub areas and some cool side-quests, and it does consistently give you choice about how you approach missions.  However the choice is more a narrative choice about which faction to support, rather than the sneak/shoot/hack approach of the other Deus Ex games.  There is a little of that too, but not separated to the degree seen in the other games.  I'll still recommend playing the game for historical interest, and there are some interesting ideas in here both narratively and mechanically (universal ammo, for instance, was probably a mistake but nonethless a novel idea).  There's also some rather poignant moments revisiting some former locations from the original game.  So whilst I don't claim this as a good game, it's still something you should play if you haven't.  And if you only played it back in 2003, it's worth revisiting for it's curiosity value.  Ideally, though, pick it up on sale.

38067576.review:
[u]What I liked about the game[/u]
[list]
[*]	Good soundtrack.

[*]	Characters from the original game make a comeback. I also liked the protagonist. 

[*]	The updated graphics look nice, especially in locations like Medina. 

[*]	I found the augmentations useful, especially the invisibility.  

[*]	Plenty of side quests. 

[*]	Interesting story. You get to choose sides. The game also has multiple endings.       

[u]What I disliked or was disappointed with[/u]

[*]	Crappy interface. The interface has been simplified too much. I remember in the original Deus ex you could hack or enter the username and password, to gain access to a person’s account. When you hacked security terminals in the original game, it displayed all the different camera angles and controls; which was cool, but now it just gives you a menu; you have to click to access each security angle. The original game also displayed the players anatomy and you could heal individual body parts. The original also provided the transcripts of each conversation. 

[*]	No skill points. Hacking has been made into an augmentation. In the original game, Skill points allowed each character build to feel different. 

[*]	No lockpicks. The multitool does both lock picking and keypad hacking. The multitool looks shit, it looks like a wand, which fires lightning. 

[*]	The game is short. You don’t visit half as many locations like you did in the original. The levels are also very compacted; the levels are not big and open like in the first game. The levels quite limited.   

[*]	Stealth in this game is awful. You can’t take advantage of the dark, enemies can easily spot you. The stun prod makes too much noise and there isn’t a dart crossbow  

[*]	Wasn’t keen on the weapon models (except the SMG).   

[*]	Not many augmentations. The flash light takes up one slot. I wish they combined both invisibility augmentations. The drone augmentation looked a bit crap; just a floating ball of electricity.    

[*]	More dialogue with NPCS. 

[*]	Buggy and glitchy. When the game loads, it closes and then reopens the game. The player can go through objects. Sometimes multitools don’t work despite having the correct amount. 
[/list]

[u]Conclusion[/u] 

Average game. The game is nothing compared to its predecessor. It has been simplified too much. It could have been so much more. If you want to know what happens in this Deus ex timeline, then I recommend you buy this game at a discount. 

[h1]6/10 = Okay[/h1]

37596182.review:
I've owned this game since it came out, and despite its age and some well-deserved criticisms, I still now and then go on a binge and play it through a few times in a row. The game has enough depth that you can do that and still find new ways of doing things. 

When this game came out, there was a lot of negative press about it. Even once you filter through the hyperbole, there are some disappointments and flaws. The three major criticisms of any substance that you hear most often are:

[olist]
 [*] Small areas and frequent load screens. This was the result of making a game for both the PC and the consoles of the day.
 [*] Universal ammo. It was an experiment that didn't quite work out. It's an interesting idea, and as long as you pay attention, it doesn't affect game play that much.
 [*] It isn't as good as the first Deus Ex. Very, very few things are.
[/olist]

One warning: Windows 10 (and I think 8) don't play nice with the game. If you check the message boards for tips, everyone will recommend VisibleTweaker and for good reason. It was the only way I could get it going after I upgraded, plus it incorporates various higher resolution texture mods. After I upgraded to Windows 10, I couldn't reinstall because the original disks and some horrible content protection, so I re-purchased on Steam, so I do know that VisibleTweaker will work with a Steam version.

Like the original and the prequels, Invisible War has enough richness that you can pick biomods and weapons to suit (or challenge) your play style; there are enough side quests and alternative paths to suit your mood, sense of humor, or sense of ethics. Pacifist, non-lethal, or unnecessarily lethal are all legitimate options. Myself, I tend to either sneak past or knock unconscious clock-punching security guards and frustrated working-class stiffs. deal with soldiers pragmatically, but when it comes to the Templars (uniform-loving purists), I like to set them on fire and watch them run around screaming. If that's not your style, then there is an exclusive boarding school for girls, and you can kill everyone inside if you'd like.

There are male and female versions of the protagonist, Alex D. (Skin tone can also be adjusted). Gender doesn't make a huge difference, but a side-quest or two have different possibilities depending on which you choose.

The dialog is solid and has the same attitude that the series is known for. The voice actor for the male Alex D is good, but personally, I think the voice actor for the female Alex D nails the delivery perfectly. She is probably a big part of why I keep replaying it; her verbal smackdowns are that good.

Overall, I think it has aged quite well. I've forgotten most of the other games from its generation, and of the ones that I can remember without going back and looking through what I own, this is the only one I still play. With the one caveat that you might have to do some tweaking before it will work, I think it is worth it. Maybe it's just nostalgia talking, but I think it is fun enough that I paid for it twice.
