36610571.review:
As I write this (18 Nov 2017), the reviews of "Deus Ex: Invisible War" (the 2003 sequel to the original "Deus Ex" (2000)) are running 335 to 501, or about 40% negative.  Oddly, as an individual, that group divide pretty much summarizes my feelings toward the game.  Just before playing this game, I re-played the original "Deus Ex."  As I played it, the overriding emotion for the game was awe.  On the other hand, for "Invisible War," my overriding emotion was disappointment.  Why?  In a nutshell, it's because the developers dumbed the game down.  Since this was written for the consoles of the time and ported over to the PC, I can understand the reduced gameplay:

- Small levels,
- Long loading times (15 seconds),
- Fewer Biomod upgrades (I fully upgraded about half way through the game and ended up with 14 standard and 8 black market upgrade canisters sitting unused in my inventory),
- No exploration points (heck, no points at all),
- No skills to apply for each upgrade,
- Very restricted weapon mod ability (as with Biomod canisters, I finished the game with 25 unused weapon mods sitting in my inventory),
- Ridiculously tiny inventory.

But, the big problem is the dumbing down of the philosophical, social, and political thought in the game.  I guess I can understand that, too:  there are probably far more people who want to just play a game than those who enjoy thinking about the philosophical underpinnings of the game.

Another problem is that this game seems to target a much younger audience than did the original game.  That's especially noticable at the beginning where all the characters behave pretty simplistically.  But, that does get better by the end.

So, why am I recommending the game?  Because about 14 hours through, I realized I was still playing.  As a sequel to "Deus Ex," yes, this game is disappointing.  But, on its own, it's actually pretty good.  Again, it's no "Deus Ex."  But, a list price of about $7 (and I paid a whole lot less for the total "Deus Ex Collection" bundle) for 27.5 hours of reasonable game play justifies it.

Note:  I used the full Visible Upgrade mod to this game to update the graphics and fix a lot of the problems:

http://www.ttlg.com/forums/showthread.php?t=147423\

36559239.review:
After playing through the whole game, I honestly don't get the hate or denial of this game's existence. It has areas that are inferior to both Deus Ex 1 (DX1) and DX: HR, but also many areas that are just as good or simply different. Sadly, that widespread opinion is one of the reasons why I waited longer to play this than I should have. Although, in this case I guess it's fitting, because Deus Ex are about global AI's with their own opinions/agendas and the Internet can seem like that at times, although with a major case of split personality and other mental issues. 

IW has lots of things that I associate with Deus Ex and other games like it, e.g. Knights of the Old Republic, The Witcher and VtM:Bloodlines. The mentioned games are all personal favorites of mine, because they give you quest/gameplay/dialogue options and let's you roleplay a character or attitude, which says something about how I view IW. 

There's quite a lot of voice acting, something I look for in every game. Even most no-name NPC's say 5-6 lines of dialogues before they start repeating themselves. This helps with immersing you into the game world, makes the whole gaming experience more interesting, encourages you to explore and, above all, pester everyone until they've run out of dialogue lines, even if they tell you to go away, heh heh. On that account, IW is every bit as good as DX1 and it also has several references to the first game, both small and large. 

The story and world created through that voice acting is intricate like in DX1. I play Deus Ex games for the gameplay options, but I enjoyed the story. You have several different companies/factions/people to keep track of. with several story twists along the way. The characters themselves aren't as memorable (or amusingly stereotypical) as those from DX1, but I wouldn't say they are one-dimensional or boring. 

The level design is also very Deus Ex-y, with the vents and being able to approach an objective/mission area in different ways. Perhaps not entirely as well made as DX1, but it's nothing that made me stop and think that I wanted to play DX1 instead. 

The biomod and tools/weapons are great and I was able to get most of what I wanted early on for my non-lethal stealth playstyle. However, it's here that I first realized what people had against IW, since like in DX1, you have to choose between 3 options in five categories. For some reason, hacking and invisibilty is in the same category, which didn't bother me at first, because I rarely found the need for either. At the end of the game, I wished I could have had both at the same time. 

The end stages are where you encounter heavily armed/armored troops that you can't knock out via tranquilizing darts/gas and can't backstab like in DX1 (DX1 had the Dragon's Tooth nano blade, IW has an energy blade that is much less effective). It's possible that I could have just sneaked/run away from them and I did at one point, because I didn't have enough ammo or desire to to take them all out. I had switched from invisibility to hacking by then and even when crouching, enemies hear you very well and are able to locate you. It was much easier to ghost my way around in DX1, while IW practically requires the "soft feet" and invisibility biomod for successful sneaking (not many large spaces because it had to work on the Xbox as well), which means you can't use the hacking or jumping biomod at the same time.

Exploring the area by jumping up on stuff and hacking were two of my favorite activities in DX1. They don't work as well in IW. The jumping mechanic is odd, seems like you jump higher if you jump up on a small ledge and then jump again. It's imprecise and unintuitive and you most often push away boxes when trying to jump up on them. DX1 had excellent box stacking mechanics, something I really miss in IW. Hacking might be more useful than it seemed, but money is quickly a non-issue and there were too few (well placed) security terminals to hack, so you could turn the tables on your enemies or simply turn off cameras.

A large source of hate for IW is perhaps because one of the factions wants you to kill certain people. Being loyal to one faction all throughout the game doesn't make you feel good, they both want you to do stuff at times that doesn't rhyme well with how I want to roleplay my character (a good-natured hero). The Witcher 1 was better at making factions be both good and bad, I didn't feel at home with either of IW's factions, because of the things they asked me to do. 

Most of my complaints are from the end stages. It made it much harder to sneak/knock out people and I found my health/ ammo reserves depleted, couldn't keep on playing like I had before. I was ready to say "it's been great, but now it's over, time to start a new game from the backlog" like five hours before the actual ending revealed itself. It has good moment-to-moment gameplay, I never felt like I wanted to quit, but I sometimes felt like it didn't matter if I continued playing or not. Each point in the game felt as good as any to stop playing or to continue. 

Then again, it was at the end that I realized how I could have done some things better, things that would have nullified some of my complaints and annoyances. This is a game best played twice to get the most out of it and I'll do so one day (will choose the female protagonist then, to hear a new voice do all the hero's voice acting), but the backlog beckons and I have had my fill of IW for now.

35897076.review:
If you've come from the original or the newer prequels, you're going to be sorely disappointed with Deus Ex: Invisible War. Even if you're coming in fresh, this is a below-average FPS that has not withheld the test of time. Fans of the series, FPS enthusiasts or nostalgics desperately craving another hit of Deus Ex should forget that this game ever existed for the following reasons:

[list]

[*] Because the game had to be developed for both PC and the original Xbox, loading times are long and the levels are simple. While this may be due to the graphical limitations of the Xbox, large environments that offer many paths to complete objectives are iconic to the franchise. It's just not here. These seemingly large environments are segmented into much smaller areas. Because the environment is so segmented, you're forced to focus on how painfully linear these smaller environments are. This also gives way to limitations in terms of the amount of AI present in certain areas (in some areas there were only 3-5 enemies)

[*] Much like its level design, Invisible War suffers from an array of shallow storylines. [spoiler]There are two factions that are revealed to be under the same veil of the Illuminati despite having polarizingly different methods of solving weighty in-game conflicts. No matter which side you choose, it always feels that your choices really do not matter. Your in-game actions towards other members of the factions do not matter, either. For instance, I had wiped out an entire WTO security compound only for their leader to say that he was disappointed. He gave me a biomod canister anyways. [/spoiler] While I will say that the scenarios seemed well thought out, I just didn't like how unoriginal [spoiler] the illuminati reveal was, and this rush to revive JC Denton because the main protagonist is a clone of him. [/spoiler] This then paves the way to an ending that is [spoiler] painfully predictable and in the same vein as other games. However, because the other games give you a more visceral look into the world's social problems, I felt more attached to the end-game choice [/spoiler]

[*] Tedious sidequests offered piddly rewards or sums of credits. This gave me a poor incentive to really do them. Because Invisible War  became a game where [spoiler] you could not buy or rank up for your augmentations and largely relied on finding them, you got to a point where you had enough credits early on in the game to not worry about them. Because the levels were not all that complex, it didn't even make sense to grind for rewards or interact with merchants since you could find everything you're looking for in the levels anyways. [/spoiler]

[*] Stock weapons and basic weapon customization complimented the augmentation system rather well, I felt that the one-ammo-fits-all weapon aspect a serious cop out. This was largely because of how small the inventory system was, and ultimately the weak selection of weapons. In that vein, this game has very few explosive options, which was an element that really made the other games a lot more interesting. They compensated for this by including a lot of [spoiler]multi-tools[/spoiler], but sometimes you really just wanted to blow up a door or so instead of hucking explosive crates that often lead to you getting killed in the process. 

[*] Because of how old the game is, I needed to rely on mods to get the resolution right and make the game more presentable in terms of graphics. Visible Upgrade was what I used, and I was pleased with the changes it made to the game. But even without mods, the game is quite prone to difficult crashes that can mess up your saves and progress. Although there are quick save and load features for you to abuse, there is only one quick save. Seldom do you receive current saves from the beginning of some levels. Luckily, [spoiler] because you are told how the game is going to end before going to two other main locations in the game, the game just saved me anywhere between 2-4 hours of my life chasing a story I already knew the end of. [/spoiler]

[/list]

With those points in mind, I would ask you to not buy this title. Because of how contained the story is and how much it banks off of the first game, you can miss this title entirely. For people looking to enter the series, start with the first game or the prequels. I will credit it for its high concept story and execution of neat augs, though it's poorly executed through weak plot and level design - the two things the Deus Ex franchise rests its laurels on.

Dues Ex: Invisible War is a 2004 RPG, Action-Cyberpunk game is that is developed by Ion Storm. It is the sequel to Dues Ex that released in 2000.

Dues Ex progresses through the future in an expansive story and gameplay with many sci-fi and cyberpunk features. It is for me one of the very first games I have played back in the day and I still admire it today. It isn't the best Dues Ex game as this game in particular got mixed reviews as listed on Steam and some other websites but it still holds a place in my heart. The music is great, the action is good but are times where you can't kill everything or you are not supposed too.

The story is that it is set 20 years from the first game and follows a character called Alex Denton who is a clone from J.C. Denton who was the main character you play as in the first game. You must inflitrate a religous cult that is reshaping worldwide governments to there agencys.


If you want Cyberpunk, Sci-fi and some action and something to pass time, than this game is for you.

35018417.review:
[h1]Consolized Deus Ex in virtually every aspect[/h1]

Back when Deus Ex came out, PC games had a reputation for being more complex than their Console bretheren. PC titles tended to be more complex, have a ton of hotkeys that just couldn't be fit onto a controller, and were larger in just about every way owing to the same factors that make PC's technologically superior to consoles to this day. More RAM, more HD space, better graphical capabilities, etc etc etc. 

Well into the 2000's this reality was still prevalent, and no game better encapsulates this contrast and mentality turned reality than Deus Ex: Invisible War-a title made with consoles in mind first and foremost.

Whereas Deus Ex had massive maps that are still respectable to this day. Invisible War entraps you in confined rooms and locales seperated by doorways and gates that lead to loading times. Necessary as the XBox hardware wouldn't allow massive areas. Invisible War attempts to create the illusion of being outside when not in a building, but you might as well be since everything is still corridors and rather tight spaces. The only difference is that there is now a skybox (sometimes) when 'outside', but that skybox is hidden by conveniently large buildings that make the difference between being outdoors and indoors a question of how high the ceiling is and if the ceiling is a solid ceiling or a skybox.

I can't fault this too much as it *is* a game of its time, but it's worth noting since Deus Ex 1 didn't suffer these limitations and it's 5 years older than this title at the point of release. It's taking a step back. To its defense its not a massive deal or anything that would deter the creation of just as engaging a game as the first.

But that's where this title fails again. 

Continuing its console syndrome, this game eliminates a vital aspect of the first game: the RPG elements. You don't receive differing damage on your various appendages. You don't have as robust or intriguing an upgrade system to your biomodifications. Gone are the various abilities you could level up from the previous game (proficiency in weapons, heavy weapons, computers, etc). There are no more computers where you can read characters' emails that build the lore and world. You don't hack anymore, you don't talk to as many NPC's and engage in the various side quests that have you building lore and the world. I do not understand why they engaged the subtraction game in aspects that made the first title unique. That was basically all of Deus Ex there.

If they focused on the gunplay and enhanced it, that would be fine, but it's the same as before. Meaning, below average, only now all weapons share the same ammo pool which is just confusing. There is no reason to carry anything past a sniper rifle and perhaps an SMG or shotgun since all weapons have the same ammo pool. It completely defeats the purpose of carrying variety, its just....I don't understand it. I'll have to google the logic behind that.

What of the story and side missions? Well, just as with everything else this area has also been downsized....severely. God has it been downsized. As stated, the sidequests and various characters to talk to are gone for the most part. There just isn't as much there, and what is there is typically rather linear. Wheras in Deus Ex you would engage in quests and be able to maneuver the ordeal and side with parties, here you just get quests and do them. Very few of them require siding with any party. It's just quests to do. There are no repricussions, or rewards for that matter.

Surprisingly, the story isn't *that* bad. Deus Ex had three endings, and here we have a sort of mixture of all three. It actually makes sense, and is rather basic. So basic that I can't really poke too many holes in it, only to say that for a franchise of this caliber this is really....tiny. Deus Ex built on the underlying concepts of the plot through character conversations, books, and logs. You'd delve into the nature of Democracy, Governance, and Free Will which underlied a game about massive institutions lead by a few governing the many. It was a philisophical work.

Invisible War, on the other hand, gives you character dialogue and....that's it. Rather short discussions with no explenation or delving into the underlying concepts. It's rather sad; when they got rid of the RPG elements they *really* did a disservice to the plot. It's as if they had a general outline for the plot....and shipped the game out like that. 

And the plot is alright. Some character motives and elements are just left at simple, "it is what it is" explanations. *Slight spoiler warning* the Illuminati is involved once more, and when told that they control factions, including oppositional factions, not much is said as to how contradictory and braindead that is other than, "yeah, its weird right? You gotta build and control" or some other such nonsense. It's a GLARING PLOTHOLE THAT REQUIRED A LOT MORE EXPLENATION

A LOT MORE.

But you know, for convenience sake and to have you follow a linear route lets just say the factions were one in the same. It's such a cop out.

Speaking of which, its difficult to take this game seriously when you can kill faction leaders and...just really disgrace a faction but the ability to still partner with it is available and they merely chastise you over the radio for not following orders. "Well, anyway, please do follow this next order...."

I understand its so that the player can still make his choice in endings, and its much appreaciated. At the same time, it deligitimizes your plot points; you can allow options in endings without disrespecting your world and characters within it. 

All in all I'd say its rather mediocre. Wiki the plot or something; its actually decent even if barebones. It follows logically from the first title and makes some familiar faces into villains if you view their actions as villanous...which you totally can. Otherwise, as its own title it really is bad. Only the most dedicated of Deus Ex fans will play it, and only for the plot...and this is assuming they don't just retcon the hell out of this.

34767731.review:
[h1] VIVAN LAS CAJAS [/h1]

Canónicamente, el último juego de la saga, secuela del juego de 2000, Deus Ex (The Conspiracy).

Sigue la historia de los Denton, en este caso, del miembro más jóven del grupo, Alex Denton, quien se desenvuelve en un mundo surgido a partir del final (o finales) del juego anterior.

Este juego fue aclamado por unos y criticado negativamente por otros, y si bien no es lo que uno esperaría como secuela de una obra maestra, sigue siendo un juego excepcional.

Los puntos fuertes del juego, en mi opinión, residen en los gráficos (espectaculares), la dificultad, y la libertad que le da al jugador de desarrollar la historia a conveniencia de este (Podría comparar este punto con quests del The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind o con Mass Effect, pues las acciones del jugador afectan al desarrollo de los personajes en torno a este).

En Deus Ex: Invisible Wars encarnamos a Alex Denton, quien, tras un ataque a su domicilio, donde recidía con otras personas, todos miembros de una organización de seguridad, se ve envuelto en situaciones en las cuales deberemos decidir qué acciones tomar y cómo actuar, pues, por ejemplo: podríamos convencer a tal facción de darnos autorización para entrar a cierta fábrica de armas y una vez adentro cumplir con los objetivos de otra facción, traicionando a la primera, o podríamos ignorarlos a todos y destruir el mundo entero.

Si bien la primera entrega profundizaba sobre la historia y el trasfondo de los personajes y las situaciones que acontecían,   haciendo énfasis en conspiraciones de la vida real, [b] Invisible Wars es, más bien, un epílogo [/b] por lo que, para disfrutar de la historia, es necesario conocer el "Lore" de la saga. Esta entrega, a diferencia de la primera, posee un [b] Gameplay más pulido [/b] y, de cierta manera, es mucho "mejor" Shooter que el primero, pero sin descuidar los puzles que caraterizaron al primero juego (puedes resolver los niveles de muchísimas maneras, ya sea siendo sigiloso, de manera violenta, sabiendo con qué personajes hablar [b] o usando CAJAS [/b]) o el Juego de Rol.

Como en todo RPG, el personaje (o los personajes) del jugador evolucionan a conveniencia de este, y normalmente pueden llegar a ser muy distintos del personaje (o personajes) de otros jugador. El jugador deberá de decidir qué Aumentos son los importantes para su personaje, y, aunque paresca que hay una gran falta de aumentos, porque parecen ser pocos, la verdad es que son suficientes para hacer pensar a cualquiera durante horas qué aumento es más conveniente, y, de hecho, en muchos casos da la sensación de que sin ese aumento por el que te decidiste nunca habrías pasado de cierta parte del juego.

En cuanto a mecánicas: Son las mismas del juego original, con alguna que otra simplificación, pero la más destacable es el hecho de que las municiones son universales (cosa que a muchos gustó por lo problemático que era llevar muchos tipos de munición en el Deus Ex original, y cosa que a muchos disgustó porque lo vieron como algo simplista)

En cuanto a dificultad: Es más dificil que el primero (The Conspiracy) y el tercero (Human Revolution), aunque obviamente depende del estilo de juego por el cual el jugador se decida.

En cuanto a controles: Yo jugué usando un Gamepad, lástima que no es totalmente compatible y en algunos momentos tuve que usar el teclado y el ratón...

En cuanto a música: Excelente, en especial su versión del Tema del Deus Ex original.

En cuanto a gráficos: Igualmente excelentes, luces y sombras dinámicas, me soprendí al ver que hace tantos años existía esa tecnología que yo pensaba era de tiempos más modernos. El único punto negativo aquí es que los modelos de los personajes puede llegar a parecer feos y el HUD no gustó a muchos.

En cuanto a Rendimiento: Este es, sin dudas, el más fuerte de los puntos negativos, ya que parece ser que el desarrollo de este título fue bastante problemático y tuvieron que recurrir a diversos "trucos" para hacer que el juego pudiera funcionar perfectamente, mapas pequeños (caminas unos pasos y te salta una pantalla de carga), muchas pantallas de carga, y el juego se reinicia cada vez que cambias de mapa (me refiero a que, al pasar de un mapa a otro, el juego se cierra y se vuelve a abrir, pero cargando el otro mapa, quizá porque era la manera más eficiente de limpiar la memoria). Ya por estas fechas el Framerate no debería ser un problema por la antiguedad del juego, así que ese punto lo omito.

[h1] En conclusión: [/h1]

Si jugaste al Deus Ex original (Deus Ex: The Conspiracy), deberías jugar este, seguro quieres saber qué fue de los Denton y de los Iluminati.

Si buscas un buen Shooter con un buen toque de Sigilo, Ciencia Ficción, RPG y una dificultad algo elevada, este es tu juego.

Si buscas un buen Deus Ex, este es uno, pero no comienzes por aquí, comienza por el primero (The Conspiracy), o quizá por el tercero (Human Revolution).

[b] *** Altamente Recomendado *** [/b]

(Si se fijan en el primer Trailer de Humankind Divided de 2015 (el animado), se darán cuenta de que gran parte de las escenas son referencias a este título, así que es posible que veamos un [b] remake [/b] en el futuro).

34436779.review:
I have very mixed feelings about Deus Ex: Invisible War. I had fun playing it most of the time but at the same time there were so many annoying things I had to deal with. I've never really written any "not recommended" reviews. Here I was close to doing so, but I changed my mind. I finished the game, it wasn't bad. It wasn't great. Let's not be too harsh.

I liked the story. I liked doing missions for different factions and feeling that I have to make some decisions in order to form my own story. Meeting some familiar faces from the first Deus Ex game was also very nice. The voice acting in Invisible War made me laugh so much. For example the grays (the creatures looking like aliens) or the biomodified  cyborgs smugglers called Omars have very funny voices. And of course people say silly things. The reactions in some situations don't feel realistic but it's not a bad thing in my opinion. How could we possibly take a game seriously when there are violent toilets which are trying to kill you, right? [url=https://clips.twitch.tv/AttractiveCloudyPenguinPastaThat] Fancy toilet-killers Twitch Clip	[/url]

The most annoying thing in the game are loading screens. Everytime you want to enter a location, BOOM loading screen! That's not all. The game will shut down before loading a new location. My Steam friends were suffering almost 20 hours by "PlasmaWasp just started playing Deus Ex: Invisible War". I am so sorry, guys and girls ;)

I was a bit disappointed that Invisible War ignores my decision from the first Deus Ex game. I don't want to include any spoilers but this game will completely ignore your Deus Ex (2000) ending. It's not like in Mass Effect where you can import your save files and continue.

The game was much more fun for me at the beginning. I felt like there was less and less exploration and less missions as the game progressed. In the end there was almost nothing. Just OP Paladin patrols and not enough supplies to take them down. It stopped being a tactical game. The only thing which worked for me was running fast through them while healing with biomodes. It didn't feel right. It didn't feel smart. I think part of the problem was universal ammo. Really bad idea if you ask me. The controls are bad. Obviously made for consoles. It got me killed several times just because switching weapons and inventory management are unnecessarily complicated, Definitely not what I am used to on PC. It should be simple and it should be fast!

It felt like they rushed the ending because they didn't have enough time to finish it properly. I don't really mind. At least I can start playing Human Revolution! It was a nice experience, I don't regret playing this game. I recommend Invisible War to big fans of Deus Ex games and its enviroment. It's probably not for casual gamers or gamers who don't have the patience to deal with older games with bad controls.

33531877.review:
My acquaintance with Deus Ex series continues. Despite the advices of many to skip and forget this game, I, after all, decided to play it and… they were right. It’s the worst Deus Ex title. Nevertheless, I don’t regret completing it, because now I can get enough of mocking this game and show you, why things are so bad and what’s broken here (though it is easier to show what is not broken here).   

Initially the review turned out to be bigger than I thought - 2500 words. And I think it's obvious that it hasn't fit into Steam limits. So, if you are willing to read the whole text with details - [url=https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Kdy4YB3vWiToGiK8bSZIBoSdmEjHLTsM/edit?usp=share_link&ouid=115064339293618789031&rtpof=true&sd=true]here is the link[/url]. Others can read this short review or, if they are tl;dr type of people – scroll down right to the end. Let us begin!

[h1][b] To begin with, surprisingly, pros of this game: [/b][/h1]

1) All food is now stacked in one slit without dividing into bars, soda, beer and etc.

2) Now there are 3-4 side quests on level, and sometimes it can turn out that one contradicts another and you have to choose which side to take. 

3) Occasionally nice ambient is played in the background.

[h1][b]  Pros are over… Here the cons go… [/b][/h1]

1) Inventory, interface and resources

Now, instead of nice RPG inventory with limited space, we have some semicircular crap with a bunch of slots where you can put anything you want. Body distribution damage system is changed with usual HP bar. Lock picks were removed, multitools now both hack electonics and open usual doors.Skills and augmentations are now comdined into one system
(not a bad idea actually, but how they combined them…).

2) Augmentations

And from here I honestly wanna start swearing. Dear developers, what the f*cking hell did you make? 

Canisters are no more divided by abilites, any usual or black market canister can give you any of its abilites. Okay, it’s even more convenient, but the division of these augmentation… oh, sh*t… 

It just doesn’t exist, the same thing as with the inventory: there are 5 slots, that are kinda arms, legs, eyes, noggin, torso. But in reality – nope! For instance, “into the head” you can implant: a) computer hacking b) invisibility for organic creatures c) toxic protection. And I think it’s already obvious that this is a complete bullsh*t. Cause you will need all 3 of these augmentations for stealth but you can put in only one of course. And this is not some kind of difficulty, no – this is just idiocy. Also I think you’ve already got that balance is totally screwed, cause the choice between two augmentations was just discarded, because invisibility for tech is put in into torso. 

3) Gameplay 

Oh, heavens!.. It’s just something I dunno… something unseen. Our dear b*tches developers decided to remove the ability to look round the corner… remove the ability to look round in stealh-action… Why? What’s the point of it? What had you been thinking with while doing it? 

The game’s locations are f*cking tiny! They are 1\10 times size of those, which were in the original, and during transferring between them and save loading the game relaunches (f*cking relaunches), and then a loading follows. All in all, the whole process takes about 30-40 seconds, during which the whole presence effect fades away (though it was never here… see below). The design of these locations is also a sight to behold. In 99% cases there are only two ways: a) here are a gun and a mine, kill the guard and blow the door b) there is a vent on the right, go by it and you will get behind the door. So the whole interest with tactical approach just flows away. 

I think that after all of the above, mentioning that AI is kinda stupid here will seem like a fly in the pile of sh*t. And as a subtotal, if all of this is combined together, you will understand that playing “this” is sometimes painful. 

I’ve completed first title in about 50 hours, thoroughly exploring all the levels. The second title with the same attitude was completed by me in 15 hours. Of course, considering pain from the gameplay, this is even got, but in reality… the game is 3 times shorter than the original.  

4) Atmosphere 

It is completely f*cked up here. Maybe because of the engine, maybe because of the handlessness of the developers, maybe because it’s the sequel – I do not know. Anyways, you do not sense yourself as a part of this world at all. Everything seems kinda toy and unrealistic. During the walkthrough I felt the game not like a dark cyberpunk world, that survived an apocalypse, but like a playground where children decided to play soldiers. And not that it’s a bad feeling, but man, not in a f*cking Deus Ex! 

5) Story

Well, it’s veeery so-so here. Really interesting it stars to be only at the end of the game, when you meet JC Denton. And I am sure that if you cut off the beginning and the middle of the game nothing is gonna change. At all! Because all the game characters, except those which were in the original (though these were messed a bit too), are dull and hardly memorable. Characters do not develop in any way, except JC which does a little bit. But he is nearly the main hero of this series and leaving his branch untouched would be a complete screw-up.And our hero or heroine – their gender does not really change anything - Alex D is on the same level as other characters: also dull, also hardly memorable. So, not to get into deep and complicated notions, I am gonna just say that I loved JC since the very first dialog with Paul on the Liberty Island and I didn’t give a hell about Alex up to the end of the game. 

And, after all, now actually the main drawback of the game that creates all the cons – the game was casualed! Man… this game… it was not even casualed… here a thoroughly thought-out gameplay system was thoroughly r*ped and f*cked!   

Damage distribution – f*ck it, different ammo for weapons – f*ck it, classical RPG inventory and resource management – f*ck it! And you know why it did get casualed? You’ll never guess…
  
RATING!
RATING!
F*CKING RATING!
SH*TTY RATING!
RAITING, B*TCH! 	
M RATING! 

So, school-attenders could also play Deus Ex! You think schoolers would like making difficult moral choices think about global story and compare facts? No!  As an end… a good moral choice is only the ending choice, and facts with the plot were not given sh*t about.

Summing all up… 

Is Deus Ex Invisible War a bad game? Surprisingly – no! In fact it has everything to give you a nice stealth-action experience or shooter with not really a complicated plot. Is Deus Ex Invisible War a bad game in the series? Definitely – yes! It has nothing of what fans like about the series, and even if it is presented, it’s totally broken. The second title could be completed one time just to get what’s going to happen in the future of Deus Ex

[h1][b]Conclusion[/b][/h1]

I don’t know what happened to Ion Storm by 2004: harmonic convergence, collective intelligence disable or sequel fever – but second Deus Ex came out the most hideous and the worst title in the series, nevertheless, in 2005 they released Thief Deadly Shadows. Yeah, the  game also was far from perfection: small locations, long loadings between them, but, man, the game had an atmosphere, gameplay and story. And the engine was the same! Why couldn’t you perform like this with Deus Ex Invisible War? C’mon you had made the first title! Of course, maybe, after second Deus Ex release you understood your mistakes and fixed them in third Thief, but anyways! Didn’t nobody get a feeling during alpha or beta test that that’s some kind of crap and not a Deus Ex game?..

P.S. Do not look at the time spent in the game, as I’ve mentioned, after loading a save file or transferring between locations  the game relaunches but Steam overlay does not. So, Steam counts only time spent in the main menu.

33367543.review:
[h1]I never asked for this...[/h1]

Steam really needs a [i] Maybe [/i] button.

After finishing one of the endings of Deus Ex: invisible war one feeling came to mind: regret, while at the same time I was confused. Was this a good game? Was this a mediocre game? Or was this a bad game?

Eventually, I came to the conclusion that the answer was none of the above.

At its best, it felt like the original Deus Ex. 
At its worst, it was nearly unplayable (I'm looking at you: escape from Antarctica levels)

The game itself is broken from a Deus Ex standard: the levels are broken, the freedom of gameplay is limited, the sound design is worse than Deus Ex GOTY and many functions which made the original fun are reworked so that what made them interesting in the first place was gone.

Bearing this mind, the game (obvious down grade from the original) still surprised and even impressed me in certain points, and occasionally managed to capture the original's atmosphere.

[i]Pros[/i]

-interesting story which follows Dues Ex.
-Contains many of characters from the previous Deus Ex game such as: Tracer Tong, JC Denton and friends.
-HUD, either you like it or you don't. I liked it.
-during the first acts: morality was actually tested and decision making somewhat mattered - I would go as far and say it was a slight improvement over the original

[i]Cons[/i]
-Level design, unlike the original game which featured open levels suiting for every style of play. Deus Ex: invisible war only really suits guns-blazing gameplay. Oh and also the levels are mostly cramped corridors, so expect rocket spam in the later levels.
-Gameplay: it's just guns-blazing. So no stealthily ninja melee only (melee is broken) moments. Nuff said.
-worst jump ever.
-Voice acting: bland and uninteresting for the most part.
-music: bland and just a single cord been pressed for a minute. However, there are some interesting half-decent tracks present here and there.

-Simplification of mechanics: honestly expect the worst. Even after thoroughly researching the downsides of this game. I was still disappointed on so many levels. This is something you have to find out yourself.

33321487.review:
I have always enjoyed this game since it first came out on Xbox. I finally got it for PC on the last steam sale and I ran into two problems that are easily fixed but the answers were difficult to find.  I hope this helps anyone else who encounters them or was reluctant to buy it because of them.


1.  No widescreen resolution support

This game does not natively support widescreen resolutions,  bummer for all of us running widescreen resolutions on modern hardware.  You can stretch to fit one of the very few supported 4 x 3 resolutions, but it just plain looks terrible no matter what you do.  However there is a simple mod that allows the game to play pretty much any widescreen resolution without any graphical, aspect ratio, HUD or FOV bugs.  It is called Deus Ex Widescreen Utility V2.2  It is available on the internet if you choose to search for it.  Just place it in the system folder of Deus Ex Invisble War directory and run the EXE, it will walk you through it.  


2,  No controller support

If you are casual gamer like me and play from a couch in the living room on a home theater system, you will be disappointed to find out this game does not natively support the xbox or xinput controllers.  They will work in the menus but the keys and axis will not fucntion or map properly.  This game does however have full directinput joystick support.  So if you have an xinput to directinput emulator, an old directinput controller or a logitech controller with a xinput to directinput toggle switch, then you are in luck.  Just map the controls to the appropriate buttons and sticks of your controller and the game will play just like it did back in the old xbox days.  You will have some buttons left over so you might want to map the start button on your controller to the escape key because you cannot map the menu button.  It not you will have to press the escape key on your keyboard any time you wish to bring up the main menu to save.

32122363.review:
Deus Ex:  Invisible War Review (Spoilers)

Twenty years after the events of the original game's official ending, the Illuminati and other related factions have once again risen in a struggle for power.  JC Denton's existance is almost mythical as he has merged with the Helios AI.  In Invisible War you play as Alex Denton, a genetic offspring project of JC Denton.  Unlike the original JC Denton who already had a goal from the beginning working for UNATCO, in here you'll have the options throughout all the levels to aid certain factions in their goals.  Of course, more of the "conspiracy" stuff is strewn about.  Although unlike the last game which was red pilling anyone who played it, in here it's more of a convenient plotline.

This is essentially a watered down and more buggy Deus Ex.  It's also a lot shorter.  This game receives a lot of flack for not being as good as its predecessor, but the original was so damn good that it's almost asking the impossible.  So although this has many flaws it's still a good game worth playing.  Some of the improvements:  the "nanokey" and all the door codes that you'd otherwise have to check your notes for have all been condensed into one system.  This means that while speaking with characters who give you codes, or reading datacubes that have passwords/codes, all of them are automatically logged onto your keyholder, or whatever it's called here.  Also the voice acting and dialoge is great.  The graphics, as expected, look a lot better.  Also this game's color scheme is very different from the original and a lot of the places look great.  Some of the locations are unique, like the Mosque in Cairo.  You'll also revisit places from the original game which is a nice treat for prior fans.

And now for the bad.  This game is buggy.  Enemies may end up blowing themselves up.  The game crashed on me every other time I played it.  Loading takes forever.  The ammo system is awful.  Instead of each gun having its own ammunition, in this world you have universal ammo clips.  What this means is you'll have a little bar in the corner of the screen that shows how much ammo you have left.  Each gun requires its own amount of ammo used.  There's no number to track it, you just see the bar go down and the clips get used up as you use the gun.  This would not be the worst thing, but the guns take so much damn ammo.  I was running on empty nearly the second half of the game.  Somehow I made it through but this gets really frustrating.  Also the biomod system is screwed up.  Originally if you had a biomod canister you'd simply use it on whatever feature you'd like improved.  Here though it's not so simple.  There are two types of canisters - regular and black market.  Further, the features you want to improve are divided into a few catagories, which then have subcatagories of their own.  You can only choose one of these subcatagories EACH.  So if you have strength upgraded fully under one main catagory but then you choose to upgrade the black market biomod, your melee attacks are gonna hit like a wet noodle because you will lose it.  I didn't figure this out until it was too late and I was swapping biomods, essentially wasting the precious canisters and wondering why all my upgraded levels for certain things was reverting back to nothing.  This is frustrating and not necessary.  Also the inventory system is weird.  You'll have six main switchable items where you can hit 1-6 on the keyboard and switch to it quickly.  To access the other items you need to press "V" (because all the menus are awkwardly divided) and then switch from the storage to the main 1-6 to use it.  Not a gamebreaker, but again, frustrating and not necessary, especially considering how the original game got all this stuff right the first try.  Characters are unlikeable and easily forgotten.  The only good thing is you'll get a chance to kill some of them off as you play through the game.  

And of course there are multiple endings to keep with Deus Ex tradition.  Although in the first game I blew up everything up and reverted man back into the stone age, the official ending was JC Denton merging with the AI.  Since that had already been done, I decided to merge my own character with the AI.  The ending was weird with a speech from Helios about how humanity is becoming a hive mind or some crap like that.  With the lack of impact from the story and overall inferiority to the original, I'm probably not going to remember this game way down the line like I did with the original.  Everything is simply watered down.  Still, I will say play it.  It's a good game, we just have our expectations too high.  If it was some sort of original IP, we'd all agree it was a good first entry for the franchise.

[b]Deus Ex 2: Invisible War is in all aspects the lesser version of its predecessor and will easily be forgotten.[/b]

[b]The Good[/b][list][*]DX2 tries to offer [b]player choice[/b], through the main quest but also while working on puzzles/quests. Though not at all as much as DX1.[*]There are (of course) lots of [b]references to DX1[/b] that are fun to see as a DX1 fan.[*][b]Graphics are slightly better[/b] than DX1. Even though that one is 5 years older! There is also a physics engine now that tries to add some realism.[/list]

[b]The Bad[/b][list][*]The game suffers from [b]Console Dumb Down Syndrome[/b]. The inferface is very clunky. Game mechanics are simplified compared to DX1: universal ammo, less augmentations, no skills, bad menus. Maps are very small to fit in the XBOX its memory, but still take a long time to load, even on SSD.[*]The story is quite bland and tries to continue on from DX1. Characters are very [b]one dimensional and unlikable[/b]. Result: you don't care.[*]Despite using the same engine family as DX1 (Unreal Engine), this implementation is not as flexible as the one in DX1. No [b]custom resolutions or FOVs[/b] without modifications. The interface also does not scale well to different screen ratios.[/list]

[b]The second Deus Ex game luckily appears to have a higher quality successor that I'm looking forward to: Deus Ex Human Revolution![/b]

31894903.review:
TL:DR at the bottom.

After playing and completing the first 3 games in the Deus Ex franchise, I can say with confidence that this is the weakest one that I have played, but is not completely unplayable with no redeeming qualities. This is a game that takes a lot of forgiving some of the bizarre choices the developers made to get enjoyment from this installment.

First off, this game needs to be played with the Visible Mod to improve some of the more awful aspects of this game. It will improve resolution and load times plus more. 

The biggest thing that you will notice right off the bat is that the whole UI has been given this circular look, where part of the inventory is shown on the left side of the screen. Accessing the rest of your inventory, biomods, and objectives/images is done with hotkeys. The change was made to accommodate console players more, however the pc crowd will reject this new look, as it is less convenient, and feels clunky to work with.
The inventory system has been changed dramatically to simplify things. Every weapon and item, regardless of size, will take up the same amount of space in your inventory. This change was unnecessary, since it creates more frustration with items, punishing the value of small items. Resident evil 4 used the box method and it worked fine, and it was made for consoles. Ion Storm has enough good developers to make the system work on console.
All ammo is now universal which may not sound like a huge issue, but this system shows its flaws when you use certain weapons a lot, and the issue really shows in the last level. As absurd that it is that a rocket launcher and a flame thrower use the same ammo as a pistol, the real issue is how the weapons use the ammo. Certain weapons will use more ammo per shot than others, typically reflected by their strength. However, to conserve ammo, (since some enemies that become much more common cannot be realistically killed with melee weapons), you will not use certain strong weapons, which takes a lot of joy out of these weapons. The more powerful, interesting weapons would be more attractive to use if each weapon had their own ammo type, and balancing the weapons would’ve been more successful in this case.
Skills are completely removed from this game, taking this franchise from a first person rpg to a clunky shooter with stealth elements that poorly implemented. All depth from the combat is removed, taking most of the strategy out of fighting, and it’s no longer fun to try to stealth your way through most rooms. The game puts a large focus on shooting, which isn’t what the franchise was known for. 
The endings of the first game were genius in the sense that people can argue about which one they think was the best. Invisible War’s endings are not nearly as debatable, with some of them being awful, and others being just meh. They left less of an impression on me than the first game did.
The biggest problem I had with Invisible War was the awful worldbuilding the game did for the first 3-5 hours. With the first game, it was clear as to what you were supposed to be doing always; the intro of the game covered that perfectly. Invisible War goes out of its way to not tell the player who anyone is, why they do what they do, and why should I care about any of this. The characters in the beginning of the game won’t tell Alex who is doing what, what the state of the world is, or how he’s tied up into all of it. The first parts of the game are extremely slow plot wise because of this. I had so much trouble staying interested throughout the first 3-5 hours because of the complete lack of knowledge about the world. However, once you learn more about the factions involved, it shows that the factions themselves are what they appear to be, and don’t operate under the same shades of grey that the factions in the first game did. 


The game does do a good number of things right. The soundtrack is excellent, as well as most of the voice acting. Once the plot starts existing, it is well told, and is interesting throughout the rest of the game. Levels are designed well, and the places that Alex will travel are interesting and one of the strong parts. The lore is interesting. The game does a great job covering philosophy, and certain characters can convey their thoughts in a coherent, and new way. It’s one of the few hallmarks of a Deus Ex game that remain here.


TL:DR
Overall the game isn’t bad, but meh. If you aren’t willing to forgive the awful worldbuilding, the move away from rpg elements, and the mostly forgettable cast, then you will not enjoy this game. If you are a hardcore Deus Ex fan and you can forgive these shortcomings, there is enjoyment to be had, and is worth picking up when the game is on sale. Get the Visible Mod to fix some issues the game has.

This is not a good game, I repeat, this is not a good game. But... it doesn't matter anymore.

I remember seeing the first screenshots from the so-called Deus Ex2. I was totally impressed by the dynamic lights, the graphics and rest of the stuff, it seemed to me that the news Deus Ex will be one dark and awesome game, full of conspiracy and great cyberpunk atmosphere. And it's REALLY hard to me to not compare its world-shattering predecessor. I was absorbed by it fully, after all. Because it's one bad Deus Ex game, stripped from all the best features we all loved - the skills, the weapon-mod and the ammo system. On the other hand it's one easy and mediocre FPS, which would not be remembered if the company named it "Invisible War" instead. 

Playing it for the first time (and returning to the game for the third time in ten years) I must say that something feels off from the very beginning. It's about the intro movie and the graphics, they feel cheap, not fitting the whole Deus Ex universe. And then it gets worse, once you spot the famous Oblivion like game physics. Claustrophobic maps are the biggest problem here, as well. How the hell is it possible that the first map in the original Deus Ex was almost 10 times bigger than the city hub in this one? No loader screens, no interrupting, you were free to explore. Here, on the other hand, you are just like a rat, closed in your small, not-so-cozy cage. 

The story doesn't make you going either. You just play to kill, to get more ammo, because you ALWAYS need it. No stealth, no other way, no picking or guessing the code. It doesn't matter if you kill the guards or commit homicide in the whole hub, you simply do not care about the people (even the main characters), they are void of emotions, like robots. 

It's recommended to play with the most recent unofficial patch, it resolves some compatibility errors in windows 10 and fixes AI and graphic glitches. 

The fnal rating - 4/10

+ It's still a Deus Ex game. Unfortunately.

- The broken physics, voices and plot.
- The small maps.
- Lack of the ammo, weapon-mod, skill system.

30685689.review:
Tags: 1PStealth - First Person Stealth
Recommended: Community Patches - See Forums

TLDR: Sound effects - presentation are still the correct flavor for a Deus Ex entry. Main quest has some interesting side characters and sidequests. Is very handicapped for having been designed for Xbox, areas are tiny, game is streamlined/consolized

Review/Commentary: 
Deux Ex : Invisible War, Second in the franchise, does not have the scope, narrative buildup and flair, charisma of the original, nor does it have the mechanical complexity of it, relinquishing some of its RPG hybrid features in favor of a more streamlined experience. No more skills, experience, biomods are no longer permanent and can be re-allocated. What hurts this game the most is the general cluelessness of the main protagonist, the AI is both a little dumb and goes berserk if provoked by hacking.

The game compares fairly well to say system shock 2, with a similar level of complexity, a more approachable level design.

The plot has some layers and some reveals, and multiple factions with different objectives will all try to sway the main protagonist's actions in their favor, it is sometimes, even often, possible to play the game trying to maximize rewards by playing on multiple fronts but the game might be more enjoyable picking a side, and living with the consequences of treating the opposing camp as enemy. There are at least three different endings with vastly different choices.

The game does not tie-in very well with the rest of the deus ex series, although it is the second in the series, the events happen last chronologically in the deus ex lore, and it is sometimes easier to treat this world as an alternate universe version of the deus ex franchise than a direct continuation and makes the game more enjoyable.

Conclusion: Worth a playthrough if you adjust your expectations and have nothing better in the genre on standby

30502289.review:
When people say that games are controversial, that usually involves two sides screaming at each other, saying their opinion is the correct one.

Deus Ex: Invisible War is controversial in the sense that you have the majority of people saying that it's a hyper-streamlined mess, and a smaller, more demure audience saying that "Well, I mean, it's an okay game, just not a great Deus Ex game".

That second audience has a point. Or would, if I could fit the rest of the sentence in without a 15-second long loadpoint inbetween. 

[h1]"When ability becomes a public resource, what will distinguish people will be what they decide to do with it. Intention. Dedication. Integrity. The qualities we would choose as the bedrock to the new society."[/h1]
[i]- Paul Denton[/i]

Here's Invisible War in a nutshell; Remember Liberty Island from the first game? Nice place, good view. 

Now remove everything in the middle, the statue and complex, and quite a bit off the sides. Remove the bunker, that's a loading zone. Remove all the objects, all those walls and suchlike, replace them with some scattered crates. Split what's remaining into 2 different loading zones that you can and will have to repeatedly travel back and forth between. Because that's the final level.

Kneecaps the game straight off the bat. 15 seconds of loading every two minutes. Even less downtime if you're trying to complete a sidequest. 

Real shame. Mechanically it's not even bad. Probably enjoyed running a Terminator build better than the first game, energy cells are liberally thrown at you along with unlimited recharge points, and it wants you to use augments whenever you feel like it.

Augments themselves are fun to play it, and weapon mods actually have a couple of interesting effects over just damage and range. Only real issue itself is that your character progression caps out almost immediately if you don't decide to respec with the amount of initial biomods and weapons thrown at you.

Also hacking is an augment now because reasons.

[h1]"I have no enemies, merely topographies of ignorance."[/h1]
[i]- JC Denton[/i]

Gameplay itself is standard console FPS stuff. Nothing broken, nothing to write home about.

Unless you're packing the speed augment, movement is slow and enemies, apart from one lategame enemy type, are fairly stationary. There's multiple enemy types to incentivize carrying both EMP and ballistics weapon types, but the universal ammo system, the fairly small ammo cap and that enemies will never really hit you when you're sprinting with the speed augment on, means you can probably just run past them.

Universal ammo and the ammo cap being so small does make it a weird balancing act of strafing and concentrating on actually hitting people in the head. Stop n start pacing. If that sounds strategic, it's not. It's generally pretty good about "refunding" your ammo loss through ammo drops and the environment but there's a lategame enemy type the game loves to spam that doesn't drop ammo and explodes immediately when it dies, making melee a no-go.

There's presumably some stealth stuff, I didn't bother with it. 

[h1]"Now for the REAL endgame"[/h1]
[i]- The secret party level with 150 pages of quotes in it[/i]

With your choice of either teen dream pop star with gelled hair, or girl with her eyes textured directly onto her face and looking in slightly different directions, you solve the rather rushed mystery of why your secret biomod academy was raided.

Let's stop this review to say that you don't get to say it's an Invisible War when your main enemy has recruitment booths in the mall. 

Invisible War does have the distinction of being the one Deus Ex with decent endings, but the writing does have some anti-climactic pacing issues. It's pretty underwritten and doubles as a tumble of reveals and plot twists without buildup. Ends up feeling floaty. 

The best paced reveal in the game is about two competing coffee shops.

So the only real, crippling problem with Invisible War is the tiny levels and constant, unending load times. And that's a very real, crippling problem. So crippling it's booted to the footnotes of history, despite the very real care and effort that went into the game proper.

If you're playing this, you're playing it to see just exactly what happened for this game to end up so ignored. An archaeological dig more than a functioning tour. If you're here for that, it's playable.

Otherwise I'd recommend moving on, like everyone else.

30075543.review:
Hoo boy, Invisible War. Where do I begin? Well, first off, no, I don't think it's the worst Deus Ex game (that unfortunate honor goes to The Fall, and don't even get me started on GO), but that doesn't mean I think it's the best, either. There are some things I even believe go above and beyond what Deus Ex 1 did, like the fact that you can choose which faction you can side with, and it actually has consequences for who you decide to help. Granted, you can change sides at a whim, but it was much better than having the game say "nope, you're on this side now because your brother told you so" like the first game, and definitely miles above the later games in the franchise, which have no excuse for how linear they are. Hell, I'd even go as far to say that I prefer IW to the Squeenix DX titles in a good amount of ways.

But, of course, as you've probably all heard, there are some issues with the game. Glaring issues, at that, the largest and most pervasive of which is the dumbing down of the systems relative to Deus Ex 1 in order to get the game running (and selling) on the original Xbox. Skill points are gone, with the skills they represented either gone completely or implemented into augmentations. Individual weapon ammunition gets the boot as well, with a universal ammo system that sounds good on paper but fails in implementation in their place. Independent limb damage also gets the boot, meaning that you can't blow your arms and legs off and crawl around using your nipples anymore. The levels have been shrunk in order to fit into the Xbox's 64 MB of RAM (a limitation that the PC port is also upheld to), which means more loading times as well. And, to top it all off, the script complexity got chopped down heavily in order to get it to look good at 480i on a CRT television.

Unfortunately, on top of that, the game has not aged well in the slightest. Without a patch, it wigs out whenever it's played on a multi-core processor, it crashes frequently, and sometimes even refuses to boot for no discernable reason until you reboot your system. It also doesn't support widescreen displays without hex editing or special tools, and even then, it looks absolutely awful. The visuals (which I'm led to believe were a major cause for the levels being so small) are absolutely horrid by today's standards, even when compared to Deus Ex 1. This mainly comes down to the fact that all the humans rest firmly in the uncanny valley. The DX1 characters were awkward, blocky, and all looked the same, but it worked in their favor because the animation matched that. DX2 characters look realistic in comparison, but... Jesus, they're all grotesque. This falls on the animation, mainly. They animate almost exactly like the DX1 characters, and if you've ever seen DX1 with the HDTP models, you know how bad decent models look with that. 

But, overall, I enjoyed Invisible War in spite of its flaws. It's the last game made by the original DX crew, and it's definitely got the same spirit as the first, and is quite fun even if it was cut down. You can do much worse for games, hell, you can do much worse for Deus Ex games than Invisible War, and I'd say it's at least worth one go through for you to decide for yourself if this really is the worst DX game like everyone says it is.

30050057.review:
The invisible game that some people insist doesn't exist, despite it being better than some of the major titles released in the past year or so. As others have stated, this game would probably have a much bigger fanbase if it simply didn't have "Deus Ex" in the title.

Deus Ex: Invisible War is a sequel to the original Deus Ex, taking place 20 years after a combination of all three of the original game's endings. The world has suffered from "The Collapse", where all global communication was shut down due to what happened in Area 51 at the end of Deus Ex. In the aftermath, the WTO and the Order helped the world recover. But the conspiracies of those who would control the fate of the world--and humanity--didn't end at Area 51. After a terrorist attack that destroys Chicago, the player is put into the shoes of a biomodified agent-in-training that discovers the truth behind the governments and organizations that run the world in 2072.

As one might expect from how many Deus Ex fans pretend the game doesn't exist, there are a few flaws with Invisible War. Said flaws are important to know in advance to give a proper framework for enjoying the game. One of the big ones is that the game was designed specifically to run on the original Xbox as well as the PC, which means that it doesn't always play nice with modern (Windows 7 and onward) PCs and doesn't make use of multiple CPU cores. This also reflects in the level design, which cuts up some areas into smaller sub-areas with loading screens. The Xbox platform also ended up causing a simplification of the interface, which can go a little too far in some cases (such as the low number of potential keybinds).

Another issue with the game, which it shares with the original game, is the blandness of the voice acting. Aside from the voice-modulated Omar cyborgs, a lot of characters sound more like students reading lines from a textbook than characters in a conspiracy thriller. Sometimes it was intentional or justified (such as JC's monotone in both games, which has reasons that the developers have stated), but most of the time you'll have to add inflection mentally to really get into the story.

On the good side of things, Invisible War allows the same kind of emergent solution-finding as any other Deus Ex game. If you really try, you can play the game in almost any way you want. With the right gear and biomods, you'll almost always have at least two ways to accomplish an objective (and you'll probably have an alternate objective that still continues the story). Stealth, combat (lethal or non-lethal), diplomacy, hacking, lockpicking, and vent-crawling are all encouraged. There are a few overpowered builds (such as melee strength + stealth + baton for near-instant KOs of unarmored human enemies), but almost every option has at least some use. And unlike some games, you'll get more than enough upgrade points to upgrade every biomod, and you have the ability to swap out biomods if you don't like them (at the cost of losing the spent points in the rejected mod). So if you regret your choice in biomods, you don't always have to start over to try again.

The story is much shorter than the original game and Human Revolution, clocking in at about 10 hours if you do ~90% of the content. However, there are enough alternate scenes and objectives that it can be worth replaying if a single playthrough isn't enough. The story itself is decent as a more sci-fi followup to the ending of Deus Ex, but there are some important characters that don't get enough development or screentime and the pacing ramps up a bit too quickly near the end (and leads to an area with so many enemies that some playstyles will be extra difficult at the end). The final choices in the last location are interesting from a philosophical standpoint, but the endings don't seem to fully develop these ideas (many of which were better handled in the ending monologues of Human Revolution).

All in all, it is a good game that gets more bad press than it deserves. It won't ever be able to step out of the shadow of the original Deus Ex or the more recent revival prequels, but it's still a good diversion for those who enjoy cyberpunk games that allow for the freedom of problem-solving that Deus Ex is known for.

29841047.review:
Wow, I don't get all the negative reviews about this game.  Although, I agree with the general consensus that this is not on the level of the first Deus Ex in terms of overall game mechanics, depth of story, and function; I still think this game in and of itself is worthy of at least a decent rating to say the least.

What I liked:

I personally liked how the game integrated weapon upgrades and I liked how the weapons themselves functioned, although I do agree that the biomods and overall mechanics are more deeper in Deus Ex 1, this games mechanics while not as intricate are still good in their own right, and you have to remember this was made for both PC and consoles simultaneously so naturally there are going to be some hardware limitations both in function and overall game layout (now weither that is the way it should or was intended to have been is up for debate).

I also liked the very deep explanation and reasoning that JC Denton gave for his world plan, I thought some of the end game speeches were very emotional in terms of philosphy and relatability to the current state of affairs in our world and evolution.  I also liked how alot of the side quests had some end-ties that made you think about people and morality (like the 'coffee wars' and the 'real' NG resonance).

What I disliked:

What I disliked about the game were its minor bugs and quirky mechanics (like the jumping sometimes was springy and ascending and descending ladders sometimes was glitchy as well).  I also disliked the loading screens and I think the devs should have addressed this for the PC release, but as for a console the loading screens are justified due to obvious hardware constraints.  

I also disliked the random crashes when simultaneously alt-tabbing and using google chrome, as well as some very rare crash(es) that only happened 1 or 2 times out of 30+ hours of gameplay.  I also thought the keymapping wasn't very well implemented and the fact the steam overlay didn't work due to some .exe anomoly was kinda lazy to not be addressed for the steam release in my opinion. And lastly I thought some of the dialogue was dry and uneventful during some parts of the game. 

What is up for debate:

The universal ammo system could be a tossup in terms of it being good or bad as well as how the limited augmentations are implemented, althought the limited augs/biomods and the ability to interchange them mid-game somewhat makes sense in terms of form and function.  As well as how the devs decided to merge all three past endings to be the cannon for this game is all up for debate and is not either good or bad in my opinion.


Pros:

+Very good mid-game and end-game story dialogue that really has some deep morality and philsophical messages.
+Good weapon mechanics and entertaining ragdoll physics.
+Stylish weapons and atmosphere that really capture the futuristic cyberpunk lore.
+Game title that really fits the layout of the game (the wars really are invisible as they are mostly all internal).  As well as some good cannonical endings and happenings that mostly tie in well with the first deus ex (although the implementation of all 3 endings of Deus Ex 1 is debatable in terms of how it was implemented).
+Good music/ambiance and implementation of throwback remixes from Deus Ex 1


Cons:

-Load times that should have been addressed for the PC port.
-Poorly implemented steam interface in terms of in-game functionality of the overlay that should have been addressed pre-release in steam.
-some minor mechanic bugs that seem obvious (namely the jump mechanic and ladder climbing seemed like it had clippng issues at times).
-debatable mechanics in terms of form and function (namely universal ammo and a debatable sneak detection mechanic)

Overall I give this game a strong 7.5/10

29294491.review:
If you know anything about Invisible War, you're probably aware of its many shortcomings: cramped levels, frequent and long loading and simplified gameplay to name a few, and while all of this is true, resulting in one of the most disappointing sequels in video game history, Invisible War is still a solid game in its own right. That won't stop me from bagging it for the majority of this review, however...

I'm not going to be saying anything new here. Invisible War is inferior to the original masterpiece in almost every single respect, but that's not to say it has no redeeming features. Firstly, the soundtrack is underappreciated. It's nowhere near on the level of the glorious original, but it is still some solid ambience that suits the game's atmosphere well. Secondly, the game still delivers when it comes to player choice. While few decisions truly impact future outcomes outside of the endings, there are many choices you can make that have immediate benefits and detriments, so it feels like you're making a difference in the world regardless. Lastly, while the game's artstyle has been drastically changed for the worst, featuring a more generic sci-fi aesthetic rather than the cyberpunk, near-future vibe crucial to the theme of the first game, this is still a very impressive looking game for its time with awesome dynamic lighting and detailed character models.

What drags IW down most of all is the level design. All paths available are immediately evident to you because areas are so small that the opportunity for exploration is greatly restricted. There's no real need for creativity or ingenuity because there's always a vent right in front of you or a front door to blast through. There's not enough wiggle room to offer genuine freedom and stealth is a joke. These levels are truly tiny and sneaking in this game revolves almost exclusively around going invisible with your augmentation and running past enemies rather than circumventing threats via alternate paths, distraction or timing. The game's also braindead easy. You're going to get hurt a lot in combat, but the game dumps ammo and healing on you at all times to the point of making damage and ammo quantity negligible, and the game offers almost all available weapons, weapon mods and augs to you by the third hour. There's no consequence to bruteforcing your way to objectives because there's no challenge anyway.

The worst thing about this game is the story. I don't understand what went wrong here. The original was a relatively realistic depiction of where humanity would be in fifty years - except that every conspiracy theory ever is true. It was greatly exaggerated at times, but there was typically a believable explanation for everything and nothing felt extraordinary given the time and world it took place in. It was deep, philosophical, political, conspiratorial and relevant. It touched upon a broad range of topics and cultures. It also had plenty of heart. You developed relationships across the game and saw the blights of humantity, but there were also many moments of brevity from the bleakness with humour. It's a game that raised a lot of questions and tackled real-world concerns and it feels shockingly relevant even 23 years later because it was just so intelligent and insightful. It didn't so much "predict" the future so much as it presented the possibilities of the future based on the current world events in the time that it was created - both tangible and... less tangible. Invisible War doesn't really accomplish any of these things. It doesn't say anything particularly profound or ask any questions not already pondered over previously. When it does, it lacks subtelty. It's more interested in its immediate plot - a lacklustre retread of ideas from the original featuring recurring characters with twisted motivations, lame plot-twists and ridiculous faction objectives and contrivances set in a post-societal collapse yet simultaneously hyper sci-fi world that has no valid explanation for existing - rather than keeping things grounded and offering insight into the current world we exist in. It's too far, too silly and feels a whole lot too much like fan-fiction. There's little emotional weight and none of the characters are likable. The new ones are forgettable and largely one-dimensional with few notable exceptions (the Omar and NG Resonance), and as previously mentioned, the reintroductions of old ones are highly questionable. I don't think anyone would have predicted the decisions the original cast would have made in this sequel and that's because they're not them. They don't have the same traits or motivations and where they end up and how is just odd. See for yourself and ask yourself if any of them align in any way with the characters you were once familiar with. Perhaps one or two do... the rest? I don't see it. Lastly, of the four Deus Ex protagonists, Alex D is definitely the least interesting. He/she doesn't have much of a backstory or character arc, only being a servant to other people for the entire game and a clone of JC and Paul Denton in more ways than one (this isn't really a spoiler because the game makes it obvious from the start and announces it unceremoniously). This game is almost more about JC Denton than Alex - in which case, I'd rather we had just played as JC again. They also don't have the charm of Adam or JC. No James Bond one-liners, no lengthy debates on philosophy and politics and just generally barely any emotional response to the world around them. No line of dialogue comes remotely close here to even the dullest of the original game and Human Revolution's moments.

Another terrible letdown about Invisible War is its generally janky nature. Physics are absurd, movement is clunky, and it is bugs galore. Don't get me wrong, the original had more than its fair share of unintended goofiness, but unlike Invisible War, it rarely took you out of the experience.

With all that being said, what I like about IW isn't outweighed by its necessary comparisons to its predecessor and successors. Ultimately, while simple, combat is really satisfying. Blasting people in the face with an explosive shotgun then watching their ragdoll's limbs twist and morph as they fly into a bunch of physics objects never gets old. The story has moments of intrigue and interacting with the citizens of the world can be a joy when it isn't directly relating to a certain other game. Participating in petty corporate wars? Amusing. Being tasked to break into a club's basement to steal data to a group of blackmarket cyborgs? Entertaining. Probing the AI facade of an international popstar for being a blatant piece of spyware? Intriguing. Even hearing the ideologies of a universal religion, no matter how unbelievable they may be, is still deeper and more interesting than what most games can offer. Exploring these bite-sized environments (breaking into apartments, bartering with snake oil merchants, completing side-quests) is still a ton of fun too and while I think overall the story is a joke, there are again moments where it holds up on its own. Dude Sex: Invisible Whore is a satisfying shooter that gives you more flexibility in approaching objectives than most and honestly, that's enough to make a good game.

If this was 2003 and we had been eagerly anticipating the sequel to what I consider to be the greatest game ever released, only to be served a significantly shorter, pitifully underwhelming experience at full price, there's no way in hell I'd recommend it... but given that there's a simple mod to improve compatibility on modern platforms and the game is only a little over a dollar on sale, it's a pretty easy recommendation given that it's still a fairly solid game. Just forget about trying to stealth through it, be rewarded for thinking outside the box or being immersed in a relatable world because this game's inept at those things. This is "baby's first im-sim" at best.
