28937690.review:
[NO SPOILERS]

If ever there was a game that was judged by association, this it it.

More than anything, Invisible War is judged by the Deus Ex in it's name. Before it is even installed, it is expected to be at least as good and preferably better than one of the greatest games of all time. Hardly fair odds.

As a result many people don't see anything other than the fact that Invisible War is not the same as the original Deus Ex. It doen't get a chance to stand on it's own and be judged on merit.
It's like starting a music career by being told that if you don't do better than The Beatles, you are a complete failure.

IMO Invisible War should be seen not as the sequel to Deus Ex, but as a different game in the same universe. The was Thor is not a sequel to Iron Man, but simply a different film set in the same universe.
While there are many of the same themes and elements, the end products are not the same.

If judged on it's own merit, Invisible War is a pretty great game. Sure, the levels are small, but they are well designed and offer many gameplay options.
The shooting is competent. Much better than it ever was in Deus Ex. Controls are well above most games of it's time.

It's no secret that many things were dumbed down from Deus Ex. While I do prefer the old, more advanced system which gave more player options, the new, simpler system is perfectly functional. And given the in-game time gap between the two games, such changes can easily be explained by technological development. Just look at the difference in weapons from WW1 to WW2.

One major point that divides people is the universal ammo. Personally, I think it's interesting. While it doesn't make much logical sense that all types of weapons would use the same ammo, it does bring something new to the game.
Since different weapons use different amounts of ammo with each shot, inventory management becomes more important. Especially for people like me who in most games are used to just using the pistol 95% of the time and therefore always having plenty of ammo for the big guns. In Invisible War you can't just squirrel away lots of ammo for the big guns and save it for the big enemies. Now you actually have to plan ahead from time to time.
While it's not a system I would like to see widely used in games, I do find it interesting.

Bottom line:
I personally think Invisible War is a very solid game. It is unfairly judged by it's association with a game it could never live up to.
Take it as a single game and judge it on it's own merit. Do that and you will likely find that it is much better than people give it credit for. In fact, it is very good game.

27914567.review:
Although currently my steam ID says I beat this game in 10 hours, according to the save time it was actually 8 hours and 2 minutes. To put that in perspective it took me roughly 25-26 hours to beat the first Deus Ex the first time and around 15-16 to beat Mankind Divided, which almost everyone agrees is too short. This game is very short for a Deus Ex game, so don't expect the same amount of build up and revelation that you might have gotten in other games. For instance, in the first hour you discover that the illuminati still exist and are up to no good in the neighborhood. All of that being said, for the price that you can get this game on sale (around $2.49 I think) it's a solid chunk o' fun. You end up going to like 4 cities, so if you were pissed that all of Mankind Divided took place in Prague, then this game might suit you.
The most obvious problem with the game is that it was made for consoles, and by consoles I mean OLD consoles (like the first xbox). Therefore you won't get any large areas or levels. Even when they redo liberty island from the first game it is split into 3 different sections (not including UNATCO headquarters). The game was certainly not optimized for PCs and the game engine will crash if there are too many objects with physics. There were a few times when I was stuck because the game would spawn in enemies right after I had made a save and them spawning would crash the game. The way that I found would fix this was to destroy boxes and such that were using the physics engine, but such a problem shouldn't exist in such a simple (both graphically and mechanically) game. Sometimes it feels like no work went into the areas of the game because you generally run into the same features in each city.
-A bar where you hire a pilot and progress the main objective
-A locked off area where the final objective in that area will end up taking you
-Apartments where you have to kill someone or something
-The same factions and coffee shops (I know that it's important to the narrative for both of these, but seriously)
IF I were to commend the game on one thing, it is that each city has roughly the same amount of secondary objectives. I remember when I played the first Deus Ex that all the side quests were in New York and places like Hong Kong had literally nothing to do but follow the main quest (despite Hong Kong being larger and better designed than New York).
Really the only other reason I would recommend this game besides the fact that I like Deus Ex is that this game has some interesting lore. This game doesn't cling on to companies and characters from the first game (although it does include them) and the developers seem to have taken the time to try to develop new ideas. The most interesting that comes to mind is the Omar, who are like a more extreme version of Helios's final phase.
Whatever. I like the game, it was okay, and most importantly it was cheap. Get it when it goes on sale.

26895868.review:
I'm a die-hard fan of this franchise, and after playing Deus Ex and Human Revolution, I decided to give this game a shot.

Storyline wise, I feel like it failed to live up to the complexities of plot associated with the Deus Ex title. When I saw that one of the side quests was about coffee sellers, I was a hightly underwhelmed. Of course, it being Deus Ex, they found a way to make such a trivial thing a part of a more meaningful framework, and that, however, was the impressive part. Such a silly thing was used as an illustrator of the absolute means of control that was in place by the Illuminati.

The numerous options of progressing in the game were a plus, however. Invisible War's faction system that provides you with different groups to give your loyalty to, and the ways that these groups may still ask you to do things that make you uncomfortable are an impressive reflection of the not-so-black-and-white situation of being affiliated with any group. I appreciated the faction system and their contrary objectives in a given stage.

Gameplay was a bit clunky though. That ring-shaped HUD, for one, was a massive, epic fail in my opinion that obscured far too much of the line of sight than I would have liked. Additionally, the limitations on the holding capacity were just silly. Beyond this, the game didn't give you much of an opportunity to stick to a non-lethal approach when it came to the armoured Templars. There was absolutely zero way for you take them down without blowing them up.

There were a few things I really thought were good. I really liked the spiderbombs and the Mag Rail. I really liked the differences in the storyline that you could encounter depending on if you were playing as a female character or male one. I also really, really loved all of the little storyline details that connected the first and second games, such as the Gunther Hermann Skul-Gun request. The reproduction of the original stages and transgenics were also nice to see. I like how those details were reworked into this game.

All in all, if you were a massive fan of the first game, this one might be worth playing if you just want to see what they managed to do with the plot.  It might not be an enjoyable experience, but it might give you a sense of achievement, and might be entertaining to see how they address some of the details that went into the first game.

25677511.review:
I am in a very odd camp. I love this game. I love it because it's a game that offers you choice. Because of this the environments are condensed, the side missions are short (yet impactful) and the game itself is honestly one of the better examples of how to have choice effect your game.

This game is well noted for having odd technical issues. The UI is laggy and some of the gameplay choices such as inventory slots being 1 size fits all and the universal ammo not forcing people to use different weapons.

If you are able to look past the above three flaws then the game is amazing. The narrative is great, the side missions give you depth into the world and the environments while small are very well done. I've played through this game a number of times from both sides of it. You can get dropped off in different places for each new location, you can side with eather faction at any given point in the story and you can actually make meaningful choices at the end as to which faction will rule the world.

[h1] Spoilers are below [/h1]

Not only that but it digs up the past in the best way possible. It determines that Paul and JC are alive and possibly well if you pick that faction. It boils the game down into a nice package.

In a way I am happy the modern games didn't try to tack onto the series ending that invisible war created because it ended it in a casade of choice.

So for those who value choice and well written narrative the game is worth it.

25494155.review:
Give it a little patience, download the improved Unified Texture pack made by a fan, patch to 1080 resolution, and this game is quite a good game.

It came from the Eidos era or 2003, which is the same era as Tomb Raider Angel of Darkness,  which could have a great game, but Eidos of this era pushed development teams very hard and had impossibly short deadlines, etc. While AOD wore the brunt of these behind the scenes problems, Deus Ex: Invisible War managed to be at least a coherant complete game. With some problems, sure.

Its biggest problem may be that it has to live up to the incredible success of the first game. A hard task by itself. And does it? Yes and no. While it does not start with the same atmosphere as the first game, after a few levels, and after a few biomod upgrades, it becomes more obvious that it really does exist in the same game world as the opiginal. It is not as long of a game, and its a pity that it ends not very long after reaching its full momentum, but there is enough Role Playing and Action to be fresh and entertaining.

The zones are divided into sections makes it feel less open world in the "safe areas" (i.e. non combat zones where as opposed to zones with 90% combat) that, say, Hong Kong did in the first game. And even on a modern (2016) pc, loading is a bit slow. On Windows 10, you get to see your desktop for at least 10 seconds of loading, and I doubt there will be any patch to fix this in the future. This just means that loading between sub areas can break the momentum and mood slightly. However, there is enough complexity and there are enough missions in the "safe areas". Also each map, while following the city architecture, is different enough to justify it being stored in seperate zones. It would be nice if it was remade in one unified map, but that is unlikely to ever happen. However, it shouldnt ruin the experience.

I've seen many people complain about the UI, which is different to most first person games. I personally liked it. Its circular rather than linear, and that is really the only difference compared to other first person games. Unlike most games, you get to choosethe UI colour. I liked that I could choose a nice subtle red colouor. However, I had some minor issues with the controls. Pressing action on locked objects like doors or chests automatically changed your currently held item to the multi-tool lockpick. Which is fine when you arent in combat, but, if you accidently hit action during combat while beside a locked door or chest, you find yourself trying to defeat the opponent with a lockpick instead of your weapon of choice. The other minor thing, you dont have a "put the item away" button, so its possible to forget you have your weapon out in a non combat zone and accidently shoot an npc. Two minor issues that generally shouldnt be a problem if you are paying attention to what you are doing.

And that is about it. But to summarise:
- It can take some time to setup on a 2016 PC, but there are community guides in the game's section on steam to help with this. Get the improved textures and resolution fixes.
- Its slow to get into the pace of a Deus Ex game, but well worth giving the time to reach its full pace. Sadly I would have liked that pace to have lasted 2-3 additional levels but it is stilla  full complete game that is worth the time.
- There will be many loading screens, but do not let that give you the feeling that the game itself is small.
- There are some minor UI issues but nothing truely problematic.

25486722.review: There's some enjoyment to be had here for fans of the franchise in discovering the creators' vision of a far-flung, nano-augmented future and the eventual fate of the original games' protagonists, but the lack of options in tackling your objectives due to the segmented, claustrophobic game world, and the blank-stared, unmemorable characters make this hard to truly recommend. Approach with managed expectations.

25420004.review:
I know this will say I've only put in point-whatever number of hours into this game, but that's somewhat inaccurate. I've been trying to force myself to play through this game since about 2007 on multiple computers and the original Xbox... and I just can't do it.  To me, it looks worse, runs worse, and feels worse than its predecessor.

Yes, I'd rather play through the original Deus Ex with its stiff, robotic character animations and relatively simplistic engine than this bloated, compartmentalized, rushed-out cash-grab of a game.

There is nothing about Invisible War that isn't disappointing.  The HUD is atrocious and obtrusive, the game engine is obviously the same one Ion Storm used for the (equally disappointing) Thief: Deadly Shadows... complete with floppy bodies and almost nonexistant light sources (did it really need to be this dark EVERYWHERE?), there's universal ammo, switching weapons and items is a chore, there's no character customization beyond biomods (of which you can only have up to five TOTAL - yes, you read that right), skills are gone, and with them, any reason to play this game as anything other than an action FPS (non-lethal is pointless, exploration is pointless), your inventory is tiny, the plot is shamefully bad, the NPCs stare at you with these creepy, wide open, unblinking eyes (again, even with worse graphics, the original Deus Ex did it better), a lot of items in the environment lack even basic textures, and then there are the load times... THE LOAD TIMES!

As Invisible War was developed concurrently with the Xbox version, it was built from the ground up with the Xbox in mind... which meant lots of tiny level segments with loads between each.  However, even on current hardware, this game takes forever to load.  I dread level transitions because of this.

This game is pure amateur hour and, as I mentioned, feels rushed and unfinished.  Even for its time, this is just bad.  Thief: Deadly Shadows, which came out about the same time, was made by the same people, and used the same engine, is better and more polished than this (though strangely, it seems Ion Storm had a fixation on forcing the player to choose between multiple, one-dimensional factions during this period, much to the detriment of both games).

So that's it.  I just can't force myself to try to play it anymore.  I'm done.  I'm not going to waste any more time on what will eventually be as much of a disappointment at the end as it was at the beginning.  It will forever be the black sheep of the Deus Ex universe (even with Square Enix at the helm of the series).  This is absolutely not a recommended game.  Play something - anything - else.  Hell, play the IOS games instead.  They can't be any worse than this.

25412536.review:
Granted, the maps are small, the UI is odd, and the game does NOT look like the screenshots in the steam store (must be screenshots of a mod or something), but Deus Ex: Invisible war, is overall a good game. The game needed 5 minutes of work after it was installed on my Windows 10, i7, gtx1080, but I solved the problem I had (where game was always in window mode but not filling the whole screen since I kept seeing my desktop which was annoying) by selecting the second highest resolution in the graphics options and that solved the issue for good. Since then I had no issues. Each time the game loads however your screen flickers around as if you would crash back to desktop, but the game each time gets a grip of itself and the map still loads normally, thus, I so far did not even have one game crash, as it runs smooth and stable.

The graphics are very good for a game of that time period, but be aware, this is a much more simplified version from Deus Ex. No more manual input of codes, no more lock picks (multitool does all), no more different ammo types, as MAKO is the only weapons manufacturer which all require the same ammo type (whether a pistol or a rocket launcher). The voice acting also had a bit of a downgrade compared to its predecessor, so let's say the predecessor was a 10, this here would be a 7. For instance, when you traveled to Hong Kong in the predecessor, all NPCs spoke English with a Chinese accent, but this time when you go to Germany or Egypt, most still speak with American accents but there are NPCs that speak English with Arabic or German accents as well. If such minor details do not concern you, you will still love the voice acting. If you play as a male (Alex Denton), your voice seems very tired, which can be a bit frustrating, but then again, the rest of the voice acting is still top notch for today's standards! 

Graphics as mentioned before are good. But too bad no more in-game animations like in Deus Ex, where you could see your chopper fly off. Another minor detail but I believe it added a lot of quality to a game for its time, and now it is gone. You just click your aerial transport (Jet or Helicopter, you pick your pilot!) and that is all. Then again, each pilot drops you off in different locations, which was kind of neat, but then again, with the maps so small it won't really matter.

Weapon controls. This is a bit of a disappointment. It is extremely easy to kill now as compared to the predecessor, and another downside is that they completely removed the skill system, so you have the same shooting abilities from the start to the end of the game. Also, you carry much fewer mods than before, and upgrading your mods is extremely easy, so you are already at max strength before even reaching mid-game. If that is good or bad, you tell me, but I liked it better when I used to be JC.

tl;dr:

Pros:
+ Continous great storyline right after where the predecessor ended (Key point in Deus Ex universe!!!)
+ Still pretty good voice acting overall
+ Some nice locations!
+ Fun side quests
+ You can sometimes make some funny choices!!
+ Sound in the night clubs! Real Band known as "Kidney thieves". Good stuff!
+ Plenty hours of gameplay for the price.

Cons:
- Apparently unstable in many systems. Took me 5 mins for it to work well, others apparently need more time.
- Small maps.
- Simplified weapon usage
- no skills, no lockpicks, multi tool does all now. 
- Overall simplified game from its predecessor. 
- Much more linear gameplay than predecessor.
- Less Augmentations and augmentations very easily upgradeable (simplifying game).
- Less in-game notes (less newspapers, books, texts, logs, screenshots, etc. In Deus Ex you really felt the conspiracy, here not as much).

My advice:

If you just just got into Human Revolutions and then Mankind Divided and find yourself intrigued by the Deus Ex story, then pick up Deus Ex GOTY edition which runs smooth, enjoy that amazing classic, and then afterwards, play through this game as well. Both are worth the money and the first Deus Ex has probably the best replay value for any Single Player game of all time, I play it once a year since 15 years and each time still encounter new hidden areas and locations and outcomes!!! It is incredible!

25302538.review:
[h1]Introduction[/h1]

The sequel to the game Deus Ex, where Alex Denton - an nanoaugmented agent working for the Tarsus academy is met with sudden opposition from a long, lost enemy. The enemy detonates a nano-thermite device which decimates Chicago leading to the conspiracy of who carried out the terrorist act.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

A far less clunkier version of Deus Ex but half of the complexity has been taken out of the game to possibly appease a more casual audience. Gunplay is far more responsive but less detailed and you cannot instantly kill with headshots or a spinal tap with a pistol/baton. Skill points have been removed, replaced more or less with "augmentation biomods" - these change your characters build in a roundabout way.

[h1]Recommendations[/h1]
Further answers the plot of the first Deus Ex game, introduces old characters in states of improved power. It focuses heavily on the aspects of technological advancement beyond socio-economical control.

[h1]Criticisms; Minor[/h1]
The main character's voice actor is quite possibly the most bland attempt at mimicking J.C Denton and hearing him makes me cringe. Yes, cringe. The female version isn't any better.

[h1]Criticisms; Major[/h1]

Severely lacking depth in a lot of it's mechanics. Gone are skills that would dictate your avatar's capacity for overcoming the obstacles in the past game. Due to the level design, jumping augmentations are extremely imbalanced and as such can be used to break the game.

Remarkably poorer, isolated level design. Very labyrinthine, easily leading to confusion of map loadout. If this was the future for claustrophobics, I'd be very, very afriad.

[h1]Music[/h1]

A more streamlined version of Alexandor Brandon's work but with much more techno, orchestra but it is lacking the dynamism that could be found in Deus Ex but otherwise a massive improvement in tone, far more tragic sounding than enthusiastic.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]

Almost all characters now have more polygonal usage, giving the characters in-game a far greater diversity of faces, expressions and body proportions. J.C Denton and Paul Denton in particular were given a lot of detail, realizing them in a new age.

A majority of cities, hubs now have full 3D skybox support, adding a massive range of immersion

[h1]Storyline[/h1]

A few decades had past after J.C Denton and Paul Denton, agents of UNATCO revealed the massive conspiracy
of shadow governments and the Illuminatus bloodline fighting within. J.C Denton merged himself, nano-technologically becoming Helios-Human hybrid, exploded Area 51 and left the area in ruins. However, this caused an event called "The Collapse" which resulted in many proxy wars and economical depression. Eventually, Alex Denton was enrolled after these events making J.C and Paul terrorists but also living mythos, like Aquinas, the mythical Hill of the Gods. Alex Denton is eventually surrounded by factions he has never heard of before, becoming entrenched in the conspiracy  similarity J.C Denton had became involved in.

[h1]Evaluation[/h1]

Deus Ex Invisible War is a game that suffers from a rather ironic lack of transparency regarding the structure of the story, gameplay and the engine's capacity for graphical fidelity (Unreal 2) and a disturbingly awful port seen for a game of it's time requiring a dedicated GPU capable of Shader 3.0 (this used to cost hundreds and wasn't exactly compatible with many motherboards). Invisible War is a horribly camoflagued console port and Warren Spector, Ion Storm's creative director back in it's hayday should realized half-way into it's beta that it is not a Deus Ex game nor a game that would be held in high regard.

25300750.review:
[h1]THIS GAME SCORES [0 1 2 | 3 *4* 5] = ~75% (67%-83%)[/h1]

I've played through this game [i]many times[/i], at least well above 10. That's not as often as through its predecessor, the original Deus Ex, which must have been well over 20.

I agree that this game is limited in comparison to DX1: The locations are small-scale - Upper Seattle seems like a set of rooms and corridors instead of a city, and the loaded maps themselves are small, so you'll often load a new section, but it's not much higher in frequency than in DX1. There are no skills. There is only one type of ammunition which happily feeds into every weapon. The dialog feels cheaper and rushed (probably to keep the data size small). There's also a lot [i]less[/i] dialog/writing. The user interface is simplified, its functionality is limited, and the inventory is small. Quite a few angles from which the console origin shines through. And there must be other reasons that I only played [i]this often[/i] instead of [i]very often[/i].

But I don't agree in the least that the game looks crappy or is considerably worse than DX1. I like the graphics, especially the realtime lighting engine, it's fun to physically toss unconscious/dead people around, and I like exploring / sneaking through the (small) environments. And by the way, the too narrow FOV can be [url=http://pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Deus_Ex:_Invisible_War#Video_settings]fixed[/url], apparently the resolution can even be cranked up.

"Invisible War" is a proper entry of the Deus Ex franchise, because it's all there: Lone wolf 1st person superhuman experience, choice of passive/stealthy/aggressive gameplay, alternative routes to objectives (incl. vent crawling), free exploration incl. looting, and a story that starts slow and small, then expands into various factions incl. conspiracy ingredients, then becomes increasingly big just like in DX.

If you think about it, the ending is even done better than in DX1 because while DX1 mostly relied on an end-o-matic solution like DX:HR except the buttons and panels were spread around the map more, DX:IW's ending choices involve battle (incl. all strategic freedom of the franchise except "just sneaking past it"), dialog (Faction relations partially kept open to the very end.), button pushing, and more.

You can even choose whether to play a man or a woman (both conveniently called "Alex").

Deus Ex: Invisible War is a really well done game. It does not live up to the original, but a good part of the reason would be that it follows a template established by DX1 instead of pioneering said template. You play it with expectations instead of not yet knowing what's up and getting your mind blown. Player freedom is also clearly lower.

But it's a firm double-thumbs-up recommendation that, if you haven't played it yet, should be on your list, especially if you love the Deus Ex universe. Just don't forget:
[list]
[*][url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/6910]Deus Ex[/url] was published in the year 2000.
[*][url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/6920/]Deus Ex: Invisible War[/url] was published in [i]2003/2004[/i], so that's the kind of technological level you need to expect.
[*][url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/238010/]Deus Ex: Human Revolution[/url] is from 2011.
[*][url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/258180/]Deus Ex: The Fall[/url] (which is relatively crappy, and most of all it has damn low FOV, but that can be fixed now according to [url=http://pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Deus_Ex:_Invisible_War#Video_settings]PCGW[/url]) is from 2014.
[*][url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/337000/]Deus Ex: Mankind Divided[/url] is from 2016.
[/list]

25016100.review:
This is a game you are free to hate and be right about it. 
Customization is very limited, most weapon mods both don't make sense and useless, levels are cramped, game as whole looks bleak, plot is not that bad, but script is like these $2.50 pocketbooks, complete with ugly drawings. 
Game can't be even played properly to the end since enemies suddenly become bullet sponges with unresponsive hitboxes. Slap universal ammo on it (Which means once you are out of ammo, you are out of it for EVERY WEAPON YOU HAVE) — and all the talks about ability to choose right tool for the job go down the drain since the only weapon that can manage scarcity of ammo is unique (assassin) pistol with Damage Upgrade and Ammo Scavenger.

But what about good sides? Yep, that's what makes just terrible game PAINFULLY terrible one. It's got good sides!

First, the most responsive climbing mechanic. Ever. No more stupid waist-high walls, you may pull yourself up. You can stack crates high enough for your head to touch the railing at the highest point of jump? You can pull yourself up. And it's not based on some stupid special places to climb - if you can reach it and there is sufficient place to fit while crouched - you'll make it.

Second, EVERY weapon got a secondary mode. SMG with flashbangs? I'll take two. Railgun with alt fire allowing to shoot through walls? Awesome. Flamethrower with alt-fire that allows to bring the flame into mid-range? Neat. Sure, these days everyone and their mothers got weapons with two or more modes, but back in 2003 it was that or Unreal. And Unreal hasn't any RPG elements.

Third, grenade goods. You got regular, flashbangs, smoke, gas, noise (Yep. Extremely rare, and since it's one use…), emp, scramble and… spider grenade. Which spawns actual spider bot, complete with cute zapper and funny turn animation. Same as above, nothing Unreal hadn't, but Unreal is not an RPG in any way.

Fourth, very cool bot hacking mechanic. You stay hidden, then you charge at turret/bot, "tag" him and then you try to hide somewhere waiting for timer to expire. Cha-ching, you are now controlling a piece electronic. Want to shoot the baddies? Not so fast, they don't even know that bot is no longer on their side. Take your time, pick the best position for massacre — fun starts when YOU trigger it.

Fifth, this game got awesome hidden pony — Omars (Appreciating your bussiness, yeah, right), who succesfully achieved hivemind (In other words, creating succesfuly that Helios failed to achieve) and, well, the prosper while rest of the world is crumbling. While they have limited role, they are interesting as concept for post-apocalyptic world. And they got somewhat justified ending should you kill every major faction members in the end (All the wannabe rulers die in a nuclear fire, world is fading out while Omars prosper, later advancing enough to leave the Earth behind).


Conclusion: I wish Steam had ability to be neutral about "Thumbs up" and "Thumbs down".

24669058.review:
[b]If you're not lucky enough to have the game work right off the bat, or you're not willing to spend a bit (around 5 minutes at least, 30 minutes at most) setting it up to make it work properly, I wouldn't recommend it. Read the near the end for problems I had playing it.[/b]


There are many differences between Deus Ex: Invisible War and the first game, for example:

The maps are fairly smaller.
The skills and augmentations have been combined into biomods.
As the skills have been removed, you are pretty much as proficient with your weapons in the beginning as you are in the end, unless you are using weapon mods or melee biomods.


Despite the skills and augmentations being removed in favor of biomods, there are still many different ways to play the game.


[b]Problems I had playing the game[/b]

The game didn't allow me to change to windowed mode without manually editing the config, as it was not in the options menu.

As far as I know, by default the game doesn't support aspect ratios outside of 4:3, or changing the resolution to anything besides what the default options menu supports. When I tried either of these, the text in menus often disappeared, and sometimes the game just didn't render at all.

Loading screens often took minutes to load, I believe I fixed this by closing the Logitech Gaming Framework (lcore.exe). Combined with the small areas, which means more minute-long loading screens, it is very annoying to play with this issue.



Like I said, if you don't want to spend time trying to fix it (I almost gave up myself, it took me about an hour before I realized that setting a custom resolution was causing the second problem I stated above), I wouldn't recommend this game. I'd say that it is definitely worth spending some time to get it working though.

If you like the Deus Ex story and world, or you're looking for a fairly simpler version of the first Deus Ex (gameplay-wise) I'd definitely recommend this game, however.

24430711.review:
[h1] Should you play this game? [/h1]

[u] Short Answer: [/u]
Whether or not I recommend you play this game depends on your answer to one question. [b] How much did you like the story and universe of the original Deus Ex? [/b] If you really liked it, then I definitely recommend playing this game because I really think that, for all of the game's shortcomings, the story is not one of them- and it carried me through to the end. On the other hand, if you didn't much like the story and universe of the original Deus Ex, then I wouldn't recommend this game- because I found that the story is its one saving grace. Without this factor, you're left with a decidedly subpar game, especially when compared to the original Deus Ex.

[u] Long Answer: [/u]

[b] Background Info: [/b]
Action role-playing game developed by Ion Storm, as a sequel to the hugely successful original Deus Ex on PC. The game was released for PC and the original Xbox- with the developers seeming to focus heavily on optimising the game for the latter. 

[b] Gameplay: [/b]
The game itself plays out as a fairly rudimentary action RPG. It feels like the developers took the in-depth systems of Deus Ex and stripped them down to their bare essentials- probably in order to downsize the game for the benefit of the Xbox. As a consequence, the “skills” system has been completely removed; ammo is universal for all weapons and multitools/lockpicks are now a single item. However, there is one saving grace in the form of the biomodification system. This system plays out in much the same way as the augmentation system from the original Deus Ex, with plenty of scope to craft a character that will cater to your playstyle. The augmentation system was one of the most interesting parts about the original Deus Ex; so I’m glad to see that the developers at least had their priorities in order in this regard when creating Invisible War. 

Gameplay itself resembles the original Deus Ex, and the options available to the player in order to achieve certain objectives are much the same. Stealth, combat and hacking are viable options. Similarly you can choose between a non-lethal/lethal playstyle. These options are very rudimentary compared to the original Deus Ex; however their inclusion is appreciated. On the other hand, a major problem of the game is how easy it is. I played on the hardest difficulty (realistic) and didn’t get stuck at all. For the record, I played a stealth character; however I did try out combat as well and wasn’t impressed. 

However, hands down the biggest problem for me is the game’s miniscule areas. It’s no secret that the original Deus Ex had massive areas, which you could explore for hours and continue to find new things. The areas in Invisible War are so small that you can finish each in 10 minutes, tops. And after each area you are forced to endure another painfully long loading screen. Any tension or momentum that the game might create is utterly sapped by the repulsively frequent and lengthy loading screens. This is a huge issue, and I would be much more tempted to recommend the game were it not for this problem. Finally, the physics engine is hilariously bad- so be prepared for some unintentionally funny moments if you do decide to play this game! 

[i]Final Verdict:[/i] Adequate. Feels like the developers downsized the original Deus Ex’s systems and were left with incredibly subpar gameplay mechanics and insufferable load times. 

[b]Soundtrack:[/b]
It's no embellishment to say that the original Deus Ex had an outstanding soundtrack- with not a single unmemorable tune in the whole repertoire. The sequel to this game, Deus Ex: Human Revolution, also had a great, fitting, memorable soundtrack. Invisible War, once again, falls short of these lofty standards. Tunes aren't particularly memorable, and there aren't too many of them either. Nevertheless, I would say that the soundtrack fits the cyberpunk setting of the game- so it deserves credit in that regard. Similarly, the soundtrack does have SOME particularly good tunes, such as the "Heron's Loft" theme and the title theme. 

[i]Final Verdict:[/i] Adequate. Some standout tracks, but for the most part unmemorable. Nevertheless appropriate for the setting of the game- which is worthy of credit, I think. 

[b]Story and Setting:[/b]
Deus Ex: Invisible War, takes place 20 years after the original Deus Ex. An interesting point of note is that the original Deus Ex had multiple endings, so you may be wondering how Invisible War could continue such a story. Interestingly enough, Invisible War does not commit to a single ending- instead melding aspects of each ending into one, and building off of that. I acknowledge that some may not be a fan of this decision- as it essentially invalidates the endgame choices of the original Deus Ex. However, I found this design decision interesting, and was intrigued to see how the game would continue such a story. Overall, I think it did it well. Thematically, Invisible War is extremely similar to the original- tackling the ethics of body modification, as well governments and secret societies and how they influence the world at large. In other words, the game is rich in conspiracy- in true Deus Ex style. 

The plot starts out fairly slow- with a tedious tutorial area followed by being ejected into the first “hub area” of the game- Seattle. I found that Seattle was the hub with the most activity; boasting lots of areas and a lot of side missions. However, at the same time I found it to be the least interesting. Instead I think Seattle serves as the area where all of the main factions of the game are introduced, offering the player choice in terms of who to side with at a very early stage. Thankfully you don’t have to commit to a faction for the whole game; you’re given plenty of time to ponder individual ideologies and motivations. In a way, Invisible War trumps even the original Deus Ex in this regard, wherein a lot of the decisions pertaining to “choosing a side” were out of the player’s hands (at least until the end of the game). 

[i]Final Verdict:[/i] Invisible War’s one true claim to fame in my opinion. Not as enthralling as the original Deus Ex’s plot, but it still kept me going until the end. I consider that the plot gains traction when you reach the second hub area, as this is the point where I felt connected to the story, and the compulsion to see it through superseded the subpar gameplay mechanics. 

[b]Conclusion:[/b]
If you’ve stayed with me for this whole review, then I’m sure you’ll have noticed the amount of comparisons to the original Deus Ex. This just goes to show how the odds were stacked against Invisible War from the get-go. It came in with a TON of sequel baggage: the pressure to surpass what many consider to be the greatest game of all time. Couple that with being majorly downsized in order to appeal to the console demographic and it seems that Invisible War was doomed from the start. However, as a huge Deus Ex fan, I find myself recommending this game. Yes all of the gameplay systems are “adequate” instead of “superb”; yes the soundtrack is “okay” instead of “incredible”, but as an entry into the Deus Ex universe of conspiracy and intrigue, it’s just as worthy as Human Revolution in my opinion. 

So, if you really want to see where the Deus Ex chronology ends, then I definitely recommend buying this game. On the other hand, if you have absolutely no connection with the story and universe of Deus Ex, then there really is no reason to buy this game- as there are much better alternatives in terms of gameplay. To conclude, I’m perfectly fine with accepting this game into the Deus Ex universe; however it certainly doesn’t hold a candle to the original Deus Ex and Human Revolution. Here’s hoping Mankind Divided will be another worthy addition to the franchise!

24304743.review:
Deus Ex: Invisible War is a fun game, and it stays true to most of the things that made Deus Ex so incredible; however, it seems to be an overall downgrade. Here is a list of some of Deus Ex: Invisible War's major shortcomings compared to it's predecessor:
-The loading times are much more severe
-The levels are less open and feel more like a series of long hallways than an open map
-Important statistics for various items and abilities that used to be displayed in the menus are no longer viewable, which harms the RPG aspect of the game significantly
-The upgrade systems for weapons, biomods, and your character in general have been harshly simplified and minimalized so that they now lack many of what I considered to be essential aspects of the first Deus Ex
-The game has a lot of bugs that make it difficult to play, whereas the first Deus Ex game was relatively glitch free
-The game no longer features equipment (which, granted, felt relatively useless for most play-styles)
-The notes and various acquired data is less detailed and less diverse; I frequently come across duplicate datapads and books, whereas every datapad and book in the original Deus Ex was unique
-You can no longer assign custom keys for biomods or quick save/load, which is surprisingly tedious in the middle of combat when I have to hit “fn + f6” just to activate my enhanced speed mod, when I’d much rather hit “v” like I could in the first Deus Ex game
-Acquired data, passwords, and passcodes are no longer saved and viewable at any time. Additionally, passwords and passcodes are no longer managed by a player, and the player never has to enter or remember passwords or passcodes in the game. This especially bothers me, because having to manage passwords on your own made hacking feel more like actual hacking, like an achievement of the player. I’d always find myself searching a room for clues as to what a password might be, which felt cool, but I never do that in Deus Ex Invisible War.
-You get so much goddamn money within the first 5th of the game that it loses it’s value. Every other mission or “quest” in the game gives you money, and your rarely use it.

There were some improvements, however. that Deus Ex: Invisible War made to the original game:
-The stealth system is more complex and requires more strategy than the first Deus Ex
-There were many new and interesting weapons and biomods, which give the player even more gameplay options, many of which were very fun to play around with
-The game utilizes factions and loyalty systems to add a level of depth to the RPG experience
-The graphics, obviously, are much better
-The ragdoll physics are really cool, and they make moving bodies way more fun
-The game allows you to play as a female, which is nice
-The characters are slightly more developed, though completely static (as in the first game)
-I imagine that for most people, it’s actually very convenient not having to manage passcodes and passwords themselves
-The narrative in Invisible War is a bit better and more central to the game. In the original Deus Ex, I remember the story being very rough, and the characters to flat to care about. The narrative isn’t great in Invisible War, but it is an improvement.

That was, of course, just a brief list of changes made between Deus Ex 1 and Deus Ex: Invisible War. Even that, however, is likely more information than necessary. In all honesty, there are only a few things to consider if you’re thinking about buying this game: did you really enjoy the original Deus Ex? If the answer is yes, than you should buy this game. As a fan of the first Deus Ex, I thoroughly enjoyed Deus Ex: Invisible War. I would say that the original Deus Ex was better, but Invisible War is still a good sequel that does not betray the aspects that made the original so good.

Overal Score = 6.3/10 (Good, but nothing special)

Total Score: 61 C+ (Deus-ish)

Graphics and Art: 7
Sound and Music: 5
Story and Plot: 7
Controls: 8

Length, Content, and Replayability: 5

Do stuff, some of it fun!  OK, so, yes, as everyone will tell you, this game doesn't live up to the original Deus Ex, a deep creative-powerhouse that managed to not only be a thoroughly enjoyable cyberpunk game (and there are never enough cyberpunk games) but which, for the time, pushed the technology available and crossed the line from being just a fun game to adding to mankind's philosophical body of knowledge about life.  The first Deus Ex was a work on art in every sense.  Now, I'm not saying that Invisible War had nothing to say.  It had numerous useful witicisms and social and political-economic comentary.  But it wasn't quite as refined as Deus Ex the first.  But, honestly, there's a lot in this game to enjoy.  The hacking gameplay is just a blast, as you vicariously mow down enemies with the robot or turret of your choice, though it certainly could have been more.  The graphics is acceptable for the time, if uninspired, and you have a lot of options with how to take your character in terms of both story and gameplay, though you top out way too early, and there's really not much mechanical reason to do everything there is to do other than the fun of doing it.  The character development isn't nearly as involved (or excellent) as the original either.  I mean, you get money, but you won't have much to spend it on.  The game is also pretty short and somewhat lacking in the challenge department, though it does have the admirable quality of awarding intelligent tactics.  This is a good, fun game, just don't expect a great game.  And, if you're a Deus Ex fan, might as well play it...kind of...if you want to.

23120141.review:
Now hold on here. Hold your horses. This game is not as bad as people say. Not by a long shot.

Sure it is nothing like Human Revolution, and sure it was a bit of a departure from the original title. Sure it was made for the xBox and suffered from some small environments, but this was a [i]great game[/i], one of the few games I have ever honest-to-god completed (something which, honest to god, doesn't apply to the original, which was just a little too outdated when I came back to it to try and win through where I had lost interest back in the early 00s)

Put in some hours and you might experience some nice surprises! The graphics might improve dramatically as you venture deeper into the experience, the level design too! The alternate routes that are so famous in the series are right there, waiting for you to exploit them, and the combat is satisfying.

A bit of intrigue does exist, and the controls work well. The story is a lot longer than you expect it to be, and the levels really well made.

Honestly, this is a really fun game, even if it is a little previous-previous-gen. Frankly at certain times the graphics are so well handled that you could be forgiven for mistakenly thinking you were playing a much more recent game.

It is a real shame that this game got such a bad wrap. It was never the same as the original in so many ways, but in a lot of unexpected ways it was a little bit better, and it was a really wonderful taster of the potential of the series in a next-gen world, a taster for a the utter banquet that would be Deus Ex: Human Revolution, my favourite game of all time.

I wish that if they were going to be focusing on a era of remakes and reboots that Invisible War would get a spotlight and be remade adding more sidequests, weapons and get a scenic overhaul. 22747812.review:
Well I didn't end up playing the game for long before I uninstalled it and jumped onto the IW-hate bandwagon. I barely left the academy (first level) before I decided to not play this game again. As subjective as my opinion is, I cannot see any way of recommending people to put money into it; and I would be reluctant to even say 'go for it' if it was a free game out of fear I will create personal vendettas against me by wasting time.

From the intro alone it has no Deus Ex feeling at all in my opinion; it looks less like a dystopian cyberpunk and more like a bad sci-fi that has none of the charm of the original Deus Ex, if you're pondering on trying the game because it has the name in the title, I recommend looking up the intro on youtube and ask yourself if it's still what you're hoping for.

The second thing I noticed was how utterly difficult it was for me to even get the game to run at all because of the outdated engine that is damn near incompatiable with anything that has multi-cores (which is to say every modern computer) that made it a pain requiring me to down a few hours in searching for a fix online in various forums; which is already a major nono for anything that gets put on steam, if it's on a platform like Steam asking for money to play it, it should at the very least work by default.
If anyone is interested, I'll leave the link that finally made the game run for everyone's convenience: http://yoni0505.blogspot.se/2012/08/deus-ex-invisible-war-windows-7-fix.html

With the game finally running and having recently finished the original Deus Ex (Revision), I was eager to try the game for myself and see the continuation of the previous game and what effects the events of it would have on the world of the sequel. I knew it was widely hated, but somehow the arguments never quite ran. Small levels and clunky UI sounded like something you could overcome if you were interested in the story, and I really wanted to explore Chicago and Seattle of the future. 
So the first thing I do is to set the keymapping to be more akin to the original Deus Ex's controls as much as possible for my own comfort and fixing the mouse sensitivity to be lower. Then I start the game.

First I get that intro cutscene and realize that exploring Chicago is not really on the agenda here. Maybe I should've read into it more, but I guess it just gets destroyed in the cutscene and welcome to Seattle. Okay, fair enough I think.
Then there is Seattle where I try to immerse myself and get comfortable with the controls before I get earthquakes shoved in my face; no time to rest there. When I get into my first conversation I experience a rarity for me: graphics cringe. I'm not one to typically care about graphics; I like the old styles such as the original ones over things like Crysis even, but fuck me they couldn't have made a poorer job with these. This is without mentioning how lackluster and horribly paced the conversations are.

Go to a let's play and check just the first conversation with Billie to determine it for yourself. If it becomes unbearable, save your money to something more productive. Maybe there's a hobo nearby who could use a cup of coffee for the dollar or whatever that Steam wants for the game.

Anyway the next thing I notice is that the criticisms of small levels well, the fans were not exaggerating; imagine UNATCO HQ in the original game from the moment you step into the upper level where Manderley and your office etc is. Know how there is a lower level too? In IW, that lower level would be behind a loading screen; and the upper level doesn't contain the eye scanner or anything of the sort either. That should give an idea of how small the maps are, and I'm even unsure if that's an exaggeration.

What kills it for me though is how a game riddled more loading screens than semen in an elephant's cum seem to have an unhealthy obsession with resetting everything upon a new loading screen; it's like the game restarts itself before the loading screen itself appears, and when it's done loading all the key mappings are reset and all the items- including weapons -are gone. This world of item-vaporizing elevators/doorways becomes especially bothersome if you wanna cap some heads, because good luck getting anything done in terms of combat if you don't have any weapons on you; and weapons aren't in a habit of just laying around everywhere either.
At the final bit of the Seattle Tarsus Academy I just gave up and casually ran past everyone in full view, not even caring about getting shot twice or thrice (which took less than half my hp) and just kept going to see if I could at least get value out of seeing Upper Seattle. Some story blocks along the way I didn't care about later and I realized.. Pretty much no. 

The environment is stale and uninspired and conversations don't get anymore interesting from the three or so places in the level that had people. You get more character interaction and personality from a Choice of Games than what I got in Upper Seattle. And that's where I finally lost my last interest and justification for having spent any money on this even at a sale. The only thing I got from that money spent is buyer's remorse; but hey, at least the buyer's remorse is consistent unlike the fucking keymapping in IW.

=TL;DR=
I only played so much, but if you are interested in seeing this game then I would say don't waste your money on it; look up a let's play of someone else who wasted money on it instead and save yourself the effort. If it still looks appealing after an episode or two of said let's play; only then should it ever be considered.

*Poor environments.
*Poor voice acting and conversation pacing.
*Poor graphics and character models.
*No cyberpunk or Deus Ex feeling.
*Difficult to run on a modern system and requires a lot of system fuckery to at all get started.

That's my experience after less than an hour with no real expectation going for it coming in; I should've listened.

22276836.review:
There are very few examples of a sequel in any medium being better than the original in the series. This is no exception to that.

Now that I've gotten that out of the way, I'm going to do something a little different than what other reviewers do and repeat what I did with the Duke Nukem Forever review. Instead of pointing out the postivies and negatives, I'm going to say that my opinion is more valid than yours and that most of the negatives I see are either non existent or actually positives.

1. The combat is clunky.
I don't understand this complaint. I played it on the XBox and it was terrible on that system, yeah. But on the PC? It really isn't that terrible and it's more than managable. I think maybe the reason for this is people were playing this like they played the original Deus Ex. In the first game when you first started you sucked with every single ranged weapon ever and had to aim your gun for like 30 minutes before you could actually hit somebody. What I assume is happening is people are doing that in this game, and you really don't need to do that because you actually know how to use a firearm. I'd actually go as far as saying that makes the combat in this game better than in the first game. For some reason, in Deus Ex a highly trained cybernetic special forces operative has no idea how to use a basic handgun.

2. It was dumbed down for consoles.
Well, yes and no. First off, the original Deus Ex engine was basically a bunch of PVC pipes and calculators glued together. It was very simple and didn't eat up a lot of hardware so you could put a crapload of shit in the game and not worry about running out of space on the install disk along with not worrying about overworking the system memory. This game uses a (for the time) modern next gen engine with (for the time) amazing graphics and effects and stuff, not to mention a (for the time) decent physics engine as well. The short length and small size of levels allowed this to be put on XBox, yeah, but it also made it so we wouldn't have to use like 20 discs on PC. Sure, it would have been cool for the game to be the size of the original and use 20 discs, but come on.

3. The story is dumb.
I agree to some extent. The game is short, and since it's a Deus Ex game there's a plot twist like every 10 minutes so I can't really say much without spoiling like 35% of the story. Basically, at one point in the game you get two huge plot twists at the same exact time, and both of them got completely different reactions from me. The first one I saw coming from a mile away and was so obvious I could have sworn was already mentioned like two hours earlier or something. The second one I didn't see coming from a mile away but felt like a total idiot because I didn't in that it was completely logical. Sudden plot twists, especially of this caliber, are rarely done in such a way that it seems like the perfect conclusion to every single event that preceded. While elements of the story are really, REALLY stupid, for the most part it's very well written and worth your time.

4. Too many RPG elements were removed/Character progression is gimped too much.
I disagree here in that I like to play both of these games when I have completely different mindsets. If I want to play System Shock 1 or 2 but without horror elements I'll play the original Deus Ex, and if I want to play Bioshock 1 or 2 without the horror elements I'll play this. In my opinion, just because a sequel is different, doesn't mean it's bad.

5. There's no multiplayer.
Yes. This is a complaint I've seen people actually make. The original Deus Ex actually had deathmatch multiplayer for some really stupid reason that nobody but total nerds actually played. My guess is this was just one more feature they could complain about being removed from the game so they'd have another bullet to put in IW's skull.

Overall, I give this game 8 out of 10, Deus Ex 9 out of 10 and Deus Ex: HR 8.5 out of 10.

21742499.review:
A brief note before review: Ever since I upgraded to windows 10, the game seems to be alittle unstable for me now and I can't confirm wether thats a compatibility issue or just something unrelated on my end.

A short game by deus ex standards but what it lacks in play time it makes up for with replay value. Throughtout the game, there are various factions that you must work either with or against often times with competing goals for the same objective. Weapons share a universal ammo and can be customized with up to two upgrades. This will make you want to carry a variety of weapons and upgrade combinations for certain situations.... until the last quarter of the game but more on that later.

It takes place some time after the first deus ex and the graphics haven't aged too terribly over the years. The story isn't quite as good as the first one but then again, not many stories can compete with such a high bar. It doesn't have quite the same dark grittiness of the original in presentation to the point where when your character makes a threat it almost comes off as comical. 

The gun play and physics are much improved from the first one but its still an early 2000s game so there will be shenanigans here and there but its shouldn't be anything too gamebreaking or distracting. What will be distracting and must be learned to be embraced is that everytime you enter a new zone or a previous zone or a sub zone within a zone, there will be a loading screen that in my experience actually takes you out of the game and shows a poorly res'd version of your steam launcher until it comes back on. Luckily these screens don't take long (atleast on my device) and after a while they're not as jarring. 

Now, for the one major con in this game. The gun play is fairly balanced for the most part until the end when one of the factions starts using troops with what is essentially power armor. The power armor has a weak spot but it isn't a critical weak spot so even if you hit them in it with a damage enhanced sniper rifle (which easily wipes the floor with any other kind of opposition except for robots) it will only hurt them alittle bit and then they pursue you and never show you their back again. The solution to this is simple albeit really damaging to the fun of the fps aspect of the game. 

You get a rocket launcher, you attach an ammo saving augment to it and thats all you use for the rest of the game. They usualy use rocket launchers as well so having the gun play devolve into rocket launcher duels is very very disappointing. Don't get me wrong, you can use other guns at that point but the amount of ammo it takes to take out just one of them with a conventional firearm is completely ridiculous let alone when there's multiple of them (which there will be).

All of that taken into consideration, I think its worth a couple playthroughs taking different paths each time to get a feel for the entire package it has to offer. As always, Buy the deus ex bundle when its on sale for the best value.

21467723.review:
I spent a long time not believing that this game could be that bad. I'd read countless reviews of how this game was a disappointment, tried to familiarize myself with its flaws without spoiling the story for myself, and made my decision: I would buy it when it went on crazy sale. $1.40 was sale enough for me. I don't regret the purchase, but I don't recommend the game, and the reasons are manifold.

First, ignore any review that says "if this game weren't a Deus Ex game, it would be regarded better". No. Even ignoring the Deus Ex aspects, what you're left with is a piss poor shooter with a trashy story, ass-ugly character models, glitchy gameplay, and poor mechanics choices. 

This game is both figuratively and literally a narrow hallway. Half of the time, you're dropped into an area that has little to no hiding spaces and relatively few alternate paths. What few areas do have alternate paths to your objective are circular and do a poor job of telegraphing that you're going backwards. The area maps are practically microscopic, and you're hard pressed to go even three minutes of normal gameplay without having to load up a new area. This makes exploring a chore, so after the first hour of gameplay I gave up and decided I would just plow through the story and get it over with. Also, just by the way, there's a glitch where the game crashes to the desktop or hangs on a black screen during every loading screen, and upon reaching the final area, it has crashed for me five times with no possible fix in sight. Just a heads up if you really want to try to see this through.

So, let's talk about the story. Where Deus Ex was a political commentary through the eyes of a conspiracy theorist, Deus Ex: Invisible War is a sociopolitical commentary through the eyes of a gender studies major, and if I let my inner conspiracy theorist come forward, I might just have to say that this is one of the first games ruined by the thoughtless inclusion of female main characters for the sake of having more "gender diversity". Default avatar gender? Female. The Order? Female dominated. WTO? Majority female. 

Borderline genocidal maniacs/nazi looking motherfucker templars? Male leader, almost completely male dominated organization.  All of that aside:

You're cast into the world of Deus Ex: Invisible War by being treated to an uncanny valley cutscene the likes of which only 2003 CGI can produce. A faceless terrorist unleashes grey goo on Chicago and later you're told it was fire. That's all well and good though, because Chicago isn't important, you're in Seattle, in what is essentially a high school anime gone wrong. With no warning or buildup, the Tarsus academy is under attack by "the Order", a group of religious zealots who think jihad is the way to go. You can follow orders from these maniacs later, while their second in command tries to convince you that they are indeed a religion of peace by explicitly asking you to murder their targets. Conversely, you can do the bidding of the World Trade Organization, who sits comfortably at the other end of the spectrum at what seems to be Lawful Neutral at worst. Following orders from them doesn't always feel right, but it doesn't make you feel like a sociopath.

It takes hours of gameplay to be drawn in even the smallest bit, and the writing never really recovers. Even the endings feel halfassed, though if you stew on them for long enough, they're just thought provoking enough to be worthy of discussion if you're bored.

Overall, this game is bad. Not because it's an unworthy successor to much better game, but because it barely stands up as a game. It is nothing more than a seven hour long walking simulator with guns added here and there for flavor.

21193635.review:
Deus Ex: Invisible War is a solid game with a great story, more focused on the action that the first part and simplifying the elements that were in this.

PROS :
- Continues and closes the storyline of the first part 
- Possibility to choose between a male or female protagonist with different options on their physical appearance.
- Like the first part, what begins as a simple story unfolds in a story full of twists and complexities.
- Like its predecessor, depending on the choices you make, you can change the style of the narrative or the relationship of certain NPC's toward the protagonist.
- Is set on a Semi-Open World structure ala Wolfenstein (2009) for its narrative.
- The exploration remains key for obtaining items, ammunition, rewards, etc.
- Implementation of Havok Physics to move obstacles, hide corpses, attack, etc.
- Multiple primary and secondary objectives to meet 
- Like the first part, there are multiple ways to meet the goals, reach a destination, get an item, etc.
- Augmentations obtained and improved can be replaced by others once installed.
- Integration of an ability to climb certain surfaces becomes quite useful.
- Being a game more focused on the action than the first part, the combat is much more polished than its predecessor (Though the element of stealth is still present).
- Most of the ranged weapons have a secondary fire mode.
- Very good textures and lighting effects for its time 

CONS :
- The protagonist, whatever male or female, does not have enough charisma.
- Most NPC's share the same face.
- Many elements are simplified when compared to its predecessor (No experience points for improve character skills, all guns share the same ammunition, many fewer weapons, the tool for hacking and lockpicking is the same one, etc.).
- Improvements of the characters are limited exclusively to augmentations (As long as you have the item that allows you to install or upgrade these).
- Each weapon only accept two modifications (From a total of eight options).
- Control over jumps is sometimes a bit disastrous.
- Many times, the use of physics in certain situations, is erratic and not let the situation settle directly or at the first attempt (Which can be a bit frustrating ).
- The Quick-Load is not so "Quick".
- The campaign lasts half the first Deus Ex (We are talking about a campaign of approximately 30 hours, although this is much more than the average for today's games).
- An annoying Black-Screen bug present in the final length of the game when you load a Savegame

21164643.review:
While Deus Ex: Invisible War isn't strictly godawful by itself, it's decidedly so in comparison to the [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/trar/recommended/6910]original Deus Ex[/url]. I really, [i]really[/i] wish Steam reviews had a 'mixed' option, because I can't recommend IW over those two games except for series completionists or dedicated genre fans.

Seriously, I had to try [i]twice[/i] to beat this game. I lost motivation on my first attempt because of how aggressively blah it gets.


I'm not one to complain much about games being "dumbed down", and the original Deus Ex wasn't exactly an ergonomic masterpiece, but Invisible War was designed for the original Xbox in mind. That means they cut out and/or simplified a lot of what made the original game distinctive: skills, aug slots, lockpicks, hacking, keycodes & damage models. Without this stuff, Invisible War essentially becomes a subpar FPS with RPG elements tacked on the side. Small, weirdly-designed maps (albeit with some nonlinearity and interesting ideas here and there) and a smaller, awkward inventory - with no dragging - don't do it any favors either. That's not mentioning the bugs, general instability or handicapped AI.

The unified ammo system is nice in theory, but in practice it becomes annoying. You can only carry up to around 9 or so clips, and ammo is [i]rather[/i] scarce for players who use a number of weapons regularly. If you chew through most of them with one weapon, you might not have enough for another weapon when you need it. That said, it makes ammo and stealth that much more valuable and worth hunting for/investing in, so that's something.

Combat controls themselves are smooth and simplified compared to DX's, but mouse movement is floaty, and it's never quite as satisfying thanks to the engine making fights janky as hell.

On that note, just like the core gameplay systems, the controls are simpler than the original...and yet somehow more clunky to use, mainly because of the fact that it was designed for use with an Xbox controller: again, no clicking and dragging are allowed. I missed leaning and I especially missed conversation transcriptions - it's difficult enough following the plot here without being distracted when someone contacts you over your infolink.

There are a few positives. Ragdoll physics may be dull sometimes, but when they're not, they're hilariously broken. Ladder climbing is improved, somehow. Automatic pull-ups over ledges are nice too, and the robot control augmentation is splendid to use.

I'm on the fence about the fact that you can choose any aug from any canister, but that there are also two separate types of canisters. For what it's worth, it's possible to have both cloaking AND thermal masking, albeit at the cost of hacking abilities. Even if I liked being able to simply waltz past enemies and always have the initiative in my playthrough, I think there was a reason that both of those augs were mutually exclusive in the original game.


Beyond core gameplay, the rest of the game doesn't fare very well.

It's pretty weird and 'convenient' that clubs and mosques and other such places have 'codes' that can disable ALL your weapons, even the blunt clubs. It's a rather clumsy implementation of plot-mandated invincibility - you can kill anyone anywhere in this game, so the devs turned off weapons in certain public places to keep players from destroying the plot.

Graphics are plasticine and blockier than the original, and the original was on the blocky side already. I'd say Invisible War's looks have actually aged [i]more[/i]. Not good for the game's verisimillitude.

By far the worst part however is the fact that the game literally shuts down and relaunches itself [b]every time you load a new level[/b], supposedly to cut down on long-term runtime errors in the engine. It breaks the game's Steamworks functionality and it's just dumb as hell considering how small the levels are to begin with & how long the loading times are. I found myself deciding what to do based partially on the number of loading screens between me and my potential destinations.


Invisible War has less bombast than the original Deus Ex. While I [i]guess[/i] it's a nice change of pace, I can't help but feel that's a liability for a game that also focuses on globetrotting power conspiracies, just like the original.

Case in point: the voice acting is pretty damn bland. Gone is the memorable, if cheesy, voicework from the first game. I still kind of like Alex's voice, though - that character's actors seem to have found a comfortable spot to let the character grow his (or her) own snarky, deadpan personality, distinct from yet similar to JC Denton's. Being able to pick a male or female character is also a nice reminder of a time before hypermasculinity took over mainstream videogames for a decade. The dynamic music that changes by location in the same level is a good touch; it's not as distinct or awesome as DX's, but good nonetheless.

I have a couple things to say about the story itself, since it's a pretty important element of any Deus Ex title, which means [b]spoilers for this game as well as the original.[/b] If you want further analysis without spoilers, you could try watching [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=59PzmOLSf00]this Errant Signal video[/url].

I do like how the factions this time around seem to be the most morally ambiguous of any in the series - except the Templar, who are pretty much cartoon evil. The actual writing might not be very good - the amount of typos and inaccurate subtitles are also surprising for a game supposedly this prominent - but it's not a complete wreck. The subjects it deals with are still rather unique in the world of games.

By the mid-game, however, the writers start trotting out characters, plot points and eventually locations from the original presumably for the purpose of keeping players going. At no point are you given any choices or quandaries to rival the original game. JC is essentially retconned into the Helios-merged being from one of the three endings in the original, which might not go over well for those who were really invested in making him their own character in that game.

There's one bright spot: the NG Resonance side story. I don't like her music, but her subplot has some of the most interesting writing in the game. All I'll say is that this game predates the Snowden leaks by a decade.


Oh yeah, [i]all three[/i] original Deus Ex endings are canon here. It feels like a cop-out.

Invisible War has four different endings - including a 'renegade' option where you kill everyone, which you couldn't do in the original. Of course, these endings aren't really on par with DX's, considering that the outcomes of each ending aren't quite what you'd logically expect from each. The renegade ending has the Omar inheriting the planet after baseline humanity blows itself to pieces in revanchist warfare...despite the very [i]idea[/i] of nation-states supposedly being weaker than ever.

The neo-Helios ending I chose in my playthrough was kind of interesting, if only because it's apparently the [i]least bad[/i] ending, and even that one entailed forced evolution and sacrifice for all of humanity. Not exactly a good sign.

The worst part, though, is how anti-climactic the end really is. For three out of four endings, you make your way to a poorly-rendered recreation of an iconic area from the first game and literally just use a computer to select which ending you want. Compare that to Deus Ex's sprawling end-game compound, where each ending entailed committing to multiple different objectives. That's not to mention how poorly the real nature of the various factions is handled, especially the early-game ones. Pretty mediocre, really, which is how you could describe the game as a whole too.

20950204.review:
I propose a new tag line: "It really isn't that bad". I avoided Invisible War for quite some time because the fan reception has been absolutely crushing. But since I found this on sale for a little over a dollar, I decided to give it a try and form my own opinion. And guess what? It's really not that bad. Sure, it doesn't come close to the greatness of the original, and I understand if the fans found the initial release in 2003 disappointing, but on its own it's actually a pretty good game.

For example, the levels themselves might be small, but even then it has a good amount of player freedom to progress however you wish. Violence, stealth, hacking, etcetera. In a way, it reminds me of Human Revolution (albeit in a lesser form). It had smaller levels compared to the original as well (though HR's levels are bigger and more complex than IW's), but it was dense enough to allow multiple ways through with different builds. Even better than both DX1 and HR was the different factions you could side with or do missions for. In the first half this gives it an extra dynamic of player freedom. Doing missions for one faction usually means not being able to complete a mission for the other groups. As a result, it adds a nice touch of choice and consequences, both in the main story and side quests you can complete.

But there are some issues with it. Most of them you probably already know if you're familiar with the fan reception. First of all, the levels are very tiny in comparison. Most likely due to the Xbox hardware. And because of the tiny levels, you're very frequently being bothered by loading screens. It's not the actual loading times that are the problem, but the amount of times you're looking at a loading screen to enter or leave areas. Also, I didn't find the augmentations ("bio mods") to be very interesting in this game. The Neural Interface is the only crucial one if you want to hack stuff, everything else is very basic. Also, there are some smaller things they've changed, some for the worse. Stuff like universal ammo, no attribute skills (not necessarily a bad thing since DX:HR doesn't have it either and that turned out to be an amazing game), less fleshed out in-game lore, and so on.

In short, Invisible War's biggest flaw is the lack of ambition. The very same ambition that made the original so loved.

So. Do I recommend it? Depends on several aspects. Do you already own DX1 and Human Revolution? If not, those two are vastly superior in all regards, so you might want to spend your money on that instead. But if you already own both, then yes, I do recommend you playing through Invisible War at least once. Even if it's just to form your own opinion of it.
