20622887.review:
Deus Ex Invisible War is the Sequel to the extremely good Deus Ex which was released in the year 2000, Invisible War was released in 2003 for the Xbox Original and PC, just like Deus Ex it is a Cyber Punk RPG, set 20 years after the Original Deus Ex the world is still recovering from "The Collapse" basically a 2nd great depression when JC Denton destroyed Area 51, apparently he also Merged with Helios and the Illuminati took over? its a bit confusing, you play as Alex D, a Male or Female student enrolled in the Tarsus Academy who escapes an attack on the School done by The Order, after escaping Tarsus you decide who to trust, who to side with and generally what to do, you only know that Tarsus was secretly watching you and The Order were actually "Trying" to save you and the other Students.

For an old game it has a certain charm to the graphics, while human models are nothing fancy and weapon models are usually quite basic and generic the graphics as a whole do not look that bad at all, It has a great Sci Fi feel and some of the poorer or crime ridden areas you'll explore look run down and have a depressing vibe, the Atmosphere is pretty top notch. Colours are great as well in the livelier areas, i also love the way the shadows are "Painted" to the environment, i kind of miss old Dynamic lighting. 

Just like the First Game you'll decide who to side with and choose what you say with certain important characters and side one's as well, you can threaten people, you can bug out and return and make game changing choices, you have a good amount of freedom and choices you'll make can alter your allegiance with your chosen faction negatively, neutrally or positively, an Example of this is in Cairo you have an option of breaking into an illegal food farm to find out where Dr Nassif is and find out more about her, you have the option of breaking in to find information and boost your allegiance with the WTO, however you can go the next level and destroy the Farmhouse which will boost your Allegiance with the WTO positively however very negatively effect your allegiance with The Order. 

Story is pretty good, you find out more about Alex him/herself, what happened to The Denton's, How the Illumanati effect the world and you are the one to decide how the world will end up, It can come under total Illumaniti control, you can cause anyone who use Biomods (The Replacement to Augmentation canisters) to be practically offed, Or you can cause another Great Collapse and practically turn the World into Fallout. The Endings are all great and are satisfying enough. 

Gameplay is similar to the First Game, you'll often scout the area stealthily, hack terminals if you have the Hack Biomod, Talk to characters or take them out from afar/close, the biggest differences however is that the game has pinpoint accuracy, no more skills to upgrade and Biomods are replaced with Augmentations. While its very odd that you aim at your enemies heads and will practically have almost no spread which can make combat very easy it is still a good change and there's something satisfying about mowing down your enemies like a Badass. 

The Removal of the Skill system however is really frustrating, In Deus Ex 1 you would have a simple goal, go from Point A to Point B however possible, it was up to you to find different ways to do so or free roam first before you go to your objective, this would often reward you with ammo, weapons, items and even skill points, sometimes even an Augmentation Canister which was always exciting and a real "Awww yeah!" moment. In Invisible War however you just get rewarded with Items and mabye a different way through. 

Biomods are a replacement for Augmentations and are kind of similar, you choose a body part which have their own respective Bimods (Around 3, 1 is reserved for Black Market Biomods), for example for your Feet you can install a Speed Booster to move faster and jump higher/further, or if you prefer stealthy approaches you could install a Biomod to make your footsteps quieter, you can level Biomods up to Level 3. Black Market Biomods are very rarely found when exploring the Environment but are often purchased from Omar Traders which are cyborg creepy robot like characters who sell items, Aside from having a RED Colour Black Market Biomods don't have any significant differences, They don't effect your character's appearance or whatever which is a bit of a shame. The Biomods in general all cater to a particular playstyle and are all generally well balanced and fortunately if you wanted to change your playstyle you could as LONG as you had Biomod canisters.

Enemy A.I is both stupid and slightly smart, they hear any loud noises and they will patrol to find whatever caused the noise and alert other enemies, annoyingly however they stand still when they spot you, making them an easy headshot, the only exception is if you retreat which will cause them to slowly chase after you, still you are required to make a Lethal or Non Lethal approach in all situations. 

You have a good variety of weapons to use as well and you can get weapon mods just like the first game, they aren't visible on your weapon sadly but its fun to equip your favourite weapon with Modifications to make them better for your playstyle or to better their faults, oddly however ammo is universal, a Pistol uses the same ammo as a Rocket Launcher for E.G, this was obviously done due to this game having a Port for the Xbox FIRST which is fair enough but for PC it a very strange design choice and its baffling. 

Now onto the bigger issues this game has; as it was originally developed for the Original Xbox we had to deal with that in a PC Port, its very obvious if you play Deus Ex 1 and then this you'll see what i mean, Environments are smaller, loading times are quite frequent and if you have a bad PC it'll take easily 30 seconds everytime you are entering a different area, Now as most people nowadays usually have a good or amazing PC this issue isn't that bad but back in the day you'd be waiting quite often.

The List of places you visit are also small as well, You'll travel to Seattle, Cairo, Trier Germany and more, also you'll return to several of these locations twice or mabye three times with not much else to them. 

However probably the coolest thing about this game is that it has Ragdoll Physics, and they are very entertaining, and due to the Ragdolls being very flexible and often times glitchy you can have real fun throwing bodies into dumpsters, behind corners and over railings, getting the Strength biomod at level 3 is pure fun as you peg bodies halfway across the map and see how much you can get them stuck and glitched (I once had a Female Body be bent backwards, her arms were stuck in an L position and her neck was also stretched and backwards, Yikes.) 

Despite being ported from the Xbox, Having odd design choices and no skill system i still enjoyed Deus Ex Invisible War, it was my First Deus Ex game and i loved it, i much prefer the vastly superior Deus Ex however but Invisible War is not that bad, it doesn't deserve its harsh criticism that it still gets, its an Underrated game and i'd recommend it for fans of the series easily, for RPG Fans i'd still recommend it however don't expect a futuristic Elder Scrolls or whatever.

19678612.review:
[b]Pros:[/b]
-Character customization is still fun, just much more limited
-Gameplay is still fun, just... not like the other Deus Ex games
-Multiple solutions to problems
-Decent amount of content
-Moderate replayability
-Actually a decent standalone game

[b]Cons:[/b]
-Decidedly awful as a Deus Ex game
-Dated graphics
-Choices over entire game are basically made meaningless
-Don't walk forward while using the flamethrower

[b]Overall:[/b] With the exception of Deus Ex: The Fall, which we just don't talk about, this is the most dumbed down Deus Ex experience out there.  Character customization is much more limited, the solutions to problems are all much simpler, and the storyline is just... sorry.  Ninety percent of the game consists of making choices that have zero effect on the endgame, despite feeling important at the time.  This game suffered because it was the sequel to the absolutely outstanding Deus Ex, and after waiting for a sequel, fans were delivered this disappointment.  They wanted more Deus Ex, and this failed to deliver.

That said, this was the first Deus Ex game I ever played, and it was good enough to make me want to play the others.  It's a fun game, with fun gameplay and intriguing mechanics.  If I had played the other Deus Ex games first and played this one after, yes, I would have been disappointed.  This is a failed attempt to match the other games' depth and customization.  But it's [i]still a fun game.[/i]  This of it as Deus Ex Lite.  You'll get the Deus Ex experience, but nowhere near the level of Deus Ex 1 or Human Revolution.  

It is worth playing, even as a Deus Ex game.  The plot is passable, as are the NPCs.  There is a "true pacifist" route to be taken if you desire, and there are some fun easter egg references to the first game buried in here.  For $6.99, the game is fantastic and fun, just don't expect a Deus Ex level experience.  Go in with that mindset, and you'll probably have a good time.

[b]Bottom Line:[/b] Worth the price tag.

17438722.review:
It doesn’t equal the predecessor, however this is a solid FPS/RPG cyberpunk hybrid with fun gameplay, gripping story (despite far-fetched twists), much optional stuff and several factions (tricking your enemies into attacking each other is always hilarious). 

My main complaint concerns the unbalanced and limited biomod system: maximum level 3 can be reached very easily, while some biomods (e.g. aggressive defense drone, vision enhancement) completely pale in comparison to the really useful ones (e.g. thermal masking, regeneration). 

All in all, if you like cyberpunk games, don’t miss this one.

17166936.review:
A superior sequel to Deus Ex unfortunately bogged down by technical issues.

PROS:
+ Better gunplay
+ Compelling story
+ High replayability
+ Open-ended gameplay
+ Biomod respecification
+ Stealth and non-lethal options
+ Visually acceptable for its time
+ Lockpick and Multitool, now a single item
+ Rewarding exploration and experimentation
+ Much better representation of women and diversity

CONS:
- Terrible UI
- No mod support
- Abrupt conclusion
- Many loading times
- No skill point allocation
- Some game-breaking bugs
- Small, claustrophobic levels
- Few meaningful story choices
- Occasional performance drops

Take into account that this is the sequel to arguably one of the best games ever made. The follow up performance left something to be desired, understandably so, but the story itself is still fantastic. If this game were a stand alone title and not part of the Deus Ex series, it'd of received rave reviews from the players as well as media outlets.

Take into account that this game was one of the pioneers for dynamic lighting and ragdoll physics. At the time, Deus Ex: Invisible War was the pinnacle of graphics technology and left me baffled when I played at as a young man.

This game is well worth a play from start to finish, Deux Ex fan or not. It's a fantastic title.

Well, where do I star?
some years back I saw a motivational image about deus ex that says "DEUS EX: every time you mention it, someone will reinstall it" something that stupid made me want to play the game, and as outdate as the combat mechanic is, the game catched my heart, and with and the same time I heard the comments of how it's sequel fall short.

In my experience the original Deus ex is or was the "The Ugly Duckling" and Invisible Wars is Pyrite the fool's gold, looks like gold but it is not.

[B]GAMEPLAY:[/B] the original Deus ex has a big flaw for me;the aim sistem, it is a big NO, too inaccurate and too little ammo easily wasted missing 85% of the time, but since I like stealth games I was able to over look it most of time and played stealth non-letal. So when I started this game I saw the new and proved aim system, I was happy, but that is the only thing I can say it's better than the original one.

the game is way too easy everything is given to you, you will never run out of anything even the upgrades, you will never have to use your brain, you will never have to manage your items like the original, making the different routes pointless, for example:
you have in front of you a door and one key in your hand, you can; A) use the key, B) find another way and save the key for later. ¿what you do? the answer is "A" you will never run out of keys.

and of top of that It's too easy, I barely used any gun, 90% of the game I used the baton: "Strength Enhancement lv 3 + Electrostatic Discharge lv1 = all you need" I was terminator with a stick (and you can get set up in the very first level), I could take down soldiers, bots, cameras, laser alarms turrents with just that, making items even more useless and [i]even without those two skills[/i] each level provides more tools than you really need in that same level at plain view.

[B]STORY:[/B] the first one you feel some weight in your decisions, but in this game you just do it and that's all, you never wonder if you choose right or not, you may as well just toss a coin. the main character is just too bland (and so is everyone else expect Leo, I fine with him) he may as well be a silent a silent character, in fact it would be better he was a silent character, nothing what he says really matter after the second level.

choosing a faction in video game is not a bad thing but when both factions star bombing you with missions left and right the in very beginning of the game is not fun, specialy if the only thing you know about them is their name, and it feels like you never make any progression with any of them until the very end, so who cares!? just do some mission for this one and do some that one later.


in less words:  the game stars okay, but it feels more and more empty the more you play. story wise you don't get to feel that you actually progress or change something , you just did or not some missions until the very end. and gameplay wise gets way too easy way too fast because you get everything you need too early.

16056982.review:
Being a huge fan of the Deus Ex series, I had high hopes going into Deus Ex: Invisible War. The story starts off with Alex, an Orphan, raised by a couple in Chicago and put into a special schoolfor gifted children, where she eventually found her way into the Taurus program, a human augmentation program. You start off being attacked by religious fanatics and are given both sides point of view, with each side trying to persuade you the other is the real threat. Interesting story, I like the concept and it had be playing for over an hour, when I only intended a short demo for the review. It appears to further the Deus Ex Canon, and while it has all the wonderful potential of a Deus Ex game, I will warn you now there are bugs.

First of all, every time the game wants to load a new area, It jumps back to your desktop for a a few seconds and the resolution change makes your desktop appear to be supersized. It does this a lot. The graphics are not quite up to par for a sequel to Deus Ex, but it is passable. The game almost has a feel as though it were rushed or poorly ported from a handheld or console. I think it would be a prime candidate for a reboot, as it was interesting. All in all I will recommend it, but only to those who are familiar with the Deus Ex series, so as to acquire this piece of Deus Ex Canon for your collection. Otherwise, if you are looking for a quality game, and don't care about the series, the Original is great, and Deus Ex: Human Revolution is fantastic. Either way, the series is solid.

15783055.review:
Deus Ex: Invisible War is a game that, in my opinion, receives WAY too much flak. Ok, it's not on the EXACT same level as the original, but the game is a must-buy for any true fan of the Deus Ex franchise. The gameplay is fun, challenging on occasion as it should be, and the story is very in-depth, as you would come to expect, with many Datacubes and News Terminals to hear about the world from. Other than the gripes outlined below, I can see no reason that this game gets as much crap as it does.

#1 - The interface. It's just flat-out not as good as the original.
#2 - Stability. I've not technically beaten this game yet. I only just now reached the abandoned VersaLife base near the end of the game, and I've been completely stopped dead in my tracks as far as Progression is concerned. I've been trying for little over 40 minutes now, and I crash almost every 1-2 minutes, or whenever I try to headshot someone with my sniper rifle.
#3 - The Universal Ammo system. I shouldn't need to explain this one, but it essentially makes it very hard to have more than one weapon. I for one carry many different weapons, including a Silenced Pistol/Sniper Rifle, Shotgun, and a SMG. Shared ammo just doesn't work in a game like this.

15361277.review:
The original Deus Ex is one of the best games ever made, so when Invisible War suffers from a bad reputation, I assumed it was undeserved. I assumed that it would at least be "pretty ok", and that its poor ratings were due to people comparing it to the first game. Holy cow, was I wrong.

This game is atrociously bad, and not just compared to its older brother. It's genuinely a waste of time and money completely by itself. In short: Had I known how frustratingly bad Invisible War was, I wouldn't even have picked it up for free.

Some of the bad parts (no real spoilers):

- The writing. While the story builds on Deus Ex, you get no build-up, no twists (excepting a few incredibly obvious attempts), no suspense, no room for wondering or doubting. You're never allowed to be curious about the world, the backstory or the events of the past, as most of this is just dumped bluntly at your feet. At one point you walk into a bunker, find some high-level people, and out of nowhere these complete strangers start telling you about their deepest, darkest secrets.

- The pacing. At times, people will warn you that "someone has a secret agenda for you", and you can be certain that within two minutes that same "someone" will give you a call to explain their agenda for you, right to your face.

- The level design. Pretty much every single level is a tiny, cramped area. For reference, the 'ton Hotel in Deus Ex is one of the smaller levels in that game, but it would easily fit in as one of the larger levels in Invisible War. This means you'll enjoy a lot more loading screens a lot more often, but it also makes the game feel so much more shallow: When security HQ is 15 meters from the doorstep of the terrorists, suspension of disbelief drops like a rock. It also means walking through four levels blasting bad guys, then walking back through four empty levels.

- The loading screens. Loading time is usually not an issue for me, with a fast SSD in a fast PC. Invisible War doesn't care. Every so often it goes through a complicated series of steps to load a new level, which includes shutting down the rendering engine to flash you your desktop for a few seconds, then going all white for a while as it restarts, and then it starts actually loading, which takes another 10-15 seconds.

- The number of loading screens. In one typical part of the game, you go through a door - loading screen - across a square - loading screen - across a room to talk to someone, then back out - loading screen - around a corner and down a street - loading screen - down some stairs, talk to a guy, and then retrace the whole route with all the loading screens all over again. Steam tells me I've had the game running some 12 hours, but my save game clock tells me I have 7,5 hours playtime. Including a little menu browsing, that means I have likely spent a quarter of my ingame time looking at loading screens.

- The AI. It is so bad it can sometimes be an involuntary source of rare fun. At one point, members of two opposing factions are involved in a firefight, while a couple of guards stroll idly through the crossfire, taking no notice. As the fight ends, the same guards suddenly freak out over the bodies at their feet - "Ah! A body! There's been a murder! You won't get away with this", they exclaim, and then just keep walking. On a different occasion, an NPC shoots another NPC, and then freaks out over the body *which he just made*. "There's been a murder!" - no, really? And that's saying nothing of the shoddy combat AI, nor the incredibly poor search AI. You can actually hide from enemies by standing on the other side of a glass door, or by closing an air vent cover, and they will have no idea where you went.

- Graphics – and I don't mean "it's ugly", I mean it's really poorly designed. Most weapons are close to identical both when equipped and as inventory icons. With a few exceptions, it's hard to tell what things you can pick up in the field really is (except blinky and futuristic). Are those credit chips, datacubes, or maybe weapon modifications? Who knows! Better break into this locker to find out.

- User interface. Of all the compromises made to make this game possible to run for its intended Xbox, this is likely the worst. Honestly, the UI of Invisible War is worse than trying to do internet banking with a broken gamepad.

I could go on for a long time - this is in no way a complete list - but honestly, if you still think it "can't be that bad", go right ahead and buy it. Or save your money, go on YouTube and find a "let's play" video. I enjoyed some 25 hours of fun on my last Deus Ex playthrough. In Invisible War, it took me less than 8 hours to reach the 2nd to last level. Then I just decided I couldn't be bothered, uninstalled it, and would rather just read about the ending than suffer through more.

15243328.review:
I came into Invisible War expecting the hatred to mostly be the result of the high bar set by the first game. Now that I've actually played it, I can safely say that this is a bad game even outside the context of the vastly superiror Deus Ex and Human Revolution. Bugs abound, the story is boring and full of holes, combat is inane, and most of the biomods are completely uninteresting. 

(NOTE: My playtime is inaccurate. I had to play offline because of an obnoxious design flaw that has the game start a new process every time you go to a new area - Steam interprets this as restarting the game and sends annoying popups to all your friends every 5 minutes. My actual time with the game was around 12 hours.)

Pros:

- You can throw furniture at people's heads. Everyone has 5-7 lines of dialogue to complain about you doing this and a funny recoil animation. They'll never go hostile despite threatening to attack. It's fun, and I did it to basically everyone in the game once I realized it wasn't any good. 

- You can kill everyone. There are only lasting consequneces for killing plot characters, though, and even those are fairly negligible. See cons. 

- The voice acting is generally pretty good. A few minor NPCs do their best to ruin that. 

Cons:

- Bugs. So many bugs. A few of the ones I encountered: Multitools sometimes won't stack or count correctly because the devs couldn't ID things correctly, autosaves will randomly delete and send you back 30 minutes, one full CTD, ragdolls try to reach the fourth dimension when shot by turrets or patrol bots, and tons of minor inconveniences like small items not being accessible behind useless aesthetics with large hitboxes or the light from lamps not remotely matching where the bulb is pointed. 

- The story is terrible. It tries to be deep, but mostly ends up being nonsensical. International air travel hasn't existed for 20 years, supposedly, but there's a private pilot hanging out in a slum bar in the first area you visit. He owns a Harrier and can fly to Cairo from Seattle. 

- There's basically no music.

- The AI is incredibly stupid. You can kill people by pushing flaming barrels into them and no one will care. In combat, they'll stand still with their backs to you for no reason and all try to be in exactly the same spot. The only real threat comes the lack of health restoration in the early game. 

- Once you get a sniper rifle, there is no reason to use anything else. It can kill any human enemy (with a very late game exception) in one shot from any distance provided you hit them in the head, which isn't challenging since they're so fond of standing still. Pistols do pathetic damage, shotgun damage dropoff is too high, and all other weapons drain ammo too quickly to be worth using. 

- Ammo is shared between all weapons and obnoxiously rare. Quite a few enemy types apparently fire using dark magic and will never drop ammo. 

- You can kill everyone, but nobody cares. I walked into a nightclub and proceeded to murder everyone, including a security chief and the Culture Minister of Seattle. The police outside didn't care, and no one ever brought it up again. 

- Quests that clearly should be mutually exclusive aren't. You can take a quest to become the enemy of the Omar and the ally of the Omar. If you finish the enemy quest first, you'll briefly be penalized, but then can still reach friend status by completing the other quest. Another early quest pair involving rival businesses can also have both halves completely for full reward. 

- No meaningful choices until the end. 

- Bad level design. Where Human Revolution and Deus Ex have multiple routes into everything and allow for a stealth approach, Invisible War rarely has alternate routes more interesting than air ducts and seemingly goes out of its way to make stealth unviable.

-------

Some good get a bad reputation for failing to live up to their predecessors. This isn't one of those - it's simply bad, and not even the ability to bean bartenders in the head with their own kegs can save it.

15216154.review:
Now just to be up front; this game makes bad sequels look bad.  After the sheer joy of the first Deus Ex, I was very excited to give this one a try; too bad for me.

While you can still find echoes of the open, multi-method gameplay that Deus Ex is known for, the overall experience is dull.  The AI appears less capable, and the voice acting does nothing to make up for the limitations.  The story just feels less compelling, and they even have one massively contradicting feature from the previous narrative (no spoiler here).  The individual maps are tiny and relatively featureless, and lack enough NPCs to give them life (even the night club’s population is a joke).  There are also no transition animations/mini-movies, which is painful given the amount of traveling you do (remember the small maps?).

Moving on from the atmosphere, the gameplay reeks of a bad console port.  Your options for character customization are a far cry from the previous title; there are less augmentations and items to play with, too.  I also found a severe imbalance concerning ammunition.  If you don’t play it safe and stockpile munitions by the time you’ve got heavy hitters coming at you, and you didn’t plan on using stealth the whole way through (kinda go hand-in-hand, right?) then things get painful.  Oh, and all weapons are supplied by one ammo type, and you can only carry so much.  Not to say, however, that this game is overly challenging all the way through (quite the opposite).

Just everything about this game was “less” than its predecessor.  Unless you are planning to purchase just out of dedication to the Deus Ex franchise, don’t waste your time with this one.

15199433.review:
It is with some very mixed feelings that I DO recommend this game. I wouldn't call me playing it a waste of time, because I have played plenty of games worse than this one. The game is awash with bugs - but many are in my opinion only aestethic, and does not affect the general gameplay as much. Sure the floating objects, invisible spider-bots and massive amount of clipping (mostly in cinematics) are disturbing - but again, nothing that should deteriorate you from playing this game, because it does function still.

The ragdoll-graphics bring both joy and annoyance - at times they are hilarious (yes, mostly at the beginning of the game), but at other times they are just plainly frustrating. Not to mention even a bit surreal - but extremely surreal. Sure, this ordinary enemy takes 10 shots to his torso and still lives (like what?), but one shot to the head and he's tossed like 30 feet out from a balcony. From a pistol-shot. With a silencer.

The loading-screens are many, and extremely frustrating. My first (and only, thank God) play-through of this game is roughly 18 hours. Not 18 hours that I was tormented non-stop. More like 3 hours of "damn, this is actually a very good game!" and 15 hours of "omg, I just wanna finish this game so I can move on". Point is, without the extreme amount of loading-screens every 5-10 minutes, my play-time could have been shaved down to like 11 hours or something. Not to mention random crashes (five in my play-through), and the fact that every time the game moves on to another loading-screen it minimizes to my desktop - stays that way for about 20 seconds and then resumes to the loading-screen which is another 30-40 seconds of waiting. And it randomize my oh-so-carefully organized desktop each and every fucking time, too.

I didn't really have a problem with the HUD, I thought it was aestethically acceptable and easy to learn and understand. What I did have a problem with was the over-simplification of the biomods, and inventory-screen. Only 5 slots to fill with biomods, and none the ordinary biomods (except for the muscle-thing that expand you inventory) are that appealing seeing as you get a hold of your first supposedly illeagal - and almost too helpful - biomod after about 1 hour of play.

The story of the game is good. Not as good as the first Deus Ex, mind you. But it is still good, and frankly was the only thing that kept me going and completing the game. I think the level-design negatively impact the story-line and sort of cramps the ability to go about everything the way you could in the first Deus Ex, but on the other end the level-design did promote a more direct, fast-paced sort of action (seeing as upgrading the speed-biomod to max-level could be done in about 2 hours of game-time, and thus could be activated basically non-stop the rest of the game due to low bioenergy-consumption and a complete overload of energy-cells throughout the game).

To sum it up: Play this game for the story. It will not perform miracles gameplay-wise. The storyline isn't fantastic either, but I can't call it a waste of time because I did enjoy building upon the legacy that JC Denton left in the original game. I think with a bit more effort from the developers, that this game could have been somewhat better and more of a worthy sequel to the 1st Deus Ex, as opposed to the bleak shadow of the 1st game that it is today. The game is worth 7 €, but I got it on a sale, which somehow eased the discomfort I experienced while playing it.

60/100

15035239.review:
[b]"You are only minimally modified. We can help you correct this."[/b]

Deus Ex: Invisible War is a for the most part linear FPS-RPG in a sinister Sci-Fi setting. 

It's graphics pale compared to other titles using the same engine, levels seem a bit confined especially when compared to the first [i]Deus Ex[/i] and the inventory is tiny - design concessions that had to be made in order for a release on the original Xbox console to be possible. 

Frequent loading screens in between small level sections can be somewhat annoying and take between 20-30 seconds even on a SSD. (Save regularly to avoid having to replay lenghty sections because very rarely the game did crash on me and even corrupted a save-file once.)

Sounds bad? Nah. 

I played through the game close to its release and played through it again just now. Don't be fooled into thinking this is the abysmal game enthusiasts of the first game often make it out to be. It's less complex in just about every aspect, yes, but it still an enjoyable experience for fans of the series and FPS-RPG fans alike. Shooting feels fine, weapons and gadgets/biomods are fun to use, different approaches to enemy encounters / completing objectives are possible and encouraged, even some plot altering decisions can be made. 

Overall it was an enjoyable 20 hour experience (if you take your time like me, and try to find up to six special weapons well hidden in the game). A recommendation when on sale, especially for fans of the first game for story reasons and for fans of the cyberpunk/noir/dark Sci-Fi genres. 

(Note: I ran this game on Win 8.1 64-Bit using the community texture pack, at 1080p resolution, 120 FOV and reduced HUD size. Using all these tweaks (to be found in the community section here on steam) I even found it visually to be a somewhat pleasing experience.)

14966057.review:
If this game has taught me anything, it is to take what others say with a grain of salt. I went into this expecting an experience akin to that of arm wrestling with a chainsaw, but I guess that everyone's talk of this game lowered my expectations to unreasonable depths. Invisible War is, while not as good as its predecessor, a good game.

A big complaint I notice is the "consolization", the clear downgrade in many aspects of the overall design of the first game, including large levels, complex controls, dynamic damage, skills, and swimming. (The multiplayer is gone as well.) There is a lack of control options, which correlated directly to removal of leaning, reduced toolbelt size and biomod (augmentation) slots, and an ugly HUD. As for the size of areas, I would chalk that up to incredibly sloppy coding and graphics that were ahead of their time. One might look at the game's system requirements and then remember that this released in North America in 2003. However, as far as I'm concerned, it is still little excuse; The smaller areas force a different style of gameplay, and the frequency and time of the loading screens is just annoying.

Atmosphere-wise, there is nothing wrong. The graphics are great, and the story, a direct sequel, I would say surpasses that of the original, at least in terms of depth. In terms of how memorable the characters are... eh, I don't really have much to say. Open-ended missions change the flow of the game. Rather than being given one main objective at a time a la the first game, the player is given multiple objectives from warring factions that ultimately branch to the end, and make the ending seem like more of a result of the path taken throughout the game, rather than a rushed decision made at the last minute, though the latter is certainly still possible should you enjoy being chaotic in choosing your allies.

Sadly, if the story is more open than the original, the same cannot be said for weapons and inventory management. Multitools and lockpicks are now one and the same. Items now only take up one slot each, so there is no need for inventory Tetris, but the small size can only be increased by installing and upgrading a specific biomod. Food can be stacked regardless of the type. Firearms have universal ammo, which I saw to be a self-defeating mechanism. In the original Deus Ex, running out of ammo for a weapon forced me to rethink my entire combat strategy and apply it until I could renew my supplies. Here, run out for one gun, you run out for just about everything else. On top of that, weapons can only take two mods at a time, and mods cannot be removed once applied.

Even with a decent variety of weapons, I found little point to using nonlethal tactics. At least during the first few hours of the first game, you would get reprimanded for it. Here, there is almost never a reason to not just kill enemies on the spot. Even when I do use a nonlethal weapon, the game treats the character as having died, and he or she will not appear again. The small area sizes, while not too restrictive, encourage more aggressive gameplay by giving very limited options as to approach.

The player has fewer biomods/augmentations at one time. Luckily, many of the classics are here, as well as some new ones to compensate for the ones which were pulled. The best change here is having three to choose from for any specific slot, and the ability to change between them should you have the materials. It's a fine way to keep the player from restarting when he's realized that the combination he's chosen to go with is ineffective.

I'm certain I've left something out, but this review has to end sometime. Even with all of its simplification problems, it manages to cling enough to the core Deus Ex gameplay. I plan on coming back to this sometime in the future, as I'm certain there's a lot more for me to discover, and the mission structure provides a great deal of replay value. Methinks people would treat this game better were it not called Deus Ex, but as it stands, Invisible War is a fine addition to the series.

What's OK or good - story, robot enemy design, voice acting, genuinely different ways to do most things, the game rewards you for exploring, nice weapon sounds, good stealth sections, the odd genuinely amusing line (my favorite was the NG AI's reply to what she's gonna go about her manager), setting Templar bigots on fire from distance with the Hellfire Boltcaster. The game is pretty much worth it just for that last one. 

What's bad or terrible - It's a whole lot less fun than Human Revolution, the levels need to re-load very often due to the whole "aimed at consoles" thing, making the level management feel older than the smooth transitions of Half-Life, you can't sell things to traders, and there's not really a whole lot worth buying either, you need to have several saves because of the high chance of your latest one going kaput and refusing to load. It used to do that on Xbox too. Ahhh, Nostalgia. 

Can't take F12 screencaps either despite steam overlay claiming to work. That might just be my PC though.

14711527.review:
[h1] My Adventure with DX:IW [/h1]

[b] TL:DR Version: [/b] Couldn't even get it to run, compatibility issues abound, don't waste your money.

 
I really wanted to play this game having just finished the original Deus Ex and Human Revolution and loving them both. I know this game has gotten a lot of hate so I wanted to see if it really stood for it or if that was just the angry nostalgia talking...

 Too bad I was never able to find out. 

Right off the bat the game wouldn't run, it would sit on a black screen and do nothing as task manager repeatedly warned that it was not responding. Eventually I found a fix for that and was able to get it started, and thought I was on the road to beginning the game, but a short time and an intro cutscene later the game threw my hopes of that out the window. I was able to choose my character and clicked the done button and then I was greeted by another black screen. I ended the task and the game refused to let my resolution go back to normal. After I went and manually turned it back, the game randomly decided to start back up, and I was thrust into the first level. I went through it and got to the next level, and again, another black screen. This one wouldn't go away no matter what I did. I searched forums and tried all sorts of "fixes" but none of them worked: compatibility settings, resolution changes, "fixed" start exes, even changing the affinity of the exe to a single core. None of these things worked. The only thing I didn't try that people said worked was a compatibility problem with Realtek audio drivers...which I wasn't about to uninstall all of my audio to run this game. Not worth it. So, having never gotten to play the game except for the first "level," I have to not recommend this game simply for it's horrible compatibility problems.

The voice acting is atrocious.  It literally sounds like the voice actors are reading right off an index card without any emotion what so ever. The placing of codes and data cubes with highly top secret information is absurd.  Yet I still recommend the game.

No lean function?  Ridiculous.  But I still recommend this game.

AI?  None.

But the game was........fun? Yep.  Take it for what it is: mediocre entertainment.  Had cheap.  Just enjoy it.  Its simple and it is just that simple: mindless entertainment.

14461526.review: I give up. I really wanted to give this game a chance, because I love the Deus Ex world. After playing slowly and deliberately for an hour, trying to take in the slightly changed gameplay mechanics and learn about the new world post-Area 51, the game quit to the desktop. Not the standard "restart from desktop" that happens literally every time you enter a new area (3-4 rooms), but "click lift button to enter new area, game quits as usual, desktop appears as usual, game never comes back". I spent hours trying the different hacks and tweaks documented online: changing resolutions, binding the executables to individual CPUs, downloading hacked executables, setting it up in compatibility mode, alt-tabbing at the perfect time, creating junctions for 32-bit C:\Program Files, but nothing worked. It's a shame, because I actually quite liked the "circle interface" and the graphics and enemy AI seemed improved over Deus Ex GOTY, though it's hard to tell since I only got to see 6 bad guys and about 10 rooms in total. Running Windows 8.1 on tablet the in-game performance was great, but troubleshooting a show-stopper bug like this is not worth my time, even if there is a great game hidden in there somewhere.

14091399.review:
This game isn't SO bad. It's just ok and mediocre. It's a watered down, shortened version of the original Deus Ex. That being said, there are a couple of things that made this game worth playing through.

PROS
+ The freedom of choice is fairly broad and there are different ways to complete various objectives.
+ Fairly good story/Interesting to see the world post Deus Ex 1. 
+ Good amount of missions per area to keep you busy.
+ NG Resonance Holo-Sim is waifu material.

CONS
- Mechanics from the first game became overly simplified (Guns/ammo, biomods, keycodes, locks, etc).
- Characters are not interesting.
- Stealth and combat are hit and miss.
- HUD is atrocious.
- Loading screens everywhere.
- Game can be a pain to get running correctly sometimes.

One thing I really want to comment on is the fact that I've had this game crash on me numerous times for the most random of reasons. I still don't know what was causing them or what fixed them, it just happens. It also seems to take up an obscene amount of computer processing power/memory for a game made over a decade ago. 

It's not a terrible game per se, it's just not the follow up one would hope for after Deus Ex. I played through this because I was curious of the what the world was like after the events of the first game and that alone was what carried me through it. That and NG Resonance Holo-Sim. 

6/10

14014278.review:
I tried really hard to like this game, I really did. I first came across Deus Ex and fell hopelessly in love with it, played it over ten times in a row; I went as far as turning it into a book for a big school project. The characters of the first game are memorable and lovable. JC Denton is my favorite character of everything, Bob Page is the best villian of all time, and who could forget Jock? They've made big impacts in my memory and I can never stop thinking about it.

I discovered Human Revolution next and fell in love with that one, too. Adam Jensen is a fantastic person with awesome sunglasses, doesn't take crap from anyone, the great Francis Pritchard, and the twisted Hugh Darrow. Between these two games, I sometimes get chills down my spine.

Then I found Invisible War. The first time I played it I liked it, not loved it. The characters didn't make a big impact on me, Alex D just doesn't fit in with the Denton crowd. There isn't one villain to focus my hate on. (Don't get me wrong, I love the villains.) In the other games I was scared, my heart was pounding, I was forcing myself to meet deadlines as fast as I could. In Invisible War it felt like there was something I should be doing. There was no big motivation. The ultimate freedom of this game is a hinderence. This fell way short of my expectations.

13814674.review: A polarizing sequel, Deus Ex: Invisible War chopped off some of the old-school PC RPG elements held dear by some fans of the original and streamlined the essential experience of the series: getting your nano-augmented secret agency safely through a level with as much or as little bloodshed as you like. The conspiracy-cum-cyberpunk flare of the original remains, however, and the soundtrack sparkles in a way the first game's didn't. Invisible War holds up better in the playability and graphics departments than its progenitor, despite being only three years younger. A worthy successor.

13656627.review:
Deus Ex: Invisible War is infamous for being unusually inferior to its predecessor, but exactly how is a question I decided to answer myself by playing the game. Invisible War is a decent game I must stress this, but decent is simply not good enough if you are the direct followup to what many considered, even at the time, one of the greatest video games ever made. Invisible War has a distinction of taking away far too many of the original game's features and depth and offering very little in return aside from prettier graphics and the option to play as a female.

For starters, this is a port of a console game, while the original Deus Ex was custom built exclusively for the PC platform. This alone is a terrible thing, as the game is inherrently bound to the original Xbox's limitations, and these limitations negatively impact nearly every facet of the game. No environment is even half as big as the first level of the original, load times tend to take more screen time than gameplay, and your key binding options are much more limited. There are even actions that cannot be rebound to a different key! 

Second of all, ammo across all weapons is universal, the health system is a standard percentage based system rather than one based of areas of the body inflicted (while Human Revolution also does this, that game allows such a system to be upgraded, thus adding depth), and you CANNOT MANUALLY RELOAD YOUR WEAPON. It stupefies gameplay to such a degree that it insults both console players new to this game as well as existing fans. It's the fisher-price version of Deus Ex, and it stars a protagonist that looks like a long-lost Backstreet Boy. There's a reason why it took so long between this and Human Revolution; the new devs had to figure out a proper way to unfuck this franchise.

Other than all that shit I just said, it's not a broken game. It can be played and enjoyed, especially as a stealth or action game, but do know ahead of time that this is not the proper Deus Ex experience. Choices matter much less, and at times you simply HAVE to kill someone or HAVE to hack this thing. Player flexibility is discarded when seen useful, and that goes against the design philosophy of both the original and the excellent Human Revolution. Only play this as a history lesson on why this is one of the most disappointing sequels ever made.

13490424.review:
Many people will say that this game is the worst.  "It's nothing like the first game!  It blows chunks!"

Well, I'll say you're wrong.

It is DEFINATELY not the best game in the series, like the first one.  Like Deus Ex: The Fall you need to look at the game as what they wanted it to be and how accutare the game got to their target.  As we can see in the ad for it, most of what is shown is firefights and explosions.  Perhaps they wanted a more action-esque game?  Yes and no.

I know it says that I'm played very little of the game here on steam, however I had a CD copy of this recently and decided to play it one day as it had only been opened a few times before.  My older cousins would come once in a while and since we had a desktop, cousin P would come and play his collection of PC games he would leave here.  Recently, within the last few months in the smmer, I found the stash and this was in it.

After 6 hours of playing it off the CD I can say, yes the game IS NOT the first one.  Most scenes are better done by running and gunning rather than slow and comprehensive plans and watching the walking patterns.  And sure, it might crash once in a blue moon; who cares!  This is a windows 2000 game :D

Other than the main RPG flaw being that you need a gun no matter what to go anywhere fast, you can definately play the game the old style if you want to.  This does prove to be tougher over all as the enemies don't USUALLY walk on a path anymore.  Nor do the have a specific walk area.  Enemies tend to explore, and if they find you you're done unless you flatten them ASAP.  Armor is indeed hard to come by as an upgrade so it is worth having health items as often as possible.  You will take a hit, even it a random fire starts.

Different from the first game, where in the beginning you have to collect items from enemy guards and such instead of finding them in random places, in this game it is flipped:  you can just find random whatever anywhere on the map.  As I said earlier the RPG elements are indeed lowered.

So what were they aiming for?  While the first game revolutionized how we think of FPRPG's nowadays, at the time quake was the holyfartcow of the universe just as COD is now.  What was most likely being aimed for was the idea of being more like a shooter than an RPG, even though those elements are still there.  Not helpful in a stealth FPRPG.

Overall score?  7.6 / 10.  Not a bad game, just not as good as the first.

13259316.review:
Haven't played through much of the game yet so I can't give an evaluation of the story. 

This game is definitely the worst pc port I've seen yet, admittedly I steer clear of the really bad ports but this is definitely a red flag. Compared to the original game which actually seems to handle anything I threw at it fine (played the game in a window and used a tool to make it borderless) this game flat out refuses to cooperate.

Max resolution available to me is 1280x1024, you can force change this in the ini but the game automatically re-writes settings when it reloads (which is often, more later) so I had to forcibly deny access via Windows security settings. 

Windowed mode is also an option via .ini edit however do not expect borderless, the game flips out and the window simply becomes invisible if you attempt to modify anything about the size of the window while it is open, whether that be borderless using a tool or maximizing it in task manager to get rid of the ugly gap beneath the window.

The game also reloads often, loading in any area seems to do this as do some cutscenes, and believe me this is often. As a result of the console release presumably and the limited hardware of said consoles at the time the actual areas loaded in at once are horrifically small (Funnily enough, a criticism of the newer "The Fall" title too). However, this is not just loading screens, the game actually reloads itself entirely each time it does so, other reviews were certainly not exaggerating when they said you will spend more time watching loading screens than in game.

There are some other minor issues arising already, the controls are certainly not as freely rebindable as the first game and the UI compared to the previous game is clearly console-based though workable on PC. Other issues of varying magnitude by individual preference are a somewhat lacking options menu and more.

Overall, as far as a PC title goes this game has a whole host of issues, this game is certainly not for the impatient and many will find the port frustrating to work with (hopefully some of my points help people get the game working how they like it).

As for the story, o far it seems like it could be promising, seen a few Deus Ex 1 style options, the core mechanics are still there though I'm not well they're handled later down the line. So far the game has been very much like a tutorial (or perhaps the game as a whole is too linear). There is certainly a clear conspiracy style storyline (as you would expect for Deus Ex) though perhaps its a little forced this time, as I mentioned I haven't played much so far, only about to leave the first area and I am already being presented by two very distinct sides and making a major choice between the two.

This review isn't really to cover the storyline though, if you've previously played Deus Ex you already know the reputation of Invisible War and are considering playing it because you want to find out what happens after the 1st game, just keep in mind the hurdles in doing so I mentioned earlier. I do think I will play this to the end regardless, just might be in shorter bursts than HR and DX1.

When I first played this game (as a port to the XBox), I thought this game was amazing.  Then I played Deus Ex 1 and my opinion of Invisible War changed for the worse.  Invisible War offers good game play, a good story, some interesting choice mechanics, and smart writing.  But all of this is not as good as what the first Deus Ex, or many other games for that matter.  The game play often times feels streamlined to the point of being dumbed down.  The way choices are presented to the player feels more overt and clunky than Dues Ex.  While the writing is smarter than many other games, the dialouge too often takes the form of exposition dump or feels out of place.  Deus Ex had a similar problem with out of place philosophic dialogue, but Invisible War did it worse.

If steam offered a mixed choice instead just yes or no in terms of recommendations, I would choose that.  Given the binary nature of recommendations, I have to choose yes.   DE Invisible War is by no means a bad game and is actually very enjoyable.  Due to some unfortunate design choices it is not as good as it could have been.

13124734.review:
Fantastic game. If you are looking for a clone of the first one than don't look here. 

Pros: You can kill everyone if you want. Decent graphics for when it was made, especially for consoles.  Fun, yet confusing story that gives you many side quests and a good bit of moral and faction based choices. Many ways to complete a quest: stealth, run and gun, or let the machines do your work for you.  Good choice of weapons along with secret variant weapons that only the dilligent will find. Also has aome pretty cool weapon modifications you can add to your weapons. Decent physics.  The biomod system is fun and has you getting excited everytime you find a biomod canister.  There are also 4 different endings that you can receive depending on how you handle the last mission.

Cons:  Allthough the story is fun, it IS confusing.  The universal weapon ammo system sucks balls; so even though you are guaranteed ammo for every gun you have, you still have to ration ammo because some guns use more than others (I myself found myself out of ammo more than once and had to rely on my biomods to get me out of a jam).  Some might say that the religious stereotypes in the Templar and Order factions could be a con (I myself could care less but Im putting it here because someone else might).  

I myself thouroughly enjoyed this game even though it did not live up to the expectations of the first.  A great buy for those who want a fun gaming experiance.

13024430.review:
This game surpassed my expecations. There is a surprisingly large amount of choices which have a real impact on the story. I found the story and side stories to be interesting and supportive of the gameplay. The gameplay itself is pretty damn fun and comparable to the first game, involving stealth, gunplay, tech equipment, special abilities, etc.

I've beaten both the original Deus Ex and now Invisible War and I must say, besides the changes to streamline certain gameplay aspects, Invisible War is just as high quality as the first. It definitely seemed like a true sequel to me, despite what I've read online. And hell, I'd even say the changes make the game a lot easier to get a handle on, as the first game at times felt a bit overwhelming to deal with. I actually felt a lot more engaged with the biomod system in Invisible War because of the fact that it laid out the details more clearly. 

The main issue with this game is the loading screen issue. Levels are HEAVILY segmented into separate areas that must be loaded individually, and every time you enter a new area, the game minimizes for a few seconds, comes back up and then takes another few seconds to load. This process also occurs every time you load a save, meaning that even hitting quickload (F12) will force you to wait 10 seconds. The original game had instant quick loading, as MOST games do. 

If you are wondering if you should play this after playing the first game, then the answer is yes. Don't let whiny comments about the game being terrible because it was "consolized" fool you. This is a true, high quality sequel to the original Deus Ex.

13001703.review:
I played the first Deus Ex years ago and went back to play the next game in the series. I am sad to report that this game is a total piece of garbage. Overall, it was a very consolized and poorly designed sequel. Here is why I would recommend skipping this game:

[b]1.  Loading screens. [/b] You will probably spend more time watching loading screens than actually playing the game. The game is set up so that only tiny pieces of each area are loaded at one time so that you have to watch loading screen after loading screen after loading screen just to move through the game. Even the main menu has a loading screen. It is so oppressive that it ruins the gameplay.

[b]2.  Cramped level design. [/b] All the maps feel like you're moving through tunnels. Even the outdoor areas seem very close quarters and boxed in with loading barriers every 15 feet.

[b]3.  Incessant bugs and crashing (which of course leads to more loading screens).[/b] This is kind of self-expanatory, but I personally had a particularly bad problem with random crashing and then corrupt savegames. There were also the other classic bugs such as stuff getting stuck in walls, NPCs battling each other when they're not supposed to, buggy objects jittering around the levels, etc. The camera angles during cutscenes were a joke. It's kind of hard to take the game seriously when the camera angles switch between close up of the floor and half a character's face during every cutscene.

[b]4.  Flat characters and lame storyline.[/b] The game played like one of those choose your own adventure books with a little target shooting thrown in here and there. The designers really got into this 'choose between factions' idea and took it too far. All the interactions and cutscenes were nothing more than each faction trying to persuade you to join their side with very little underlying plot or consequences for your actions. The characters seemed so dull and one dimensional. The designers tried to get all philosophical with many elements of the game but failed to impress me with the depth of their ideas and understanding.

[b]5.  Crawling in air ventilation.[/b] After a while, you start to realize that attached to every room it is a grate leading to a gigantic man-sized ventilation shaft with convenient ladders for all the vertical sections. Not only is this kind of silly, but it becomes annyoing when you spend half the game crawling through these vanilla cloned tunnels. Of course you don't HAVE to go that route, but when the alternative is to waste an item, ammo, or other resource, and vent crawling is free, you are encouraged to spend your time exploring the ducts.

[b]6.  You get all firearms and items way too early.[/b] The game essentially gives you every item in the game in the first hour of playing. I had about 10 unused biomod upgrades at the end of the game with all my biomods maxed out. You are loaded up with so much stuff that it destroys all the fun of spontaneously finding a new item or upgrading your skill to a new level.

[b]7.  Side quests for money to buy WHAT?[/b] There are quite a few "secondary" goals that typically result in a small cash reward. However, you are already overstocked and a millionaire with nowhere to go and nothing to buy. They add very little to the gameplay because the story underlying each quest is trivial (e.g. go find someone and talk to them to make sure they're ok) and you're so loaded with cash anyway.

12266178.review:
This game is... interesting. So interesting, in fact, that I would recomend playing the original game, skipping this title completely, and then playing Human Revolution. Anyway, if you care about my opinion, read on! Otherwise, I hope you have a nice day anyway.

As far as ambiance goes it is reminiscent of the original game. The dark and oppressive cityscape, the futuristic techno music, the neo-noir use of shadows and, of course, the color blue.

The one improvement this game has over it's predecesor is the ragdoll mechanic. Stuffing the limp bodies of victims into the ventillation grates is more entertaining than the story itself.

This, of course, leads into the story. I played this game for about five and a half hours. In that amount of time in the first game, I stopped numerous political terrorist plots, took out some nasty drug dealers, saved a girl from a pimp and many, many other things. I definitely felt like I was making a positive difference in the world.
In the first five hours of this game, I escaped from a bizarre super-soldier training prison that was under attack from generic religous terrorists and then wandered around for a while fighting mercenaries, killing random gang members, discovering that the terrorists were purposefully religously generic, cheated in some illeagel gambling, burglarized some rich dude's apartment, and wrecked a coffee shop. I felt like a roving psychopath.

In the first game, I felt torn between the urgency of completing the story missions and helping people by completing the side quests.
In this game I felt like there was something I was supposed to be doing, but I had no idea what that thing was or if it even mattered.

The first game eventually gives you a sense of moral ambiguity; over time you learn more and more about all the factions competing with each other and also that every side does varying amounts of honorable as well as evil actions. Aligning with a certain side doesn't make you feel any better than the other side, but you just feel like you need to go with the lesser evil in order to save humanity.
This game gives you an immediate feeling of moral ambivolence. You discover within the first hour that every faction you've encountered has a mixture of good and bad intentions which culminate in stupidity. There is no urgency. These people are just going to fight amongst each other for ambiguous reasons and they want to draw you into it. At that point I figured I'd just go and see if there was anything remotely interesting happening elsewhere. Cheat in some underground mutant lizard fighting betting? Why not. Get involved in a feud between rival coffee chains? Sure! It's more interesting than helping the Orwellian police force fight some self righteous murderers.

Last and perhaps least, we have the player character. In the first game, you get to be the badass JC. Do you think his baggy coat is unnecessary and it's ridiculous that he wears sunglasses at night? He could not care less about your opinion. If you order him to do something he thinks is questionable, he will not blindly follow your orders. He will do what he thinks is right, and he will go about it however he wants. Playing as him, you feel like an awesome futuristic warrior as you gradually upgrade his nanotech and acquire new and better equipment.
In this game, you are Alex. His/her character was not developed at all in the time that I played. All in all, (s)he pretty much just lets the different factions tell him/her what to do with very little (if any) question or objection. Truely, a compelling character. Playing as this wimp, you get a bunch of weapons and upgrades almost immediately and not much of anything to do with them.

This game is not technically good. It is not even that fun. As an experience, it's a mediocre spiral into the depths of a deranged world. The prequel is amazing, and the first game is a masterpiece. This sequel is ultimately disappointing. It is basically just one of the many Godfather 3's of the game industry.

This is all, of course, just my opinion and I sincerely thank you for reading it. I hope it was helpful. Have a nice day!

12262609.review:
The original Deus Ex (DE1) is my favorite game of all time … so I looked forward to its sequel (Deus Ex: Invisible War, DE2)

As each game of the series, you will move in an awesome cyberpunk environment, which is as complex and consistent as in the best SF books. Cyberpunk games are usually really interesting because they often deal with a lot of interesting concepts such as transhumanism, bioethics, economy and law.

### Pros:
- Fair story & good cyberpunk environment involving corporations, secret societies and charismatic characters
- Large number of side quests (you have to speak with most NPC to find them)
- Your choices will have major consequences on the subsequent missions, and there are several endings

### Cons:
The gameplay was oversimplified by contrast to the original game. That was the consequence of the parallel development for both PC and Xbox-1
- Tiny levels and long loading screen every 5 min
- Inventory management system was simplified
- AI can be improvable
In DE1, some guns had 3 different ammo types … and in DE2 all weapons use the same “universal” ammo … rofl !

### Conclusion:
DE2 is not a bad game, but it is not the worthy successor of DE1 ... that's why most people badly criticised it !

[b]PROS:[/b]
+ fun gameplay (multiple ways to clear a mission)
+ interesting story
+ hacking system
+ nice variety of weapons to choose
+ story continuations from Deux Ex
+ multiple endings

[b]CONS:[/b]
- weird UI
- simplified game mechanics and systems
- multiple endings in Deus Ex combined into one to continue story
- a bit ruins image of JC from first game

[b]Comment:[/b]
As the second game of the series it gets a lot of hate. And it is sort of justified as the game UI, mechanics and system got simplified/dumbed down. Later it was explained that this was due to consoles being the primary target and PC only a secondary port. Because of this it fails to capture that awesome essence the first Deus Ex had. However, this game is still enjoyable and even more if you actually played the first one because it continues the story. It does have a lot of flaws but it is undeniably a good game worth the money during a sale. So yeah, I do recommend it although expect a more "casual" approach.

Ya me habían comentado que la segunda parte de, quizás, uno de los mejores juegos hechos hasta ahora, era bastante decepcionante, pero seguramente porque ya llevaba esa idea a mi deus ex invisible war me ha gustado. 

El juego se desarrolla veinte años después del primer deus ex, tomando como partida el gran colapso producido por Jc Denton. Al final hay cuatro finales (cinco si contamos el "extra") que dependerán de la última decisión que tomes.

Al final me lo termine, pero porque era deus ex, sino quizás no hubiera tenido ese aguante.

Recomendable instalar la traducción de dlan y el mod de texturas hd, que aunque es todo visual, le da un toque más moderno.

11458744.review:
So as far as I can work out, for this sequel they figured "hey let's make it for a console," at which point they ripped the guts out of the game to simplify it for a console audience that couldn't type in numbers, logins, didn't want to read bunches of stuff, allocate skill points or have a working inventory and in fact mostly just wanted to shoot stuff in the face with minimal complications. Then they looked at the limitations imposed by that console and they made the areas claustrophobically small and mangled the game engine they were using so that the far too frequent load screens take an inordinately long time to load (and bounce you to the desktop while they're doing it just to add to their immersion breaking act). It becomes at some points not unusual to spend 15 seconds traversing an area hitting a loading screen, waiting, spending another 15 seconds moving across the next area, waiting...

So so far they've mangled the game contents, the interface, the world detail and the engine. Oh yeah and the weird designs of some areas make absolutely no sense whatsoever. Whatever could be left? The story? Surely that's got to be good, after all that's part of what made this series great, right? Well, no. Between the odd character animations (which weirdly make the characters look *less* natural than the first game) and the god awful factions all of whom appear to be filled with entirely awful people who elicit no sympathy whatsoever you are left either having to roll a dice and decide which of the awful factions to join in with or alternatively just running missions for whoever you feel like. None of it really makes a huge difference though as (as per the first) you are offered a nice clear cut choice to get each ending in the end. In terms of the actual storyline, with everyone so unlikable as you learn to hate them all you'll also realise just how thoroughly they have butchered the story of the first game by trying to include all three of the endings from that in the current timeline which is a mistake because it massively reduces the possibilities going forwards, and also completely trivialises the (actually interesting) choice the player had to make at the end of Deus Ex.

If you enjoyed Deus Ex, don't buy this game. Really. Truly. Just skip it. Read a synopsis or something if you need to know how the story goes.

11415321.review:
This game gets kind of a bad rap, and it's easy to see why. For one, it's a sequel to one of the most heavily lauded games ever made. That automatically put it in the position of trying to live up to a nigh-impossible standard. But the game isn't bad, it's just very average. That's it's biggest problem, really: It's an average game that's a sequel to an amazing one. (Well, that and the stupid cover with the guy holding a pistol sideways.)

Invisible War takes place about twenty years after Deus Ex. Events at the end of that game triggered something called "The Collapse", which basically crippled civilization and caused a wide variety of problems that people are still recovering from. In a way, the game implies that all three endings from DX1 sort-of happened: J.C. Denton attempted to merge with Helios but fails, which causes the global network to cease to function, which results in the downfall of national governments and the rise of "city-states". Some people have a problem with this, and while I'll certainly agree it could have been handled better, I'm not sure what people expected. Did they think that the developers would make three radically different settings depending on which ending you picked in the first game? 

You play as Alex D, a nanoaugmented student in the Tarsus Academy. Of course, things aren't what they seem, and just as in the original Deus Ex, you have to uncover a conspiracy and puzzle out what's really going on.

The game plays out much as the original; you go from city to city performing missions, although in this game you get to choose whether you want to work for the Order (a religious group that springs up after the Collapse) or the World Trade Organization (which has more or less become the new version of the U.N. in this game). Which you choose does affect how the missions play out. However, it ultimately has no bearing on the way the game ends, which is another problem people have with it. I don't want to spoil the plot by explaining this, but I will say that I agree that the ultimate reveal is kind of dumb and renders a lot of your choices meaningless.

Another story element that some people complain about is how several characters from the first game return, but have radically different points of view than in the first game. However, this complaint seems rather naive to me. First of all, it's been twenty years. People change a lot over that period of time. But more importantly, the characters in question were all directly involved in the events that triggered the Collapse. If your ideals led to a catastrophic event causing untold amounts of death and devastation, don't you think that might change your outlook?

Gameplay-wise, the game is very similar to the original, but there are a few changes that were made to simplify things that ultimately work to the detriment of the game. The biomod system is less interesting, the level areas are smaller in order to accomodate the X-Box's memory limitations, but the worst change (and the one you will hear EVERYONE who plays this game bitch about) is the ammunition system. In the original game (as in real life and in most FPSes), each weapon had its own ammunition, and in many cases a weapon had multiple ammo types you could choose between (for instance, shotguns had both buckshot and armor-piercing rounds). In this game, someone decided it would be a good idea to have every weapon use the same ammunition counter. The conceit is that the weapons are using nanomachines to build ammunition, and that your "ammo" is actually the raw material used to make bullets and whatnot. The biggest problem with this is that the amount of this material that you can carry is severely restricted, and heavy weapons take a huge amount of material to fire. If you, say, use a rocket launcher a few times, you may suddenly find yourself having no ammo for your pistol.

Like I said: Overall, it's not a terrible game; it's just not good, either.It's easy to see why, when they made a third game, they chose to make it a prequel. Even if this had been a great game, it's hard to see where the series could go from here. I think the only way we're ever going to get a Deus Ex game set after the first one is if they reboot the original first... which, depending on how it's done, could be pretty cool, actually.


 If you're a fan of the original Deus Ex, I would recommend playing through Invisible War at least once to see for yourself what's good and what's bad about it.

11180957.review:
La trama de este juego se desarrolla 20 años después (si no me equivoco) de los acontecimientos del primero, [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/6910/?snr=1_7_15__13][i]Deus Ex Game Of The Year Edition[/i][/url]. Me resultó muy curioso que los hechos de este juego partan de una mezcla de los tres finales posibles del anterior. Aunque no es completamente imprescindible haberlo jugado, lo recomiendo fuertemente.
De hecho, voy a escribir este análisis suponiendo que habéis jugado al primero (del cual también hice un [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/e_t_m/recommended/6910]análisis[/url]).

Hablando un poco de la [b]historia[/b], sigue un poco en la línea de [i]cargas filosóficas sobre hasta dónde nos puede llevar la ambición por evolucionar[/i]. Hay una lucha constante entre los que defienden la evolución mediante [u]biomodificaciones[/u] (habilidades introducidas en los humanos mediante nanotecnología que les permite realizar hazañas tales como dar saltos enormes o hacerse invisibles durante un tiempo) y los que argumentan que eso es una aberración contra la humanidad. Aunque no encontraremos solamente dos bandos.

En relación con el apartado anterior, tenemos la [b]toma de decisiones[/b]. Durante el transcurso del juego deberemos tomar decisiones que afectan en una medida [u]muy considerable[/u] los acontecimientos que ocurrirán después. También influirán sobre [i]de parte de qué bando estamos[/i],  y, por último, en el final que obtendremos (hay, si recuerdo bien, 4 finales distintos). Algo que [b]me gustó[/b] bastante es que [u]muchas decisiones no son definitivas[/u]. Es decir, que puedes ir favoreciendo a un bando y a otro alternativamente dependiendo de lo que más te convenza en cada momento (o sea, que, si, por ejemplo, la primera decisión que tomas apoya al bando [i]A[/i], eso no quiere decir que obtengas el final en el que [i]el bando A gana[/i]).

En cuanto a la [b]jugabilidad[/b], hay cambios importantes con respecto al primer juego. Dispones de un inventario en el que ocupa lo mismo un lanzacohetes que una barrita energética (aunque puedes [i]stackear[/i] unas 50 barritas energéticas sin ocupar espacio adicional). Las biomodificaciones que eliges pueden ser cambiadas durante el juego (a diferencia de la precuela, en la que, biomodificación que elegías, biomodificación que no podías quitarte). Un aspecto que me llamó la atención es que las armas no se recargan y todas usan el mismo tipo de munición (aunque no gasta lo mismo un disparo de escopeta que un disparo de pistola). También encuentras a menudo modificaciones para tus armas (silenciadores, munición explosiva, etc.).

Ahora he de comentar un [b]aspecto que he odiado durante todo el juego[/b]: [u]los mapas son completamente herméticos[/u]. Me explico. En cualquier otro juego encuentras puertas cerradas, escombros, vallas… Es decir: ambientación que te hace pensar [i]oh, no puedo pasar por aquí, pero esto me hace deducir inconscientemente que estoy en un espacio grande y el mapa continúa por allí[/i]. En este juego no. Está todo lleno de paredes, y todas las puertas que hay, se abren. Esto me dio una sensación horrible de claustrofobia, de estar todo el rato metido en una caja de zapatos. Por no haber, casi no hay ni ventanas que te enseñen [i]lo que hay fuera[/i].

Terminando, mencionaré [b]algún otro aspecto[/b]. Hay muchísimas misiones secundarias. Algunas armas tienen un disparo secundario. La inteligencia artificial no está mal. Hay unas físicas un poco raras (desde la calle, puedes tirar un cadáver hasta la cima de un edificio sin mayor esfuerzo). Aunque me parece un juego algo más lineal que el primero, también puedes elegir entre apañártelas para entrar por los conductos o irrumpir por la puerta principal. Además, para cambiar de escenario, a menudo tienes que contactar con un piloto, y existen dos opciones: hay una que te lleva gratis pero te deja un poco lejos de tu objetivo, y luego hay otro que te cobra pero que te deja en un lugar mejor. Luchas mayormente contra humanos (a veces biomodificados) y algunos [i]bots[/i] de seguridad, aunque alguna remota vez te encuentras a algún [i]animal poco amigable[/i]. Me llevó 11 horas de juego en la máxima dificultad (un poco corto, y eso que soy de los que inspeccionan mucho y dan un montón de vueltas), más luego un par de horas adicionales que emprendí para desbloquear todos los finales posibles. El juego no tiene traducción oficial; nivel de inglés requerido.

[b]En definitiva[/b], si te gustó el primero, probablemente te guste éste. Es más corto y, en general, a mí me gustó menos. Pero lo suficiente como para recomendarlo. Si no has jugado al primero, empieza por ahí y después considera comprar éste (yo, sin apenas conocer nada de ellos, me compré los dos un día que estaban al 75% de descuento).
