A mess. A paltry mess!

Invisible War could have been so much more. Why this game happened however, and why people thought it was a good idea, are the questions I pose. How could anything possibly follow Deus Ex? It is an utter impossibility for a game often tipped as game of the century. Furthermore, Deus Ex ends with 3 possible endings, and while Invisible War tries hard to tie these three endings together, it does not give the game full justice I feel as the plot feels incomplete. Characters from the first game are dragged back in for cameo roles, and this just feels redundant. Moreover to be questioned is which developer of the game decided to use generalised ammo throughout the game - I could garrote them for that move. I kid you not, I am unable to complete the game with ammunition without entering system files before playing and multiplying ammunition found in the world to 7 TIMES THEIR VALUE. Anything less, and I spend the last few levels of the game running around like a maniac because I have no ammunition at all, and the enemies later on require a lot to kill, and they drop so little ammunition! It just doesn't add up. The game also lacks the choice and diversity that Deus Ex so proudly boasted, and generally falls short in any respect I can think of.

It is understandable as to why so many die-hard Deus Ex fans do not count this game as being canon whatsoever.

10700274.review:
As a sequel to the original Deus Ex, Invisible War is weak, being inferior in most aspects. The levels are much smaller, the the levelling system is massively neutered (you can only upgrade augments, as opposed to additional skills) combat is weaker in many ways.

With that said however, Invisible War is actually a pretty good game when taken on its own merits. First off, the atmosphere is fantastic. Even though the worlds are way smaller than those of Deus Ex 1, Invisible war uses lighting, music, and visuals to great effect, resulting in a moody world that draws you in, despite being so far removed from anything in the real world. The art direction is really fantastic. Furthermore, the storyline is really interesting. It doesn't start out quite as compelling as the original, but it picks up quickly and has loads of great twists. There were lots of memorable characters, as is series tradition, and it's great to see what became of certain characters from the first game (although I didn't care for what they did with JC Denton). Also, the fact that this game essentially provides closure for the Deus Ex Universe makes it very much worth seeing the game through to the ending.

One really interesting thing this game does that the first game didn't (and I'd even say Invisible War might be slightly better in this regard) is that you can actually choose which faction to work for during each mission. Invisible War carries on the first game's tradition of having your choices make a massive impact on how the story plays out (I've heard that your choice of character gender actually has an effect on some of what side-missions are available, but I haven't done a second playthrough so I'm not sure what extent this alters things to), and being able to choose who you work for brings this to a whole new level, as it lets you experience the story from different perspectives, and what you do at certain points in the game actually does effect which endings are available (as opposed to in the first and third game, where you essentially choose your ending at the last minute). How you interact with characters is key and your relationships with the characters can affect the gameplay in numerous ways. The dialogue plays out more naturally than in the first game (I do miss how all the random NPCs seemingly had PHD's in philosophy in the first game, as it was cheesy, but also really interesting and part of the original's charm) and the story covers some interesting topics. Interestingly, this game goes into a lot of the same pro-augmentation vs anti-augmentation debates that characters in Human Revolution had (this topic was in Deus Ex 1 a bit, but not to the extent of this game and HR), so it does seem to have at least had some influence on future installments of the series. Overall, the storyline is definitely a strong point, and worthy of the Deus Ex name.

Now, about the gameplay. Yes, it isn't nearly as good as Deus Ex 1, but it's still better than many games. Whereas the original was an RPG played through the interface of a first person shooter, this game is more of a first-person shooter with light RPG elements. Overall the guns feel decent (although the pistol is pretty useless), but the melee attacks lack punch. You'll be progressing through a series of cramped, but surprisingly non-linear levels and are given the freedom to choose your objectives based on what faction you like. There are a surprising amount of side missions, and just like in the original game, you can opt to do a pacifist run. Your augmentations can let you do some crazy, almost game-breaking stuff (Bot Domination is particularly awesome. It lets you take control of enemy robots, and getting the jump on an enemy patrol who was hanging out with enemy robots is both awesome and hilarious), which can lead to some fun situations. Something that's interesting about how this game handles augments is that you can actually replace your augments with a different ones if you find yourself in a desperate situation where an augment you didn't choose would be helpful. This is a last-ditch strategy though, as the new augment starts out un-upgraded, so you'll usually have to carefully weigh your options. Unfortunately, the weight of this decision is lessened a great deal by the sheer abundance of upgrade cannisters in the game. By the time you finish, you'll probably have at least 10 or so extra cannisters laying around, meaning that if you swap augs for a situation, you can often easily swap back to what you had before and re-upgrade it to the maximum level. Swapping is still an interesting and useful mechanic, even though the abundance of upgrades hurts the design.

The inventory system is a bit awkward. You can only carry somewhat small amount of things, which makes sense from the standpoint that the developers want you to pick and choose a playstyle, but gets frustrating when you just want to pick up a medkit and all of your slots are full. Not too bad, but it does add up over time. Furthermore, there's a bug where sometimes more than one of the same item won't stack, which is especially frustrating for the lockpick multitools, as some doors need a certain amount (so if a door needs four tools, and you have two stacks of two, it won't open), which is incredibly frustrating. The interface of it is also a bit clunky, being clearly designed for a gamepad. It's not offensively bad, but moving an item to be equipped is a bit tedious, as you can't click and drag. Instead, you click the space for the item you want to move, and then click which slot you want it to go to.

The main flaw of the gameplay is the universal ammo system. Basically there's one type of ammo, and if you run out of it for one gun, you're out of luck for all of your guns. It's frustrating and you run out often, but there are some benefits. It does force you to use stealth in some places and it encourages an efficient style of play (always go for headshots if you can). It also leads to some tense situations (such as you versus 15 armored guys and some robots with little ammo) that force you to think way outside the box and come up with your own solutions to problems, and it was actually during these parts that the game felt the most like Deus Ex 1. Despite these interesting situations, Universal ammo is a pretty ham-handed way of of making these things happen, and the same effects could have been achieved in different ways with better design. For all the neat gameplay scenarios it causes, it also causes a noticeable amount of annoyance (although there's always some way out of your problem). 

The level design is solid (despite levels being really small) and it does encourage you to expore the environment. You still have multiple ways to do things and what you do has a fascinating imact on the story. The real problem with the levels is that they're split up into many separate maps, which means you'll be seeing loading screens a ton. This isn't too bad as today's computers can load things rather quickly, but for some reason the game minimizes to the desktop each time a map loads, and then goes back to normal once everything is up. This is jarring and does take you out of the game abit, so an actual loading screen would have been nice. The levels themseles are densly packed with detail, and there is a great variety to the environments you'll be in. Most levels have a nice kind of back and forth flow, almost reminiscent in some ways of the level design in an oldschool Doom game (in a good way). The game mostly takes place in interiors as opposed to the large outdoors environments of Deus Ex 1, but the levels aren't bad.

Overall, Invisible War falls short in many areas, especially compared to the original Deus Ex, but taken on its own it is a very interesting game that's definitely worth playing. There are a lot of unique ideas, and even though they don't all pan out, it mostly falls on the "good" side of things. Recommended.

10256537.review:
Invisible War is a decent fps rpg, when you consider how rare those actually are.  It unfortunately distills what made it's predecessor great down into mediocre banality.  Where computer skill would allow you to sift through people's personal emails in it's predecessor, learning important information, here you only need click on the computer with a hologram of a rotating letter above it - an insulting symptom of dumbing down of the core game mechanics into big signs that the dumbest of people can see, understand and use.  

In fact, gone are the experience points and skill leveling of the first game entirely.  Instead, the only leveling to be done is by biomod cannisters which add and improve abilities (strength, stealth, hacking, etc.) but is so uninteresting and rote in it's implementation that I wish it didn't even bother.  Any "skill" you choose to apply in excludes some others from consideration, but they max out at 3 cannisters each, leading you with a load of unusable biomod cannisters at the end of the game.  Unless you choose to experiment with another "skill" which you won't, because most of them kinda suck anyway.  

Weapon modification is worse, because you can only add 2 mods to any weapon and some weapons can't be modded at all, so again, you'll have plenty of weapon mods you can't use.  It's almost pathetically comical that characters give you biomods and weapon mods as rewards in the last several hours of game when you've already settled into the biomod "skills" and weaponry of choice and have modded them all out already.

The story is mostly a rehash with some of the same characters returning for what amounts to the same end game:  control of a technology for world domination, or freedom, depending on your point of view.  The character conversations are sometimes so insipid I just skipped through them, and most of the choices involve either a "yes" or "no" style answer which has no impact on the actual story, because at the end of the game the ending you get is determined, literally, by which button you decide to press. 

 I just played through it a second time, completely forgetting I had played through it previously, because the visual tone of the game is so bland, and the endings so bad.  It's 90% values of blue and gray.  Beginning of the game you're in a lab, then you're in a city, then you're in another city, and more labs, and another city, at some point you'll be in antartica and at another on Liberty Island (also looking like antartica).  The palate in this game is severely lacking.  And the 4 different endings are all kind of distasteful. 

This game also had performance issues on every system I've ever played it on, except the Xbox.  Certain areas would have profound, inexplicable slowdown.  I've had similar performance issues with Thief 3, which was developed by the same peeps using the same Unreal engine,...  my guess is they optimized the engine for the Xbox at the expense of the PC versions.  Still, it's worth a play.

10227273.review:
My personal favourite Deus Ex. It is a great underated gem. Did it level up to the hype? No to most. To me, i love the game despite its flaws. I can hear the fans yelling at me about that. 

I will give a basic opening to the story for you: "Deus Ex Invisible War is set 20 years after Deus Ex, and is about the actions of JC Denton in the first game, (using a combination of all three endings from the first game) and how they caused the world to go into a state of war and "economic depression". It is known as THE COLLAPSE. Many factions then became into power, including the WTO and THE ORDER. Chicago gets attacked at the beginning of the game, and that is where you, Alex D, and your friend Billie Adams and others get evacuated to another Tarsus place. That gets attacked too, and you begin by doing side quests and must choose which faction you want to go with. 

Let me start with my personal favourite things about this great piece of gaming:
- The graphics are great. Even by todays standards. It has aged well. (Made in 2004, it looks better than games released today)
- The characters are fine. Not amazing, but ok. 
- THE BIOMODS! The Biomods are great. They add special abilities to the player for a mild amount of time, such as Cloaking, Increased Walk/jump speed, Increased strength, just to name a  few. 
- The menu's. Something small, but i like them.
- The  weapons are simple and good, and there is several new weapons. 
- I always love craking something open or taking over something with my trusty Multitools. 
- Many more little tiny things. 

Now the bad. 
- The ai is basic, not bad but somewhat mediocre. 
- Some characters are bland, the order asian chick is my prime example. 
- the biomods are somewhat simpler to the first game. 
- Very minor technical hiccups. 
-  THE LOADING TIMES. THEY ARE BAD, THAT IS PROBABLY THE WORST PART ABOUT THIS. THEY ARE NOT INSANE, BUT THEY ARE BAD. 

IN CONCLUSION

I freakin' love this game. I look past it's supposed 'SHI*TYNESS'. Back at its release it recieved good reviews, but today everyone hates it. I love it, quite a bit, it's Well worth the price if you like RPG / FPS / Story driven obscure gems. 

Scarcey Out.

10227190.review: This game should be reported for false advertising. The war was clearly in plain view.

10194966.review:
I'm in for a series marathon, and playing each back-to-back seems like a good way to examine the evolution of the whole. I have to disagree with most of the negative feelings toward this title, because a "bad" connotation or "worst in the series" designation to a Deus Ex game still makes for a really great experience. Why? The vastly improved physics certainly don't hurt. That's fun in its own right. Most of the worst reviews I've ever seen lobbed at this sequel come from long-time fans of the original game, and if I had to choose my own least favorite difference between the two, honestly, it is the loss of the corner-leaning function that felt so good in the first; but to me, that is one of the few reductions where many other gameplay elements are definitely improved upon and streamlined. I know that can be a bad word in gaming. Streamlined can easily mean less. Here, it applies. 

One of the most common critiques I've heard, from professional critics and caring fans alike, has to do with Invisible War's level design. This seems hollow, I think, given the way this refers almost exclusively to size and wide-open feeling areas. In fact, the generally smaller levels of this sequel are far more efficient in their use of space -- something that seems to help it run better, actually, apart from some crashing which might be rooted in the series' early, unlucky business choices over bad drivers/graphics support for their engine -- you will quickly find so many tasks to complete that your head will be spinning, each with multiple choices, outcomes, and courses to get there. If you play many angles and think on your feet, trying to outwit what only ~seem~ like restraints on the surface, you will not only feel like an absolute bada$$ very early in the game, but be gratified at what you can do with some good creative planning. This is very much in keeping with the spirit of the Deus Ex name, the first mission areas alone having as many or more different paths to victory as any level in the original (if you only look hard enough), with all the cleverness and depth of story and world as every competent fan has come to expect. It doesn't always look or sound pretty, but in plenty of moments remains reasonably passable. Indeed, the beauty of this one, a learning experience in terms of its basic design aspects, are the ways in which your decisions invariably tie together in an emergent fashion. The greatest showcase of its true depth is probably best explained by pointing out how no two walkthroughs for it seem to contain all of the same information, each being subtly different and personal with an active community of explorers necessary to continually discover new things. You might find something new and unexpected, too. I feel like I do each time I play Invisible War, no different than the original, no less than any other standard of the series. 

Heck, to provide one non-spoiling testimony, even the most obscure details such as the names of coffee chains they included as a side-plot/metaphorical example to hint at the greater whole of this mystery, are remarkably witty little nods to our every day real life... though they seem almost laughably dumb if you don't know, I realize, that's exactly the point -- the whole story highlights how ignorance can be taken advantage of and manipulated from above, after all... Pequod and Queequeg were two principle characters in Melville's "MobyDick," and the name of the ship's first mate in that old, famous story just happened to be "Starbuck." See the connection? Did you ever realize? It takes digging, sometimes. This game, like the whole series, is overflowing with little details of that sort, the creators working well with whatever they had at hand, and is no less rooted in literature, history, or the greatest schools of philosophical thought than its counterparts. If you are an avid reader, especially of classics, this will be a fun game for you -- as would any Deus Ex game. It is a title that means your brain will be taxed, you'll go to bed either dreaming about your experiences or lying restlessly awake over its implications, and left saying, "wow," at every new twist. Yes, this one seems smaller, and yes, this might be the easiest of the series if you already have a grasp of how to play from the first, but there is a ton of detail within this title which can turn out to be just as rewarding as any other to carry that glorious logo. It's great. For my own part, today, feeling like a kid again, Invisible War was as equally amazing in its own day as the original had been, before.

9745049.review:
I really tried to like this game, but after numerous playthroughs, I just can't. Not only is the game - by far - not finished, it's almost completely broken. I mean, practically everything that made the first Deus Ex good has disappeared.

The large open levels from the first game were replaced with small, closed levels. A walk from one level-change door to the next takes less than a minute on all levels in the whole game! The only thing that prolongs them are conversations and enemies, of which you can either skip or run past. While load times has been reduced due to the advancement of computers overall, they were a real pain when DXIW was first released.

The story, and/or the world, has been transformed from the cyberpunk future of the previous game to some kind of anachronistic sci-fi future. Explanations are almost nonexistant. For instance, in 20 years since the Collapse (i.e. the end of the previous game), somehow, a weapons manufacturer managed to completely take over the global market AND develop universal ammo for all those weapons. Yet, airports do not exist or have been transformed to garbage dumps, people have stopped driving cars (or bicycles, or any other vehicle except helicopters). How was this possible?

The story isn't all that bad, but the smallness of the game makes it too big. There simply isn't room enough for exploration or any meaningful sidequests. The choices you make are also pointless, since loyalty is changed back and forth at the slightest wrongdoing, and, as another reviewer said, the missions you get are practically all "kill this person or let it live". 

The character you play, as well as the game's NPCs, are almost all irritating fools. The voice acting is ridiculous, and the only two characters I liked were JC Denton and Luminon Saman, them also being the only two characters in the game who have anything interesting to say. The player, Alex D., have been made into an idiot, because it seems that he/she accepts anything another character tells him/her. Now, I know this was due to saving space to crunsh it inside an old X-Box console, but at least let the player read a datacube (which can store documents and so on). Parallell this with JC Denton's skepticism in the first game.

Game mechanics are almost completely broken. Characters have to spin their whole body to face you straight on when they talk - even in a conversation between three people, and for EVERY new sentence. Something seems to be wrong with their eyes, because many NPCs look like they're on drugs. Combat is the only way forward. Want to sneak past an enemy or stun him in the back, like the previous game? Forget it. Get the "silent running" biomod if you want any sneaking, otherwise they will hear you miles away. Besides, where are you going to sneak about? The levels are too small for any kind of "Thiefing" around. Civilians become enemies without you ever touching them, even though they don't attack, but still. Why wasn't this refined for final release?

Skill points are gone, and so are the choices of augmentations. Now there are biomods, and they are everywhere. You can also swap biomods at any point in the game, so it's not like your choice really matters. Besides, about halfway through the game, you have to use rocket launchers, sniper rifles or energy weapons to get anywhere, or you won't stand a chance against the enemy.

Miss the techo-esque music from the first game? Too bad, it's now replaced with ambience. Some band, represented by NG Resonanse, also made it to the game, but they failed after like five songs (I think they were called "Three Faced" or some such). Now, I have no quarrel with ambience, or especially ambient game music (just listen to Fallout 1 & 2 soundtracks, for instance, or Mass Effect soundtracks). But imagine The Elder Scrolls soundtrack being replaced with, say, Viking rock or death metal, playing constantly? Not very moody.

So, is it all that bad? Well, the game is certainly playable. The graphics are pretty neat, but that can't be a "positive" aspect of the game, because games do evolve. New engines are developed. It comes "naturally" if you will. It's just like aging, it happens, people grow up, get jobs, whatever. Of course it will have better graphics. The funny thing is, would it be better if they had reused the Unreal 1 graphical engine? I think yes. It would certainly fit more content. It would be "ugly", but hey, Wasteland 1 is "ugly". Fallout 1 & 2 are "ugly". System Shock 2, the Thief series. That doesn't mean they are bad games.

In any case, get Deus Ex: Human Revolution instead. While it is a prequel, it is a good one in my opinion. Is Invisible War the worst game ever created? Of course not. But it certainly is not anything like the first game, or even close to the prequel.

Oh, wait, there is one good thing about this game - how to not make a sequel. Game developers should definitely try this game then, after playing the first one. The sad thing is that if they had just waited for a couple more years, just until X-Box 360, this game could probably have been better.

So; not recommended.

9672311.review:
Now, don't get me wrong, I would very much like to play this game.

I'm a huge fan of DE:HR, and the original Deus Ex was also fantastic. I picked up the Three-Bundle of Deus Ex games during a sale last winter, and after completing and fully enjoying DE:HR, I thought I'd move over to the the original Deus Ex: Game of the Year Edition. Needless to say, it was fantastic, and my enjoyment of the series increased further.

Then Deus Ex: Invisible War.

I'd heard reviews, from YouTubers mainly, but from non-IGN sites as well (gotta keep it reeeel). I wasn't expecting something great, but the opening cutscene was cool, and I was interested. Ready to play.

If I could play.

After the opening scene, and finishing my "character customization", I started the game, to which it decided to hang.

And then I lost control of my mouse. And my system started crashing.

After hours of frustration, I found that the most likely cause of my woes was the game attempting to use all CPUs on my PC. Luckily, I was well aware of how to change affinity, and this was not a hard fix.

But again, the game hung, and my mouse froze, effectively forcing me to force quit the entire game.

While DE2.exe can be changed, it is Ion Launcher.exe that destroys my ability to play. Considering I couldn't actually fix it from the Task Manager (no mouse control = no right click = no affinity change), I went to cmd.exe to try and use imagecfg to sort that shit out.

Well, apparently imagecfg doesn't exist on Windows 8.

This is not a negative review for DE2, this is a negative review for Windows 8's shitty self. However, unfortunately, this game was the first game of its kind to bring this kind of frustration forth. I'm going to uninstall DE2, and I'm gonna push it to the furthest corner of my library. Even when I transition over to Shell, or W7, or WXP, I'm not coming back to this game.

Multicore users BE WARNED.

9486955.review: Deus Ex:  Invisible War is just as full of conspiracy, and interesting real world parallels as part one.  I have heard and seen mamy people complain that you ar not as free as you were in the first Deus Ex, but I did not notice this.  I find Invisible War to be a more refined experience.  You still get to hack, mod yourself, and choose if you want to be stealthy, melee, hack or whatever.  It's still a multiple ending affair.  This game is a sequal to the first game story wise, and you will run into people and items from the first game, but you do not need to have played part one to understand the story or gameplay of this game.   I love Deus Ex, and Dues Ex: Invisible War both.

9365919.review:
Deus Ex 2: Invisible War was Ion Storm Austin's first console game and a game that would later be described as having a "troubled development" by its creators. Many fans of the original game were quick to slam this game on release for being a "dumbed down" mess built for the console gamers.

Like its predecessor, Deus Ex 2 is a First-Person Shooter / Role-Playing Game with stealth elements. Set twenty years after the events of Deus Ex, you play the role of Alex D, a student at Tarsus Academy. After being rescued from a terrorist attack that destroyed the entire city of Chicago, you are woken in your room by an assault on the Tarsus Academy facility in which you live. From there, the plot thickens as you are thrown into a world of corporate, government and ancient global conspiracies.

Writing a sequel for Deus Ex would always be a difficult task because the first Deus Ex has multiple endings depending on how the player wanted to complete the game. All the endings were radically different and so, for Deus Ex 2, they chose to set the game around a mixture of two of Deus Ex's endings, which might not make logical sense given the nature of those two particular endings which I won't spoil here.

Just like the previous Deus Ex, from start to finish, you have multiple ways to deal with any given situation and depending on what you do, the game will adapt accordingly. People will react to how you behave and can affect the course of the game and the only way you can Game Over is if you die.

The game even offers a bit more flexibility with regards to factions over the previous game. Deus Ex had a few moments where some characters, even though they might have been killable later in the story, would be essentially invincible until their moment of demise arrives. Some might argue that this was necessary to keep the plot going but in Deus Ex 2, everyone is killable as soon as you meet them and the game can adapt with no problems. This is one of the moments in which Deus Ex 2 has an advantage over its predecessor, albeit a very small one.

The story is also very good. It is not as paranoid or as quirky as the first Deus Ex and in some places, especially at the beginning, it feels slightly rushed and not enough things feel very well explained. All becomes clear in time however and putting the pieces together is just as good as it ever was.

The game also has a very sci-fi feel to it. The art and sound design, devices you use and the omnipresent blue lighting all make the game feel as if its set further into the future than it probably intended to feel.

Being made for the Xbox as well as PC, Deus Ex 2 has a few differences in terms of its inventory and its level design. Gone is the intricate inventory management of the first game. Instead, it was been replaced with six simple slots. Each slot can store one object or a group of objects stacked which means that three packets of Soy food take up exactly the same amount of space in your inventory as a Rocket Launcher. Some items such as energy cells and multi-tools also have a problem stacking correctly and there is no way to stack them manually.

The level design also has undergone a huge change. Whilst the levels in the first Deus Ex were large but void of much detail, the levels in Deus Ex 2, whilst having dynamic lighting and were nicely detailed for a 2003 game, are extremely small in size. The modified Unreal engine they used for the game is butchered beyond belief. You will find yourself bumping into loading zones around every fifth corner. This probably has something to do with the game designed for the Xbox and its measly 64MB of RAM.

The skill system that was present in the first game has been completely removed and the augmentation system has been replaced with a more streamlined system where you can choose one of three potential upgrades for specific areas of the body. You can upgrade the ability three times or, if you no longer want that particular ability, replace it with another of your choosing, though you'll have to find the Biomod canisters to start and advance your newly chosen skill.

And then there's the Universal Ammo system which is, depending in your point of view, the worst or an interesting aspect of the game. All the guns in the game use the same kind of ammunition simply known as Universal Ammo. Different guns use up a different amount of universal ammo per shot so, for example, the pistol will use a small amount of universal ammo whereas the sniper rifle will use up a bigger amount. Weapons can be modified to use less ammo, destroy glass without setting off alarms attached to them and more.

For all its small faults and bugs, Deus Ex 2 is a well made game and is head and shoulders above what was on store shelves around the time of its release. It's not a bad game and as long as you go into it not expecting it to be exactly like the first Deus Ex, you'll have a lot of fun with this game.

9325237.review:
The second part of the franchise came to us through the same creative team that developed the first part. With a limited development due to its console version and more directed towards the action, we have a pretty solid game that keeps most gameplay elements introduced in its predecessor.

PROS :

- Continues and closes the storyline of the first part (Characters, organizations and elements of the story previously established in the first part, make their appearance here, either explicitly or through a mention).
- Possibility to choose between a male or female protagonist with different options on their physical appearance.
- Like the first part, what begins as a simple story unfolds in a story full of twists and complexities.
- Like its predecessor, depending on the choices you make, you can change the style of the narrative or the relationship of certain NPC's toward the protagonist.
- Is set on a Semi-Open World structure [i]ala[/i] Wolfenstein (2009) for its narrative.
- The exploration remains key for obtaining items, ammunition, rewards, etc.
- Implementation of Havok Physics to move obstacles, hide corpses, attack, etc.
- Multiple primary and secondary objectives to meet (Some of them create conflicts between them, as the fulfillment of a goal to a specific faction can affect another one and their relationship towards the protagonist).
- Like the first part, there are multiple ways to meet the goals, reach a destination, get an item, etc.
- Augmentations obtained and improved can be replaced by others once installed.
- Integration of an ability to climb certain surfaces becomes quite useful.
- Being a game more focused on the action than the first part, the combat is much more polished than its predecessor (Though the element of stealth is still present).
- Most of the ranged weapons have a secondary fire mode.
- Very good textures and lighting effects for its time (Thanks to Unreal Engine 2).

CONS :

- The protagonist, whatever male or female, does not have enough charisma.
- Most NPC's share the same face.
- Many elements are simplified when compared to its predecessor (No experience points for improve character skills, all guns share the same ammunition, many fewer weapons, the tool for hacking and lockpicking is the same one, etc.).
- Improvements of the characters are limited exclusively to augmentations (As long as you have the item that allows you to install or upgrade these).
- Each weapon only accept two modifications (From a total of eight options).
- Control over jumps is sometimes a bit disastrous.
- Many times, the use of physics in certain situations, is erratic and not let the situation settle directly or at the first attempt (Which can be a bit frustrating ).
- The Quick-Load is not so "Quick".
- The campaign lasts half the first Deus Ex (We are talking about a campaign of approximately 30 hours, although this is much more than the average for today's games).
- An annoying Black-Screen bug present in the final length of the game when you load a Savegame (Which can be corrected going to the Task-Manager and placing a single core in the affinity of the application).

Deus Ex: Invisible War is a solid game with a great story, more focused on the action that the first part and simplifying the elements that were in this.

[b]My Score: 7.8/10[/b]

Note : Played it on Windows XP - SP3

[h1]Action[/h1]

"A game people either love or hate" - well, I think they love and hate it for all the right reasons. Brainless, heartless, but not gutless - it's pretty much a straight SciFi-FPS with a DX story, fun to play if you skip all the boring, badly acted conversations (if it weren't for those looong level loading times!).

9211550.review:
I have no idea how this game has a metascore of 80. It was a 67 at best when it was brand new; it's aged badly since then. It suffers badly from having been designed for the memory and control constraints of the original X-Box. The levels are cramped and ugly. The field of view is far too tight (and requires using a hex editor to manually edit memory values in the executable to change to something tolerable). The guns are forgettable (with the exception of the gun mod that makes glass windows dissolve instead of shatter, that was mildly amusing) and all draw from the same universal ammo pool. Worst of all the main story is plain old tripe that not only does not hold up well to scrutiny but which commits the sin of trivializing the first game's ending by declaring that all three mutually exclusive endings in Deus Ex 1 happened simultaneously. By watering down and blending three very distinct and different endings they weakened and cheapened the story space for both Deus Ex 1 and Deus Ex: Invisible War.

The three main factions in the game, the Templars (hypocrtical neo-Luddities in power armor), the Illuminati (representing capitalist concerns), and the Dentons (who are trying to properly finish the Helios ending from Deus Ex 1) are all easy to hate. By the middle of the game I was annoyed with all of them. By the end, I decided to actively sabotage everyone, giving me the Omar Trader ending where the world burns in an apocolypse and Russian cyborgs end up ruling the cinders. I was actually happy with that, since the "good" endings required working with characters I had come to despise.

On the up side, the game does have a somewhat interesting side story about a corporate war between two coffee chains. This was in no way a worthy sequel to Deus Ex 1, and would have been a better game if it'd been divorced entirely from that intellectual property.

9154786.review:
Video game sequels are pretty serious business. Although the sequel has become popular in nearly all forms of media, gaming is clearly one arena where its reigned supreme. In 2013, only 6 of the top 100 best selling games were entirely original works. Even critics in 2013 showed a preference towards established properties with only five original games scoring over 90 on MetaCritic. As such, there’s a great deal of pressure on developers to match, if not exceed, their previous work, and when a game’s considered a masterpiece, the expectations are magnified even further.

As such, it’s no wonder that a game like Deus Ex: Invisible War has been so reviled by fans of the initial game, and many of the complaints are difficult to refute. Deus Ex has become one of my personal favorite games, and after having spent some time with War, I must concur with the majority that the first installment is a more complex and smarter game with vastly greater possibilities, but that’s not to say that this sequel has no charms or is inferior to most.

The most marked change to the game’s core play is the removal of the skills system, which had allowed gamers to customize their play style in drastic ways, giving the cyberpunk shooter a distinct RPG flavor. Invisible War still contains RPG elements, primarily in the dialogue options and in the inclusion of Biomod super powers, but even these seem less malleable than before. Thus it plays in a much more straightforward way. There usually are still several ways to get through an area, but there are fewer times in which creativity is profitable.

Level design philosophy has also shifted in major ways. The areas the player explores are significantly smaller and more straightforward, which results in a much greater amount of loading screens. This design choice was obviously made to make the console porting process smooth, but for what it’s worth, they cram an awful lot into these areas. In the first game, the areas may have been large, but some of them were mostly empty. The reverse is true in Invisible War with almost none of the filler, inaccessible background areas that plagued the cities we explored in Deus Ex.

Whether this is a welcome change or not could be debated, because it does make it easier to find relevant destinations and exploration was a major draw of the first game, but were this an entirely new game, I would likely think nothing of this decision, and the same could be said for many of the games ‘flaws.’ Take the oft-criticized universal ammo approach. While the ammo can be used in any weapon, each weapon uses a different amount of ammo. I found myself favoring the sniper rifle for it’s accuracy and power, but this came at the cost of conservation, especially later in the game. Though most of the enemies drop ammunition, their clips do not cover the cost of a sniper shot, adding a strategic element that was lacking in the first game with its plentiful resources. Along with this the player has a smaller inventory, making management essential, serving as a stark counter to the comically large selection of weapons a player could carry in the first.

Besides these controversial elements, the game is a major improvement in several areas. Even on release, Deus Ex was criticized for its bland art design and blocky textures, and the years have not done it a favor. Some of this blandness may have been to emphasize the destitute state of the poor, but that could also be a convenient excuse. Invisible War, however, has a vibrancy to it and is fairly detailed in spite of its age of over a decade. The difference in graphics becomes especially noticeable when comparing objects that appear in both games, such as the repair bot, which sports greater detail here but is instantly recognizable. The backgrounds are also better, effectively nailing the dystopian future.

It’s the storytelling where the game really excels over its predecessor, though. The first game had plenty of interesting political and philosophical ideas, but since it was a longer game, the plot could get rather convoluted. It also featured rather poor dialogue and voice acting, although it could be humorous at times and sometimes even intentionally so. Though this game lacks some of those campy bits of fun, the writing feels a lot more professional and the story is concise enough that every section feels important, and it does this without losing the core debate between utility and freedom that was waged in the first game. The voice acting also has been given a boost. A few of the foreign accents are just as bad as in the first game, but the principle cast has been improved with a few small cameos from the first game thrown in for good measure.

Along with these upgrades, the approach towards female characters is also laudable, particularly for its time. The first Deus Ex was smart, but it was a game dominated by men with most of the female characters playing in menial, background roles such as secretaries and receptions or in less flattering positions like hostage and muggee. Here, there seems to have been a very conscious decision to level the playing field. Besides letting you choose the protagonist Alex D’s race and gender, there are plenty of female enemies, and the majority of the figures that you encounter through the game from the pop star NG Resonance to your teacher Dr. Nassif to your classmates Billie and Klara to a potential pilot are women, and all of these figures are powerful in some ways or other. Although this sort of thing is much more common these days, it wasn’t the case in 2003, and I would bet that the game’s clear feminism has not received its due praise.

Whether Deus Ex Invisible War is a good sequel is hard to say. It loses some of the things that made the first game such a joy to play and doesn’t necessarily subtract for the sake of its strengths. When looking at the sequel to such a popular game, though, the more pertinent question might be whether it is simply a good game or not, and to that the answer is a definite yes. It may streamline much of what made its predecessor good to such an extent that it becomes barely recognizable, but after all, when it comes to a sequel, who really needs or wants a carbon copy? Invisible War makes a number of bold changes that don’t always pay off, but it’s a must play for fans of Action RPGs and 1st Person Shooters.

8821289.review:
I recommend this game, with a catch. If you absolutely loved the story of Deus Ex, then this game is a must play, but not until half-way through when it really starts getting good. 
That Deus Ex: Invisible War is an inferior sequel has been stated by many people before me. The interface has been streamlined to the point of ridiculousness. My favorite part of Deus Ex was that you actually felt like a hacker. The keypads and terminals had an interface where you actually typed in the numbers and logons. You felt cool. This one does it automatically.
The game is much shorter, which normally would be a knock, but considering the circumstances under which I played it, it was it's greatest asset.
Let me explain. I never played it in 2003, but today, it is absolutely broken. The areas are small, which often force you onto the loading screen. The loading screen is a nightmare. I looked up every fix available, but none of them worked. Let me explain the situation (this will sound crazy, and unless you really care about the story, like I did, you will probably quit playing). The game freezes on every loading screen, without fail. Every loading screen, you must ctrl alt del and end the non responsive program. After about 1 minute or 2, the game pops up again without being prompted and will load normally. The areas are cramped, so there are a lot of loading screens, and every time you die, it goes back to the title screen, so you have to do this process again. Because I was so invested in the goings on, I developed a system. Every time the game loads, I would do homework until it popped up again. When the difficulty ramped up near the end, I edited the .ini file to make me invincible. Now, don't get me wrong, I'm hardcore. I can beat most games without cheats. I did it for my sanity.
Another problem with this system is that it doesn't track my playtime on Steam. The game is about 10 hours long, but Steam only shows me as having played an hour. That time is only the amount of time I waited for the game to load before I figured out how to play it.
So, the gameplay is weaker, the interface is terrible, and it's broken beyond belief. Why do I recommend it, then? Because, especially near the end, the story is fascinating and a great continuation of the plot of Deus Ex. I put up with the madness because I could not wait for what happened next. 
So, if you are fully immersed in the universe and are able to put up with everything else, I recommend this game. If you're not okay with anything I described, it's probably not worth it.

8619212.review:
Coffins used to be built with holes in them, attached to six feet of copper tubing and a bell. The tubing would allow air for victims buried under the mistaken impression they were dead. In a certain small town Harold, the local gravedigger, upon hearing a bell one night, went to go see if it was children pretending to be spirits. Sometimes it was also the wind. This time, it wasn't either. A voice from below begged and pleaded to be unburied.

"Are you Sarah O'Bannon?" Harold asked.

"Yes!" The muffled voice asserted.

"You were born on September 17, 1827?"

"Yes!"

"The gravestone here says you died on February 20, 1857."

"No, I'm alive, it was a mistake! Dig me up, set me free!"

"Sorry about this, ma'am," Harold said, stepping on the bell to silence it and plugging up the copper tube with dirt. "But this is August. Whatever you are down there, you sure as hell ain't alive no more, and you ain't comin' up."

8375869.review:
Deus Ex: Invisible War is the sequel to Deus Ex, an RPG/shooter hybrid which garnered so much universal praise that you might say its sequel was always destined to be a disappointment. Its followup, released in 2003, received generally positive reviews from publications, although the general consensus was "It falls short of the original." However, the fans overwhelmingly hated it, even refusing to think of it as a true Deus Ex game. Was it a case of inflated expectations or overzealous fanboys?
In my opinion, Invisible War is not as bad as its reputation, but the fans still have a point.

The first problem is it was designed from day one as a console title with mass appeal and simplification in mind. The skills system is gone, every item occupies one space in the inventory and all weapons accept a universal ammo type. That's a big problem because in the final levels, most enemies can be defeated only with heavy weapons, which drain ammo fast, and when you're out, you can't even switch to a standby. Oh, and did I mention there's no way to non-lethally pacify one particular enemy? The weapon mods are no longer a modular increase of stats, but singular installations that have a strategic use like breaking glass silently or dealing EMP damage. The boltcaster replaces the old crossbow, the stun prod makes a return and the baton is also non-lethal and several grenade types are also added to aid the player. The fairly rare noisemaker draws enemies wherever it lands and the flashbomb (you guessed it) blinds enemies for a few seconds. In addition, the gas grenade returns and the LAM (in the form of concussion grenades), the scrambler and the spiderbomb grenade, which spawns an allied spiderbot.

The levels are much smaller compared to the first game, almost claustrophobic and unsettlingly empty, yet they're even more confusing to navigate. Different areas are broken up by frequent, lengthy loading screens that not-so-subtly re-launch the application, which of course breaks the immersion like Hell. Just getting around can also be a pain because of the physics. For example, jumping on a create is a feat in patience and luck because although the physics are mostly sound, the weight of objects is severely flawed; The slightest bump sends even the massive, unliftable crates flying across the room like they were made of styrofoam.

The graphics still... technically hold up today. Being designed for the XBox, the engine utilizes dynamic light and shadow, bloom, ambient occlusion, facial animation and more, but aesthetically it's a different story. The world feels very "Jetsons-ish" for lack of a better word, everything covered in neon blue lights. The NPCs have been upgraded from a graphical standpoint, but still stand and animate like the first game, and some of the facial animation is just... Well, some NPCs look like they're perpetually surprised. Installing the unified texture pack massively improves the visual appeal, adding HD textures to almost everything and even toning down the cosmic horror of the facial animations.

The AI is still dim and will ignore you even in plain sight if you're about 20 feet away. You can pick away at them from behind cover and they may never confront you, watch their friends get blown up in their face and still wander aimlessly and when you're cloaked, they continue walking right into you without attacking. But they can still provide a challenge in numbers, especially the biohazard-spewing greasels and big, dumb, lumbering karkians. On several occasions, my maxed-out see-through-walls aug didn't detect them (yet another flaw) and I waltzed right up to one, getting the **** scared out of me.

The voice acting is, well... The major characters sound alright, but some of the NPCs just sound awful. Some of the sounds (especially the weapons) can be grating, but others are... kind of nice? The music is appropriately futuristic and retains the aesthetic from the first game, but is much less noticable and eargasmic, less memorable themes than ambient background music to put on before bed. That seems to be the way of this game: a mixed bag; some of it a ham sandwich, some of it stale vomit.

The story is the best thing about this game. Despite all its flaws, that's what kept me interested enough to keep pressing on. Without spoiling anything, you'll get wrapped up in many conspiracies (Even the coffee shops are part of one!) and be forced to take sides, which you can still switch even at the final moment of the game. That sounds like freedom, but then you realize that none of the choices you make effect the outcome of the game, beyond the last level or two and a pre-rendered end cutscene. But still, sociopolitics, government, privacy, ethics, enterprise, technology, religion, god itself ...politics, bureaucracy, mismanagement... are all discussed at some point. Two factions have a clear motivation, although others (which aren't revealed until late in the game) really don't give you a reason to carry out their bidding. Invisible War also connects with the original game through returning characters, and is set in a world still reeling from the effects of "The Collapse", a combination of two endgame choices the player could have made. Your role takes you through Seattle, Cairo, Trier, Antarctica, good old Liberty Island and of course, several secret bases in between, unraveling a web of deceit over which the player has the final choice. Invisible War expects the player to have finished the first game, but if you read books, listen to newscasts and talk with NPCs, it's enough to fill you in.

But Deus Ex was all about freedom-of-choice for the player, so does that still hold true? For the most part. You can play through most of the game without killing anyone (unless you side with the wrong faction) and incapacitate enemies from the shadows, or gun down everything in sight, multitool a locked door or coax a code out of NPCs. There are plenty of hacking opportunities and alternate entrances as well. The only thing I hate is being forced to do side missions for extra credits before I can travel to the next level, so take my advice: rescue Ava Johnson in Seattle; she flies you around for free! There are enough side missions to extend the game by a few hours and plenty of rewards for the explorer, such as supplies, weapon mods and rare secret weapons. You can also read plenty of datacubes and books, listen to the news terminals and talk to countless NPCs to learn more about the world you're in. But even if you complete every side mission, explore every area and talk to everyone, it's a pretty short game.

As for the technical flaws I played through the game until one of the final levels, saved and quit and when I returned, my saves were corrupted. But even though I rushed through the second time, I still felt intrigued to learn more about the story. The game crashed regularly and unpredictably as well, every 30 minutes the first playthrough and only twice the second time. And the second time was with mods!

So, is this the worst game ever? Far from it; but it is held back by design flaws and cursed by a poor PC port. Deus Ex had flaws too, but they were easily overlooked. With Invisible War, it's much harder. But does it deserve the "Deus Ex" name? In my opinion, yes. The story follows that familiar thread, full of conspiracies and philosophy and despite a shift toward FPS gameplay, it still manages to create that feeling of being an augmented agent, sneaking, hacking, fighting and completing the game in your own style.

It's true what they say: This is the worst sequel I've ever played, not fit to hold a candle to the original. Doesn't add to the plot at all either, as the other games were set before this one.
Let's start with the Protagonist (I can't say "Player character" because there is absolutely no trace of character to be found in Alex D.) Nothing but a dull monotone voice and a refusal to commit to anything. "I'll think about it" is a catchphrase which Alex often repeats, but sadly this thought never leads to any resolution. Alex never truly expresses an opinion about anything, or takes a stand for any of the rival factions on offer.
After the numbness of the main lead. the bland voice acting is another point where nobody seems willing to stand out. It's like a scene out of Equilibrium where everybody is terrified of showing some emotion, even when trying to convert you to a religion.
The many factions set against each other are equally apathetic. If you decide to gun their agents down for no reason and steal their stuff, or even to trash an entire building of theirs, they'll forgive you if you run a small fetch quest for them, and if you decide to slaughter them all again, they won't hold a grudge.
All of this combines to stifle any RPG aspects of the game. There's no role to play, and even if there were, there are no real choices by which to express that role.

4619695.review:
As Deus Ex proved itself be one of the most immersive stealth/shooter/RPG's ever developed, any sequel would certainly be hard-pushed to be its equal. Sadly, DX: Invisible War received mostly mixed and somewhat negative reviews on this issue. At first, like most, I felt a little disappointed by the end of my first playthrough. For a game developed four years after the original, I expected some new, exciting ground to be explored and ideas for  improvement on the original. 

Many fans took an instant dislike to DX:IW for one, some, or all the following reasons: 1. The graphics weren't much of an improvement (and perhaps worse) than the original, 2. The maps seemed claustrophobic and clunky when compared to fantastic spacious environments featured in the original DX, 3. Combat wasn't much better (again, perhaps worse), 4. Voice dialogue for the most part fell flat, boring, without emotion and lacked credibility, equally less memorable as the characters themselves, 5.That the gameplay had been too simplified and lacked ambition, ie: loss of ammo variation, skills system dropped, no XP points, absence of lockpicks, etc, 6. That while Alex D could take on secondary missions, they turned out to be nothing more than minor distractions far too easily accomplished (amongst many things that DX: HR had got right), 7. That the game itself was too short - it could be completed in about 10 hours first playthrough, while completion of its predecessor perhaps required four times as long!

But then something pulled me back to play it again, even a third time....Certainly, if you can see past the shortcomings listed above, then you might be able to enjoy IW's more positive aspects. For example, I considered IW's weapon mods to be far more interesting than the ones in DX. I also enjoyed a couple of innovative ideas: spider-bot bombs were tremendous fun, while the health leech and bot-domination were fantastic ideas included in augmentation. Also, Alex doesn't share JC Denton's frustrating inability to climb over waist-high crates! 

As the world has moved 20 years on from DX, so too has nano-augmentation: the cybernetically enhanced Omar deal in black market goods, while nanite detonaters and harmful nanite clouds lend IW an intriguing backdrop to the conspiratorial story. The Greys make a return and this time around given a more sentient role in IW's affairs.  

Holograms also make a welcome return - although these are far more complex than the mere communication types featured in DX: such AI constucts styled in the image and voice of a fictitious pop star of this future, NG Resonance, are able to interact with people, even licensed to offer rewards for solving crimes (since as a precaution such holograms are connected to police databases)...not to mention report on everything said by someone suspicious. Another nice little idea. 

The game music - while not quite as memorable as DX's - helped enhance the atmosphere of each mission. There were some great angles on the story itself: one particular mission meant a return to some place from DX (I don't want to spoil it for those yet to play IW!) as if everything had come full circle. It was quite a satisfying, if somewhat poignant moment. 

Project Leader Harvey Smith was given the chance to explain why events turned sour: DX:IW suffered a rushed development shipped with both good and bad ideas due to fan feedback mismanagement, there was little teamwork chemistry within the studio, and the need to cater for a console version confused matters even further. Not in the least he was going through a divorce. Later that same year, another big project by Ion Storm  was completed in the form of Thief: Deadly Shadows - and really that's what demanded DX director Warren Spector's attention. In hindsight, Invisible War should have been developed with a full studio complement in the same pioneering spirit as the original DX. Even if this meant waiting a couple of years for an improved engine to come along, the planning of more in-depth characters with credible dialogue, gameplay design and sharper mechanics, intriguing secondary missions, and complex map levels. Perhaps, one day, there will be a 'remake' of Deus Ex: Invisible War...?

One last note: if you have played Deus Ex, then be prepared that Inivisible War is a somewhat different beast to its predecessor. And please let me know whether you agree, disagree, or have something you'd like to add!

1200821.review:
A good game but a disappointing sequel.  DXIW has a good deal going for it - unique weapons, cooler weapon mods, expanded and easier-to-use augmentations - but really pales in comparison to the original Deus Ex.  It's a lot of little things which I could list in great detail - mediocre plot, painfully simple weapon system, endings that feel more like "choose the least crappy one" than "choose the one you like" - that just make DXIW see like a step backward, not forward.  If you were expecting the worthy successor to Deus Ex you will be very disappointed indeed.

Now that said, this isn't a bad game.  If you evaluate it on its own, without the first Deus Ex as part of the equation, it's actually a neat game.  It's certainly entertaining and somewhat compelling, just not nearly as much as the first.  But because so much of the game has to do with its predecessor the comparisons are inevitable.  It's unfortunate, but there you go.

Bottom line, it's worth a play.  Just don't go in expecting to be blown away like you were by Deus Ex, and brace yourself for a fair bit of "seriously wtf" when it comes to dealing with characters from the previous game, especially in the endgame.

124936.review:
If You think about playing DX:IW there is a good chance that You came across its older brother, DX.
Either You hated it because at first glance the options were overwhelming, playing it like a shooter was hard and frustrating or loved it for its complexity, the richness of the world, the great storytelling.

Either way, there are good news and bad news for You.
I was one of those who disliked DX:IW when it came out. This was the time of a new console generationt and these swallowed a large proportion of the gaming community - and this was one of the first games the developers clearly created with console gamers in mind.
This meant that the user interface was oversimplified and blocked half of the view, that the game was not properly optimized for PC, that the creators had to settle for smaller level size or decreased game complexity.
All the above meant that in the eyes of most PC gamers DX:IW was an unbecoming second installation to its truly amazing predecessor.

I played it through then halfheartedly, and then again and again with more and more enthusiasm. Now, 10 years later I will summarize my opinion as I see this game today, sometimes in comparison with DX.
First our old grievances:
- 10 years passed, so the lack of optimization is not an issue anymore,
- there are community packs to make it look bettter, looks good for its age,
- smaller levels meant more loading (game settings were broken up into smaller levels) but with today's PCs this only takes a moment - also not a problem anymore,
- hud can be customized via mods.

Bad that did not change (a matter of taste, for You all these can be aadvantagious):
- still oversimplified: awkward inventory management, less augmentations, no skill system, universal ammo is stupid, less background info through holomail or newspapers, etc,
- male protagonist looks and sounds like a member of a boy band,
- stealth gaming style does not always work
- no-kill approach does not work (in DX it was only one person You really had to kill to advance in the story)

Good that will remain good til the end of times (some of these I have learnt to appreciate only on my subsequent walkthroughs):
- somehow the writer(s) managed to incorporate all three DX game endings into the sequel, so whichever ending You are familiar with, You will easily find Your bearings and understand the premise,
- sidequests are fun and inspired,
- new augs (though fewer) are fun to use,
- similarly the new weapon mods are useful and fun,
- great level design means that most of the time You still can choose between covert or guns-blazing approach,
- one of the best intros of its time,
- great NPC additions like the OMAR or NG Resonance,
- amazing places to visit like Antarctica, Trier or Cairo (including an arcology building which looks good and feels right)

All in all in my eyes funnily enough with age the game got better. It might feel disappointing after playing DX (or liberating, if You like less complexity), but a great game on its own right. Where DX gets A+++, DX:IW is worth an A- easily.

Recommended.

944234.review:
You want the [url=https://www.ttlg.com/forums/showthread.php?t=147423]Visible Upgrade Patch[/url].

[i]“We plan to give people a sense of freedom and a prosperous world. In practical, historical terms, that’s about as good as it gets.”[/i]

There’s really nothing all that cool about cyberpunk visions of the future. They are dystopian nightmares of relentless technological progress at the expense of the human condition and the accumulation of vast wealth by a small, unaccountable few as billions live in squalor. It’s hell, and we can say that with even greater confidence than the genre’s pioneers: we’re living it [i]now[/i].

The continued fascination with the genre is largely aesthetic, I guess; CDPR literally just made a game around the very [i]idea[/i] of the genre, drawing on the visual palettes of defining cyberpunk hallmarks throughout film and literature. But lighting the path to hell in attractive neon pinks and blues doesn’t make it any less shitty, and it’s time writers and creators started envisioning new futures instead of replicating old ones that have already transitioned into our dire present.

Besides, gaming’s own cyberpunk masterpiece was released in 2000. A paranoid melting pot of conspiracy theories, Ion Storm’s [i]Deus Ex[/i] understood the dystopian roots of the cyberpunk genre, telling a story of institutions, government and otherwise, that failed to fulfil their basic pledges to the people they were meant to serve—and the devastating consequences that ensued.

As a hypothetical future it was, and remains, remarkably prescient. And in its depiction of widespread and crippling inequality amidst a lethal plague, its echoes of our present moment are more than a little chilling.

It was followed a few years later by [i]Deus Ex: Invisible War[/i], which, as I’m sure everyone reading this knows, was somewhat controversial for being seen as a considerably inferior experience to the original game. I think that’s absolutely true, but I also don’t think it’s an important detail any more.

[i]Invisible War[/i] is what it is.

My hope is that people reading this don’t just roll their eyes when they read what I'm about to say, because I’m not aiming to forward a deliberately contrarian viewpoint—it’s just how I see it. [i]Invisible War[/i], then, is the best [i]Deus Ex[/i] game after the original. And not by a small margin, either. [i]Human Revolution[/i] was a fantastic game, and taken on objective merits a slicker, top-shelf product compared to [i]Deus Ex’s[/i] first (and, well, only) sequel.

But I don’t think the defiantly cyberpunk [i]Human Revolution[/i] is a very interesting game, nor do I think it pulses with the spirit of the series—and [i]Invisible War[/i] is and does.

The general consensus is fortified against this stance. Even some of [i]Invisible War's[/i] own developers now disregard its existence. ‘Invisible Bore,’ sneers one friend. ‘In this house we love and appreciate the [i]Deus Ex[/i] games that are not Invisible War,’ mocks another. Bad friends both, and a reminder that, really, it’s not worth having friends at all.

[i]Invisible War[/i] is set twenty years after the events of [i]Deus Ex[/i], which culminated in JC Denton merging with the Helios AI as he destroyed both Bob Page and Area 51, severing global communications and triggering an event known as the ‘Collapse’.

The post-Collapse world of [i]Invisible War[/i] bears plenty hallmarks of its cyberpunk past, but this is a science-fiction game first and foremost. This distinction might be the most important qualifier for [i]Invisible War's[/i] worthiness as a successor to [i]Deus Ex[/i]. It’s something a lot of fans reacted negatively to, and I’ve read some of its developers argue that the fans are right: the game strayed too far from the world of [i]Deus Ex[/i] (i.e, cyberpunk).

Yeah, it did—but for the best possible reasons. It envisioned a new future, with its own stresses and anxieties, born out of the world [i]Deus Ex[/i] inhabited. It moved forward and the result, I think, is pretty fascinating.

This future is a weird and frightening place in which humanity is at last rising from the ashes of a shocking dark age, and where competing factions are at war over what shape the ultimate form this rising humanity will take.

The two factions central to this struggle are the WTO, led by former political revolutionary Chad Dumier, and the Order, a religious organisation which aims to subsume all faiths under the guidance of the mysterious ‘Her Holiness’. One speaks to the need for economic and political centralisation to enshrine human freedom, the other to the spiritual needs of the individual whilst espousing a collective movement away from industry and towards nature.

Both are seeing their power undermined by the reemergence of nanotechnology and its radical impact on the human body.

The technology that gave birth to the Denton brothers, and which Bob Page utilised in his failed attempt at world domination, is starting to flourish in new and unprecedented ways. It has inadvertently allowed the Templars to emerge—a group of fanatics who seek to ‘purify’ the planet, namely by committing genocide against the biomodified.

At its heart, [i]Invisible War's[/i] narrative—which is really fucking good, actually—speaks to a shocking lack of imagination and political courage on the part of some of its key players—and the terrifying power of bigotry to swell in number when enough people are left to fend for themselves in darkness.

Is all of this to say that [i]Invisible War[/i] is some forgotten masterpiece? Absolutely not. It is a game hobbled by technical limitations, leading to tiny, often sparse levels that rely heavily on a few small flourishes to work.

Like [i]Thief: Deadly Shadows[/i], which was released around the same time and built on the same engine, it comes with the ability for players to ally themselves with individual factions. This could’ve been interesting, but the game undercuts its own efforts at every opportunity, as you can never really fall afoul of anyone. Ignored the WTO’s instructions and assassinated a scientist at the Order’s behest? It’s okay, they’ll still have another task for you.

I would also question the logic of choice-based loyalty when the game features a clear-cut villain in the Templars and their leader, Luminon Saman. No matter how many times they try to kill you—and oh, they will—Saman still solicits your aid. It’s all a bit laughable.

And yet the game works.

I think its tiny levels have an ambience all of their own, even when the engine can’t be relied upon to faithfully depict its larger ideas, like Seattle having a city on top of a city, or a colossal arcology in Cairo. It’s all still there in the details, partially lost in the mist of unrealised ambitions, but I can still reach out and touch it—the idea that [i]Invisible War[/i] is something awful is just not true.

The gameplay has been streamlined since [i]Deus Ex[/i] and arguably for the better. Its menus, whilst simplistic, are far easier to navigate. Your nanotech upgrades have similarly been reworked, becoming ‘biomods’ that you can install throughout the game to improve your abilities. They’re better deployed here than in [i]Deus Ex[/i], although the balance is poor: you will end up with a massive surplus come the end. Combat is also improved, but given it was atrocious in [i]Deus Ex[/i] I’m not inclined to award it too much praise.

[i]Invisible War[/i] deserves your time. If it can’t keep it, that’s fair enough, but give it a chance. It’s well-written and thoughtful with a science-fiction world more interesting than many give it credit for.

It also has a notable sense of fun about it. In the Cairo arcology you will find a recruiting booth for the Templars. That’s the [i]Knights[/i] Templars. A recruiting booth. It’s eminently silly…

...but if you think it’s [i]too[/i] silly, you probably haven't been paying attention to our own insane, dystopian present.

1479589.review:
I'm so happy that I went back and played Invisible War again after so many years. When I installed all I really had was a few sketchy memories about a couple of plot twists, coupled with smiles about my first experience with marijuana and ragdoll physics. By the end though, it was clear that I had been playing a game that, despite the outdated textures and AI, still beats many of the modern-day FPS shooters hands down in every important aspect. What I mean by that, is that Invisible War delivers an excellent plot with multiple endings and engrossing moral choices; often comical side missions, that stay well within the realms of possibility, leading to increased immersion while giving the player a little change-up from the main "Spy-spy-genocide-jihad" storyline - interestingly, something Human Revolution fails to do and is less of a game for it; and the abilty to access it all playing whichever way you want. Want to sneak? Cool bro, go for it. Want to burn people alive and laugh at them while they run around screaming? Go nuts. Want to just beat everyone into a bloody pulp and then throw the bodies off a building into a skip bin? (Is me fave) Well you can do that too!
Invisible War also has many features modern shooters (and I can't understand why) don't include. Modifying my guns is A MUST for me in any action game, and Invisible War delivers, not only that, it gives you a legitimate ability to be non-lethal and still have a number of weapons and abilities at your disposal. So many things in this game are done better than in many later games that you really get the feeling it's still superior.
This game (not franchise) is one of the best of all time for me - easily on par with the likes of Morrowind in terms of execution. Perfectly balanced gameplay.

This game suffers from a strong slant towards the console delivery and over simplification of the originals core games systems. Lets face it. The first games Core Mechanics where very complex and hard to follow along with at first glace. But there is streamlining and then there is over dumb down a very smart game for a thinking man.

In the end this game suffered gravely for this but the game it self is still one that I enjoyed most of the time so long as I didn't try and fit it into the last games high bar for standards. It's story line was a bit easier to follow and understand most of the time. It's graphics where okay for the time it came out in and the game had a few flaws that would brake it at time but not bad enough where I wouldn't stop playing it and panning it all together.

The voice acting was much better then the first games campy almost monotone voice acting. It's felt more alive at times and yet so very void of a soul. Which I actually think is one of it's suggestions to be honest, along with a limitation for the Game engine and systems of the day.

If your gonna Deus Ex from start to end, you'll want to play this one at some point. If nothing more it will make you realize how awesome the third installment really is when compared to this one.

The good news is that the writing and voice acting are both very good. The bad news is that the levels are all wildly cramped and the graphics look awful because the textures are low-resolution. Both are casualties of some idiot having demanded that this game should be ported to the original XBox, which had approximately zero bytes of RAM in it.

The graphics look good again once you install the freely-available fan-made high-res texture packs, so that's fine. The cramped levels aren't really problematic any more, because Moore's Law has contracted the load times between levels to almost nothing. So in practice, this is a pretty fun game now, with branching plot lines and relatable characters - even though it was difficult to play and heinous to look at upon the day of its original release.

175196.review:
Deus Ex Invisible War was a game that had the greatest of challenges. It was the successor to what was, and is, perhaps one of the greatest shooters of all time, the original intelligent man's shooter. Deus Ex. Invisible War had some mighty big shoes to fill.

And it failed.

It's not that Deus Ex Invisible War is a bad game. It's just that it fails in every aspect to live up to it's predecessor. Every piece of gameplay, of graphics, of sound. It's just a step down from where it used to be. A little bit slower, a little bit stupider, a little bit simpler.

The game is less open and far more linear in both gameplay and story. The weapons and aguments are simpler and you'll quickly find yourself missing the original.

It is a game that suffered from the developers thinking they had to follow the stream of what was cool and new when in reality, the original Deus Ex had redirected that stream all by it's lonesome. The result being that Invisible War is just another game that tries to be Deus Ex and while that might be fine for most of the clones out there, it just doesn't work when your game has the Deus Ex name on it.

It is a shame that they couldn't do more with the franchise. I would have loved to play a proper sequel to Deus Ex. Still would.

604989.review: The received opinion is that Deus Ex is the best game ever and this is the terrible sequel. Given how underwhelmed I was by the original my expectations of this game were very low. And there are some changes for the worse such as the removal of the nice inventory system and the universal ammo system which results in you running out of ammo for all your weapons at once and being reduced to throwing random objects at your enemies. In balance it seems no worse than the original to me it still had a plot that failed to interest me; confusing level designs with a poor mapping system which leave you wandering round in circles and the occasional fun section hidden amongst the tedium and frustration. I think overall there were more fun sections in this than the original but I still have no intention of ever playing through this game again.
