Was this game rightly panned? Yes. Is the engine terrible? Yes, with maps under half the size of its predecessor, and twice as crude, albeit with some very nice dynamic lights. Is the gameplay horrendously dumbed down and fundamentally broken in ways (in particularly the universal ammo)? Yes. Although despite losing lean keys, Alex gains the elusive ability to mantle, a welcome return from the SysShocks.

Do you, just for a fleeting moment, sometimes get a little whiff of being an augmented agent preying on terrified goons? Yes, but then you hit a map load barrier. Does it undermine JC and sometimes venture too far into "look, look, a person from the previous game, love me!"? Unfortunately.

But does it still have smart dialogue if you poke about? Yes. Does it have allegiances more complicated and subtle than "good" or "evil"? Yes, and more freedom than DX1. If you can get it stupid-cheap in a sale, is it worth putting up with the gameplay to weave yourself a plot?

Probably.

154231.review:
Deus Ex was a groundbreaking entry into the world of FPS and RPG. Some, such as myself, have praised the first installment as PC gaming's finest masterpiece. Needless to say, Invisible War (IW) had a lot to live up to. As a standalone product, IW is no doubt a competent competitor. However, as a sequel to a legendary franchise, it merely captures what made its predecessor remarkable, doing little to improve anything.

Perhaps the most noticeable change in this game is its simplicity. The original Deus Ex offered an overwhelming amount of skills you could invest in, ranging from your weapon proficency to your augmentations. IW kept only the latter. While this made the game easier to comprehend and manage, it also drastically reduced the versatility so proudly flaunted by the first game.

The AI devolved and bugs are aplenty. Fortunately, moral choices and combat approaches are still as open ended as ever and that, at its core, is what makes IW a great game.

Grade: B+

A bomb.

Now, the first game was THE bomb. It was a gem that transcended genre and time. It had its flaws, but its brilliance far outweighed them. Therein is the difference between DE and IW. Only a couple hours in and I'm prepared to declare that much.

The gameplay changes between DE and IW remind me of the Mass Effect series. Mechanics were streamlined. Dynamics shifted towards more action. But in ME  those changes made the core gameplay more fun and exciting. It was about less busywork, not oversimplification. But with IW, the result is that everything is dumbed down. Shooting, augs, missions all just seem dumber than before. And boring.

But it was the story and narrative that was the strongest part of the original, I felt. It was a wonderful cyberpunk tale set in an inspired dystopic future. Glimpses of that do peek through in IW, but this tale just isn't nearly as well-crafted or executed as the first.

And it isn't one I'm anxious to keep following.

I haven't tested this on Win10, so these are few thoughts from playing it on my Win7 PC a couple of years ago.

Firstly, there seems to be some weird issue during load screens where the game re-initialises itself and Steam gets confused about whether the game is still running, so this explains why my hours are so low despite making a bit of progress in the game.

The Jetsons-esque visual style was really off-putting for me. One of the great things about the original Deus Ex was that the world and tech felt grounded and relatable. This just feels too far out there. It's a pretty big leap from cyberpunk (high-tech, low life) to full-blown plasma sci-fi.

The city hub sections are extremely claustrophobic, with many corridors and alleys bridging the various points of interest. It's believed this was done deliberately to help optimise the game for the original Xbox, but it comes at the price of feeling very restricted in the open play area.

The combat was okay from memory; the biggest issue with it is the universal ammo system. Every gun in your inventory uses the same pool of ammo. Bleh.

I really wanted to get invested in the story after the brilliant Deus Ex, but it was quite hard to bear through these gameplay and tech issues.

What a shame.

462653.review:
That IW is a colossal step down I won't deny.  The two biggest pains in the patoot being the tiny-as-fudgeknuckle box-shaped locations to explore providing far too many visits to the often broken loading screen and the writing itself heading into the fantastical, away from the recognizable and richly-detailed world of the first DX (gone are all the e-mails and most literature and admirable characters--& Pacotti/Grossman's high-quality dialogue with Australian-Chinese bartenders and hidden AI prototypes are limited to just a few instances like with the NG Resonance AI).  

BUT: The game's still addictive; the story's stil strong enough to draw you in, and some levels, most notably the Egyptian arcology, are top notch (if you look past the loading screens); the goofy physics of objects and ragdolls are fun to mess around with; the graphics have held up well; and it's beyond satisfying to snoop around and knock out 2-dimensional villains with one baton swing to the face.

701636.review: Despite all of the cool technical improvements to the first game, and some very cool storytelling, and very decent cutscenes, this game will forever be remembered as the Deus Ex game with "one kind of ammo."

2117594.review:
I have to say that I found the war in Deus Ex: Invisible War to be highly visible. I won't comment on the "consolization" of the game, because I think enough mewling man-childred have filled enough message boards with the same tired old complaints. I'll just say that Invisible War--while fun--never gave me a memorable Deus Ex moment like putting two bullets into Maggie Chow's head and then hurling her body out the window of her penthouse apartment.

Definitely a sequel that lost some of what made the original so special.

288824.review: An interesting addition to the Deus Ex universe, but not as deeply story-driven as the first. The Unreal Engine 2.x version they're using is a pig and runs pretty poorly but, it is certainly worth a play if you've loved the first game.

3643327.review:
I think a lot of people see Deus Ex through rose-tinted glasses, and this game gets a lot of flak from people who liked the first one. I'll grant you, this game has its problems, but that doesn't stop it from being fun.

Now that Human Revolution exists, this is basically just a worse version of that, but if you don't mind the step back in technology and you can overlook some bugs, this is still a fun game.

1006872.review: Lacking in a lot of the statistical nitty-gritty that made DE such a delicious numbers game, DE: Invisible War still manages to incorporate much of what made the first game great, from its cyberpunk sensibilities to its variety of fun weapons. The streamlining in DE:IW might hide some of the checks and balances, but it doesn't do so at the cost of the freedom or fun of the original. It can be played as an action game, a stealth game, a role playing game, or any combination thereof, and remains a unique shooter experience on any platform.

561579.review: While not as good as the original Dues ex, It's still very much worth a playthrough.

92481.review: Invisible War is a massive step backwards from the original Deus Ex in pretty much every facet of its design, except art. Invisible War looks prettier, that's it. They stripped out the rpg elements; there's no experience points, no skills, and no character growth. There are fewer augments overall, and you can equip/use fewer augments, You can't even roll with the same set of abilities you chose in the first game because some simply don't exist, or because of the fewer number of augment slots you have to choose between abilities. There's no inventory to speak of, and you can equip/use fewer items at any given time. The overall scope of the environments is smaller, levels that were whole and unbroken in the previous Deus Ex are now segmented with loading screens in Invisible War to accommodate the original Xbox's hardware limitations. The story is worse, the choices you have to make in exploring or interacting with various factions are much more limited. it's also only 8-9 hours long.

32566.review: Seriously underrated sequel to Deus Ex. While it offers less at some points (inventory, charakter building), it offers more on others (world, factions). And it surely isn't bad.

1311891.review: It isn't the same as Deus Ex but it has better graphics and some easier tasks which in the original Deus would kill your equipment. The only real downside is that there isn't much of an open world, which the orignal Deus Ex had. But it can stand on its two feet and let you play anyway you want too. Whether it be stealth, rambo, serial killer, saint, or FUNKY this game will provide.

1441080.review: Deus Ex: Invisible War is nowhere near THE Deus Ex. What a shame. It was a good game... What a rotten way to be continued.

1632642.review:
I gather that Deus Ex fans don't like this game for the same reasons that Thief fans don't like Deadly Shadows. I guess that's load zones and lack of rope arrows (ok, RPG elements in this case).

RPG addicts get annoyed when a game they love gets simplified, but for an FPS/stealth gamer like me RPG elements bloat the game and slow it down. I do get annoyed by having a small inventory and not being able to have skills in both security hacking and cloak, but not anywhere as much as in games like Deus Ex or Mass Effect where I am organising my inventory so much of the time that the game starts to feel like a chore.

Ultimately, the story seems more interesting and the gameplay seems more fun, but then I might be biased as I lost all my saves just before the Hong Kong mission in DE1, and that has been very annoying. If Human Revolution takes the right queues from both this and the original game then it should be great.

855852.review: First game was icon. That's what you get for being sequel - a lot of hype. Fail a bit - and everyone hates you. So the second Deus Ex easily messed up franchise by being just a good game. Maybe it's not your iconic deus ex, but it's a good game anyway. Try it. But forget about "Deus Ex" in the name, IW is different game.

685171.review:
Useful to see just how much you can fuck a game up by altering the pacing and stripping out the "unnecessay" bits. Not a bad game in its own right, but...

If Deus Ex 1 is like attending an awesome live show of your favorite band putting on the concert of their lives, then Deus Ex 2 is like watching the overproduced, abridged, edited for content, strictly time controlled Super Bowl Halftime version of them playing a few of their greatest hits in between commercials. 

It's still your favorite band, and they're still playing songs you like, but it's nowhere near as good.

159211.review: Take Deus Ex, now get rid of everything that make that game good and replace it with a horrible console interface and remove any resemblance of a decent plotline or skill system and tack on a buggy version of the unreal 2 engine. The only redeeming value of this game is the fact that Terri Brosius does the voice of one of the pilots so I just pretend that SHODAN is chauffering me around, because I have the hots for her.

933018.review:
An obvious lack of polish due to a troubled production prevents this game from living up to its true potential. Still, many good aspects shine through.

With the texture pack and the widescreen utility, this game looks amazing for its age. The combat is fun, if a little goofy, the dialogue is great, the sneaking is tantalizing, the game truly is highly playable and replayable. Every serious gamer should beat this game at least once.

This game is the sleeper hit of the century.
